HEADLINE: ECONOMISTS FAULT POPULATION FIGURE FOR NEW YORK CITY

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
Could a city that enjoyed its greatest economic boom since World War II, experienced a dizzying rise in housing prices, attracted the largest wave of immigration since the days of Ellis Island and seemed to grow more crowded in every conceivable way actually be smaller now than it was in 1980?
Economists in the city, perhaps demonstrating a rare degree of agreement, are hard pressed to reconcile the Census Bureau's preliminary finding that New York City lost 38,000 residents in 10 years with all the signs of vitality, renewal and growth that they have seen in the five boroughs during that time.
''This city had an unusually good decade,'' said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. ''This just doesn't match up with it.'' 
 
Bureau Expects Number to Rise
The Census Bureau's New York City population estimate of 7,033,179 is about 400,000 lower than estimates by the Regional Plan Association, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, and the WEFA Group, an economic forecasting service; 800,000 lower than a New York University estimate, and about 1 million below the city's own calculation.
The bureau will not comment on its figure, other than to say it expects it to rise after the city submits block-by-block challenges. But as it stands now, the bureau's count is hard for economists to explain, given the axiom that jobs attract people.
After losing about 10 percent of its jobs and about 10 percent of its population in the 1970's, New York City reversed course and gained 370,000 jobs in the 1980's. Some were filled by suburbanites, of course, but if commuting increased in the beginning of the decade, the evidence suggests that it leveled off by the end. The Port Authority's chief economist, Rosemary Scanlon, said the city was actually sending some workers to the suburbs as reverse commuters as the decade closed.
 
Rise in Births
More women entered the work force during the 1980's, but economists still consider the large rise in employment in the city a persuasive indication of an underlying rise in population.
The census estimate also seems at odds with what Emanuel Tobier, a professor at the Robert F. Wagner Graduate School of Public Service at New York University, said has been a 24 percent increase in births in the city from 1980 to 1988. That is twice the increase in the nation as a whole, he said, and reflects an echo of the baby boom as well as a wave of immigrants, many of them women of child-bearing age.
Spurred by the rise in births, Professor Tobier collected other statistics on deaths, public and private school enrollment and Social Security and Medicare enrollment and, using complex formulas and demographic trends, concluded that the city's population was 7,622,000 in 1987. Based on continuing increases in births, he said, he believed the city grew by about 70,000 in each of the next two years.
 
More Houses and Apartments
''It's a mystery,'' Professor Tobier said of the Census Bureau's lower population estimate. ''I don't know how it's going to come out.''
The bureau has not provided a borough-by-borough breakdown of its preliminary estimate, but some evidence suggests not only that there have been gains but also that they have been spread across the city.
For example, New York City added 50,000 units of housing from 1981 to 1987, according to the most recent city survey. Some 37,000 units were added between 1984 and 1987 - at a time, incidentally, when the vacancy rate barely rose. Brooklyn and Staten Island each added 11,000 new apartments or houses in those three years, but the other boroughs had increases, too.
And this was before the city's $5 billion housing rehabilitation program had produced any units and before a surge of new luxury construction at the end of the decade, encouraged by tax incentives and prosperity.
 
Other Statistics
There has also been a startling rise in housing prices during the decade, with cooperative and condominum apartments in Manhattan nearly doubling in cost, even with recent declines. Who bid them up? And in 1989, more than 22,000 first-time applicants for public housing gave a home address indicating that they already lived in public housing, presumably doubled up with other families.
Between 1978 and 1990, the city gained 84 office buildings and added 54 million square feet of space, according to the Real Estate Board of New York.
Subway ridership rose by 8.5 percent between 1982 and 1990, and motor vehicle registration in the city increased by 24 percent from 1980 to 1988.
Revenue from the city's personal income tax nearly tripled, from $879 million to $2.56 billion, in the 1980's, despite a tax cut during that time.
 
Difficulties in Urban Areas
In discussing the city's population, economists are usually quick to cite a flow of immigrants estimated at 100,000 a year during the 1980's. There has been concern that census enumerators missed large numbers of new settlers, many of whom lack proper documents and are reluctant to give information to Government workers.
Officials of cities across the country have long worried about the ability of census-takers to count urban areas accurately. In 1980, the bureau acknowledged that it missed 400,000 or so New Yorkers, but the city failed in a legal effort to compel the agency to make a correction. The city, joined by other cities and states and civic and civil rights groups, has a pending lawsuit that is seeking to compel the Census Bureau to adjust its final 1990 tally to correct for an undercount, based on results of a additional post-count survey.
Despite their longstanding anxiety and distrust of the Census Bureau, city officials, along with others, were startled by this week's preliminary estimate because it was 300,000 lower than the bureau's own interim 1988 estimate. Officials follow the figure closely because it determines Federal subsidies and House seats.
Mr. Ehrenhalt, noting that the Census Bureau's work had only begun, said a drop of 38,000 was ''not beyond the bounds of possibility,'' but added, ''I see great difficulties reconciling this with what we know about the city.''
New York City's economy weakened considerably after the stock market collapse of 1987, but employment held up reasonably well until last year. Even with problems like crime, drugs and a school system viewed warily by many residents, economists believe that it is unlikely that the city lost 300,000 people in just two years.
''There would be moving trucks everywhere,'' Ms. Scanlon said.

HEADLINE: MEDICARE FEE PLAN SENT TO CONGRESS

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
In what health officials called a major step toward overhauling Medicare's chaotic reimbursement system, the Secretary of Health and Human Services yesterday gave Congress a model national fee schedule for 1,400 commonly performed medical procedures.
The report by the Secretary, Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, is the culmination of several years of Government effort to narrow the wide discrepancies in payments that doctors in different regions and different specialties receive from the Federal insurance plan for the elderly and disabled. Officials hope the new system will raise fees for primary-care doctors, whose services are felt to be undervalued, and in general reduce those for surgeons and other specialists for their procedures.
 
Scale of Relative Value
Dr. Sullivan's report was mandated last year when Congress directed the Department of Health and Human Services to develop a national fee schedule based on a ''relative-value scale'' that would take into account physicians' time, overhead and insurance expenses in the setting of fees. 
The report made public yesterday was a preliminary proposal for evaluation by Congress, physicians and others. A final version must be in place by Jan. 1, 1992, the deadline Congress has set for the new system.
There is no national fee standard now and each doctor's reimbursement is determined separately. Payments are based on the fees physicians charged two decades ago, with small incremental increases that in recent years have often not kept pace with inflation. As a result, doctors practicing in the same field and in the same building could receive different Medicare reimbursements for the same procedure because of historical differences in their fees.
Although the specifics of the model plan are tentative and certain to be substantially changed, ophthalmologists in most parts of the country would probably have their payments reduced for cataract operations with an artificial lens implant. In the Secretary's model, that service comes out to about $1,300, but the operation is now sometimes allotted more than $2,000 in doctor's fees.
For general practitioners seeing a new patient, the results would be mixed: a private doctor in Manhattan might find his reimbursement cut from a current rate of perhaps $150 to about $70, while his counterpart in rural Kentucky might find his payment raised from $50 or so.
''The national fee schedule will be the most wide-ranging and fundamental change in Medicare's physician payment system since the creation of the Medicare program in 1965,'' Dr. Sullivan said in a statement accompanying the report.
The Government's relative-value scale will apply only to reimbursement for Medicare patients, but health experts expect rates set in that manner to influence physicians' fees and payments in the private sector as well.
While health experts have expected a proposal for relative-value reimbursement for almost a year, Dr. Sullivan's model is expected to touch off an energetic debate about how the different medical services have been valued.
Dr. James S. Todd, executive vice president of the American Medical Association, said, ''There have been many many models in the past year but this is the first official one given to Congress to say grace over and the first official document that will be acted upon.'' The association has supported what Dr. Todd called ''the radical concept'' in a general way.
''It is the first step in rationalizing the way in which physicians are compensated by the Government,'' Dr. Todd said.
The new system involves ''value units'' assigned to each procedure or medical service based on a doctor's time, overhead and risk of malpractice suits. The total relative-value score is multiplied by a conversion factor in dollars to determine the payment for a visit.
For example, a comprehensive medical examination for a new patient earns 35.9 points for the primary-care doctor's time, 22.9 for overhead and 3 for malpractice risk, for a grand total of 61.8. A CAT scan of the abdomen earns 57.6 for the doctor's time, 146.9 for overhead (presumably based on the cost of the equipment) and 16.4 for malpractice, for a total of 220.9. A skin biopsy earns 25.5 time points, 17.8 in overhead and 1.0 in malpractice for a sum of 44.3.
 
Changes Are Foreseen
The conversion factor proposed in Dr. Sullivan's report is $1. While the report states that this number is ''not arbitrary,'' experts predict it will be modified as a result of the coming debate and must be set to assure that the total cost of the Medicare program does not change.
The 1,400 services listed in the new proposal include procedures from every major medical field except anesthesia and represent two-thirds of the annual outlay for Medicare. Values for the rest of the approximately 7,000 procedures will be set in coming months. The Government is still working on how to allot relative-value units to the anesthesiologist's time, a Federal spokesman said.
Federal health officials said they hoped the proposal would narrow the gap between the incomes of specialists and primary-care doctors as well as that between urban and rural doctors, many of whom are struggling because fees set long ago are extremely low.

HEADLINE: For Elderly Just Hanging On, An Oasis of Jobs Is Shrinking

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GRAND ISLAND, Neb., Aug. 25

 BODY:
''I'm what you call a displaced homemaker,'' said Doris Gibson, who is 66 years old and by any measure poor. She traces her poverty to the day 13 years ago when her husband walked out on her, and her survival to a Federal paycheck that will be harder and harder for future Doris Gibsons to get.
Mrs. Gibson is paid the minimum wage for helping to keep the books at an adult day care center in this placid community of 39,000 people that is no more an island than the state of Nebraska is.
She and her co-workers at the center, Irene Holroyd, 71, and Howard Tibbs, 77; and other people in similar straits like Helen Shultz, 61, a kitchen aide at Northwest High School here, and Dorothy Bernice Trout, 64, who does word processing at a nearby community college, are participants in a little-known public assistance program that is a rare survivor of Washington's antipoverty initiatives of the 1960's. #20 Hours of Community Work Through the Labor Department's Senior Citizen Community Service Employment Program, the neediest of able-bodied older people are paid $3.80 an hour for 20 hours of community service work a week. But as things now stand fewer people will be able to join the program because it is feeling the squeeze on the Federal budget. 
The Labor Department says the $367 million budgeted for this year will support jobs for 64,933 people nationwide, 865 fewer than last year. In the current budget deliberations, Congress is considering spending about $400 million next year. But because of increases in the hourly minimum wage, from $3.35 to $3.80 last April and to $4.25 next April, at least 4,000 more jobs would be dropped.
The jobs are with public agencies and nonprofit institutions; the program also provides training that permits about 20 percent to go on to regular jobs. Participants must be over 55 years old and have less than $10,525 a year in income, including Social Security, in the case of couples, or $7,850 if single. Both figures represent 125 percent of the federally calculated poverty line.
 
Only Neediest Need Apply
Almost 10 million older people meet the economic qualifications, so the law requires that the jobs go to the neediest among those who hear about the program and apply for it. The average age of participants is 68, one-third are over 70, and a few are past 90. Some are under 62, the age when people can start collecting pension benefits and Social Security.
The Labor Department distributes money to states largely according to their population. California, with $29.4 million, and New York, with $24.8 million, get the most, while Alaska, Hawaii and Delaware get the least, $1.6 million each. Nebraska gets $2.9 million.
Ten national organizations screen applicants and manage the program, among them the National Council of Senior Citizens, the American Association of Retired Persons and the National Urban League.
The agency that manages the biggest part of the program, however, is a lesser-known organization called Green Thumb Inc., which is getting $93.9 million of the $367 million this year. Green Thumb was originally founded by the National Farmers Union to steer retired farmers to government groundskeeping jobs. It now manages the program for 18,000 participants, two-thirds of them women, in the rural areas of 44 states. It supports 363 people in Nebraska.
 
Too Old for New Careers
Nationwide, a tight labor market has persuaded business to look to retirees as a new source of workers. But that trend offers little hope for the people who apply to Green Thumb. Many are too old to embark on new careers or work the standard 40-hour week. Many employers also balk at hiring old people for fear that their health will fail, pushing up insurance costs.
Some people here have been rescued by their twice-a-month $152 Federal paycheck, but that does not mean they all regard it as a godsend.
Most of the women never had jobs, or they left them ages ago to work at home rearing families. While many say they relish proving themselves in the workplace, they resent the turns of fate that forced them to go to work at a time of life when so many others are relaxing. And they say it is demeaning to learn that their homemaking skills are worth just the minimum wage.
 
An Array of Life's Problems 
Participants tell widely different stories of the circumstances that drove them into the program, but most involve deteriorating health or the loss of a spouse or sometimes both.
Mrs. Gibson's husband, Bob, was a traveling man, an agent for the Railway Express Agency, now defunct. ''He loved people,'' she said. ''He loved women.''
''He was going to Sioux City, Iowa,'' she recalled. Then the homebound mother of two young daughters, she said she told him: '' 'Eleanor and Leonard live there. Why don't you look them up?'
''He called the next night and said, 'I found Eleanor.' I said, 'What about Leonard?' 'Divorced 15 years,' he said.
 
I said, 'Uh-oh.' ''
Suddenly alone, poor, middle-aged and searching for work, Mrs. Gibson said, she found that no one could use her for the work skills that her husband had asked her to put aside a quarter century earlier. So, for several years, she did menial jobs in Grand Island nursing homes and took Government-subsidized courses to get the equivalent of a high school diploma.
Then three years ago, when she was hounding the local office of the state's job service, people there urged her to see Ada Miller, Green Thumb's area director. ''Ada said, 'How about an office job?' and I said I'd love it. At the center I do bookkeeping. I keep track of the volunteers - their hours and expenses - and then I have to write a check for them every month.''
 
Ailing Wife and the Janitor
The janitor at the day care center is Howard Tibbs, a spry, compact man with a full head of dark hair. He reared 10 children while operating an automobile repair shop at his home here for more than 50 years. Then his wife's poor health, and cataracts in both of his eyes, put his business on hold.
His wife, Eulalia, 71, came down with a degenerative disease 12 years ago. ''She fell through the screen door, and we laughed about it,'' Mr. Tibbs said. ''Gradually she went to a walker. After a while she couldn't do that. It's a little like Alzheimer's. I had them write it down.'' He took a physician's card from his wallet. ''Olivopontocerebellar degeneration,'' it says.
''I've been taking care of my wife most of the time,'' Mr. Tibbs said. ''Ain't nothing wrong with her mind, but her voice is gone. She can just barely move her head and hands. She's been in the hospital since the fifth of February. After I leave here, I go up there to the hospital and feed her every night.''
Her medical care is covered by Medicaid. For income, Mr. Tibbs said, ''I have Social Security, $380 a month. That's all I have besides this.'' He said he works from 12:30 to 4:30 P.M. five days a week at his Green Thumb job but comes earlier and stays later doing volunteer work there, like helping an old man with an artificial leg. ''He can't go to the bathroom unless it's off,'' he said. ''I take it off.''
 
Her Fortunes Crumbled
Dorothy Bernice Trout, whose only other income is a $455 monthly Social Security payment, says her fortunes crumbled with the loss of her husband, who was a diesel mechanic for trucks. ''He died in 1970 of Lou Gehrig's disease,'' she said. ''He was 45. We were raising three children. He had it for six years and it wiped us out. That's why I'm working. He was not a believer in life insurance.''
Mrs. Trout went to work for the first time at the age of 44, first as an editor and reporter for a small-town newspaper and later as an aide to a veterinarian. Now she has emphysema. Regular employers will not hire her for fear of becoming ensnared in her medical costs, she said, and she is only able to work part time. Thanks to the Federal program, she types course lessons into a word processor for instructors at Central Community College in Hastings, Neb., and does other clerical chores.
Delbert L. Niemeier, Green Thumb's director for Nebraska, said he has 34 active applications for the program. ''It's been going up over the last three years,'' he said. ''They lost the farm. They lost the spouse. They're desperate in the sense that they don't have enough to meet their obligations.''
Helen Shultz, the aide in the high school kitchen, never had a regular job. ''I was just a housewife,'' she said. ''I had nine children. They're 43 to 17. Men you see for jobs - they don't know what it is to run a house.''
''I've applied for other jobs and haven't gotten any,'' she said. ''Nobody bothered to call back.''
Mrs. Shultz's husband has retired from his job as a house builder, and all they had was his Social Security check of $517 a month when Green Thumb put her in the high school kitchen a year ago.
 
'Out With Other People'
''This job is the first time I've been out with other people,'' Mrs. Shultz said. ''I get the ice. I stack the cookies. I wash the tables after they eat. I took a home-care course and was certified. But I don't know if I'd like to take care of people who are terminally ill. I wanted to be around children. Happiness is children. I wanted to be around noise and activity.''
But even women with long work force experience, unlike Mrs. Shultz, and in good health, unlike Mrs. Trout, find they have to turn to the program. Irene Holroyd had three children and was divorced 22 years ago. She had run a bakery with her husband and then took a job as a dental technician.
Mrs. Holroyd retired at 65 but could not get by on her Social Security check of $393 a month, her sole income. ''I own my house,'' she said. ''I raise practically everything I eat. The insurances are what's bad.'' She spent weeks looking for work through the office of the state's job service here.
''They couldn't find anything because of my age,'' she said, so Mrs. Miller of Green Thumb found her a job at the day care center. ''Today I cooked oatmeal and fixed their breakfast,'' she said. ''I try to keep them busy, like playing cards with them or whatever they want to do. I do the dishes.''
But the days at work appear to be numbered for her co-worker Doris Gibson. Mr. Gibson never divorced her, and just before he died in April, he told their daughters of his railroad pension.
Mrs. Gibson said she should be getting the pension checks, $814 a month. She is glad for that, she said, but she expects it to put her beyond the limit for the work program and out of a job that means so much to her - the only job she was able to get.

HEADLINE: Mideast Crisis Puts New Spotlight On an Idle Oil Plant in California

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GAVIOTA, Calif., Aug. 31

 BODY:
After standing unused and mothballed for nearly three years on a desolate bluff over the central coast of California, the Gaviota Oil and Gas Plant here is emerging as a key element in the American response to the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.
The plant was meant to receive and separate crude oil and gas from the Santa Maria basin off Point Arguello, where three offshore pumping platforms, also mothballed, are poised to tap into the largest domestic oil field to be discovered since Prudhoe Bay in Alaska in 1969. Oil experts say the field, with more than 300 million barrels of recoverable reserves, could produce nearly 100,000 barrels a day to replace some of the lost supplies from the Middle East.
But environmental objections and local politics have combined to thwart production in a complex dispute over whether the oil should be transported to gasoline refineries by tanker ship or by pipeline. And now, in an effort to mediate the dispute and get the oil flowing, the Federal Government is stepping in. 
In an interview in Washington on Thursday, Energy Secretary James D. Watkins said the Point Arguello oil was considered a major part of a short-term strategy to raise domestic oil production. A team sent by Mr. Watkins conferred with company and local officials in Santa Barbara last week.
The plant, about 30 miles northwest of Santa Barbara, was completed in late 1987 but has remained idle since then for two reasons. First, the company could not complete plans for a direct pipeline to refineries in Los Angeles. And then the California Coastal Commission rejected plans to move the oil by tankers, citing environmental concerns.
So the plant, built at a cost of $2.5 billion, stands silent.
The Gaviota plant has emerged as a symbol to the oil industry and to its environmental foes of what is wrong with the nation's energy policy. The industry contends that overbearing local requirements have thwarted domestic oil production; environmentalists maintain that more drilling only promotes further energy profligacy at the risk of fragile ecologies.
The oil industry, led by the Chevron Corporation, leader of the 18-partner project, says the time has come to ease local environmental rules to permit the shipment of oil to refineries in Los Angeles at least temporarily by tanker, which would be faster and less costly than any of several pipelines that could serve as an alternative.
''This is the largest single nonproducing source of domestic oil that we can tap in the short term in the entire United States,'' said Richard T. Hughes, a lawyer for Chevron in San Francisco.
 
Memories of 1969 Blowout
Officials in Santa Barbara County, where memories of the 1969 Unocal blowout that fouled local beaches are still fresh, say they prefer pipelines as environmentally less risky and accuse the companies of using the Iraqi crisis to force their will.
''The oil companies see this as a window of opportunity to prove that local government is standing in the way of national interest,'' Thomas A. Rogers, chairman of the county board of supervisors, said in an interview.
Even under the best of circumstances, the Point Arguello field is not likely to start producing oil soon. Chevron has requested a permit to begin tanker operations but, after studies and hearings, it will not come up for a vote of the five supervisors until early November. If they permit the use of tankers to carry the oil, appeals by environmentalists could force further delays.
Moreover, even if a decision is made to begin production it will take six months just to prepare the mothballed plant here, said G. Michael Marcy, a Chevron spokesman. And it will take another six months to reach full production; the pumps at the plant are filled with special grease to preserve them while inactive, and the pipes are filled with inert nitrogen.
Robert D. Almy, deputy director of the county's Resource Management Department, estimates that it could take up to 15 months to reach peak production.
The county maintains that the oil could be shipped through the unused All-America Pipeline inland to Bakersfield, Calif., and transferred to other pipelines there to Los Angeles or to refineries in Texas. But Chevron says that because the Arguello oil is a heavy, low-grade crude these alternatives are either too costly or impractical.
The Point Arguello project is a decade-long story that has brought the political conflict between energy development and environmentalism to its sharpest point.
 
Three Platforms Built
Chevron and its partners bought leases in Federal waters in 1979 and struck oil in 1981. Two platforms, Hermosa and Hildago, were built by Chevron, and another, Harvest, by Texaco Inc., but they have been capped for five years amid a dispute over how to bring the oil to the refineries.
In 1984 the county supervisors approved the Gaviota plant on the condition that it ship the oil by pipeline to the Chevron refinery in El Segundo, near Los Angeles.
The plant here is designed to separate propane, gas, sulfur and other products from the oil before shipping the remaining crude to gasoline refineries. Two buried pipelines would carry the oil and gas from the platforms, about 10 miles offshore, to the plant. These pipelines, which were completed in 1987, are not a matter of dispute.
Mr. Marcy, the Chevron spokesman, said that the plans had gone through 44 permitting agencies and that the company agreed to 165 conditions imposed by the county, including planting thousands of eucalyptus and pepper trees to try to hide the plant from U.S. 101, and to preserve a nearby monarch butterfly habitat.
''We have agreed to hundreds of mitigations,'' he said. ''We are close to the point where we cannot do anymore.''
Sam Davis, the plant manager, said the partners are spending $3 million a month just to maintain the unused plant.
 
Interim Permit Sought
Plans to build a special pipeline to Los Angeles were dropped in 1987 because of political opposition from Los Angeles and other cities along the pipeline route. The company then asked the county for an interim permit to move oil by tanker. That was approved in May 1989, but it was revoked on appeal by the California Coastal Commission, a state agency, on the ground that the oil companies had not made adequate precautions to clean up any spills.
''We tried to make a pipeline and we were stopped,'' Mr. Marcy said. He added that Chevron was exploring plans to have a pipelilne built along railroad tracks that pass the plant and extend 120 miles to Los Angeles. That would be he shortest route, but it would take more than two years to build. In the interim, the company wants to ship the oil by tanker.
Political opposition to oil drilling along the central coast of California is fierce. Henry Feniger, president of Get Oil Out, a 20-year-old group formed after the 1969 blowout, said the solution was not drilling oil but saving oil.
Asserting that his group was ''opposed to oil drilling as a way to solve domestic energy problems,'' Mr. Feniger said: ''We do not have an energy policy. We like to waste on the one hand and exploit on the other.''
Even so, since the offshore wells are already drilled here, Mr. Feniger and county officials are reconciled to having it shipped through Santa Barbara by way of a pipeline.
''If Chevron decided to ship by pipes we'd help them,'' said Mr. Almy, the county resource management official.
Mr. Rogers, the supervisors' chairman, said there were two feasible pipeline alternatives. One is the heated All-America Pipeline, which runs just behind the Gaviota plant to Texas; the other runs to Los Angeles by a connection to the Four Corners pipeline at Bakersfield.
Mr. Rogers said either of these would cost only $1.50 more a barrel than tanker shipping, a cost that he said was ''dwarfed'' by the recent increase in oil prices.
Given the low quality of the Arguello crude, Mr. Marcy of Chevron said, both alternatives were economically impractical. In particular, he said, the ''Rube Goldberg'' connection at Bakersfield would require the crude to be diluted with a lighter oil because the pipeline leg to Los Angeles was not heated.
 
Pipeline Plan Termed Costly
This would mean 50,000 fewer barrels of Arguello crude would reach the refineries and would ultimately add nearly $1 billion to the overall cost of the project, he said. The companies estimate that shipping by pipeline would cost $5 a barrel, compared with $1.80 a barrel by tanker.
The Federal Government's role in efforts to solve the controversy is unclear. Environmentalists here have suggested that oil company lobbyists in Washington interceded with Secretary Watkins to put pressure on the local government.
Chevron has issued a statement saying it was the Energy Department that approached the oil partners and that ''we have no interests in circumventing the county process.''
In a letter to Mr. Rogers on Aug. 15, Mr. Watkins wrote that the Point Arguello oil could have a ''significant impact'' on ''our overdependence upon insecure foreign sources'' and that he hoped his general counsel, Stephen Wakefield, could serve as an ''intermediary.''
Under the county's zoning ordinances, Chevron can request a waiver from its pipeline commitment by proving that there is a national emergency, or that the available pipeline has inadequate capacity or that the pipeline costs are ''unreasonable,'' taking into account alternative transportation costs and environmental effects.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
U.S. READY TO SEND ISRAELIS NEW ARMS AS SIGNAL TO IRAQ

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31

 BODY:
The Bush Administration is preparing to transfer as much as $1 billion worth of advanced weapons to Israel to buttress the country's defenses against Iraq and address Israeli concerns about recent arms sales to Saudi Arabia, Administration officials said today.
Officials said the promise of advanced weaponry to Israel is intended to send a clear signal to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq that the United States intends to stand by its main Middle East ally.
Israel, while keeping a low profile in the Persian Gulf crisis, has placed its military on heightened alert. Israeli and American officials have warned that Iraq, in an effort to shatter Arab opposition to the invasion of Kuwait, might try to draw Israel into the Middle East conflict through a direct missile attack against Israel or by moving military forces into Jordan. 
 
Military Balance in Mideast
Aside from worry over the possibility of an Iraqi attack, Israel and its American supporters see a need to offset the new arms sales to Saudi Arabia, Egypt and other Arab countries, which they believe could alter the military balance in the Middle East.
American and Israeli officials are still negotiating final details of the arms package, which could include the delivery of F-15 and F-16 fighter planes, Patriot ground-to-air missiles that can be used to intercept incoming missiles, M-60 battle tanks and Apache tank-killing helicopters, largely from United States stockpiles in Europe.
The idea for additional aid originated with the Israelis and has been approved in principle by the Defense Department and top national security officials at the White House, Administration officials said. The details and timing of arms deliveries remain to be worked out, with both sides hoping to begin the transfer of some weapons as soon as possible. Officials said the value of the transfer could range from several hundred million dollars to about $1 billion.
 
Apart From $1.8 Billion
The transfer of weapons, through leases or sales, would come on top of $1.8 billion in American military assistance to Israel planned for this year before the Persian Gulf crisis developed.
Administration officials in recent days have reaffirmed to leaders of American Jewish groups and members of Congress the longstanding American commitment to maintain Israel's military advantage in the Middle East.
Defense Secretary Dick Cheney met last week with leaders of Jewish groups, and this week a delegation of Israeli military officials, led by David Ivry, the Director General of the Israeli Defense Ministry, traveled to Washington to discuss additional American military aid with the State Department and Defense Department.
Washington's relations with Israel have been relatively smooth during the gulf crisis, American and Israeli officials say. Israel has been responsive to American requests that it not become directly involved in the conflict, or take any pre-emptive action against Iraq. Washington, in turn, made clear that it was willing to consider added military aid to Israel.
The crisis has deflected attention from the impasse that had been developing between the Administration and Jerusalem over the Israeli Government's reluctance to open a dialogue with the Palestinians on the basis of a compromise formula proposed last spring by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d.
To bolster Saudi Arabia against a possible attack from Iraq, the Administration announced this week that it would make an emergency sale of $2.2 billion worth of weapons to Riyadh, including 24 F-15 fighter planes, 150 M-60 tanks and 200 Stinger anti-aircraft missiles. In addition, Pentagon officials said the United States would probably sell the Saudis another 24 F-15's early next year.
''The White House and State Department called to say they recognized an imbalance was occurring and that some form of additional weaponry for Israel would be found to remedy that,'' said Senator Rudy Boschwitz, Republican of Minnesota.
 
'Shifting Alliances'
One leader of an American Jewish group, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said: ''Arms to the Saudis pose a real dilemma for the Jewish community. On the one hand Saudi Arabia has legitimate defense needs right now. But this latest package constitutes a clear threat to Israel in the long run. No one knows what will happen to Saudi Arabia in the future. Middle East politics is made up of shifting alliances.''
Several hurdles must still be cleared to complete the proposed arms deal. One problem is matching the list of weapons that Israel wants with what the United States can afford to give up.
 
Soviet Talks May Free Tanks
The Pentagon, for example, expects to have surplus M-60 tanks once arms control talks with the Soviet Union are concluded. The available tanks, however, are an older version of the model the Israelis would like, and would not be available for several months.
In addition, the United States has already earmarked surplus F-15's and F-16's to other nations, including Morocco and the Philippines, as well to reserve units in the United States.
Israel's principal requests include Patriot ground-to-air missiles to counter enemy missiles, and top-of-the-line fighter planes to protect Israel in a multi-front air attack.
Financial terms are also under discussion. Israel cannot afford to pay for the weapons, and the United States is facing its own budget constraints, worsened by the costs of the Persian Gulf military operation, now estimated at $2.5 billion.
 
Looking at '1,001 Ways'
As a result, ''people are looking at 1,001 ways to solve the financing problem,'' an official said.
The options under study include leasing arms to Israel and positioning American planes and tanks at Israeli bases, transferring ownership in an emergency. An official said the United States might also give or sell at discount general military supplies or ammunition, thus freeing money that the Israelis could spend on weapons.
Creative financing is not new in American military aid to Israel. In the 1970's, the United States lent hundreds of millions of dollars to Israel on favorable terms. The terms were so favorable, said Richard Grimmett, a military analyst with the Congressional Research Service, that many of the loans were completely forgiven.
In the 1980's, the United States gave Israel military assistance with no strings attached. Since 1986, Congress has fixed the military aid to Israel, the single largest recipient of American foreign assistance, at $1.8 billion.

HEADLINE: FOREIGN AFFAIRS;
Bigger or Stronger Europe?

BYLINE: Flora Lewis

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
The two Germanys have signed their treaty of unification, the last major act of the German Democratic Republic before it disappears into a single Germany on Oct. 3. The question of its role in Europe, indeed the role of nation-states in Europe, becomes increasingly urgent as the countries to the East move on from the euphoria of freedom to the agony of transformation.
Preoccupation with the Persian Gulf crisis has diverted attention from the critically decisive period ahead in Europe. It adds difficulties because it has always been harder for the Common Market to move in periods of economic dislocation such as the new oil shock will bring. 
The whole timetable of Europe's evolution has changed. There will be a new all-German government based on elections Dec. 2, even before the European Community (absorbing East Germany) begins its major meetings on monetary and political union later that month in Rome. Their results will determine whether there is a European Germany or a German Europe, as the Federal Republic's Hans-Dietrich Genscher puts it.
There are hints that Bonn's pledge for a strong new push to integration is eroding with the temptation of a special role in the East. There have been suspicions this would happen. But so far Chancellor Helmut Kohl, and Mr. Genscher as well, have insisted they are resolved to anchor the new Germany in a union with increasingly limited national sovereignties.
The issue is put in terms of priority for ''broadening or deepening'' the Common Market, that is, opening to a number of new members, or tightening rules to move nearer a United States of Europe. Both cannot be done at once. The more countries involved, the harder it will be to unify them.
Eastern Europe is clamoring for an early promise of inclusion because it sees it as the lifeline out of its doldrums. So the debate can be veiled in the argument over sympathy for its plight versus the Community's need to build its own house solidly first.
A meeting of Aspen Institute Italia this week showed second thoughts about Europe's direction, in favor of accommodating Eastern wishes. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who hates the idea of integration, would have been delighted. It sounded as though Germany and Italy were moving her way toward a loose, unconstraining Community, or at least a ''two-speed Europe'' allowing choice of how much national power to pool, leaving France a lonely federalizer.
This is a crossroads. It's not just a matter of diplomatic haggling. The founders' idea was to defang the nationalisms that had devastated Europe by creating common institutions binding states together. Their success was based on mutual obligations.
Despite concern about a ''Fortress Europe,'' America should continue to support that idea because it is in a confident, supranational Europe that it can find its most effective partner. Germany will be the weightiest member whether the Community is weak or strong, but the stronger the Community, the less a future Germany is likely to go its own way.
In the longer run, this is in the interest of Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union as well. But they are understandably desperate about the immediate future and want close ties quickly, even if that would undermine the foundations of a sturdy Europe.
There are better ways to meet their needs for a sense of attachment. The new European Bank for Reconstruction and Development is working on coordination of aid to the East, but it isn't doing anything so far to promote coordination among recipients. None of them are asking for that, they are so eager to shed their old ties.
But destruction of the Soviet bloc doesn't mean they no longer need to trade with each other. They will benefit from mutual exchanges just as Western Europe did. Their trouble is that up to now their exchanges have been distorted, aggravating inefficiencies, because of their system.
All recognize the advantage of achieving convertible currencies, but it is beyond their present capacity. On Jan. 1, the Soviet Union will charge Eastern Europe hard currency for gas and oil supplies, a devastating blow to them made all the worse by the sharp rise in prices.
Brussels has proposed an Eastern Payments Union, like the one sponsored by the U.S. during Western European reconstruction. It is a good way to speed transition to open trading. The stabilization fund the West would need to provide would cost less than convertibility support for each country separately and ease pressure on the Community to sidetrack integration. The U.S. is hesitant but it shouldn't be. It knows better than anybody about the value of union.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-ed

HEADLINE: Letter: On Garbage;
Let the Free Market Tackle Solid Waste

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It is difficult to understand your casual dismissal of my proposal to use an auction system to site undesirable plants like landfills, incinerators and radioactive dumps in New York State (''Mr. Rinfret on Garbage,'' editorial, Aug. 15).
Siting is the most difficult part of the solid waste issue. We ship 11 percent of our solid waste out of state. The states that receive our garbage are becoming resistant and may soon close the door. 
The fundamental problem is twofold: (1) there is very little economic reward for any municipality that takes such a facility, and (2) there is no cost to a municipality that deals with the problem by pushing it into someone else's backyard. Because this process is essentially political and involves pushing costs onto others, anyone who ends up with the facility is regarded as a loser, and everyone who avoids the facility considers himself a winner.
My proposal would impose costs on municipalities that do not take the facility and offer a reward to the municipalities that do. Because of shared benefits and burdens, there would be no winners or losers.
The auction would help the affected locality deal with three important externalities: (1) The bonus money would be used to assure that the facility is top-notch, safe and sound; (2) the money could be used to compensate those neighbors who are most directly affected by the facility; (3) the money would be used for general compensation of local residents by lowering taxes (or, if the locality is run by Democrats, raising spending).
You criticize the plan by arguing, ''Poorer upstate communities would stand little chance against the resources of, say, Scarsdale, Bronxville, Rye and other well-heeled communities in Westchester County.''
You ignore the fact that my plan envisions a regional approach, and nothing would require small upstate counties to participate with downstate neighbors on the issue of solid waste.
Eight years of Cuomo administration inaction has not solved the problem. Witness mishandling of the proposed resource recovery facility at the Brooklyn Navy Yard.
I believe New Yorkers have had enough of government inaction on solid waste. Let's get private enterprise and the free market more involved in the solid waste issue. Why be afraid of trying something different?
 
PIERRE RINFRET
 New York, Aug. 23, 1990
 
The writer is the Republican candidate for governor of New York State.

LENGTH: 352 words

HEADLINE: Economic Cooperation for East Europe

 BODY:
Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Poland are now vigorously competing to be the first to throw off their remaining Communist shackles and free their markets. In time, these steps will benefit them economically. More immediately, they'll help attract Western capital and assistance. 
But some aspects of this rivalry are worrisome. Cutthroat competition for foreign investment could lead to wasteful efforts - excessive tax breaks, for example. Protectionism against neighbors' imports in the hope of saving failing businesses could be pernicious. Unfettered economic nationalism could make these countries less worthy aid recipients and riskier business partners.
To head off such nationalism after World War II, the United States gave Marshall Plan aid to the war-devastated countries of Western Europe on the condition that recipients cooperate regionally. That same strategy could be usefully employed in Central Europe today.
Eastern Europe's recent history complicates the task. Comecon, the Communist version of a common market, gave cooperation a bad name. Comecon geared production to serve Soviet needs, thereby distorting national economic development. And much of the cooperating was bilateral, with the Soviet Union, rather than regionwide.
One striking measure of Eastern Europe's lack of integration is that, even today, only six flights a week link Prague and Budapest by air. On most days there are none.
As if Comecon's legacy weren't problem enough, rival nationalisms, long suppressed under Communist rule, are now surfacing to further impede cooperation. When Hungary's Prime Minister Antall declares he's ''responsible'' for Hungarians outside his borders, he stirs resentment in Czechoslovakia as well as Romania. A better way to assure the well-being of Hungarians wherever they live is for old rivals to cooperate.
If Czechoslovaks, Hungarians and Poles work together on regional development, they'll help reassure skittish investors that they're ready to overcome centuries of national antagonism. Washington can help make its own aid more effective by promoting regional cooperation.

HEADLINE: U.S. Guidelines Address Meatpacking Injuries

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31

 BODY:
The Labor Department is establishing a test program in the meatpacking industry to protect workers from painful and crippling injuries caused by repetitive motions.
The new guidelines for the industry resulted from negotiations between industry and union representatives, department officials said Thursday. Compliance is voluntary. The Labor Department is not ordering packing companies to adopt the new guidelines, which will be sent to them in the next few days. But if they do not adopt them, department officials said they would fine packers whose workers have a high incidence of repetitive motion ailments. 
Elizabeth Dole, the Secretary of Labor, said the guidelines would emphasize design of the workplace with the physical needs of workers in mind. New approaches might include revised tool designs, improved safety equipment and rotating workers to reduce repetitive work.
The department plans to study the program's effectiveness and use the results to reduce injuries in other occupations, especially those in which computers are used.
 
Carpel Tunnel Syndrome
Office workers striking the keyboards of video display terminals and supermarket checkers who sweep items over electronic scanners frequently complain of repetitive motion injuries like carpal tunnel syndrome, a nerve disorder of the wrist and hand.
''Repetitive motion injuries, which include lower back injuries, carpal tunnel syndrome and tendon disorders, now comprise 48 percent of all recordable industrial workplace illnesses,'' Mrs. Dole said. ''The economic burden of such injuries to employers and society is enormous.''
According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, 240,900 workplace illnesses were reported in 1988, the last year for which figures are available.
Mrs. Dole said the beef and pork packing industry was chosen because its 140,000 workers suffer from workplace injuries at a rate 10 times the national average. Meatpackers are often required to repeat the same motion as much as 8,000 times an hour, which can cause cysts, swollen tendons and nerve damage.
Mrs. Dole said it would take years of study before any enforceable rules could be established.
 
'Real Protection' Demanded
A spokesman for Howard M. Metzenbaum, the Ohio Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee's Subcommittee on Labor, said the Senator was troubled by the program because it was voluntary and had no enforcement power.
''After 10 years of Administration neglect, American workers deserve real protection,'' Mr. Metzenbaum's spokesman said.
J. Patrick Boyle, president of the American Meat Institute, said the organization had already taken steps to redesign tools and equipment.
Al Zack, a spokesman for the United Food and Commercial Workers International Union, which represents 100,000 meatpackers and helped develop the guidelines, said, ''The guidelines are a positive step forward, but without an honest-to-goodness inspection and enforcement program they are meaningless.''

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
No War Unless Iraq Strikes, U.S. Gulf Commander Says

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: IN SAUDI ARABIA, Aug. 31

 BODY:
The commander of American forces in Saudi Arabia said today that there would be no fighting here unless Iraq launched an attack.
''There is not going to be any war unless the Iraqis attack,'' said the commander, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf.
In his first news conference since coming here four days ago, the four-star Army general played down the possibility of using offensive force to compel the Iraqis to withdraw from Kuwait.
''The force that I am assembling here is exactly the force that was briefed to the President of the United States as necessary for the defense of Saudi Arabia,'' said the general, who described the discussion of a possible use of offensive American forces as ''hypothetical.'' 
 
Military Buildup Continues
The general appeared to be signaling that the main means at present for driving the Iraqis out of Kuwait would be economic pressure and not military force. His comments may also reflect the calculation that the United States is still building up its military presence here and has not yet assembled the kind of ground force that it would like to have if it were to mount an attack on Kuwait or Iraq.
General Schwarzkopf visited American forces in this country today and spoke in blunt terms about the Iraqis and about the American military presence here. During a visit to an Air Force unit at a base here, the general said the United States was prepared to repel any Iraqi attack.
''If he dares come across the border and comes down here, I'm completely confident,'' General Schwarzkopf told members of the 354th Tactical Fighter Wing from Myrtle Beach, S.C. The wing is equipped with A-10 attack planes, which are designed to destroy tanks. General Schwarzkopf said the deployment of the A-10's here greatly increased the American ability to take on Iraqi armored forces.
During his news conference, the general also expressed confidence that the United States could repel an Iraqi invasion but was less categorical. ''If the Iraqis are dumb enough to attack, they're going to pay a price,'' he said, but added that he could not give a 100 percent assurance that the United States forces could successfully defend the Saudi kingdom.
 
Warning on Chemical Weapons
The general also issued a blunt warning that any Iraqi use of chemical weapons would prompt a major American military retaliation. If Iraq uses chemical weapons, he said, ''they will pay for it big time.''
The general, a former football player with an avuncular manner, described Iraqi's military leaders as a ''bunch of thugs.''
Yet at other times the general appeared to be playing the role of a diplomat. He repeatedly emphasized that the United States had no intention of establishing permanent military bases in Saudi Arabia and tried to sidestep questions about who was ultimately in charge of the multinational forces deployed here.
''This is not NATO,'' he said. ''This is not a single command, and there doesn't need to be.''
The general also did not give a direct answer when asked whether the United States could employ military forces based in Saudi Arabia without Saudi consent. The head of the Arab forces here, Prince Khalid bin Sultan bin Abdulaziz, who is a Saudi lieutenant general, told reporters this week that the United States would have to consult with Saudi Arabia before taking any military action using forces based in the kingdom.
The general declined to give a general breakdown of areas of operations of the forces in this country or to say whether the American military was aiding Kuwaiti guerrillas fighting the Iraqis.
 
Assessment of Iraqi Army
Discussing the Iraqi military deployment, the general said Iraqi forces were still in a generally defensive configuration but said they could shift into a more offensive mode. Describing the Iraqi Army, he said that ''some of their equipment is fairly good, some of their units are lousy, so if their equipment is lousy, we certainly are taking this all into account.''
The general suggested that the presence of American hostages at military targets in Iraq would not influence his decisions.
''I would tell you that obviously I am just as concerned as anyone else about every single human life,'' he said. ''What I have to do is plan the military component and not concern myself with the hostages.''

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
In Moscow, Gulf Crisis Ranks Second

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Aug. 31

 BODY:
Although Iraq is closer to the Soviet border than New York is to Boston, the gulf crisis that has fixated the rest of the world seems almost peripheral to residents of this capital of competing crises.
In a week when the newspapers predicted that tobacco riots might soon be followed by shortages of bread and aspirin, when a bumper wheat crop was rotting in the fields, when Moscow was puzzling over a diphtheria outbreak, when President Mikhail S. Gorbachev was wrestling with threats of secession and depression, Iraq did not dominate the headlines and scarcely figured in conversation on the street.
If Mr. Gorbachev sometimes seems to have less fire in his belly than President Bush when it comes to taming Saddam Hussein, one reason is that on this issue Soviet public opinion is less intense and more ambivalent than in the West.
 
Public Opinion a Factor
And Mr. Gorbachev, unlike his predecessors, has to reckon with public opinion in making his foreign policy. 
''The effect of Iraqi behavior and especially the hostage situation has been to solidify Western public opinion behind President Bush and strong sanctions,'' said a Western diplomat here.
''In this country, the balance of opinion is very different - much more introverted, concerned with domestic problems, scarred by Afghanistan, and very wary of getting involved in any sort of an overseas commitment.''
Western and Arab officials here say that given the isolationism here and decades of close ties to Iraq, the wonder is how fully Mr. Gorbachev has collaborated in the American-led campaign against Moscow's longtime ally and weapons client.
They say they have seen no evidence that Moscow is circumventing the embargo against Iraq, or the cutoff of arms deliveries that Moscow announced before the United Nations imposed sanctions.
 
Position Is Clear
The Arab diplomats say Moscow has so far made plain to Iraq and its supporters, including the Palestine Liberation Organization, that it will not support any settlement short of a full Iraqi retreat. Moscow has not nibbled at Iraq's attempt to link a withdrawal from Kuwait to Israel's surrender of its occupied territories.
''There can be no doubt that the Soviet position is very firm and very clear,'' said one senior Arab diplomat.
Diplomats here put little stock in the accusations of some American conservatives that the Soviets are playing a double game in the gulf - pretending to support the campaign against Mr. Hussein, the Iraqi President, while privately relishing the higher oil prices that play hell with the American economy and promise a windfall of several billion dollars to Soviet producers.
Higher oil and gas prices, and the higher gold prices that accompany a time of crisis, are indeed a boon to the Soviet Union, although the decrepit industry is in poor shape to take advantage of them. Oil production has actually been declining because of antiquated equipment.
''You could make the windfall argument against a number of oil-producing countries, including Saudi Arabia and the United Kingdom,'' a Western diplomat said.
 
'Small Net Gain'
More important, the diplomats contend, it is hard to imagine that Mr. Gorbachev would jeopardize the most valuable prize he has won for his country - Western good will, and the prospect of long-term financial assistance - for a short-term oil profit.
''The Soviets get a small net gain, but not on an order of magnitude to provide a motive for a double game,'' said a Western diplomat.
By collaborating in the sanctions against Mr. Hussein, Moscow stands not only to secure its candidate membership in the club of civilized nations, but to greatly enhance its relations with the rich Gulf states and moderate Arab countries like Egypt.
 
Wider U.N. Role Sought
Soviet leaders have been pressing to give the U.N. a wider role, and multilateralism has become more urgent to Moscow with the withering of the Soviet bloc in Europe.
Against the advantages of cooperation, however, Mr. Gorbachev has had to weigh the risks of becoming embroiled in an enterprise that could lead his country into war, or that his political rivals and the military might view as shamefully subservient to America.
The Soviet and American approaches have diverged on several points.
Mr. Gorbachev has been slower than other members of the United Nations Security Council to sanction the use of military force against Iraq, and has so far declined to send ships to help the blockade.
On Thursday, senior officials of the Foreign Ministry and the military expressed deep misgivings about the American-led buildup in the region, and worried aloud that United States Marines might be planning a permanent encampment in Saudi Arabia.
The Kremlin has not severed its treaty of friendship with Iraq, contending it is useful to keep open the lines of communication.
When Iraq ordered that all foreign countries leave their embassies in Kuwait, the Kremlin insisted that its embassy and its recognition of the Kuwaiti Government in exile remained legally intact - but removed all Soviet nationals from occupied Kuwait.
 
Many Technicians Remain
Moscow has also made no public attempt to withdraw 193 Soviet technicians who were sent to Iraq before the crisis to explain and maintain Soviet weapons, and several thousand other specialists have continued working in construction and oil-field projects.
Soviet officials say publicly that these experts do not violate the letter of the U.N. embargo. Privately, they say that a quick withdrawal could have precipitated reprisals, and that they hope to pull the specialists out as soon as woman and children go.
Mr. Gorbachev has also been trying to avoid any step that could draw his country into a conflict. Russian mothers took to the streets in revolt last year when the Kremlin tried to call up the reserves for peacekeeping duty in Azerbaijan, a Soviet republic.
Serious doubt has also arisen whether a country still bitter from its 10-year failure in Afghanistan would support a decision to send soldiers abroad, against an enemy armed and trained by the Soviet Union and prepared to use chemical weapons.
Indeed, the Western diplomats suggest that ordering troops to Iraq, when the military is in disarray and the country is mired in an economic crisis, could be the end for Mr. Gorbachev.
 
A Lukewarm Affection
It is not that Mr. Hussein enjoys any popular affection in this country. Iraq to the ordinary Russian is just another third world country that sups at the Soviet treasury. But neither is there much feeling that keeping him in line is a Soviet affair.
''Isn't it enough that so many young men die in Afghanistan, and continue to perish in Armenia and Azerbaijan, Uzbekistan and Kirghizia?'' mused a writer in the liberal weekly New Times, arguing against ''the role of Don Quixote.''
The writer concluded, ''There is no reason for our people to go charging at windmills in the name of 'restoring universal justice,' or to shed their blood beyond the borders of the fatherland.''

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
U.S. Says Gulf Moves' Cost Will Far Exceed $25 Billion

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., Aug. 31

 BODY:
The worldwide burden-sharing program for the Persian Gulf operation will require tens of billions of dollars in financial aid to third-world countries, repayment for trade lost in the embargo against Iraq, donations of fuel to American military forces and other contributions, Administration officials said today.
The officials said they could not provide an exact price tag. But they said the cost would significantly exceed estimates of $25 billion that were reported today. Much of the program remains to be negotiated by President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, who plan missions abroad next week. 
 
Counting on Fuel for Military
But officials said the United States expects, among other things, that the oil-producing nations will provide all the fuel for American military forces deployed in Saudi Arabia, that Japan will contribute significantly more than the $1.3 billion it has announced it will give to the program, and that Washington will have to pay a ''sizable share'' of the cost.
As part of its contribution, the United States is planning to eliminate a substantial portion of Egypt's military debt of $6 billion to $7 billion, officials said. The exact figure is still under discussion.
In the Red Sea today, the Pentagon said a United States Naval vessel stopped and boarded an Iraqi oil tanker for the first time since the United Nations authorized the use of the military to enforce the trade embargo on Iraq.
The guided-missile cruiser Biddle stopped the tanker at 8:36 A.M. Eastern time, found it to be empty and allowed it to proceed, the Navy said. The tanker's captain cooperated and no violence was reported, officials said.
In Kennebunkport, Mr. Bush's vacation home, the White House said today that the President had spoken to the leaders of France, Britain and Saudi Arabia as part of effort to coordinate the ''burden sharing'' program he announced on Thursday in Washington.
All three countries are expected to play a major role in the effort, which is intended to give financially strapped countries an incentive to adhere to the economic sanctions against Iraq and make it more difficult for President Saddam Hussein to simply hunker down in Kuwait in hopes that the embargo will slowly start to unravel.
The program has two essential elements, they said. One is to help pay for keeping scores of thousands of American soldiers in the Saudi desert, along with dozens of British, Canadian and French warships in the waters around the Arabian Peninsula. Saudi Arabia has been contributing aviation fuel, and the Saudis and other oil producers are eventually expected to provide all the fuel for the American military in the Persian Gulf, officials said.
 
Helping Mideast Economies
The other element is to aid countries that are suffering financially from the economic sanctions because they are losing trade with Iraq, income associated with Iraqi oil exports, or the incomes of their citizens who normally work in Iraq. The officials said the first phase of the project will focus on Egypt, Jordan and Turkey, which the United States says have been hardest hit by the gulf crisis.
In the longer term, one official said, assistance will be arranged to another tier of countries, including India, Morocco, Bangladesh, the Philippines and countries in Eastern Europe.
''This crisis hasn't happened in a vacuum,'' an official said. ''If you look at the efforts we've made recently to bring stability to Eastern Europe, we don't want that all to be undone because of what's happening in the Middle East.''
In most cases, aid - direct payments, loans, loan guarantees and other programs - will be provided without the requirements of economic revisions usually attached to loans to developing countries, officials said.
''Simply to insist on ideal economic reform policies in a very trying and difficult situation does not make good sense,'' an official said.
 
Girding Political Stability
''To be blunt about it, we're trying to stabilize countries and it does not make a lot of sense to ask them to adopt economic policies that will destabilize them,'' he continued. ''We're sensitive to the need for Egyptian economic reform, for example, but not at the price of political stability.''
In Washington today, Reuters quoted Barber B. Conable Jr., president of the World Bank, as expressing concern about the issue. He urged nations taking part in the financial aid program not to drop the usual conditions attached to the bank's lending programs.
Administration officials declined to give targets for contributions from individual nations, although they said a large percentage would come from oil-producing countries. Nations like Britain and France, which are already contributing military forces to the region, also are expected to provide financial aid under the program, officials said.

LENGTH: 999 words

HEADLINE: CONSUMER'S WORLD;
Despite Complaints, Solicitation by Phone or Mail Is Growing

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
Your name, address and telephone number are no longer yours to give out only as you choose. Direct marketers all over the nation have them and are using them with increasing intensity to sell products and services.
The flood of unsolicited third-class or junk mail and intrusive telephone calls is reaching new heights and a good many consumers are irritated by what they regard as an invasion of privacy. In most cases, the sales pitches are legal and there are no laws, state or Federal, that prevent marketers from legitimately seeking your patronage by mail or phone. And because these techniques are showing better and better results, they are likely to continue to be a major factor in selling merchandise. 
Even if you contact the companies offering unwanted material, or take other action to stop calls and mail, you may still be solicited. ''There's no sure method of getting off all the lists,'' said Sara Cooper, a senior program associate of the National Consumers League, a nonprofit organization in Washington.
Of course, not everyone objects to direct marketing. The in-home sales market has grown because more Americans like the convenience of shopping by mail or phone.
 
 'Free' Vacations
Almost 92 million people ordered goods and services this way in 1989, compared with about 64 million in 1984, according to the Simmons Market Research Bureau in New York. The Direct Marketing Association, a national trade group, reports that businesses mailed more than 13 million catalogues last year and that consumers placed 3 billion phone calls to place an order or obtain information on products.
With such demonstrated interest, direct marketing companies are stepping up their efforts not only to keep customers, but to attract new ones. Good prospects are people who have bought similar items from their competitors.
The attraction of shopping at home for so-called bargains accounts for the variety of offers of ''free'' or inexpensive vacations, magazines, home-improvement packages, insurance policies and other items. And it means that advertisements for sweepstakes - games of chance in which no purchase is required - are appearing in consumers' mailboxes with more regularity.
''Like any direct marketer, we will mail to certain households more than others,'' said David C. Sayer, director of advertising of Publishers Clearing House, a magazine subscription agency in Port Washington, L.I., that runs many sweepstakes. ''If you bought from us in the last year, you could get two to five mailings a year.''
The sales pitches from some companies that sell through the mail are often frenzied, carrying names of the recipient in large type and suggesting that you will lose millions or forfeit a luxury car or trip if you do not respond immediately. Sometimes there are exaggerated promises of a prize or unrealistic savings. Cases of high-pressure marketing have been reported in which improper charges are made against a person's credit card and no merchandise or promised travel is ever received.
''You often get in the mail an artfully worded notification to claim an award or a distribution,'' said Stephen R. Jones, a vice president of the Council of Better Business Bureaus, the umbrella organization for local bureaus. ''But there are some catches to it. You may have to pay a redemption fee or pay a high shipping and handling charge.''
Telephone marketing is also on the rise. ''The telemarketing industry has become a huge operation in the last six or seven years,'' said Herschel Elkins, a senior assistant attorney general in California. ''You have an increase in the number of companies that are primarily engaging in interstate activities.''
Where do these marketers get your name and address? There are lists galore that are sold or rented to them by periodicals, associations and thousands of companies that deal with consumers. There are lists available by occupation, age group and special interest. And there are lists obtained from motor vehicle bureaus, ZIP code directories, telephone books and dozens of other sources.
Certain lists also have telephone numbers, many of which are obtained simply from the telephone directory. Direct marketers sometimes call holders of unlisted numbers, too, much to their surprise. Marketers may get these numbers by making random calls via a computer. They also get unlisted numbers of people who gave their phone numbers when entering a contest or requesting information about an investment, product or service.
Legislation has been introduced in both houses of Congress to prevent telemarketing fraud and abuse. The House Committee on Government Operations has said telemarketing fraud costs consumers billions of dollars annually.
The Senate bill has a provision that could prohibit computer-generated calls that cannot be terminated immediately by the consumer. At present, a consumer's line can be tied up until the recorded message is completed, even if the person receiving the call no longer has the telephone off the hook.
 
THROW IT OUT OR JUST HANG UP
If you want to receive fewer unsolicited letters, postcards and telephone calls, write to the Direct Marketing Association at 11 West 42d Street, P.O. Box 3861, New York, N.Y. 10163, and ask to have your name removed from company mailing or phone lists. You can also write directly to the companies.
Here are some tips for dealing with direct marketers from the Better Business Bureau of Metropolitan New York.
Resist succumbing to high pressure sales pitches on the phone. If you are interested in an offer, a legitimate company will send you information or give you time to consider an offer.
Never give out your credit card number unless you initiated the contact or are confident the caller will not misuse the information. If you suspect fraud or misrepresentation, hang up the phone or throw away the mailing.
If an offer intrigues you but you doubt its authenticity, check with the local Better Business Bureau.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Telemarketing has become a huge industry, said Herschel Elkins, senior assistant attorney general in California. Sweepstakes offers, right, have also increased. (Michael Tweed for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Gasoline Up As Supplies Stay Tight

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
Wholesale gasoline prices jumped again yesterday, but crude oil prices rose more modestly. Demand for gasoline remains strong, because of shortages of refinery capacity, traders said.
The United Nations trade embargo has shut down nearly all large refineries in Kuwait and Iraq, and other oil exporters lack the equipment to refine much of the extra production they are now putting on the market.
The wholesale gasoline contract for September delivery expired up 7.25 cents a gallon, or 8.1 percent, at 96.32 cents at the close of trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The increase followed a jump of 4.35 cents, or 5.1 percent, in the contract on Thursday. The crude oil contract for October delivery rose 55 cents a barrel, or 2.1 percent, to $27.32 on the New York Merc. 
For the week, however, oil prices dropped $3.59, and wholesale gasoline prices fell 8.3 cents. Oil and petroleum product prices fell sharply on Monday, and despite gains later in the week, they did not fully recover.
Gasoline prices are at a level that is likely to result in ''much higher prices at the retail pump, which will trigger conservation and bring the market back into equilibrium,'' said Philip K. Verleger Jr., an energy economist at the Institute for International Economics in Washington.
A strong statement yesterday from a two-day emergency session of the Arab League in Cairo, demanding reparations from Iraq for starting the current Middle East crisis, contributed to fears that a war might still disrupt production, said Robert S. Jonke, an energy futures trader at Cargill Investor Services. Oil prices jumped 25 cents when the news arrived, he said.
Saddam Hussein, the President of Iraq, has been slow to honor his pledge to release Western women and children who are being held in Iraq and Kuwait, and traders have taken that as another indication that war remains a possibility, said Virginia Wiater, a crude oil broker for United Energy on the floor of the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Gasoline prices have risen faster in Europe than in the United States, so more crude oil is being shipped there, and some cargos of gasoline are now headed there from the United States, Mr. Verleger said.
Part of the sharp increase yesterday in the September gasoline contract reflected traders' searching for cargos to meet previous commitments to deliver oil, traders said. The contract for the October delivery of gasoline rose 3.34 cents, to 86.18 cents a gallon.
But the large difference between September and October prices is also an indication that short-term gasoline supplies are extremely tight, Mr. Verleger said.
''One has to ask the question whether this is the first harbinger of impending gasoline lines,'' he said. But he projected that higher retail gasoline prices were more likely than the long lines and would be much healthier for the American economy.
Oil companies' profit margins are also being pinched now because when crude oil prices first rose, the companies did not raise the wholesale gasoline prices they charge to dealers proportionately, said Kenneth D. Miller, a senior principal at Purvin & Gertz, an energy consulting company in Houston. And they have difficulty doing so now because oil prices have slipped back a little and consumers expect lower prices at the pump, he added.
The American Automobile Association said yesterday that its nationwide spot-check on Wednesday found an average price for self-service regular unleaded gasoline of $1.307 a gallon. That compares with $1.062 over Labor Day weekend last year, said Geoff Sundstrom, a spokesman for the Orlando, Fla.-based group.
The contract for September delivery of heating oil rose 0.35 cent, or one-half of one percent, to 75.89 cents a gallon.
