HEADLINE: No Need Seen to Tap Oil Reserve

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Aug. 31

 BODY:
Saying that oil supplies remained nearly in balance with demand despite the embargo against Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil, the International Energy Agency, which represents 21 industrial nations, decided today not to recommend that members begin drawing down emergency reserves.
After a meeting in Paris, the agency's governing board said that member governments would take emergency cooperative measures, including the use of government-controlled oil stocks, only ''if the situation so warrants.''
Agency officials forecast that the loss of 4.3 million barrels a day in Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil would largely be offset in September by increased production elsewhere, the use of company petroleum stocks and reduced demand that resulted from higher energy prices.
 
Sufficient Supplies Seen
Ulrich Engelmann, chairman of the agency's governing board, said: ''For the present, the market is generally well supplied. Given the oil market outlook for the next two months, governments do not consider additional measures to be necessary right now.'' 
Some oil experts have criticized the member nations for not tapping their strategic reserves, which total a billion barrels, equivalent to 150 days of the industrial world's net oil imports. The United States and other countries contend that the reserves should be drawn down only in the event of a shortage, not to control prices. But some economists, arguing that a jump in prices can endanger the world economy, say the reserves should already have been tapped.
''They have this stupid idea that what matters is a quantity shortfall,'' said Robert Mabro, director of the Oxford Institute for Energy Research. ''For me what matters is a price explosion.''
 
Agency Set Up in '74
Some officials in the agency's secretariat said that if the shortfall were to exceed 500,000 barrels a day, the agency members would approve emergency measures to tap the reserves. The governing board said its secretariat ''shall monitor the situation carefully and prepare the necessary steps'' if such use is warranted.
The United States, Canada, Japan, Australia, New Zealand and more than a dozen European nations formed the Paris-based agency in 1974 to coordinate the industrial world's response to an oil crisis. The agency has encouraged governments to establish strategic reserves and has developed emergency plans for conservation and for tapping government stocks.
The agency, which is operated by consensus, has also encouraged the development and use of energy sources other than petroleum, including coal and nuclear power.
Helga Steeg, the agency's executive director, announced today that France had begun negotiations to join the agency. France refused to join at the beginning because it saw the agency as an anti-OPEC group and feared that membership would injure France's good relations with the Arab world.
Agency officials said oil supplies were largely in balance with demand in August principally because Iraqi and Kuwaiti production before the embargo was still being delivered and because oil companies were drawing some 300,000 barrels a day from their own stocks.
Agency officials said the first impact of the loss of 4.3 million barrels a day would be felt in September. Nevertheless, they said, supply and demand would be in relative balance because companies were expected to draw down stocks by about a million barrels a day and non-industrialized countries were expected to reduce their stocks by 600,000 barrels a day.
In addition, the agency officials say, the increased production that Saudi Arabia and some other nations began in August, after the invasion of Kuwait, will begin to reach the market in September, increasing supplies by 1.3 million barrels a day.
 
Rise in Demand Feared
Saudi officials say they have increased production by two million barrels a day, but energy agency officials say that oil will not reach market until October.
''For October, this higher oil production and further commercial stock draw is expected to meet much of the shortfall,'' the agency's governing board said today.
But the board added that demand could increase in the winter, and that companies would not be able to continue drawing down signficant amounts of their stocks.
As a result, some agency officials see a hard-to-manage shortage of more than 500,000 barrels a day developing late this year, even with Wednesday's decision of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to raise production by an expected four million barrels a day. Some officials say OPEC may not be able to get that extra oil to market by the end of the year.

HEADLINE: About New York;
A Shrine Is Born In the Incubator Of the 'Wretched'

BYLINE: By MARTIN GOTTLIEB

 BODY:
To the side of a blacktop city park at First Avenue and East First Street, a bronze plaque affixed to a fiberglass rock has been drawing a varied stream of pilgrims all summer.
It leads Arnold Howard Freeman, widely known as Howard, who sells used copies of quality books from an adjacent armchair, to marvel: ''At all times, 24 hours a day, they come here, couples, singles, too, and they read, mostly in silence. The other day someone sat down in front of it in the lotus position for about three hours and copied. Yesterday there were people here at 2 A.M.''
On the plaque is ''The Black Sheep,'' a poem by the performance artist Karen Finley. It opens with a conversation between two veteran funeralgoers in the age of AIDS, one swearing never to attend another ''death party'' for someone he didn't know. 
 
 Cause-cause-cause I feel I feel so
 sad cause I never knew their life -
 and now I only know their death.
 
 The poem moves to reflections on the multitudes in ''the black sheep family'':
 
 There's always one in every family
 Even when we're surrounded by bodies
 we're always alone.
 The poem continues later:
 
 That's our life. That's our story.
 Usually we're outcasts, outsiders
 in our own family.
 Don't worry - get used to it.
 The sentiments most pointedly encompass gay people, women, people with AIDS, bohemians and the sorts of constitutional contrarians who make up the parade on the bustling little strip that Howard calls the boulevard.
But given its location, ''The Black Sheep'' addresses and includes much more. The corner is at the heart of the city's great immigrant incubator, the Lower East Side.
Homeless men sell whatevers on either side of the sculpture.
Asian-American teen-agers play handball on courts behind it. Across First Avenue is a homeless encampment occupied mostly by African-Americans in a stripped-down park named for I. L. Peretz, often called the father of Yiddish literature and a champion of the oppressed Jews of turn-of-the-century Poland.
Ms. Finley is best known for her performance work, including ''We Keep Our Victims Ready,'' which concludes with ''The Black Sheep.'' The work has moved audiences with its at times shrieking expression of women's abnegation and abuse; its railing against a power structure, white, male and heterosexual, that Ms. Finley argues has closed itself to the pain of those outside it, and its final declaration of redemption and renewal in the arms of each other for the neglected and the hurt.
To a broader public, however, it is best known through the clumsy debate over the National Endowment of the Arts, which has rejected Ms. Finley's latest grant proposal. Ms. Finley's opponents portray the piece as little more than a contrivance summed up by her stripping to her underpants and smearing herself with chocolate. That characterization can only strike those who have seen the performance as wrongheaded and pernicious.
Ms. Finley's defenders have pointed to the power and morality of her work and - in no small part through the ways in which she uses her body - to its startling ability to voice the pain and longing of society's outsiders.
As its reception on First Avenue points out, Ms. Finley's work accomplishes something else. It strikes a particular and resonant chord in a city whose proudest heritage is the accommodation, however painful, of waves of ''wretched refuse,'' tainted by suspect ethnicity, politics, sexuality or life style.
''People stand here in the heat and read this thing - and that's pretty good for New York,'' Alun Uluc said recently near ''The Black Sheep,'' where she paused with her 9-month-old daughter, Emel. ''Basically every black sheep in every state and even Europe comes here and they all blend in - that's what the East Village is about.''
So much so that Reggie Joseph, an unemployed carpenter, sells rice paper rubbings of the poem for $5 at a good clip. Juan Garcia, who had come downtown from East Harlem to visit a friend, said he particularly liked ''The Black Sheep'' passage that reads:
 
 We always speak our mind
 appreciate differences in culture
 believe in sexual preferences
 believe in no racism, no sexism, no religionism.
 Mr. Garcia was wearing a bandage across his nose as a result of a mugging in Newark.
The Black Sheep installation cost $5,000 and is sponsored by Creative Time, which presents art in public places throughout the city. It will remain at the site until October.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
BUSH WILL MEET GORBACHEV ON SUNDAY, GULF ON AGENDA; IRAQIS LET SOME HOSTAGES GO

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., Sept. 1

 BODY:
President Bush announced today that he and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will meet in Helsinki on Sept. 9. Administration officials said the meeting was intended to display superpower solidarity at a time when Washington is eager to hold together the alliance against Iraq.
The meeting in Finland's capital, which Mr. Bush said had been arranged at his initiative over the past week, was scheduled at a time when the Soviet Union has been sending mixed signals about the military standoff on the Arabian Peninsula.
Some Soviet officials have suggested that Moscow is uncomfortable with the American presence there, 700 miles from the Soviet border, and Mr. Gorbachev expressed concern on Friday about the possibility of warfare. Others suggest that the Soviet leader is seeking a higher profile in the gulf crisis. [Page 18.] No Big Disagreement Seen Mr. Bush, who has already met with Mr. Gorbachev twice as President, said he was ''very anxious'' to discuss the Persian Gulf situation with him. But he took pains to stress that he and Mr. Gorbachev were not at odds on the Middle East, where Washington and Moscow once competed for influence. ''It wasn't driven by any worry that we might be apart,'' he said of the planned one-day meeting. ''Rather that there's a wide array of questions that could use consultation at this time.'' 
Talking to reporters at his vacation home here today, Mr. Bush said he and Mr. Gorbachev had no particular peace plan to discuss in Finland, where Mr. Bush will arrive on Saturday. He also said he did not foresee a role for the Soviet Union either as part of the worldwide financial-assistance program that Mr. Bush is putting together or as a mediator in the Persian Gulf. [Excerpts, page 6.] ''I don't see any mediating role at all, and I don't think the Soviets see themselves having a mediating role,'' Mr. Bush said.
 
Talks on Arms Expected
The President said he and Mr. Gorbachev would also discuss other issues, including negotiations on a treaty to reduce conventional armed forces in Europe. ''I think we can get done what we need to do in one day and that's what he feels also,'' Mr. Bush said.
Marlin Fitzwater, Mr. Bush's spokesman, said the two leaders had to ''overcome a few humps'' relating to artillery and aircraft in the conventional arms negotiations in order to finish off that treaty for signing in Paris at a 35-nation meeting in December.
In Moscow, the scheduling of the meeting was reported without comment.
Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev are expected to issue a joint statement after the meeting and hold a news conference together.
A senior Administration official in Washington said the United States arranged the meeting in part to make certain that the two nations would be able to continue the extraordinary confluence of interests and the cooperation that have been a highlight of the Persian Gulf crisis.
The meeting also is seen by Washington as an important symbol, the official said, to help hold together the international coalition against Iraq and to counter President Saddam Hussein's effort to portray the crisis in the gulf as a fight between Iraq and the United States. ''If you want an international and Arab consensus to hold, then we and the Soviets have to be visibly on board together,'' the official said. Having the two leaders issue a joint statement condemning Mr. Hussein is seen as a powerful way of doing that, the official said.
He added that the United States had taken note of recent Soviet concerns about the gulf crisis and wanted to make sure that a problem does not develop between the two countries and that other nations cannot take an apparent Soviet-American division as an excuse to break away from the trade embargo against Iraq.
 
U.S. View of Soviet Role
Reacting to reports from the Middle East of a possible Soviet mediation effort in the gulf, Administration officials said the United States would welcome any Soviet effort to persuade Mr. Hussein to withdraw from Kuwait. But they were eager not to have any such initiative portrayed as mediation because that suggests the fight in the gulf is between Iraq and the United States alone, an official said.
The President portrayed the meeting next weekend as part of the new, less formal relationship between the leaders of the two nuclear superpowers and as an outgrowth of the cooperation between Washington and Moscow in a region where the interests of the two countries often collided in the past.
Mr. Bush recalled that he and Mr. Gorbachev had agreed to meet more frequently at their most recent summit talks in Washington. ''We both agreed up at Camp David that this kind of informal, unstructured format might be very good in a world where there are so many changes,'' he said. ''So it's a good chance to test that now.''
Finland was chosen for the meeting because it is more convenient for Mr. Gorbachev, officials said.
 
Communication by Cable
Mr. Gorbachev is the only major world leader to whom Mr. Bush has not spoken by telephone or in person during the gulf crisis. But Mr. Bush said that he had been in ''direct contact'' with the Soviet leader, by diplomatic cable, and that he did not feel the need to telephone him because he had anticipated a face-to-face meeting.
Mr. Bush said the meeting was arranged in telephone conversations between Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and said Mr. Baker had told him the Soviet Union was very enthusiastic about the proposal.
Mr. Bush angrily denounced the manner in which Mr. Hussein has allowed only a trickle of foreign hostages to leave Iraq and Kuwait. ''It is so base and outrageous that I think most people in the Arab world are very embarrassed by this,'' Mr. Bush said. ''And I think that's certainly true of others around the world. I've talked to so many leaders and they all agree that this is just a despicable performance.''
Asked how long he could tolerate Mr. Hussein's holding foreigners as hostages, Mr. Bush said, ''I don't deal in deadlines.''
 
Relief for Egypt Weighed
Mr. Bush said it was his instinct at this point to ask Congress to drop all or part of Egypt's $7 billion military debt to the United States as part of an effort to help that country deal with the economic hardships wrought by the gulf crisis. But he said he had not made a final decision on the issue.
Mr. Bush was not asked about reports that the United States is preparing to transfer as much as $1 billion worth of advanced weapons to Israel to buttress Israeli defenses against Iraq and offset recent arms sales to Saudi Arabia.
In an earlier briefing for reporters, Brent Scowcroft, the President's national security adviser, did not comment directly on the talks. He said discussions with Israel about arms transfers were ''an annual affair of consultation between the United States and Israel.''

Mr. Bush said he would meet next week in Finland with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. (Associated Press) (pg. 18)

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Gauging Next Move by Hussein: Uneasy Wait in a Tense Standoff

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1

 BODY:
''I can't predict what he's going to do,'' said President Bush about his current nemesis, President Saddam Hussein, at a news conference on Thursday. ''The unpredictable nature'' of the Iraqi leader, Mr. Bush argued, makes it impossible to say if war lies ahead.
But many Middle East experts think they understand President Hussein well enough to deduce what he is likely to do, at least in the near future. They say his options are clear enough, his patterns of past performance well enough known, his habits of mind evident enough to make educated guesses.
Most of them believe that the Iraqi dictator, having concluded that he has made a major error in arousing the wrath of the West and of part of the Arab world by brutally overrunning Kuwait, will now lie back for a while. 
 
'Lower the Temperature'
''As we see it,'' an Israeli military official said, ''Saddam is gathering as many cards as he can now for either a political or military settlement, while also buying time. He clearly doesn't want a military confrontation with the United States.''
''The best option from his point of view,'' said Sir Anthony Parsons, a retired British diplomat highly respected for his knowledge of the Arab world, ''is to sit it out, lower the temperature, try to continue to split the Arab people from the Arab governments, split the solidarity - such as it is - of Arab governments themselves, create an antiwar atmosphere in the West and hope over a period of weeks or months that the outside world, with its well-known short attention span, will begin to not take it too seriously, that the sanctions war will start to crumble, that widespread cheating will develop.''
 
Small Concessions May Work
Academic specialists, military experts, intelligence specialists, diplomats and others interviewed in a half-dozen cities, from Washington to Jerusalem to Tokyo, tend to agree. Some said that it might be possible to offer President Hussein enough small concessions, without pandering to his dreams of regional hegemony, to reach a political solution and avoid war.
Certainly lying low has been the pattern this week, as President Hussein told captains of Iraqi merchant vessels not to resist inspection by United States Navy ships, ordered his ground forces into more emphatically defensive positions, kept his air force well within Iraqi airspace and began, albeit slowly, to release Western women and children he had been holding hostage.
Many commentators and a few American officials have pictured the 53-year-old Iraqi leader as erratic, eccentric, even mad. But most who know him and have studied him consider him cunning, ruthless, vain, bloodthirsty, but not demented in the slightest - a man whose motives and goals are quite comprehensible, even if the world considers his methods despicable.
''This is no psychotic megalomaniac,'' said Prof. Jerrold Post of George Washington University, a psychiatrist who specializes in developing psychological profiles of political figures. ''He is a highly rational man - dangerous but well focused.''
''We should remember,'' Professor Post added, ''that this is a man who waits, very patiently, uses time as a weapon, to get what he wants. If he sees a way out of this, with a fig leaf, he'll take it, and then two years from now, five years from now, his appetite for power will be undiminished and he'll strike again somewhere.''
 
'Kind of Foreboding'
Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, worried about that possibility, has called for the United States to drive President Hussein and his army from power.
Mr. Lugar, who is probably the most influential Republican on Capitol Hill on questions of foreign policy, said he found it ''kind of foreboding that the Iraqis are backing off from confrontation, becoming almost pacific, playing defense, making us sit out there and wait until something happens.''
 
No Immediate Results
Few regional experts expect economic sanctions to bite quickly. James Schlesinger, a Republican who served as Secretary of Energy, Director of Central Intelligence and Secretary of Defense under a variety of Presidents, said the other day that real results would take from six to eight months.
If full-scale war does come, he said, the United States would suffer ''many thousands of casualties.'' The only alternative, Mr. Schlesinger suggested on PBS's ''MacNeil-Lehrer Newshour,'' is a diplomatic solution in which President Bush would get much less than he has demanded - Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait and restoration of its ruler to power.
''Saddam Hussein is not a fellow to capitulate readily,'' he said. ''We tend to think in terms of unconditional surrender, but normally in the case of undconditional surrender you have to impose a military defeat before you get the surrender rather than the other way around. Just threatening him with destruction won't do it.''
An American intelligence official, deeply involved in the Persian Gulf crisis, said the situation would take some months to ripen. After that, he said, the Iraqis might strike directly, by killing some of the hostages or letting them starve, or indirectly, through a terrorist attack on a military target or a civilian airliner.
''In this situation, the strategic advantage lies with Saddam, not with the United States,'' the intelligence man continued. ''If Bush were to launch a raid, Saddam Hussein is the immediate winner. He wins in the eyes of the Arab world even if he loses, because he's carrying on the dream of the pan-Arab movement. He'd get creamed, but remember that Nasser lost the Six-Day War and came out of it as a hero.''
 
In Search of a Rationale
Hussein A. Hammami, Jordan's Ambassador to Washington, also sees a play for Arab sympathies as one of President Hussein's best options.
''Do not delude yourself that most Arabs welcome the presence of American troops in the area,'' he said. ''The United States can't be an arbiter of Arab differences and at the same time the strategic ally of their enemy Israel.''
Some experts see a pattern, especially in Mr. Hussein's relations with Iran, that suggests a willingness on his part to back down, especially if the retreat can be pictured to the Iraqi people, through tame news media, as a victory of sorts. In this case, said Marshall Wiley, a former chief of the United States interests section in Baghdad, ''He will need to find some way out where he can appear to have a rationale other than bowing to economic and military pressure from the United States.''
There are dissents from the view that the Iraqis are open to compromise.
''It is still feasible that he would say okay to a compromise, but I don't think it is in the cards'' said Dominique Moisi, deputy director of the French Institute on International Relations. ''What can he do? Basically nothing. I don't think he has options any longer. He has cornered himself into a position from which he cannot exit. If I were to be brutal, I would say he can only lose face or lose his power and life.''
What shape might a compromise take?
Mr. Hussein's overall goal, most diplomats agree, is dominance of the Persian Gulf through military strength and control of oil pricing. There is no disposition whatever among the United States and its partners to grant him anything as part of a deal that would put him closer to those aims.
But by his own accounts and those of more disinterested parties, such as Henry M. Schuler of the Center for Strategic and International Studies, an expert on oil and the Middle East, Mr. Hussein has more limited goals, too: less tenuous access to the Persian Gulf for his tankers, higher oil prices and a larger share of the enormous Rumalia oil field straddling the Kuwait-Iraq border, which can produce up to a million barrels of crude oil a day.
Those might be accommodated, at least in part, in a settlement.
 
Kuwait's Economic Resistance
By raising its output and opposing higher prices in the months before Mr. Hussein's attack, Kuwait made it impossible for Iraq to increase its oil revenues to gain the money needed to rebuild after the long gulf war with Iran. The ''newly assertive, excessively greedy'' Kuwaiti policy, Mr. Schuler said, was designed to deter what Kuwait took as Baghdad's designs on its territory. It had the opposite effect. ''We cannot tolerate this type of economic warfare which is being waged against Iraq,'' Mr. Hussein said in a speech to a closed session of an emergency conference of the Arab League in Baghdad on May 30. ''I say that we have reached a state of affairs where we cannot withstand the pressure.''
Then there is the question of access to the Persian Gulf, which has become an obsession for Iraqis. As a result of the Uqair conference of 1922, at which Britain carved up a remnant of the Ottoman Empire into pieces that became modern Kuwait, Saudi Arabia and Iraq, Iraq alone among the three was denied a satisfactory outlet to the sea. That became an especially galling circumstance when the Shatt al-Arab was closed to tankers by the gulf war between Iraq and Iran.
 
'Needs Ladder to Climb Down'
Iraq's only usable port now is Umm Qasr, at the mouth of a subsidiary channel of the Shatt al-Arab which the Iraqis have been dredging. Berths and other port facilities at Umm Qasr have been expanded. But ships must take one of two paths around Bubiyan Island, which is in Kuwait territory, to reach the gulf from Umm Qasr.
Another element of a compromise might therefore be a long-term lease of Bubiyan Island, which Baghdad had been seeking before the invasion.
Israeli officials see real significance in the fact that when Iraq declared most of Kuwait a new Iraqi province last month, it did not include Bubiyan and Warba, a smaller, less strategic island. They were declared part of Basra province, and a senior Israeli military officer said that might mean Mr. Hussein intended to try to keep them while yielding Kuwait proper as part of a crisis-ending compromise.
''It is clear to me that Saddam Hussein is flexible and powerful enough that he can pull out of Kuwait, if the alternative is his extinction or anything close to that,'' said Amatzia Bar-Am, an expert on Iraq at Haifa University. ''But he needs a ladder to climb down in order to do that.''

HEADLINE: GULF CRISIS CLOUDS ELECTION OUTLOOK IN U.S. CAMPAIGNS

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1

 BODY:
Taking to the stump this Labor Day weekend for the traditional start of the fall campaigns, politicians are confronted with a terrain in which the two most powerful forces shaping any election, peace and prosperity, could shift from under them like Arabian sands.
It has been a long time, candidates and their aides say, since so many global uncertainties have seemed so likely to shake up the political scene in the 66 days between now and Election Day.
Democrats had hoped this election would be about the sagging economy, the savings and loan scandal, the environment, abortion and education. And they continue to press those issues, as do some Republicans. But domestic concerns, which normally dominate midterm elections, are suddenly being overshadowed by the biggest international crisis in a generation. 
As a result, the issues have shifted back toward foreign policy and national defense, areas of traditional Republican strength, a development that Republicans hope will hold through Election Day and protect them from the losses that the President's party would be expected to suffer in a midterm election.
 
Expectations Upside Down
The Middle East crisis has confounded the expectations around which many campaigns were built. Challengers who thought the anti-politician mood in the land would make this a good year for them are struggling for attention. And candidates in general are finding it hard to keep their political footing and almost impossible to know what the political terrain will look like a few weeks, or even a few days, ahead.
Will there be war in the Persian Gulf? If there is, how will it go? Will the economy continue to deteriorate? Will the budget talks remain stalemated and force politically unpalatable automatic across-the-board budget cuts just weeks before the election?
These are among the major unknowns as candidates fan out in their quest for the 35 Senate seats, 435 House seats, 36 governor's chairs and 6,257 state legislative seats at stake on Nov. 6.
The speed with which outside events have altered the scene can be seen in one of the country's most hotly contested House races, in northwest Oregon. Representative Denny Smith, a Republican, was on the ropes earlier this summer as his Democratic opponent, Mike Kopetski, hammered him for his ties to a failed savings and loan association.
Then on the day that Iraq invaded Kuwait, Mr. Kopetski said the United States should avoid the use of military force and should work through the United Nations to resolve the crisis. Now it is Mr. Smith who is on the offensive, using radio advertisements that begin with Adolf Hitler screaming in German and follow with an announcer who says, ''Mike, appeasement is wrong.'' Mr. Kopetski now has to spend his time emphasizing that he supports President Bush's policy in the gulf.
 
Few Real Contests
But even a major crisis in the Middle East could not change some realities of American politics. The system has become so constricted that the outcome of many races, particularly for Federal office, is already assured. The battle between Mr. Smith and Mr. Kopetski is one of fewer than 50 races in the House and a dozen in the Senate that will be truly contested this fall, as the advantages of office - particularly the ability to raise money - make most incumbents impregnable.
Yet both sides believe a lot is at stake. Republicans would like to make gains in Congress, or at least prevent major losses, so they can make a major run at the Democrats in 1992, when George Bush will be at the top of the ticket and most House members will be running in districts newly drawn in the wake of to the 1990 census. And there is far more national interest than usual in races for state office this year, because governors and legislators elected in November will draw the new Congressional districts.
 
Focus on Redistricting
Republicans see redistricting as their last chance in this century to break the Democratic hold on the House, so they are pouring workers and money into races for governor and state legislature. Democrats are responding in kind to protect their 36-year hold on the House.
Democrats control 29 of the 50 governorships and say they are certain to pick up more on Election Day. But in several crucial races, from Ohio to Florida to California, the governors' contests could go either way.
The race for governor in California, the single biggest prize of this busy election year, is rated a tossup between Dianne Feinstein, the Democrat, and Senator Pete Wilson, the Republican.
While some consultants detect a greater resistance to negative campaigning, this California race demonstrates the continuing nasty quality of American politics. Ms. Feinstein and Mr. Wilson spent most of August trying to tie each other to the savings and loan scandal. What resulted, a recent poll by The Los Angeles Times indicates, was a considerable increase in the disapproval that Californians expressed toward both candidates.
A Wilson adviser, Don Sipple, said the month had been a victory for Mr. Wilson because his negative rating rose less than Ms. Feinstein's.
 
Rise in Campaign Spending
Although many candidates say the fear of economic hard times and the taint of political scandal have made it harder to raise money, the figures show that the amount of money being raised and spent on campaigns is still rising. House and Senate candidates had raised $279 million by the end of June, up 3.3 percent from the same point in 1988, and spent $191.8 million, a 5.8 percent increase, according to the Federal Election Commission.
In many places taxes remain an important issue. Proposals to limit budgets or lower taxes will be on the ballot from Massachusetts to California. So will proposals to raise taxes, as legislators avoid a vote on raising taxes themselves, instead asking the voters.
Frustration with the political system has also bubbled over in ballot proposals to limit the terms that office holders can serve. Two initiatives affecting state office holders are on the ballot in California, and in Colorado voters are being offered a proposal that would limit not only the terms of state legislators, but also those of the state's Congressional delegation. A 12-year limit for state office in Oklahoma is on the primary ballot on Sept. 18.
 
Looking at Military Records
The gulf crisis has already thrown off many a campaign. Candidates who were promising to pay for anything from health programs to tax cuts with the ''peace dividend'' hoped for as a result of the easing of superpower tensions suddenly find the money being spent in the gulf instead.
Other candidates find that the surge in support for the military has made their own military record, or lack of one, more interesting to voters than it might have been a few years ago. For example, Representative Roy Dyson, a five-term Democrat from southern Maryland and a strong supporter of the military, found himself under siege this week when it was disclosed that he had been a conscientious objector during the Vietnam War.
Such an emphasis on military records has implications for national politicians as otherwise different as Vice President Dan Quayle, who avoided Vietnam by serving in the National Guard, and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York, who had student deferments during the Korean War.
An expert on Congressional races, Prof. Michael S. Lewis-Beck of the University of Iowa, said basic forces, like the state of the economy and the standing of the President, were a better guide to the outcome of the fall campaigns than shifting events. Based on that, he and a colleague, Tom Rice, predict that the Republicans will lose 18 seats in the House and 3 in the Senate.
A month ago many Republicans shared that pessimism. But the gulf crisis changed that. ''If we were sitting here today debating the economy, or debating the S.& L. crisis and debating abortion,'' said Edward Rollins, co-chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee, ''I'd say these are not exactly the three campaign issues I want to run on.''
A New York Times/CBS News Poll in mid-August showed that the gulf situation had helped divert some Americans' attention from issues on which the Republicans are vulnerable, like the economy, to issues of foreign policy and defense, where the Republicans are stronger.
More than one out of every five Americans in the poll said the gulf crisis was the most important issue facing the country, and those were also considerably more likely to say that Republicans were better at handling the issue. Correspondingly, those who picked the economy as the most important issue tended to favor Democrats to handle it better.
Frank Greer, a Democratic consultant to several candidates for senator and governor, said public interest in Middle East would wane if the stalemate there continued, allowing domestic issues to return to the fore by Election Day.
In the meantime, he said, Democrats are not helpless. Paul Hubbert, the party's candidate for governor in Alabama, gets his biggest applause, Mr. Greer said, when he calls on President Bush and the Republicans to crack down on price gouging by the oil companies.
''This is a governor's race in Alabama,'' Mr. Greer said. ''People feel Republicans are more on the side of oil companies.''

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1, Page 1, Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1528 words

HEADLINE: Redone Ellis Island: Burnished but Not Brash

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY

 BODY:
When the newly repaired Statue of Liberty was unveiled in 1986, the accompanying Liberty Weekend celebration became an apotheosis of the 1980's, a four-day, multimillion-dollar extravaganza of fireworks, patriotic kitsch and corporate boosterism.
Now, as its sister landmark, Ellis Island, much of which has been restored and finely burnished as the Museum of Immigration, is readied to receive the public on Sept. 10, the mood is distinctly more subdued.
Ellis Island, the harrowing gateway for millions of terrified but hopeful refugees, more than any other place has come to symbolize the definitive American experience, immigration. From 1892 to 1924, 12 million people sought entry on its barren shores.
 
Honoring All Immigrants
But the museum itself honors all American immigrants, whether they came here freely or as slaves. It is a more complex and somber landmark than the Statue of Liberty. The sober, unflamboyant way in which it will be unveiled is also a testimony to the times. 
This time the ceremony will not include 850 drill team girls, 5,000 homing pigeons or a single Elvis Presley impersonator.
The refurbished immigration building, a grand Beaux-Arts palace of turrets and vaulted ceilings that was designed more to awe than reassure, takes up seven acres of the island. Nearby, there is an Art Deco ferry terminal, built as a Works Progress Administration project in the 1930's. It provided work during the Depression, but was rarely used.
The remaining 20 acres are dotted with 19th-century buildings that once served as hospital wards, baggage rooms or dormitories. The Statue of Liberty-Ellis Island Foundation, a private association responsible for financing and supervising the restorations, had initially envisioned turning the southern part of the island into a grandiose historical amusement park, an immigration theme park that critics quickly called an ''ethnic Disneyland.''
Instead, the National Park Service, which manages Ellis Island, decided to lease those buildings to a real-estate developer who would begin restoring them in 1990 as part of a $100 million world conference center. So far, the developer, William Hubbard, director of the Center for Housing Partnerships, has been unable to nail down investors.
 
Limits on Corporate Largess
A long-planned genealogical tracing center for the island, a computerized archive of all Ellis Island immigrants, remains unfinanced, a testimony to new limits on corporate largess.
Scattered across the landscape of Ellis Island are other, more lasting signs of a newly troubled economic climate.
Near the beautifully reconstructed $156 million registration hall that houses the museum are unrestored, dilapidated buildings that await development, a tribute to New York's stagnant real-estate market.
A black-tie benefit dinner for patrons will be held on Sept. 8, to raise money for the dedication the next day. That ceremony will be solemn, reverent and studiously short on extravagance.
 
No Glitz This Time
''It's going to be a dignified, tasteful ceremony, nothing glitzy or splashy,'' said Donald Mischer, an award-winning producer of television variety specials, who will provide the entertainment for the dinner and the dedication.
''In 1986 we were in a great patriotic surge,'' said Stephen Briganti, president of the foundation. ''Now the economy is not as good, and there are serious problems in the world, like Iraq.''
''We wanted something serious for Ellis Island,'' Mr. Briganti said, ''something more cerebral.''
The Liberty Weekend celebration, which was paid for from money raised for the restoration, ran $10 million over budget. Mr. Briganti said that the pared-down 1990 event would cost ''a fraction'' of Liberty Weekend, but declined to specify how much.
The Ellis Island Restoration Commission has been developing a high-tech Family History Center that would enable visitors to enter their names in a computer and trace their ancestors through Ellis Island. So far, the sponsors have collected biographical data on 17 million immigrants, but have been unable to raise the $14 million the project would require.
 
Costs Dampen Enthusiasm
''When you talk to companies, they all love the idea,'' Stephen Fenton, an advertising executive and commission member, said, ''until you tell them the cost.''
And few of the corporations that sponsored the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island restoration, paying $3 million to $5 million in exchange for promotional opportunities, have elected to use Ellis Island in product advertising.
''The big hitters did not see a way to get involved with Ellis Island,'' said Lee A. Iacocca, the chairman of Chrysler, who headed the restoration fund-raising effort. ''The statue is an icon, a world symbol. Ellis Island is a much tougher sell.''
In 1984, in what was considered a landmark of private-sector initiative -and marketing-driven philanthropy -the restoration was mostly financed by corporations. Mr. Iacocca, energetic, brash and, at the time, impervious to critics' charges that he had commercialized the Statue of Liberty, raised more than $300 million by selling 21 corporations extensive tie-ins for their products.
 
'Other Priorities This Year'
A.T.& T., which did not get involved with the Statue of Liberty events in the 1980's, became an Ellis Island sponsor and is currently using Ellis Island as a theme in its long-distance telephone advertising. But most of the corporations that bought the right to use the Statue of Liberty-Ellis Island logo for advertising in 1984 are not taking advantage of it this time around.
''We have other priorities this year; it's just not in the budget for a major promotional campaign around Ellis Island,'' explained John Barr, director of marketing for the Eastman Kodak Company.
''The statue was like the flag or Uncle Sam, an identifiable symbol that companies could make use of in a positive, bombastic way,'' said Carol Connell, public affairs director for Joseph E. Seagram & Sons. ''There is nothing bombastic about Ellis Island. It hasn't got the same hoopla.''
Stephen A. Greyser, a professor of marketing at Harvard Business School, said: ''Companies have less money; their advertising budgets are squeezed. Events like this are a fringe or luxury activity and are not on the budget list.''
 
Mixed Reviews of 1986 Hoopla
Also, memories of the manner and extent to which companies marketed the Statue of Liberty - there were Statue of Liberty air fresheners and swizzle sticks - remain mixed.
''It was rather difficult last time,'' said a spokesman for a major corporate sponsor who spoke on the condiditon of anonymity, and whose company has refrained from developing an Ellis Island promotional campaign. ''There was a great deal of negative publicity about the selling the statue. I can't imagine many companies were impressed with the reception they got as sponsors.''
This time, corporations that have contributed from $3 million to $5 million are choosing to soft-sell their participation.
Eastman Kodak, for example, underwrote the Augustus Sherman Gallery, a collection of photographs taken by an Ellis Island clerk in the 1890's. The company's donation is quietly acknowledged in a plaque.
 
It's the Public's Turn
''I got chastized for allowing Coca-Cola and U.S. Tobacco to 'desecrate' the statue,'' Mr. Iacocca said of his 1986 marketing blitz. ''We didn't push it too hard this time. Why commercialize? We don't need any more money.'' He was referring to the foundation's restoration projects.
When the foundation did, in fact, decide that it needed additional money to create an endowment to help cover the National Park Service's maintenance costs, it turned not to corporations, but to the public, with a scheme called the Ellis Island Wall of Honor.
Donors sent contributions of $100 to $10,000 to have their ancestors' names, regardless of whether they came through Ellis Island, written on copper plaques placed on top of the sea wall that surrounds the museum.
''I saw my name in bronze on the Statue of Liberty,'' Mr. Iacocca said, explaining the origin of the idea, ''And I thought thousands of other people would also like to have their names up there.''
Almost 200,000 people sent in checks, ranging from Barbara Bush, who paid $100 to commemorate one of her ancestors, Thomas Thayer, who emigrated from England in 1630, to a Washington restaurateur, Duke Zeibert, who paid $10,000 to have his Polish emigre parents' names inscribed on the wall. The foundation raised $20 million by selling donors the opportunity to have their family names inscribed on the Wall of Honor, and is building a second wall to accommodate continuing demand.
The Wall of Honor is the one departure from Ellis Island's rigorously accurate historical restoration, one that the National Park Service agreed to, warily.
''Maybe we wouldn't have done that wall, there are a lot of purists in the Park Service,'' said Herbert Cables, deputy director of the National Park Service. ''But the foundation raised $300 million, and we owe a great deal to that process. We are in no position to second guess.''

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: September 2, 1990

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1, Page 1, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1892 words

HEADLINE: Who Decides Who Works At Jobs Imperiling Fetuses?

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BENNINGTON, Vt., Sept. 1

 BODY:
The unobtrusive factory, tucked behind a hillside shopping center in this little college town, runs all day and all night seven days a week. The 280 production workers make lead automobile batteries for Sears, Goodyear and other big customers. Only 12 workers are women, and none of them can have children. The company won't hire any who can.
The air inside this plant, and at 15 others owned by Johnson Controls Inc. of Milwaukee, is laced with tiny particles of lead and lead oxide, indisputably toxic substances. The company says the levels of lead are low enough for adults but excessive for children and fetuses.
The only female production workers employed by Johnson, the nation's leading maker of automobile batteries, are those like Virginia Green, who are too old to become pregnant, or those like Cheryl Chalifoux and Cheryl Cook, who have had surgery to see that they do not become pregnant. The company makes no exceptions for women who abstain from sex or use contraception. ''The issue is protecting the health of unborn children,'' a company statement says. 
 
Alarms Are Raised
Johnson's policy, in effect for eight years, has begun to arouse working women's advocates in much the way the abortion debate has. A few other companies, including General Motors, have adopted the practice, and the advocates fear that more will cite other potential causes of miscarriage and fetal injury, like heavy lifting and exposure to other substances, in excluding women from the workplace.
In one of the major cases facing the United States Supreme Court this year, it has agreed to hear an appeal in October from the United Automobile Workers, which represents many of Johnson's employees. The union contends that the policy violates the 1964 Civil Rights Act barring workplace discrimination against women and minorities, and jeopardizes women's hard-won gains in male-dominated industries.
The union argues that the lead in the plants is also dangerous for men, although evidence of its effect on male reproductive organs is scant and inconclusive. So men can apply for the jobs, which are among the best-paying in a small town like Bennington, while most working-age women are excluded.
 
Company Denies Bias
The company says it is not biased against women, and it denies allegations that its policy means it does not trust women. ''You can't turn aside our concern for a child's health,'' said Denise M. Zutz, spokeswoman for the company. ''That's at the center of our position. At the same time, we have a legitimate position in protecting our shareholders' interest.''
The workers maintain that the lead in the plant is excessive for everyone, and that the company could do more to make it safer for everyone.
''We wish we knew of a way to do that,'' Ms. Zutz said. In the company's view, there is no economically feasible way to reduce the lead levels significantly. Johnson Controls, citing concerns about competition, declined to let reporters look inside the plant here or talk to its management.
The company spokeswoman said Johnson sees the issue as both a humanitarian concern, protecting fetuses, and an economic one, avoiding both the costly protective measures that would reduce lead exposure and the risk of lawsuits if any babies are born damaged.
 
Privacy Issue Is Raised
But many women's advocates see the issue in different terms. They say the debate in a way is even more basic than the debate over abortion rights, since it calls into question not only a woman's control of her fetus but also her control of her unfertilized eggs.
They say the policy also raises a question of privacy, in that by taking a job at Johnson a woman in effect lets the world know she is sterile, and that it raises the question of who knows what is best for a woman.
''It doesn't matter what I do in there,'' said Ms. Chalifoux, the 31-year-old single mother of two young children, who left a factory job here paying a maximum of $6.34 an hour to work for Johnson Controls for up to $15 an hour. ''I can't have children.'' Ms. Chalifoux had a doctor block the two Fallopian tubes, which carry eggs to the uterus, so she would have no more children.
She did not make that decision in order to get the job, but she can now reap the economic benefits of her decision.
Still, she said, the policy is unfair and degrading. ''It's your body,'' she said. ''They're implying they're doing it for your own good.''
 
'They Don't Trust You'
Ms. Cook, 34, a married mother of two, had surgery for the same reasons and joined Ms. Chalifoux in leaving the other company to go to Johnson Controls. ''I work right in the lead,'' she said. ''I make the oxide. But you should choose for yourself. Myself, I wouldn't go in there if I could get pregnant. But they don't trust you.''
In 1982, when Johnson Controls adopted the fetal protection policy, Ms. Green moved from her job stacking lead plates for batteries to a job in the company laundry, where lead levels are low. She was 50 then, the mother of a 10-year-old daughter, and still able to have children.
''They called me into the office and told me I couldn't be on my job any more because I was fertile,'' Ms. Green said. ''I feel that's your own business. They didn't say, Sorry; they just told me I was moving.''
 
Says Opportunities Were Lost
Management has continued to pay her plate-stacker wages, not a laundry worker's lower wage. But she says she has lost opportunities to do other jobs, although she is infertile now. The plant runs on three shifts - 7 A.M. to 3:30 P.M., 3 P.M. to 11:30 P.M., and 11 P.M. to 7:30 A.M. - and she said she has lost her claim on the first shift.
''Since time immemorial,'' said Isabelle Katz Pinzler, director of women's rights at the American Civil Liberties Unnion, ''the excuse for keeping women in their place has been because of their role in producing the next generation. The attitude of Johnson Controls is: 'We know better than you. We can't allow women to make this decision. We have to make it for them.' ''
Ms. Pinzler said no one had yet found an indisputable case of a lead-damaged child born to a lead worker. But occupational health experts say there is no doubt that a child could suffer birth defects because of his mother's exposure to lead.
But the company says it has a moral obligation to the parties that cannot participate in the woman's decision: the unfertilized ovum and the fetus. It says it also has a financial obligation to stockholders, who would bear the brunt of suits brought by employees' children born with retardation or nervous system disorders and other health effects that lead can cause.
 
Arguments Set Oct. 10
The Supreme Court has agreed to hear arguments about the policy on Oct. 10. The U.A.W. seeks a reversal of a 7-to-4 decision last October by the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, in Chicago. That court acknowledged the burden the company places on women, but it agreed with the company that the policy was a ''business necessity'' allowed under the civil rights law.
For the implications of the decision, women's groups cite the opinion of a dissenter on the Chicago court, Judge Frank H. Easterbrook, who was appointed by President Ronald Reagan. Judge Easterbrook called the case ''likely the most important'' involving sex discrimination since enactment of the civil rights law. ''If the majority is right,'' he wrote, ''then by one estimate, 20 million industrial jobs could be closed to women, for many substances in addition to lead pose fetal risks.''
In explaining Johnson Controls' decision not to let reporters inside, Ms. Zutz said making batteries was a competitive business and a visitor could learn something about the production of the company's batteries and pass it on to another maker. But union leaders and employees here said the company worried that someone might observe cases of lead contamination that exceeded even those allowable for adults.
Mark Santelli, the president of the U.A.W. local, said conditions were ''110 percent better'' than they were a decade ago. The company has provided respirators to about 75 workers, all with lead in the blood approaching magnitudes deemed unsafe. It provides workers with uniforms, pays them to take showers before leaving by counting shower time as work time and has installed an elaborate vacuuming system that changes the plant's air 100 times an hour, blowing in fresh air from the roof and sucking it out through grates on the floor.
Even so, Mr. Santelli said, lead particles waft through the plant, getting into clothing and settling as a fine dust on the machinery. And on occasion the vacuuming system backfires. He said the leaded dust sucked out of the plant was collected in bags, but sometimes the dampers malfunctioned and the dust was blown back into the plant.
 
From Metal to Paste
Ms. Cook runs the ball mill, a two-story-tall tumbling machine that makes the lead oxide, which is transported from the mill to a mixing tower, where the oxide is formed into a paste. The paste is then compressed to make the lead plates that become the core of the batteries.
Ingots of lead, about two feet long and four inches thick, are put into the tumbler. With heat and oxygen, the ingots are spun around and around, until they turn to dust.
Appparently because of her exposure to the lead, the company gave her a special helmet, one that blows fresh air over her nose and mouth. ''They said I had to wear it,'' she recalled. ''So I wore it and then they said this other guy needed it. All of a sudden they decided I didn't need it any more.''
Some people are more susceptible to lead contamination of the blood than others, said Joanne Leard, the union's health and safety monitor at the plant. She said Ms. Cook was among the more susceptible. As a relatively new employee, Ms. Cook is laid off when business slows in December and rehired in May, when it resumes. By the time Ms. Cook leaves on layoff, Ms. Leard said, the lead in her blood is close to the maximum allowable level and then recedes while she is out of work.
 
Five Months With pay
Men are affected in the same way, Ms. Leard said. About two years ago, a 25-year employee of the plant had to be sent home for five months at full pay, as required by law, to let the lead in his blood recede.
''He came back to work when it was down, but it's back up again even though he works in a low-lead area,'' she said. ''He now has dizziness, aches in his joints and constipation.''
''They're so concerned about protecting the female,'' Ms. Leard said. ''They should protect the men as well.'' Some people think the real issue ought to be occupational safety, not sex discrimination. The Occupational Safety and Health Administration says it has no plans to reduce its 12-year-old maximums for lead.
In the Supreme Court case, Joseph A. Kinney, executive director of the National Safe Workplace Institute in Chicago, has filed a brief on behalf of Johnson Controls, but he said that was only because letting women assume the burden of their safety undermined OSHA's responsibility in mandating safety.
''The discrimination side of the issue needs to be resolved,'' Mr. Kinney said. ''But the ideal thing is to regulate lead out of the workplace and any other toxin that poses fetal damage.''

HEADLINE: Gas Lines Form in Poland to Beat Rising Price

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WARSAW, Sept. 1

 BODY:
While Poland's elite gathered this week in Gdansk to celebrate Solidarity's glorious past, the nation's drivers were treated to an uneasy glimpse of what may become this country's future: gas lines.
Poland imports all its oil from the Soviet Union and Middle East and the queues began snaking around the gas stations immediately after the Government said on Thursday that prices would go up 33 percent beginning today. The announcement caused throngs of Poles to line up for one last tankful at the old price.
The lines lessened on Saturday. But senior Government officials say they may well return this fall if Poland is unable to make up a shortfall caused both by a cutback in shipments from the Soviet Union and the loss of oil from Iraq. 
Jan Nowokowski, a purchasing official at the state-run Ciech company, on Friday confirmed reports in the Polish press that the country has only a two to three weeks' supply of oil on hand. Mr. Nowokowski said he was now trying to buy oil from Britain and Iran. He appealed to the United States to persuade Saudia Arabia to change its policy and sell oil to Poland. ''Things are getting worse rather than better,'' Andrzej Porebiak said as he waited his turn at a station in the outskirts of Warsaw. ''Maybe they should change some ministers. The people at the top don't think about what it's like out here.''
 
Political Effects Pondered
Sentiments like that worry senior officials in the Government of Tadeusz Mazowiecki who fear that the mixture of higher gas prices - and possibly tight supplies - may prove politically volatile this fall. No date has been set for national elections, but they are widely expected within months. Mr. Mazowiecki and his Government have appeared to be increasingly vulnerable to criticism by Lech Walesa, the Solidarity chairman and undeclared candidate for President whose political appeal is based on the premise that the people ''on the top'' are out of touch with the workers.
That suggestion is likely to be reinforced by the Government's handling of the price increases. Rumors had begun to circulate about a week ago, but the announcement was made Thursday on the eve of the Polish equivalent of Labor Day weekend. School opens on Monday here, and families returning from the seaside and mountains were fighting the traffic jams brought on by the gas lines.
The rise in gasoline prices, officials here said, was caused both by the loss of 750,000 tons of Iraqi oil and the continuing effect of a shortfall in Soviet deliveries, which were 20 percent behind what had been contracted. Poland had hoped to buy 12 million of its 14 million tons of oil this year from Moscow but, as in other Eastern European countries, problems in the Soviet oil industry have caused this year's deliveries to fall well below what was expected.
All this made Poland's decision to join the economic boycott of Iraq a complicated one, particularly in view of the Government's precarious public standing. ''We had no doubt we had to do it,'' one senior Polish official said last month of the sanctions. ''But it was extremely complicated for us. In our economic and political situation, to have in a few weeks a gasoline shortage is extremely hard and could have some real consequences.'' As the lines blocked traffic across the country Friday, most of the Government gathered in the city of Gdansk to mark the 10th anniversary of the Aug. 31, 1980, agreement that ended a strike at the shipyard and began Solidarity's 16 months as a free trade union.
In two days of celebrations in Gdansk, Mr. Walesa and Mr. Mazowiecki traded salvos over whether the Government was doing enough to encourage broad political participation. Neither declared his presidential candidacy, but there were hints from both sides signaling the end of the ''cucumber season,'' the Polish idiom for the dog days of August.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Gorbachev Steps Into the Gulf Lineup

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 1

 BODY:
In the briefest possible announcement, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev informed the Soviet nation tonight that he had elected to become a far more visible world player in the critical standoff over Iraq's invasion and seizure of Kuwait.
The announcement, a single sentence at the beginning of the national television news show, Vremya, was a simple mention that President Bush and President Gorbachev ''are due to meet in Helsinki on Sunday, September 9, to discuss international and bilateral issues.''
No elaboration was offered and no reference was made to Iraq. But the sudden summit announcement made the chief topic clear, coming only a day after Mr. Gorbachev stressed his own concern that ''the building up of military confrontation might lead to unpredictable consequences'' in the tense Persian Gulf. 
 
Chance to Explain U.S. Buildup
The meeting in Helsinki, the Finnish capital, marks a further step in the evolution of closer, more peaceful relations between the erstwhile cold war rivals, with the two national leaders concentrating world attention on an imminent crisis about which they have expressed basic agreement.
Beyond that, the meeting will afford Mr. Bush an opportunity to respond to some Soviet misgivings of late over the White House's precise military intention in packing large numbers of troops into Saudi Arabia.
After three weeks of quietly tolerating the American buildup, Soviet officials began questioning the nature of the United States military strategy this week. In comments before a parliamentary committee, Deputy Foreign Minister Aleksandr Belonogov declared that there were ''no guarantees that the United States will leave Saudi Arabia after the crisis is over.''
Mr. Belonogov, who has been a principal in Moscow's collaboration with the West in opposing the Kuwait invasion, noted that the Soviet Union had never approved the deployment of American troops in Saudi Arabia and that the situation was becoming ''more and more explosive.''
 
Mediation, Not Force
But Mr. Gorbachev himself diplomatically took some of the edge off that criticism in remarks Friday at a news conference. The Soviet leader again strongly condemned the Iraqi annexation of Kuwait and echoed the Kremlin's position of a month ago when a joint Soviet-American statement was issued demanding that Iraq roll back its annexation of Kuwait.
While repeatedly stressing the need for political mediation, not force, in the gulf crisis, Mr. Gorbachev said the United States military presence was at the invitation of the Saudis and in conformance with the United Nations charter. He rejected a news correspondent's suggestion that policy differences might be arising between the Kremlin and the White House as the buildup grows.
''We all have to be very responsible so that military conflict will not break out,'' he declared. ''This is our mutual concern,'' he said of the United States. ''If you think it shows a difference in policy, I think it shows cooperation.''
The presence of Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev standing together in reiterating their criticism of the Iraqi attack will provide a graphic new factor in the attempt to exert world moral pressure and force President Saddam Hussein to withdraw his troops from Kuwait.
 
Boon for Global Solidarity
As much as the meeting is an obvious boon to Mr. Bush in his campaign to demonstrate global solidarity against Iraq, it will also allow Mr. Gorbachev to remind his own troubled people, so distracted by economic woes, that Soviet prestige remains an important factor in world affairs.
In speaking of the Kuwait crisis on Friday, Mr. Gorbachev again supported sanctions against Iraq, but he stressed the view that only political efforts, not military force, would produce success. He urged all parties to double their political efforts at ''not allowing the conflict to reach a dangerous phase.'' In particular, the Soviet leader said the political role of Arab nations should be used more.
''We should try to find keys to a peaceful settlement of this acute international conflict through using the Arab factor,'' he said.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Saudi Minister Says U.S. Force Is Only Defensive

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DHAHRAN, Saudi Arabia, Sept. 1

 BODY:
Saudi Arabia's Defense Minister said today that his country could not be used as a staging ground by the American military for rescuing hostages under Iraqi control or for beginning offensive attacks against Iraq.
''The Kingdom of Saudi Arabia is not a theater for any action that is not defensive for Saudi Arabia,'' the Defense Minister, Prince Sultan, said. He said the large American military force here could be used only to defend Saudi Arabia. 
Prince Sultan's comment came in response to a question at a news conference here at which he also complained that news reports about possible military action against Iraq were ''escalating the situation.''
The Defense Minister's comments were the most explicit recent statement by Saudi officials about the role that American forces are to play here.
 
The U.S. View
While President Bush has said that American forces are being sent to Saudi Arabia for defensive purposes, he has also bluntly warned Iraq that he is holding Baghdad responsible for the safety of American hostages under Iraqi control and has stressed that Iraqi troops must leave Kuwait.
Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, the commander of American forces in the region, told reporters on Friday that there would not be a war unless Iraq starts one. But at the same time, General Schwarzkopf declined to rule out offensive action against Iraq, saying that he would not answer hypothetical questions.
Lower-ranking American military officers have talked about the possibility of attacks on Iraqi forces in Kuwait and Iraq, suggesting the range of options in a debate over whether Washington should take military action to force Iraqi troops out of Kuwait and topple President Saddam Hussein, or wait for months to see whether economic sanctions work.
 
Senators Divided on Timetable
The debate was reflected in a visit today by 14 United States Senators to American troops here. David Durenberger, Republican of Minnesota, told a marine that the standoff will not go on indefinitely.
He said the United States will take stronger action if necessary ''in another month or so,'' adding that ''there is a limit to the expectations a lot of people have about how long American forces can stay in this part of the world.''
But Senator Carl Levin, Democrat of Michigan, took a contrary view. ''I think it is best that we not set a timetable,'' Mr. Levin said, adding, ''We have to get ready psychologically and militarily here and at home for our being here a long time.''
Paul S. Sarbanes, Democrat of Maryland, said, ''It is obvious that the President's strategy will take some time because the economic impact of the embargo has to bite on Iraq.''
 
Support for Arms to Saudis
About half of the Senators here had opposed arms sales to Saudi Arabia in the past. But today some said they would support new arms sales to Saudi Arabia. ''I was the leader of the opposition, but not anymore,'' said Alan Cranston, Democrat of California. ''Now they are allied with us. They are sitting on the front lines. They will take the first casualties.''
''Obviously, we will be a lot more receptive than I was previously'' to a Saudi arms package, said Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York.

(Photographs by Reuters)

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
A Month of Crisis in the Persian Gulf

 BODY:
Aug. 2 Iraq invades Kuwait hours after talks broke down between the two nations over oil production and debt repayment. Iraqi troops seize vast petroleum reserves and Kuwait's capital, plunging the Persian Gulf region into crisis. Witnesses report hundreds of casualties. The Kuwaiti ruler flees. President Bush calls the invasion ''naked aggression.'' The United Nations Security Council votes overwhelmingly to condemn it and demand the Iraqis' immediate and total withdrawal.
Aug. 3 Iraqis move into position for a possible attack on Saudi Arabia. Baghdad announces that its troops will begin withdrawing Aug. 5 unless the security of Iraq or of occupied Kuwait is threatened. 
Aug. 4 The Iraqi occupiers fortify positions in Kuwait. The 12 nations of the European Community impose an immediate embargo on oil imports from Iraq and Kuwait. Hasty plans for an Arab summit meeting fall apart.
Aug. 5 Mr. Bush, all but committing himself to use military force against the Iraqis if necessary, says their assault ''will not stand.'' Their withdrawal, he says, is the only acceptable outcome.
Aug. 6 The United Nations Security Council orders a sweeping trade and financial boycott on Iraq and occupied Kuwait.
Aug. 7 The United States says Iraqi forces, having overrun Kuwait, pose an imminent threat to Saudi Arabia. Washington orders American armor, jet fighters and paratroopers to the Saudi kingdom.
Aug. 8 Thousands of American troops are deployed on Saudi soil, which Mr. Bush vows to protect.
Aug. 9 United States and allied naval forces in the Red Sea, Indian Ocean, Mediterranean Sea and Persian Gulf will soon begin enforcing a blockade on Iraqi trade, Bush Administration officials say.
Aug. 10 The Arab League votes to send troops to Saudi Arabia. Of the league's members, only Libya and the Palestine Liberation Organization openly back the Iraqis as this watershed decision is reached.
Aug. 11 Egyptian and Moroccan troops begin to land in Saudi Arabia. Mr. Bush makes it clear that he will be pleased if the Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein, is overthrown.
Aug. 12 Mr. Bush orders American forces to block Iraqi oil exports and all imports to Iraq except some food shipments, Administration officials say.
Aug. 14 Pentagon officials disclose that the United States has deployed more than 20,000 troops in Saudi Arabia. The Administration is considering the partial mobilization of reserve forces to help deter an Iraqi attack there.
Aug. 15 Baghdad offers to meet almost all of Iran's terms for resolving key issues left from their eight-year war. The step is meant to counter Iraq's growing isolation.
Aug. 16 Mr. Bush and King Hussein of Jordan meet for two hours at Kennebunkport, Me., but fail to make progress toward easing the crisis.
Aug. 17 Administration officials say the President has decided to call up a limited number of reservists. The Pentagon commandeers commercial jetliners to carry cargo and troops to the gulf region.
Aug. 18 Saudi Arabia serves notice that it will raise its oil production by two million barrels a day with or without the support of other members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. This would equal half the oil kept off the world market by the embargo.
Aug. 19 President Hussein says he will free foreigners being held hostage in Iraq and Kuwait in return for a complete military and political pullout by the United States from the gulf region.
Aug. 20 Iraq begins moving Americans and other non-Iraqis to industrial and military sites for use as human shields against attack. Mr. Bush, for the first time, says the people trapped in Iraq are hostages. He says America will not be intimidated.
Aug. 21 United States naval vessels that are shadowing two loaded Iraqi oil tankers, bound for Yemen, hold in abeyance a threat to halt the vessels forcibly after Yemen declares that it will not unload them.
Aug. 22 The United States announces that along with other countries, it is defying Iraqi orders to close its embassy in Kuwait by Aug. 24. Mr. Bush moves to put thousands of American reservists on active duty.
Aug. 23 Iraq warns the United States and other nations that if they try to keep their embassies open in Kuwait, the Iraqi Government will see that as ''an act of aggression.''
Aug. 24 President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union warns Iraq that he is prepared to back further measures to tighten the embargo against its commerce. This is a long step forward in isolating Iraq.
Aug. 25 By a vote of 13 to 0, with 2 abstentions, the Security Council adopts a resolution that gives the United States and other nations the right to enforce the embargo by stopping vessels under way to or from Iraq.
Aug. 27 American officials say Iraq has reversed its orders to its merchant vessels and has told them not to offer resistance if United States or other naval forces, in carrying out the blockade, try to board the ships to inspect them.
Aug. 28 President Hussein announces that he will permit all foreign women and children to leave Iraq; he had earlier barred their departure. Mr. Bush obtains overwhelming support from over 170 members of Congress whom he briefs on the crisis.
Aug. 29 The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries authorizes its key oil producers immediately to start pumping all the petroleum they can. This forstalls a shortage, fears of which have made oil prices surge upward.
Aug. 30 Mr. Bush says he is requesting aid from other nations - including Saudi Arabia, West Germany and Japan - to help cover the enormous costs of economic sanctions and military operations in the gulf region.
Sept. 1 President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union announce that they will meet in Helsinki on Sept. 9, with the Middle East on the agenda. Iraq allows about 750 hostages to leave.

HEADLINE: U.S. Guidelines Address Meatpacking Injuries

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31

 BODY:
The Labor Department is establishing a test program in the meatpacking industry to protect workers from painful and crippling injuries caused by repetitive motions.
The new guidelines for the industry resulted from negotiations between industry and union representatives, department officials said Thursday. Compliance is voluntary. The Labor Department is not ordering packing companies to adopt the new guidelines, which will be sent to them in the next few days. But if they do not adopt them, department officials said they would fine packers whose workers have a high incidence of repetitive motion ailments. 
Elizabeth Dole, the Secretary of Labor, said the guidelines would emphasize design of the workplace with the physical needs of workers in mind. New approaches might include revised tool designs, improved safety equipment and rotating workers to reduce repetitive work.
The department plans to study the program's effectiveness and use the results to reduce injuries in other occupations, especially those in which computers are used.
Office workers striking the keyboards of video display terminals and supermarket checkers who sweep items over electronic scanners frequently complain of repetitive motion injuries like carpal tunnel syndrome, a nerve disorder of the wrist and hand.
''Repetitive motion injuries, which include lower back injuries, carpal tunnel syndrome and tendon disorders, now comprise 48 percent of all recordable industrial workplace illnesses,'' Mrs. Dole said. ''The economic burden of such injuries to employers and society is enormous.''
According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, 240,900 workplace illnesses were reported in 1988, the last year for which figures are available.
Mrs. Dole said the beef and pork packing industry was chosen because its 140,000 workers suffer from workplace injuries at a rate 10 times the national average. Meatpackers are often required to repeat the same motion as much as 8,000 times an hour, which can cause cysts, swollen tendons and nerve damage.
 
'Real Protection' Demanded
Mrs. Dole said it would take years of study before any enforceable rules could be established.
A spokesman for Howard M. Metzenbaum, the Ohio Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee's Subcommittee on Labor, said the Senator was troubled by the program because it was voluntary and had no enforcement power.
''After 10 years of Administration neglect, American workers deserve real protection,'' Mr. Metzenbaum's spokesman said.
J. Patrick Boyle, president of the American Meat Institute, said the organization had already taken steps to redesign tools and equipment.
Al Zack, a spokesman for the United Food and Commercial Workers International Union, which represents 100,000 meatpackers and helped develop the guidelines, said, ''The guidelines are a positive step forward, but without an honest-to-goodness inspection and enforcement program they are meaningless.''
