HEADLINE: CAMPUS LIFE: U. of Texas at Dallas;
Something Brand New On Campus: Freshmen

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
The University of Texas at Dallas began the 1990-91 school year on Thursday with a major addition to its campus - freshmen.
Now this 20-year-old commuter institution for upper-level and graduate students has a more authentic college flavor, with teen-agers starting off to class, filling the Student Union building and adding daytime activity to a predominantly evening university where the average age of students has been 30.
Under a new curriculum designed earlier this year, the 111 freshmen, most of them 18 years old, will receive a grounding in liberal arts while concentrating on the primary emphases of the university - research, math, science and engineering.
''The concept here is not another University of Texas at Austin or Texas A&M, but rather a Texas-style Massachusetts Institute of Technology,'' Peter O'Donnell, one of the leaders of the program, has said. 
 
'I'm Really Excited'
Before classes began last week, the newcomers completed a two-day orientation program. They toured the campus, 18 miles north of downtown Dallas, learned about university life and were divided into five groups for extensive discussions with faculty members and administrators. They ended with a Texas-style barbecue at the home of the university's president, Robert Rutford.
''I'm really excited about being a part of the first class,'' Leila Grio, a computer science major from Dallas, said. ''I will be a part of everything they do here to set examples for later classes.''
Michael Anshelevich, a math major who recently emigrated from the Soviet Union, said, ''I think U.T.-Dallas is the best place in Dallas and maybe in Texas for me. It is a good place for mathematics study, and I think I will enjoy it and have a good experience.''
The decision to add freshmen and sophomores to the 8,300-student institution came from a coalition of political and civic leaders working with the Texas Legislature.
Thinking that a four-year school was necessary to compete with the nation's leading colleges in math, science and engineering, the Legislature approved the expansion in July 1989. But the university was forbidden from spending money on recruiting until the Texas Education Coordinating Board approved the program in February.
Christopher A. Parr, the dean of undergraduate studies, then sent 12 representatives to 128 schools in all neighboring Texas counties to find candidates for the first freshman class.
''The law was very specific in its limits,'' Mr. Parr said last week. ''Until the expansion was approved, we were prohibited from devoting any resources to recruitment. Since the final approval came very late in the recruiting process, we had to get off the starting block in record time.''
Despite the late start, the freshmen include four valedictorians, four salutatorians and a National Merit finalist. These first-year students have average combined scores of 1125 on the Scholastics Aptitude Tests (out of a possible 1,600 combined score) and have grade-point averages in the top 10 percent of their graduating classes.
 
'More Noise and Energy'
David Schulz, the university's director of news and information, said the university hopes to expand next year's freshman class to 200 and ''ultimately to about a thousand.''
To accommodate the incoming freshmen, school officials have added six faculty members to maintain the student-faculty ratio at 19 to 1. They also added 20,000 volumes to the library and modified existing laboratory space.
The university is in the middle of a $3 million fund-raising drive to pay for the first two years of the freshman class. Texas Instruments is leading the drive by accepting donations from private businesses, with more than $1.7 million already raised and spent by the university.
But the benefits are worth the price, many upperclassmen say. ''I know that they are going to bring that youthful feeling to the campus, and they will bring a bit more noise and energy as well,'' said Pamela Slayton, a senior public-administration major from Dallas.
Kelly Ward, a junior economics major from Dallas, said, ''A lot of times it's kind of dead on campus, but now it's a bit more rowdy and crazy with the freshmen around. We usually have a big crowd during the evening, and now this will add to the day atmosphere.''
President Rutford added: ''This is a rare event in the U.S. to have an institution started by granting Ph.D.'s and sort of downwardly integrate. There are not many places that have ever done that.''

HEADLINE: CAMPUS LIFE: Roosevelt;
Economics Course Beckons Scholars From Eastern Bloc

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
The first two of Roosevelt University's ''Scholars for Freedom'' from Eastern Europe stepped off the plane at O'Hare International Airport last week, ready for a yearlong course in free-market economics.
The scholarship recipients, Laszlo Pribusz of Gyor, Hungary, and Petr Leidl of Kralupy, Czechoslovakia, will take two semesters of courses, and expect to spend next summer as business interns in Chicago. The scholarships are aimed at attracting students from Eastern European countries undergoing economic change. 
Gilbert Ghez, professor of management and economics at Roosevelt, initiated the program last December by persuading the university to provide full tuition, room and board plus spending money to two students from Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, East Germany, Hungary, Poland or Romania. Later, Scandinavian Airlines agreed to pay air fare and Chicago businesses and foundations donated textbooks among other things.
The program's objective, Mr. Ghez said, is to teach students ''the ways of market economies as these economies are under transformation and are seeking to adopt the ways of free markets.''
In the last six to eight months, it has been hard for course offerings in Eastern Europe to keep up with the changes there, Mr. Ghez said. Textbooks are hard to get in sufficient numbers, he said, and professors' knowledge is behind the times.
Mr. Leidl, 21 years old, who has completed three years at the Prague School of Economics, said he wanted to study in the United States because he feared change would not take place at his university before he graduated. Last fall he was a student leader in the uprising in Czechoslovakia, traveling to factories to explain the country's changes to workers who knew little of the events in Prague.
Mr. Pribusz, 24, is a graduate of the Budapest University of Economics, which was known as Karl Marx University until a few months ago. As a student, he started a desktop publishing company, using I.B.M. and Xerox machines, which made books and papers more readily available to the university's students.
Through that experience he said he found that ''very few people have the necessary education to operate a private company'' in Hungary.
Mr. Ghez emphasized that training students like Mr. Pribusz and Mr. Leidl so that they can return home as business leaders could help avoid a brain drain in Eastern Europe as the ablest scholars and business people come to the West.
He may not have to worry. After about an hour in Chicago, Mr. Leidl's thoughts were close to home.
''Prague is the most beautiful city in the world,'' he said, ''and it has the world's greatest beer.''

The students will take two semesters of courses at the school and expect to spend next summer working as business interns in Chicago (Steve Kagan for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Aspiring Jazz Musicians May Soon Have an Alternative to Smoky Cabarets

BYLINE: By PATRICIA STEWART

 BODY:
Since its beginnings nearly a century ago, jazz has often been passed from one generation to the next through a chain of chord progressions, rhythmic patterns and melodic lines delivered in smoky clubs. Within a few years, aspiring young jazz musicians may be able to study their craft in a conservatory in Durham, N.C., devoted exclusively to jazz.
Two years have passed since Durham was selected and more than three since a project was first announced to establish a conservatory dedicated to the high priest of be-bop, the pianist and composer Thelonious Monk, who died in 1982. Attention has now turned to planning a curriculum and raising a $50 million endowment and $12 million for the construction of a campus.
One of the hardworking duos in jazz is Thelonious Monk Jr., the pianist's son and chairman of the Thelonious Monk Institute of Jazz, and Thomas R. Carter, its executive director, whose fund-raising consists partly of one-day stands at government, corporate and foundation offices. 
''We're starting to change the whole concept of the way people present jazz,'' Mr. Monk commented before this year's gala benefit for the institute at Duke University in March, ''by virtue of the fact that I'm standing here and saying the word 'jazz' and the word 'millions' in the same sentence, since we are trying to raise millions for jazz and we are in the process of doing that.
''The academic setting is what's been missing,'' said Mr. Monk, adding that he hoped similar institutes would spring up in coming years. ''The academic setting is what's going to weave jazz into the cultural fiber, so that it is stamped 'Made in America.' ''
 
A Setback
The institute's fund-raising drive had a setback when the North Carolina Legislature in its June session omitted from its budget a $5 million grant, which was to be matched by private donations. Mr. Monk said the state was facing a $500 million deficit and ''we were one of a number of things that had to suffer.''
''It means our focus has shifted a little from public funding to private,'' Mr. Monk said. ''It's a blow, but it has by no means stopped us. It's slowed us down a bit.''
The Monk Institute is affiliated with Duke University and North Carolina Central University, and students will earn a Bachelor of Arts degree in jazz performance under a program certified by the National Association of Schools of Music. The institute has attracted a range of jazz players to an academic council headed by the trumpeter Clark Terry, and a broad spectrum of prominent toe tappers. Bill Cosby is the honorary chairman of a board, appointed this year, that includes Mr. Terry, Clint Eastwood, Martin Luther King 3d, George Butler of CBS Records, and Maria Fisher, president of the Beethoven Society.
The site for the institute has been acquired in downtown Durham, and a design competition has been conducted among fifth-year architecture students at Howard University.
And while the campus for the institute is still on the drafting table, two of its programs are well under way. The first stages of an international exchange program took American and European students and musicians last summer to Dolo, Italy, a small city near Venice that has named its music school for Thelonious Monk. And an international jazz piano competition aimed at finding new talent has been held in Washington for the last three years under the auspices of the Smithsonian Institution. Three participants have signed recording contracts.
The competition has been judged by some of jazz's finest pianists, including Hank Jones, Roger Kellaway, Ahmad Jamal and Horace Silver, and two closely linked with Monk - Barry Harris and Tommy Flanagan. Mr. Harris is also a leading figure in jazz education and a member of the institute's academic council.
Mr. Terry and others at the institute are now planning the Louis Armstrong Trumpet Competition, which will replace the piano competition in November.
 
Several Pilot Programs
A series of pilot programs will be conducted in the coming school year at the Street Academy High School, an alternative school in the old Boys' High School building in Bedford-Stuyvesant, and at schools in North Carolina and possibly Los Angeles.
For those on the academic council of the institute, one consideration is how to plan a jazz curriculum when one of the role models is Beethoven. The idea for the institute came largely from Mrs. Fisher of the Beethoven Society, when approached by members of the Monk family for her thoughts on a permanent memorial. At Monk's funeral, the jazz historian Ira Gitler noted the comparison that is made between Monk and Beethoven, each a maverick in his time.
''I thought, well, would it be a good idea to honor America's traditional music,'' recalled Mrs. Fisher, who is 86 years old, at the gala in Durham. ''And I inquired around and I said, has ever a classical organization honored the classical music of America, and they said no, and I thought, well why don't I do it?''
One member of the academic council already in Durham is Paul Jeffrey, the tenor sax player in Monk's band in the 1970's. Mr. Jeffrey is artist in residence at Duke, teaching jazz history and ensemble, and he expresses frustration with the number of colleges and universities with a jazz faculty of one. ''They wouldn't teach European classical music this way,'' he said.
''We envision having whole groups coming in,'' he said of the Monk Institute. ''Take the Count Basie band off the road and put them in residence for a month.''
 
Good Foundation
Mr. Jeffrey said he believes a good music education can be especially important for jazz musicians, who perform their own compositions instantaneously when improvising a solo, because ''there's no eraser.''
While the past produced the likes of Louis Armstrong, Duke Ellington, Count Basie, Charlie Parker and Thelonious Monk, Mr. Jeffrey said he thinks the eras in which they played would nevertheless have benefited from some of the changes he hopes to help bring about. ''I think the music somewhat was compromised - the lack of documentation, the lack of even adequate places for the musicians to play. I think a lot of people still think that the musicians have to be in some dive, breathing smoke.''
Mr. Harris said in New York that documentation of the music would be one concern of the institute. ''For one thing, we're going to have in our library all of Monk's tunes transcribed.''
The most important thing for the students is an emphasis on ''the ABC's of music,'' said Mr. Harris, who directed the Jazz Cultural Theater in New York from 1982 to 1987, teaching children as young as 5. ''You don't walk around talking about 'A, B, what comes after B?' That should be stuff that you don't walk around guessing at. It's the basic stuff that we really hated the most - scales, arpeggios, those are the things.''
 
No Compromises
Mr. Monk and others connected with the institute refer to it as ''the first conservatory in the world devoted strictly to jazz.''
''The primary difference with the Monk institute, other than its general size and magnitude, will be the fact that we're not going to compromise the music,'' Mr. Monk said.
''Most of the time it's a problem of economics. The music gets compromised because eventually someone makes a decision: 'Well, you know we're not moving along with this jazz thing the way we would like to; maybe we should get a couple of singers, a pop thing, something like that.'
''What we're trying to do, and that's why we're shooting for such a high goal in our endowment,'' Mr. Monk said, is to insure that the validity and the sanctity of the music is never compromised at the Monk Institute, for any reason.''
Or, as Mr. Harris put it, ''The whole thing is to perpetuate the music.''

HEADLINE: TELEVISION;
Blake, Krystle and Alexis Settle In on Polish TV

BYLINE: By ANNA HUSARSKA; Anna Husarska is an editor at the Polish independent daily Gazeta Wyborcza.

DATELINE: WARSAW

 BODY:
''Dynastia'' is Polish for ''dynasty.'' But nowadays it is more chic to say ''DIE-nas-tee,'' the American way. This new fashion started two months ago, when the initial installment of the United States-produced series was telecast on Poland's Channel 1. Since then, 10 times a week - twice daily from Monday to Friday - Poles are treated to the carryings-on of the enormously rich Carrington family of Colorado.
Some 16 million Polish viewers watch every evening at 6 and an additional 2 million at 11, when the same episode is repeated, as they follow the overheated romantic permutations of the oil-magnate Blake Carrington, his unhappy wife, Krystle, their spoiled daughter, Fallon, their homosexual son, Steve (both children from Blake's earlier marriage to the vengeful Alexis), and sundry other wealthy and glamorous Americans. 
Television programming from the United States is hardly new to Polish viewers, who as early as the 1960's were watching the western series ''Bonanza'' and ''Zorro.'' But there are a number of reasons why a fresh invasion of programming began this summer, when broadcasts of ''The Donahue Show,'' ''The Wonder Years'' and ''Sesame Street'' also started.
''Until the end of June,'' says Jan Dworak, vice president of the Polish TV Committee, which oversees the country's two Government-operated channels, ''the so-called ideological quotas that we inherited from the Communists were still in force, and there was a limit to how much material from capitalist countries could be shown. This is, by the way, the reason why the first soap operas in Poland came from Brazil, labeled third world and not capitalist.''
The first 39 installments of ''Dynasty'' were purchased for broadcast to the Polish home audience by newly created private import companies (which also import rice and oil) for $900 each. Many viewers are already inquiring about further episodes of the ABC prime-time staple laden with sultry women in furs and jewels and dashing men in tuxedos living indolent and self-centered lives amid sumptuous surroundings. Indeed, as their country switches from a centrally planned economy to a market economy, Poles are eagerly looking for guidelines on how to be a capitalist. ''Dynasty'' may provide clues, despite the fact that it's something of a stretch to equate the state-appointed manager of a shipyard in Gdansk with an oil mogul in Denver.
Not all Poles, however, feel that ''Dynasty'' offers useful role models; a television columnist in the Warsaw daily Zycie Warszawy recently wrote: ''The aim of each one of us, as taught by Finance Minister Leszek Balcerowicz, is to obtain the wealth of a Carrington. But can we treat 'Dynasty' as an instructive work? Educated on Socialist films and stories, we recognize immediately this gloomy bloodsucker with a dollar instead of a heart. I demand that 'Dynasty' be quickly taken off the air, as incompatible with the image of a capitalist recently launched in our country.''
The installments of ''Dynasty'' that Poles are seeing have no subtitles or dubbing. Instead, viewers hear a male voice reading a Polish translation of the dialogue, a practice Polish viewers are accustomed to.
The man who reads the dialogue is Marek Gudowski, a 35-year-old economist-turned-announcer. Mr. Gudowski is not very enthusiastic about the content of what he is reading; he claims that it bores him to death. ''It's a tremendous waste of time to watch it,'' he says, ''and to broadcast it daily is to put the viewer at gunpoint.''
Why is the series not dubbed or subtitled? ''Because it would be very expensive,'' explains Marek Libecajt, the director of imported programming at Poltel, the Government's TV agency. ''And, frankly, the quality of this serial does not justify huge investments.''
Mr. Gudowski suggests another argument against subtitles: ''Polish viewers have no time to lose glued to the screen. My reading the text allows them to carry on with domestic chores, such as cooking, ironing or washing the dishes.''
Apartments in Warsaw are usually small, so Mr. Gudowski's voice can be readily heard in all rooms and not a word of Krystle, Blake et al. is lost.
The dialogue from ''Santa Barbara,'' the long-running NBC daytime soap opera about well-to-do Californians, which started on the other Government-operated channel the same day ''Dynasty'' began on Channel 1, is read by a couple - a man takes the male roles and a woman the female ones.
Ania Nowakowska, a secretary to a deputy in the Polish Parliament, has not been watching ''Dynasty'' because, she says, she has ''no time to waste on stupidities.'' Yet she concedes that she would watch the program if the 6 P.M. Polish-language version were followed at 11 P.M. in its original English version. ''Seeing it first in Polish and then in English would help me learn English,'' she explains.
If not educational, what role does ''Dynasty'' fulfill on Polish television? For Jadwiga Laskowska, a dentist who watches the show, it is ''a fashion show.'' Unfortunately, however, because the episodes shown in Poland were made several years ago, the styles are out of date, she says.
Stasia Merenholz, an 80-year-old woman who follows international news closely, says that she watches every episode: ''The whole world saw it. So there must be something in it.'' But, she adds, she has yet to see the ''something.''
Wandzia Gabrys, who works as a dishwasher, says she is shocked by the wealth displayed in these programs. ''All those servants and maids - they have to pay them a lot, I guess,'' she says. ''And to think that I do not even earn enough to pay taxes in Poland. If I had so many servants, I would ask them to do the shopping and stand in line for me.''
Agnieszka Szyszlo, a trilingual secretary at the daily newspaper Gazeta Wyborcza, wonders why she has so far seen no blacks on ''Dynasty.'' She also points to the absolute lack of humor in the serial.
According to an opinion poll conducted by Polish television four weeks after the series began on July 2, ''Dynasty'' was being watched at 6 P.M. by between 53 and 58 percent of viewers over 15 years old. The approval rating was high, with half of the viewers regarding the program as ''very good.''
Is a 53 percent a high rating? In the 6 P.M. time slot, it is passable, but the weekly public address by Labor Minister Jacek Kuron at 8 P.M. is watched by 12 million, which is more than 40 percent of Poland's adult population.
In the tumultuous period Poland is now living through, leisure time has given way to real politics. When a number of viewers were asked what they do when live debates from Parliament are shown at the same time as ''Dynasty,'' they all said they switch to the coverage of Parliament. But, of course, there's always the late-evening rebroadcast of ''Dynasty.''

PUB-DATE: September 2, 1990

SECTION: Section 2; Page 21, Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1906 words

HEADLINE: TELEVISION;
This Courtroom Is a Long Way From 'L.A. Law'

BYLINE: By DAVID MARGOLICK

 BODY:
It took only a brief stint as a juror in Manhattan to convince Andy Wolk that when it came to criminal justice in New York, reality is the best story of all. But as Mr. Wolk or any other writer can attest, reality is never easy to simulate, particularly the reality of a system under siege, and particularly in a made-for-TV drama.
First, you have to strive to capture the ambiguities, the chaos, the tensions, the pressures and the pathos of a process unimaginable to those who aren't in the middle of it. To do that, you need someone who knows it intimately, to lead you through the Stygian world of police stations, holding pens and arraignment rooms, to help you sidestep oversimplification, sensationalism or sentimentality. Then you need someone to finance the project and present the results, however raw or disturbing they may be.
Mr. Wolk found his backer in Home Box Office, which pumped $2.3 million into the project. He found a stage in Pittsburgh, which opened up its courtrooms, police stations and prisons for him and allowed him to foul them all up temporarily so as to better resemble Brooklyn. And he found his Virgil in his brother Peter, who learned the legal terrain during a decade as a lawyer in Brooklyn - at Bedford-Stuyvesant Legal Services and the Legal Aid Society. 
This Saturday evening at 9, HBO will offer ''Criminal Justice,'' a 90-minute drama starring Forest Whitaker, Anthony LaPaglia, Jennifer Grey and Rosie Perez. The script, produced by Michael Apted and Robert O'Connor, was written by Andy Wolk and marks his film directorial debut. It tells the story of a 19-year-old prostitute named Denise Moore (Ms. Perez) who is brutally robbed as she leaves a Brooklyn crack den. In addition to stealing her night's earnings, her assailant leaves a Marla Hanson-like slash across her cheek.
From a pile of mug shots and a lineup, Denise identifies her attacker as Jesse Williams (Mr. Whitaker), an unemployed man in his early 20's who lives only a couple of blocks from the crime scene in East New York. He is quickly arrested, and the plot proceeds to follow Jesse through every stage of his prosecution, from the time a detective throws him down on a desk and sarcastically snarls his Miranda rights at him, through his incarceration, to the resolution of the case six months later. It is a profane and ugly trip from which many of the usual thematic signposts, like good and evil, guilt and innocence, are conspicuously absent.
''I wanted to create a story where you would go back and forth, where your preconceptions would be challenged,'' Andy Wolk said recently in a upper West Side coffee house. ''Hollywood has a perception that people want things romanticized, that they want the witness getting up there and saying, 'I did it!' But there's nothing romantic about this. This is tough and hard and gritty. This is the way things are.'' And that, Mr. Wolk said, is what HBO wanted. ''Michael Apted told us there is one word we should keep in mind: verisimilitude,'' he said. ''We repeated the term so often that it came to be known around the set simply as 'the V word.' ''
And ''L.A. Law'' this isn't; indeed, ''Criminal Justice'' takes the process of de-glitzing the big-city practice of law, already begun by ABC's ''Equal Justice,'' one step further. Mr. Wolk, 39, comes from a mini-line of lawyers: his father, Sidney, was a lawyer and regional inspector for the Internal Revenue Service; his brother, four years his junior and a graduate of Northeastern University Law School, is now serving as law secretary to Judge Leonard Rienzi of the State Supreme Court in Brooklyn. Mealtime discussions in the Wolk home in West Orange, N.J., often involved legal themes; Thanksgiving dinners and seders were sometimes followed by mock cross-examinations or jury selections.
Like many New Yorkers, Andy Wolk instinctively resisted jury duty until, in October 1986, he ran out of acceptable excuses. He ended up sitting on a crack-related murder case from Harlem, one requiring two weeks of testimony and three days of deliberations. The defendant was acquitted, and Mr. Wolk vowed to re-create the world he had just experienced, if only from afar.
''I wanted to put the viewer in the position of the jurors, to let the deliberations happen in people's living rooms,'' he said. From the outset, he tried to avoid some idealized portrayal, the kind of process depicted in Sidney Lumet's 1957 film ''12 Angry Men.''
And in fact, what Mr. Wolk has captured is more Henry Ford than Henry Fonda. The bewildering world Jesse and Denise enter is one in which everybody involved - judges, defense lawyers, prosecutors - are drowning. The object in that world is not to dispense justice but to dispose of cases. Defendants don't so much defend themselves as hedge their bets, trading away the only thing they have - their ability to tie up the system even longer - for a better break. There may still be lip service to old ideals. The words of the 17th-century English jurist Sir Edward Coke, ''The welfare of the people is the Supreme Law,'' are blazoned on the fictitious courtroom wall.
But, as ''Criminal Justice'' tries to demonstrate, trials are about as common as triple plays; what really happens, in various forms and forums, is bargaining. ''When the jury system works, it's great, but this is a system where no one wants jury cases,'' the writer-director said. ''The system is set up to do the exact opposite of what goes on in 'L.A. Law' - that is, not to go to trial. I wanted to show that in the most dramatic and frightening way possible.'' To do that, he wends his way through the various stages of the process, from booking, through the police lineup, through arraignment and indictment.
Jesse's Legal Aid lawyer, David Ringel (Mr. LaPaglia), can't tell whether his client is as innocent as he insists; Ringel seems to oscillate on the point, as many viewers are likely to do. Like most people, if not most television villains, Jesse has his good side. He is a devoted father, the type who is seen fetching disposable diapers for his son when the police pick him up. (If no one else, the Procter & Gamble Company had no doubt about Jesse's culpability: it refused to let either Pampers or Luvs be used in the filming.) He's also a good son, the type who grows apoplectic when his devoted mother is insulted.
And like most victims, if not most television victims, Denise Moore is flawed: She has a criminal record and may well have been too high on drugs either to have seen her attacker or to have remembered clearly what she saw. Adding to the ambiguity is the choice with which Jesse is faced. If he pleads guilty to robbery and assault, he can be out of prison in 18 months. If not, Ringel tells him, ''We're talking '2001: A Space Odyssey' before you hit the streets again.''
The lawyers, like the protagonists, also have their nuances. At the age of thirtysomething, Ringel speaks with the raspy Weltschmerz and cynicism of George C. Scott at sixtysomething. This is a battle-weary veteran, not some dewy Ivy Leaguer of the sort played by Willem Dafoe in the film ''Mississippi Burning.'' At one point, he commiserates with another jaded Legal Aid lawyer over a client's all-too-familiar alibi. ''Can you tell me why, if there are eight million people in the naked city, there are only two stories?'' he asks. But as Major Strasser discovered in Monsieur Rick, the cynicism only masks the idealism.
''I think Ringel is a pretty good lawyer, like the average Legal Aid lawyer,'' said Peter Wolk. ''But I don't know if Ringel is still going to be at Legal Aid in another one, two or three years.''
The prosecutor, Assistant District Attorney Elizabeth Carter (Jennifer Grey), also has her imperfections. She is only superficially solicitous of Denise and has no doubt whatsoever of Jesse's guilt. Her job is not to hold hands or assure that justice is done, but, as she see it, to convict the creep.
Under normal circumstances, the measly pay of a Legal Aid lawyer might be more palatable with a young, attractive and unattached lawyer on the opposing side, and as ''Criminal Justice'' unfolds the viewer may discern an ''Adam's Rib'' romance in the making. But one never develops - deliberately, according to Mr. Wolk. (In any case, Liz Carter is a lawyer from the Debra Winger-''Legal Eagles'' school, the sort who wears severely tailored suits, smokes continuously, rarely smiles except at one of her own cutting remarks and invariably calls men by their last names. Maybe not today, maybe not tomorrow, but someday, Hollywood's women lawyers will not consider using first names a sign of weakness.) ''Criminal Justice'' is not without its cliches, like saxophones wailing and cell doors slamming. But Mr. Wolk and his brother, who sat in as an unpaid technical adviser, say that they labored to get things right, or at least as things usually are. Most of the inmates are real. So, too, are the mug shots, the rap sheets, the files and the lingo.
Andy Wolk said that some of his brother's former colleagues at Legal Aid had already seen the film, and instead of the usual ex post facto nitpicking of insiders, walked away wondering whether or not Jesse Williams really robbed Denise Moore.
''It's very gratifying,'' the director said, ''because that's exactly what this movie is set up to do.''
 
DIRTY DOINGS
Though ''Criminal Justice'' ostensibly takes place in Brooklyn, it was actually filmed in Pittsburgh, where costs were lower and officialdom more cooperative. There was only one problem: The city wasn't sufficiently filthy.
Even in a more immaculate era, it would have been hard enough for the film's production designers, Dan Bishop and Dianna Freas, to re-create New York nearly 400 miles to the west. But doing so now, at a time when the city has seldom been scuzzier, presented a particular challenge. They did so through a process they describe as ''de-renovation,'' but which could also be called B.Y.O.G.: bring your own garbage.
To make the streets, corridors and courtrooms of Pittsburgh look more Brooklyn-like, they imported banged-up cars, soda bottles, candy wrappers and plenty of newspapers, mostly crumpled up New York tabloids and ethnic broadsheets, and sprinkled them around liberally. They turned over trash cans. They brought in stacks of ''I H NY'' coffee cups. At that, keeping pristine Pittsburgh dirty was not easy. ''We had to hire 24-hour security guards so that the stuff wouldn't be carted away,'' said Andy Wolk, the film's writer-director. ''And we had to stop the janitors. We had to tell them, 'No! Leave it dirty!' ''
To authenticate what seemed to New Yorkers to be the excessively clean Pittsburgh courtrooms, the crew rubbed paste wax on the wood paneling, then left it there until shooting was complete. They dulled up walls with lackluster latex paint, supplemented by strategically placed smudges and fingerprints. They replaced modern office furniture with dingy metal models from the 1950's.
What posed the most nettlesome problem was graffiti: there was none. Ms. Freas and Mr. Bishop drove around Brooklyn photographing specimens, then faithfully reproduced them, in both English and Spanish, on every available flat surface within the camera's eye. Only the formula was false: the paint was water-based and easily removed. Thus, when the New Yorkers departed, Pittsburgh could once more be Pittsburgh.

PUB-DATE: September 2, 1990

SECTION: Section 2; Page 26, Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1487 words

HEADLINE: DESIGN VIEW;
Trouble in 'Flatland,' or The War Against Confusion

BYLINE: By D. J. BRUCKNER; D. J. R. Bruckner is an editor of The New York Times Book Review. His book on the American type designer F. W. Goudy will be published by Abrams in November.

 BODY:
Often the presentation of information obscures its meaning. To Edward R. Tufte, the correction of this scandal lies in design. He has made it his mission to turn statistical tables, scientific observations, schedules, maps, timetables and much more into ''bright and splendid visions'' reflecting the ''crystalline qualities of information display.'' If he has his way, a piece of paper, which he calls ''flatland,'' will reveal depths, contours and subtleties of reality we have never seen before.
Mr. Tufte does work in graphic design and teaches design, among other subjects, at Yale, but the main weapons in his war against confusion are books written to inspire other designers. His first book on graphic display, ''The Visual Display of Quantitative Information,'' has been selling steadily since it first appeared in 1983. His second, ''Envisioning Information,'' was published in June.
He is a bit puritanical. ''To envision information . . . is to work at the intersection of image, word, number, art,'' he has written. The implication is that the graphic designer who strays from that intersection adds to the mess. ''Clutter and confusion are failures of design,'' he says, ''not attributes of information.'' Understanding is the whole point: information should be presented to promote reasoning about it. 
''I want information design to be based on ideas, on reasoning, and to give it the power of ideas,'' he says, ''and to develop the esthetics of information design. I don't just want to put on a scientific performance, but to produce something beautiful. There has been too much cliched thinking and not enough rigor in the field of design.''
Mr. Tufte (rhymes with mufti), who is 46 years old, teaches statistics, graphic design and political economy at Yale University. He earned his bachelor's and master's degrees at Stanford University before going on to Yale for a Ph.D. in political science.
After a 10-year stint teaching at Princeton he returned to Yale in 1977 as a faculty member. When he began teaching he also took up art; his prints hang on the walls of his home in Cheshire, Conn., near New Haven, and his sculptures rear up in the gardens, appropriately in abstract geometrical forms. The whole house bristles with design: Mr. Tufte's projects spread through all the rooms of the ground floor. Upstairs his wife, Inge Druckrey, who teaches design at Yale and the Rhode Island School of Design, presides over a large studio full of drawing tables and cabinets from which she extracts typographical designs by her students, laying them out for admiration with the care one reserves for works of art.
Mr. Tufte has been a consultant on statistics and information design to several corporations, the Federal Government, transit systems and the news media. In 1980 and 1984 he worked as a consultant to The New York Times, helping design its election polls and the reports on their findings.
Through most of this century, he wrote in ''Visual Display,'' data graphics were considered ''mainly devices for showing the obvious to the ignorant.
''It is hard to imagine any doctrine more likely to stifle intellectual progress.'' But in the late 1960's the celebrated statistician and data analyst of Bell Laboratories and Princeton, John W. Tukey, ''made statistical graphics respectable,'' Mr. Tufte said, by ''using them effectively to explore complex data.'' In 1974, Mr. Tufte and Mr. Tukey taught a seminar together on statistical graphics at Princeton. That experience led to ''The Visual Display of Quantitative Information.''
Mr. Tufte talks about bad design as a kind of moral affront. ''The world comes to us in three or four dimensions,'' he says. ''And we don't do very well when we reduce it to flatland. We take in enormous information - word, number, image - through the eye. I believe in the wide-eyed, fresh-eyed view.'' In a sense his work in design is, as he calls it, ''a kind of geometrical thinking, reducing four dimensions to two,'' and it is significant that his conversation betrays a fascination with architecture.
Computers will not alter the task of presenting multidimensional information on flatland, he says. Their capacity to affect the design of information is limited by their own design: ''The screen is flatland and merely an exterior manifestation. The computer was designed from the inside out in that sense; fundamentally it was made to do something else. To really change our capacities in design, one would have to be designed from the outside in. So paper will remain the place of the art.''
Surprisingly, publishers missed the appeal of that argument. Mr. Tufte took the manuscript of ''Visual Display'' to several. They proposed many changes, a small press run and a high price for the book. So he mortgaged his house, took out bank loans at 18 percent interest, set up his own publishing house (Graphics Press, located in Cheshire) and published ''Visual Display'' at $36 a copy.
He sold it by direct mail, 96,000 copies in 10 printings, bringing in just under $3.5 million, and he became something of a mythical figure in publishing as well as in design. The book presents a comprehensive theory of data graphics in a spare text threaded through a series of eye-opening illustrations. And Mr. Tufte's many suggestions for improving data graphics taken from scores of publications - most often by simplifying them, getting rid of what he calls ''chartjunk'' - have become a source of instruction, and amusement, throughout the design world. Ideally, he says, the work of a designer disappears altogether: ''If a design is good the reader should never notice it; it will have made the information totally engrossing.''
In 1985, two years after the first book was published, he began work on ''Envisioning Information,'' which Graphics Press published in June at $48 a copy. ''Most beautiful books are beautiful throughout in the same way,'' Mr. Tufte says. ''This is meant to be beautiful in many different ways.''
It is an extraordinary piece of typography and printing, a book with a singular and powerful personality. Of course, this author has an indulgent publisher whose success with his previous book allowed him to spend $700,000 on the production of this one. His use of color is lavish and subtle. He has some points to make about how much better complex information is conveyed in subdued colors than in bright ones, and he makes his argument through the printing process - ''the book is the message,'' he says. One chapter required printing 11 colors on 12; the sheets had to be run through the press 23 times.
Mr. Tufte shares his techniques with the reader, at one point reproducing exactly a marvelous system for learning geometry without words - by studying and combining shapes in different colors - that was first published in London in 1847, and then redrawing part of it to let the reader see how it can be done better. When he reproduces a pasted-in foldout triangle from among 20 geometric devices of that kind included in a book printed in London 420 years ago, he includes on his page the slight discoloration the triangle made on the aging paper of the original.
His examples of good information design include pages from 17th-century books by Galileo, modern epidemiological maps, charts of sunspot observations for a century, a stunning Czechoslovak airline map and schedule from the 1930's, a Japanese spy's copy of a wonderfully complex and clear railroad timetable for the island of Java in 1937, Constantine Anderson's famous isometric map of midtown Manhattan - the range is enormous. Information design, like mathematics, is a universal language, he contends - Q.E.D. And he allows himself to provide his own endorsement: ''Information design is a solved problem; this book is the catalogue to the museum of design art.''
Up to a point - for, of course, he is already working on another book - to be published, like the others, five years after it is begun. Why five years? ''Well, I figure I am not going to do a lot of these books, so I had better get each one exactly right.''
And what is to result from all this zeal? Magic. Mr. Tufte is bent on introducing action in time, a fourth dimension, into flatland. He says his first book was about numbers, the second about nouns and the new one will be ''about verbs - how you animate things.'' Research for the new volume began with the purchase of the library of a man who spent his life collecting books, catalogues and pamphlets on magic.
Now in Mr. Tufte's house easels, light tables and drawing boards display old pictures illustrating disappearing acts, men in top hats waving their arms over empty receptacles while legends printed on curved lines indicating the sweep of the arms read ''gone'' or ''empty.'' He smiles the smile of those who achieve ''innocent seeing,'' and says: ''There is a beginning. There is movement in flatland.''

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
Redemption on the Jersey Turnpike?

BYLINE: By Diana B. Henriques

 BODY:
By rights, these should have been disastrous weeks for the bonds of the New Jersey Turnpike Authority.
In the aftermath of the Kuwait invasion, the entire bond market has shuddered over the prospect that rekindled inflation would push up interest rates. The turnpike authority is also vulnerable because of the impact higher oil prices and weaker economic activity would have on commercial traffic and, thus, on toll revenue. Indeed, some municipal bond issues have fallen as much as $40 per $1,000 bond since early August. 
The authority's Series 1985 bonds, by contrast, have fallen only about $12.50 per bond - even after The Bond Buyer, an influential daily market journal, reported last Wednesday on the widening gap between the authority's expenses and its revenues. The likely reason for this buoyancy is that the market is betting the turnpike authority will redeem these bonds at face value before the Persian Gulf crisis can take its toll.
If the market turns out to be wrong, however, turnpike investors may suddenly find that the authority's ability to repay them hinges on the political muscle of Gov. Jim Florio, a Democrat whose state tax increases have made news across the country and provoked furious opposition at home.
The authority's bonds are both widely held and closely watched - especially the $2 billion issue of Series 1985 bonds, sold five years ago to finance an ambitious road-widening program.
The issue, sold in haste to avoid restrictive new Federal tax rules, was the largest ever sold in the tax-exempt market, and surely one of the most controversial. The authority's abrupt actions infuriated almost everyone except the investment bankers who profited from the deal. Those who protested, publicly and privately, included residents of the towns affected by the expansion plan, transit engineers trying to coordinate turnpike traffic with other arteries, environmentalists concerned about wetlands traversed by the road and the state officials confronted with the necessity of ultimately hiking tolls to pay debt service on the bonds.
Faced with a storm of opposition, the turnpike authority eventually backed down, sharply scaling back its construction plans. That move may placate local officials, transit planners and environmentalists. But it offers no comfort to those who must find the funds to pay debt service on $2 billion worth of bonds for the next 28 years.
The amounts involved are sobering. The authority will pay $160 million in debt service next year; when principal repayments on the 1985 bonds kick in during 1993, the authority's debt service will climb to $228 million, of which all but about $55.5 million is owed to holders of the Series 1985 bonds. And toll revenues are already falling about $40 million short of 1990 expenses.
The prospectus for the 1985 bonds warned that the authority would need to raise its tolls substantially - at least 100 percent - to finance future debt service on the bonds. ''When the bonds were sold, everybody took it for granted that, yes, tolls would be raised,'' said Eileen F. Hopkins, a bond analyst at John Nuveen & Company in Chicago.
But turnpike tolls were last increased in April 1980, and recent attempts to muster the political backing for an increase have failed. Instead, the authority board members have elected to dip into reserve funds to cover the budget gap while the Florio administration tries to find a politically viable route out of this dilemma.
The first step has been to create a new state panel to devise a comprehensive transportation plan for the state, explained Gordon Hector, director of public affairs for the turnpike authority. That process is expected to be completed late this year or early in 1991, Mr. Hector said. ''That's when we will know how our plans fit into the overall plan,'' he added.
The authority's options, obviously, are limited. Under the terms of the Series 1985 bond covenant, it can return the bondholders' money any time after Nov. 21, thereby avoiding future debt service bills. It can invest the $1.3 billion remaining from the original issue, earning interest on it and using that income to partially defray future debt service. Or it can spend the money on the transportation infrastructure in New Jersey and face the toll-hike consequences.
The bond market, clearly, is betting that bondholders will get their money back sometime soon. That is why the 1985 bonds are trading within a few dollars of their redemption value. And the market may be right, said Ms. Hopkins of Nuveen. With any major change in the use of bond funds open to legal challenge by investors, the Governor may see redemption as the best way out of a bad mess.
But the Governor and his advisers may elect to use the money - which, to be fair, is sorely needed for transportation improvements at a time when other sources of funds are scarce. In that case, the Governor will have to confront the politically incendiary problem of raising tolls on a roadway that serves 73 percent of state residents.
Mr. Hector warns that the authority is ''nowhere near a decision'' on what to do about the bond issue, and may not be for some time. Meanwhile, the state income-tax increases already enacted at the Governor's behest have produced a bitter backlash, with some critics lobbying for a recall election to oust Mr. Florio from office. That has prompted many in the bond market to conclude that the Governor lacks the political power to raise tolls and has no option but to redeem the bonds. To do otherwise, one trader argued, would be ''political suicide.''
Maybe so. But pundits in the the Garden State are still trying to figure out where Mr. Florio got the legislative votes - and the nerve -to increase the state income tax and revise the state's aid to local school districts in the face of entrenched opposition. Those moves, they say, argue against underestimating Mr. Florio's appetite for battle.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Ominous News From Japan

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
The Bank of Japan's increase of its discount rate to 6 percent from 5.25 percent has raised new questions about how much higher world interest rates will go and how many more investors will be drained from weak world equity markets.
The likely answer is that Japan will move again, adding new pressure to the upward tilt in rates. This bodes ill all around. With higher rates increasing the cost of borrowing for investment, the growing economies in Europe and Japan would slow some. Their stock markets would remain under pressure. The United States, where the economy has been kept barely afloat with exports, would lose buoyancy as slower growth abroad curbed sales. 
Higher rates abroad would put the dollar under more pressure and the Federal Reserve, if possible, would be in an even more difficult dilemma. The need to raise interest rates to support the dollar and fight inflation would be challenged by the demand for lower interest rates to keep the economy from falling into a serious recession.
And financial markets around the world were already under pressure from tensions in the Persian Gulf, as interest rates rose in response to the inflationary fears generated by the jump in oil prices after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.
In the 11 countries followed in J.P. Morgan's government bond index, the average increase in interest rates since the Aug. 2 invasion was 51 basis points or just over half a percentage point.
On average, the return for investors in August was down 1.41 percent in local currencies, following a rise of 1 percent in July. Even in foreign bond markets, where American investors recently got a lift from a weakening dollar, the return since the invasion has dropped 0.23 percent, far from the robust 5.13 percent increase in July. The rise in the dollar on Thursday and Friday, especially against the British pound, wiped out much of the currency gain for the month. A dollar return of 3.56 percent through Wednesday was cut to 1.25 by Friday.
In Australia, the return was up 3.27 percent in dollar terms, with the average yield down 37 basis points on 1- to 3-year maturities and up 33 basis points on 7- to 10-year maturities. But in Australian dollars, the local return was up only 0.77 percent. The worst market was Japan. The return for the Japanese was off 2.46 percent. But the falling dollar trimmed this loss to 0.16 percent for Americans. Interest rates on 7- to 10-year maturities rose 57 basis points in Japan.
The jump in the Japanese discount rate was expected. It conformed with forecasts of many analysts, made well before the Iraqi invasion, that interest rates would rise in Japan and Europe but hold or fall in the United States. This combination has already led to a weaker dollar and hurt stock markets worldwide. Markets in Britain and the United States have also been hurt by slowdowns in the economy and corporate earnings.
But as soon as the Japanese discount-rate increase was announced Thursday, talk of another began - because short-term market interest rates, at 8.19 percent, are still so much higher. In September, the Japanese get new data on business investment intentions for the third quarter and the gross domestic product for the second quarter. Strong growthand continued high investment levels - the factors that in June set off the recent round of rising interest rates - could trigger another cycle of rising interest rates followed by a another jump in the discount rate.
''The market is still expecting another discount rate hike,'' said Yuichi Kohashi, senior vice president of Daiwa Securities America in New York.
In Germany, no increase in interest rates is expected until after unification in October. But the costs of unification seem to be growing daily, and inflationary pressures are increasing. The inflation rate over the last year rose to 2.9 percent in August and is now expected, with the rise in oil prices, to be over 3 percent by the end of the year. These factors, said Warren Oliver, European economist at UBS Phillips and Drew in London, should be enough to force the Bundesbank's hand by the end of the year.

HEADLINE: Recession: Are the Questions How Deep and How Long?

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:
The economic news was gloomy even before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait: half a year of lackluster growth, rising inflation and a softening employment picture. Now, as oil prices rise and consumer confidence tumbles to its lowest level in seven years, the battered economy is sure to take another beating. But does it mean recession or just more of the same - the softest of soft landings? And if it does mean recession, how long and how deep?
Three economists, Allen Sinai, executive vice president and chief economist at the Boston Company; Francis H. Schott, senior vice president and chief economist at the Equitable Life Assurance Society; and R. David Ranson, president and chief economist at H.C. Wainwright & Company Economics Inc., discussed their forecasts for the economy with Joel Kurtzman of The New York Times.
 Q. Mr. Sinai, even before Iraq invaded Kuwait and oil prices started to rise, you said the country was on the verge of a recession. Is that still your view? 
Mr. Sinai: Yes. We can cite a whole host of economic data: the slow momentum in retail sales, the poor July employment report, the slide in final demand in the second quarter that showed up. And there were the fundamental factors as well: slow growth in real income and a six-quarter decline in profits. These are very negative for consumption, consumer spending and for business capital spending.
The Iraqi event is very hard to factor in because it is a political event, and could be erased from the landscape of the forecasting world at any time. But I'm assuming that we will have a protracted situation in Iraq at least through the end of the year, although not necessarily a shooting war. That means crude oil prices will settle at about $25 to $28 a barrel.
I am therefore assuming that whatever mild recession might have happened without Iraq will be intensified.
What does this mean in terms of duration? Anywhere from two to three quarters of declines in real gross national product, and a peak-to-trough decline in real gross national product of 1 to 1 1/2 percent measured fourth quarter to fourth quarter.
Mr. Schott: It's a little bit academic to say this, but before Iraq I wouldn't have been sure that we were actually getting to the point of a recession. But now I am reasonably sure and agree that we are heading toward a two- to three-quarter recession. However, I think the recession will be fairly mild. My forecast is for a three-quarter recession, most likely beginning in the fourth quarter of 1990 and going through the first half of 1991. On a fourth quarter to fourth quarter basis, we'll have positive growth of between one-half and one percentage point. The Federal Reserve will come to the assistance of the economy sooner or later.
But the excesses in the economy - the high corporate debt ratios - are going to have to be corrected. There will be workouts or even defaults during this period. We are in for some tough times on Wall Street and in corporate boardrooms for some months to come.
Let me make one reservation, however. There is some level of military activity in the Middle East - and nobody can be sure exactly what that level is - that could upset this forecast completely. Enough of a shooting war, enough of a Pentagon acceleration in spending, enough new defense expenditures and there will be no recession.
Mr. Ranson: My perspective is different. I'm not at all sure there are going to be any declines in G.N.P. Whether we're in a recession depends to on how the authorities decide it is to be defined. The standard definition isn't absolutely watertight. It's very arbitrary, you see.
However, if there is a recession, I think we're probably already in it. It just hasn't shown up as yet in the data. And any recession would be very brief. I am expecting growth next year to return to normal.
 Q.What do you consider normal growth?
Mr. Ranson: Three percent growth of G.N.P. or something close to 3 percent. In 1992, we expect growth to be even higher than normal, possibly as high as 3 1/2 to 4 percent.
By the way, if we are in a recession, it has little or nothing to do with the Iraqi crisis, and I don't expect the crisis to deepen it. I say this because the price of oil historically has not been a very good predictor of economic output.
I am a great believer in interest rates as the economy's leading indicator. It is possible to draw a graph showing how interest rates explain movements in G.N.P. over the last 30 or 40 years. It's a very tight fit. But if you add oil prices into the graph, the change is really very trivial.
Q. Rising oil prices are usually associated with rising levels of inflation. Do you think inflation will accelerate if oil prices stay where they are?
Mr. Ranson: No I don't. Inflation is likely to be stable. The best indicator I know of for inflation is the overall level of commodity prices in general. Commodities are up over last year somewhat. But I think an inflation rate of 4 percent is very likely for next year. The Iraqi invasion won't affect that.
Mr. Sinai: Well, I'm not so sure. Let's assume crude oil settles in at around $25 a barrel and the Iraqi event does not escalate into a big shooting war that shoves crude oil prices up to $35 to $40 a barrel. Let's also assume that the Iraqi event doesn't just magically go away. Then my calculations are that inflation in the consumer price index would be on the order of 5 to 5 1/2 percent fourth quarter to fourth quarter.
Mr. Schott: Taking into account the same important reservations Allen just stated, I agree that the C.P.I. will rise at a rate of 5 to 5 1/2 percent. I am also assuming that the oil price will settle around $24 to $25 a barrel and that the Iraqi event will not go away but will not get worse.
Mr. Sinai: Defining a recession in the classical way - two quarters of declines of real G.N.P. - misses the point. My sense is that business is really much more depressed - business in general - and has been in recession for longer than we have been talking about. But part of the reason recession doesn't show up in the statistics is because we have been in a protracted period of anemic growth. A prime example of that is non-residential construction and housing. We're running housing starts at a little under 1.2 million units and that really is pretty poor. We have a recessed economy that is taking another turn downward.
 Q. People argue that the savings and loan crisis and the problems beginning to surface among some large banks could deepen a recession, should one occur. Is this your view?
Mr. Sinai: The decline in economic activity that we are in the midst of will make the problems of the commercial banking system and all the financial institutions worse. We have a very fragile situation right now. There is a good-size risk that as our financial institutions come under more pressure, there will be intensified restraints on lending. That in turn would give us an even bigger decline. It could turn a mild-to-moderate recession into a standard - maybe worse than standard - recession. It's a very big risk element.
Mr. Ranson: I have a more optimistic view. There is plenty of historical evidence on the role that debt plays in the economy. As far as I can tell, changes in debt levels or in borrowing are not useful as leading indicators of the economy. They do cause distresses and tragedies on the individual and company levels, but I'm not at all sure that indebtedness plays a very major role when it comes to the overall economy.
Q. But won't high levels of indebtedness in a recession lead to more bankruptcies, layoffs and less consumer spending? Won't this make a recession deeper?
Mr. Ranson: I don't believe so. I believe the economy's resources consist of human beings, human capital, physical capital and knowledge about how to use them. The ability of the economy to operate doesn't depend on balance sheets or flows of funds. If some companies go bankrupt, however large they are, their human capital still exists. They will be taken over by other owners and the economy will go on from there. I don't feel there's a major link between bankruptcy and the aggregate rate at which the economy can perform its functions.
Mr. Schott: That is a pretty venturesome view. Most people believe that bankruptcies and workouts make a recession deeper.
Mr. Ranson: I don't see any empirical evidence of that.
Mr. Sinai: Any downturn that comes into play - especially if there's rising unemployment - will set up forces that will make the real economy spiral even deeper. This is a very risky situation. I'm afraid I'm more concerned about it than David.
 Q. What should the Federal Reserve be doing at this juncture?
 Mr. Schott: We have to emphasize the cruel dilemma that the Federal Reserve faces. I think the Fed has to ease rates some - a quarter of a percent on the Fed funds rate. I believe the Federal Reserve will ease rates some. Perhaps the Fed won't do that this week, but it will do that before the end of September.
The problem is, however, that first of all, the Fed has been trying to hold out on easing rates in order to get the Administration and Congress to come to a budget agreement. With the Iraq situation, that hope has gone down the tubes. That means trouble for the Federal Reserve, because the Federal deficit will be much worse in fiscal '91 than it was in fiscal '90.
Mr. Sinai: The Fed can't help much this year even if it lowers interest rates, except to minimize the burden of interest costs on the Federal debt and to lower interest costs on households that have floating-rate mortgage debt. This will mean a lower dollar, which carries with it an inflationary risk.
But, if the economy is sliding into a recession, then lower short-term rates ought to help housing pick up some in 1991. The lower dollar ought to help exports some. And it would cushion consumer spending a little bit. But I'm not thinking just about a quarter-point easing of the Fed funds rate. A quarter-point would be step one. A point or so reduction in interest rates is needed beginning now and over the next year. That would cushion the recession.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
A Superpower Goes Begging For Bucks

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
As the superpower amassed its tanks and planes in the Middle East last week, its top diplomat got out his tin cup and prepared to seek a way to pay for the expeditionary force.
That spectacle, of Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, along with Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, mapping a trip to the countries that have the cash, among them West Germany and South Korea, may help to explain why the dollar has been far weaker in this world crisis than in previous ones.
The need to push so hard for cash provided another reminder of how important the budget talks that are about to resume will be, and of the penalties being paid for not getting the country's fiscal house in order before a crisis hit. 
The gulf crisis did seem to ease a bit, at least from a Wall Street perspective, as diplomacy came to the fore. Gold, the old favorite in times of stress, tumbled and gave up most of its post-invasion gains. Stocks recovered only a fraction of their Kuwait-related falls, but the Dow Jones industrial average still rose 81.44 points, or 3.2 percent, to 2,614.36, for its best weekly gain since early May.
Smaller stocks, which fell further as prices tumbled, also bounced back more rapidly. The Russell 2,000 rose 3.9 percent, for its best weekly showing in more than two years.
The rebounds were not enough to keep August from entering the books as the fifth worst month since World War II for the Dow, trailing only October 1987 and three brutal months in 1973 and 1974, following the first oil shock.
Individual investors seem to have taken the plunge in stride to a much greater extent than did the professionals on Wall Street. Mutual fund companies were pleasantly surprised at just how little money came out of their stock funds, and Fidelity Investment's discount brokerage customers were net buyers in every week of the month. On Monday, when prices were rallying, buy orders at Fidelity outnumbered sell orders by a three-to-one margin. Whether that reflects wisdom, or complacency, will be determined later.
Wall Street is a place that loves to talk about the big issues, whether recession or war and peace. But just now a substantial part of the Street's attention is focused on a more parochial concern: Will Congress enact a tax on securities transactions? With the budget crisis clear, and draconian Gramm-Rudman spending cuts on the horizon, such a tax might pass.
That could hit stocks even more than Saddam Hussein did, at least if a new study, supported by the Mid-America Institute for Public Policy Research, is to be believed. Yakov Amihud of New York University and Haim Mendelson of Stanford estimated that the Dow industrials would fall by 18 percent if a half-percent tax on securities transactions became law.
Of course, every group would prefer that the tax burden fall somewhere else. But without some action to close the budget deficit, the question facing America is sobering: No matter how powerful its guns, can a country be considered a superpower if it can't afford the bullets?

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: September 2, 1990

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2, Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1650 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIARY: August 26-31

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL
 
OPEC Decides to Give the Desired Response
 
One doesn't just order a cab driver in the Arab world to head across town. One respectfully inquires if he is going in that direction. On Wednesday, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries announced that it is, indeed, going where the United States would like. OPEC members are now free to pump all the oil they can. For weeks, the United States and its allies have requested that OPEC compensate for the boycott of Iraqi and Kuwaiti supplies. But Iraq has threatened neighbors who comply with United States requests. Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, backed by an OPEC accord, appear ready to produce even more than experts thought they could. An agency representing major oil consumers decided against drawing down emergency oil reserves, but doubted that OPEC could pump enough to avoid serious shortages come winter. For now, OPEC unity has brought lower oil prices - from $30.91 to $27.32 a barrel last week. 
 
Satellites for Tonga?
 
The tiny, South Pacific island kingdom of Tonga has volcanoes, coral reefs, coconuts and bananas. Its 100,000 residents have 5,000 radios and 4,000 telephones. Now King Taufa'ahau Tupou 4th wants to add at least 13 communications satellites. Tonga has found a loophole in international law allowing it to claim the last orbital slots for satellites than can link Asia and the United States. Not that Tongans are clamoring for more ''I Love Lucy'' reruns or the ability to check coconut futures on the commodity exchanges. Tongasat, a Government-sponsored company with no money of its own, instead aims to raise perhaps $500 million from investors, then charge users millions of dollars a year for each satellite slot. Officials of Intelsat, the consortium of 199 nations that supplies most international satellite service, are fuming over the potential loss of the slots. They say that Tongasat is a front for a savvy American telecommunications specialist, Matt C. Nilson, who thought up the venture and convinced the Tongans to adopt it.
 
Japan's Rate Rise
 
The Japanese tightened last week, and the United States is likely to feel the squeeze. Japan raised its discount rate to 6 percent from 5.25 percent last Thursday, the fifth increase in just over a year. Japanese interest rates are approaching the levels of United States rates - even though economists expect Japanese consumer prices to rise less than 3 percent this year, not half as much as in the United States. Economists say that higher Japanese interest rates could hurt the value of the dollar and repatriate Japanese money that has been flowing into American bonds. The likely result is higher interest rates in the United States on the eve of a recession.
 
Soviet-Saudi Raprochement
 
The Russian Republic in OPEC? Just a recent suggestion from Boris N. Yeltsin, the republic's president, who claims control of the region's oil. The Soviet Union was drawing closer to Saudi Arabia even before the Middle East crisis, allowing Moslem pilgrims to visit Mecca for the first time. No formal diplomatic relations yet, but the Soviets hosted Saudi Arabia's Ambassador to the United States last month.
 
Bush Passes the Hat
 
President Bush sounded like the chairman of a global United Way last week as he urged other nations ''to bear their fair share'' of Middle East costs. The United States is spending billions on military forces and economic sanctions there. The President intends to dispatch Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d to West Germany, Japan and the Middle East, seeking contributions of as much as $25 billion.
 
In Brief
 
Toys 'R' Not Us: The Japanese relaxed their laws to allow some large American stores to open shop. But now come the Japanese retailers with plans to gang up against newcomers. Toys 'R' Us, which plans 100 Japanese stores in the next 10 years, faces organized opposition from domestic toy retailers who promise to aid competing shops.
 
Ernest W. Saunders, the former chief of Guinness P.L.C., was sentenced to five years in prison. He was convicted of conspiracy, fraud and theft in his successful 1986 battle to take over the Distillers Company.
 
Japan's Ministry of Finance gave one- and two-day suspensions to four investment houses, including Daiwa Securities and a Citicorp susidiary, for aiding in stock manipulation.
 
COMPANIES
 
A Boost for the Air Bag
 
At first, auto companies offered air bags as options costing as much as $800. Then they cited the weak response from customers as proof there was little demand. Last week, the General Motors Corporation said that by 1995, a driver's-side air bag would be in every car it builds in the United States. Some safety experts say the air bags might save thousands of lives, especially since the company's passive seat belts are said to be flawed. A G.M. spokesman explained the move with marketing language instead, saying, ''There's little doubt the American car-buying public is moving into a more safety-conscious mode.''Chrysler already equips almost all its cars with air bags, and Ford plans to in the mid-1990's. Toyota and Honda appear to be lagging behind - giving American companies a rare design advantage over their major Japanese rivals.
 
The United Automobile Workers named G.M. as its ''strike target'' last Tuesday. Contracts with the auto makers expire Sept. 14.
 
IN BRIEF
 
When two of the South's largest banks agreed last year to merge, they at first decided to call themselves the Avantar Financial Corporation, a name that reeked of adventure, perhaps in outer space. Well, the Citizens and Southern Corporation and the Sovran Financial Corporation were officially united yesterday - as the C&S Sovran Corporation. A mouthful, perhaps, but at least familiar food.
 
The Tisch family, betting on weak banking stocks to revive, has bought major stakes in Continental Bank, Baybanks and Equimark.
 
THE ECONOMY
 
Arguing With the Census
 
They will fight in the fields and in the streets. They will fight block-to-block and then house-to-house. Local and state politicians will not flag or fail until the Government admits there are heaps more Philadelphians, Atlantans, Houstonians and New Yorkers than the Census Bureau estimated last week. Never mind that satisfying all these complaints might leave the nation with a population larger than India's. This is what the agency gets for letting local authorities review preliminary figures. The final numbers will determine not only Congressional representation and Federal benefits, but also where many businesses and investors direct their money and jobs. For many local officials, the census has become nothing more than the continuation of politics by other means.
 
The Countryside Shrinks
 
Don't look for rural areas to rebound during the 1990's. The countryside suffered greater population losses than expected during the last decade - as many as 1.4 million people, according to preliminary census figures - after gaining during the 1970's. Doug Bachtel, a sociologist at the University of Georgia, says that the exodus is likely to continue. Even if farming becomes more profitable, it will continue to become more mechanized, he said. And factories that moved into small towns searching for cheap labor are now looking overseas. So the young and the educated move to the cities, leaving the poor and elderly back home. In Taliaferro County, Ga., where the population fell from 2,032 to 1,761 during the decade, more than one in five residents are older than 65, compared with less than one in eight nationally. ''People in Florida are getting their retirement benefits from Merrill Lynch,'' Mr. Bachtel said, referring to their investments. ''People in rural America are getting their benefits from Uncle Sam.''
 
Consumer Confidence Drops
 
Consumers swore they felt an earthquake in August, rattling them so badly that they might be afraid to go out to shop. Two indexes showed last week that, as the Middle East crisis intensified, consumer confidence took the sharpest plunge since the October 1987 stock market crash. The University of Michigan reported that consumers were less confident than at any time since the 1982 recession. And the Conference Board, a business group, confirmed Michigan's finding that consumers are especially pessimistic about the next six months - which often foreshadows a recession. Lacy H. Hunt, the chief economist at Carroll McEntee & McGinley, said that with unemployment claims also rising in the last two weeks, ''The best that we can expect is very sluggish growth.'' Economists are waiting for September figures to see whether consumers really felt an earthquake, or just the neighbors moving their furniture around upstairs.
 
More Bad S.&L. News
 
A healthy savings and loan these days seems to be one whose cancer is not terminal. The Office of Thrift Supervision reported last week that losses and loan problems are growing at many of the nation's strongest institutions. The figures raise questions about whether the savings and loan industry can survive without being taken over by commercial banks.
 
Energy: Lack of Policy
 
Energy Secretary James D. Watkins responded to the prospect of oil shortages by suggesting a rough sail and a bumpy ride. He wants to sail into the waters off Santa Barbara, Calif., to pump oil near a coastline cherished by environmentalists and tourists. And he wants all Americans to inflate their tires to the maximum pressure for more energy-efficient, but more jarring, rides. No sense in speeding the development of a comprehensive energy policy due for delivery to the Capitol next spring, Mr. Watkins added. Better to do the easy things now, make the tougher changes later.
