HEADLINE: Creating a Giant Computer Highway

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

DATELINE: RESTON, Va.

 BODY:
Traced in the phosphors glowing on the screen of his computer, Robert E. Kahn sees the 21st century:
Hair-thin strands of glass fiber are threaded through computerized libraries to supercomputers, large high-resolution video screens and hundreds of thousands of computer work stations located throughout the country.
Many scientists, educators, Government officials and corporate executives believe that Dr. Kahn has, in fact, put in place the early stages of a technological transformation that will be every bit as profound for America in the next century as the transcontinental railroad was in the last.
From his base at the Corporation for National Research Initiatives, a nonprofit company he created in 1986, Dr. Kahn has successfully orchestrated a remarkable coalition that brings together major corporate competitors, Government agencies and educational institutions. All have agreed to take part in the research necessary to create a fully integrated, high-speed national network of computers, possibly early in the next century, that will unleash a tremendous burst of scientific, educational and economic activity.
Such a national network - an information infrastructure, Dr. Kahn calls it, much like a national highway system for data - would make it possible to ship enormous amounts of information back and forth at what are called gigabit speeds (billions of bits of data per second), almost a thousand times faster than anyone using today's fastest electronic networks. 
Its planners say that once the network is completed, scientists, scholars, students, economists and business executives will have instant access to computerized libraries the size of the Library of Congress. The potential for hundreds of new businesses will be created and old ones will be energized by the emergence of a vast coast-to-coast electronic marketplace.
Doctors will have the assistance of artificially brilliant computer systems in treating patients; so will pharmaceutical companies, in designing drugs. Extremely clear sound will be transmitted cross-continent along with high-resolution television pictures on screens the size of an office or living-room wall. Business and personal travel - and the nation's voracious appetite for oil - may well begin to decline as such video becomes widely available for sales conferences, for example, or other kinds of interaction.
 
Setting the Seeds
In June, the National Science Foundation awarded Dr. Kahn's Corporation for National Research Initiatives $15.8 million to oversee the research on setting up five separate networks and experimenting with new hardware and software technologies. The grant is small, but Dr. Kahn believes it is not inappropriate to his approach, which is to start by seeding dozens of small, separate research efforts and then let the successful ones mature.
''We don't want to decide what the infrastructure will be,'' said Dr. Kahn. ''We want to be in the position of building experiments. The industry will learn enough lessons so that they will be able to do it right.''
Moreover, the National Science Foundation project has developed important funding commitments from many of the country's largest high-technology corporations. Although Dr. Kahn said it was impossible to offer an accurate estimate of private funding, several computer researchers on the project put corporate commitments at more than $300 million.
Government officials estimate the cost of building the entire national network reaching all American homes at more than $200 billion, an imposing price tag. But many economists, scientists and others, when asked about the cost, say the economic and, ultimately, the social benefits will exceed the costs by a large margin. ''It's the same question that you could ask if you were going to build a national highway system for the first time,'' said Erich Bloch, director of the National Science Foundation.
And the costs of not building it could conceivably be higher in the long run. America's principal economic competitors have already decided the investment is worth the risk. Japanese corporations have made a $20 billion commitment to building just such a network, and in France work has also begun on an ambitious national digital library. The positive side of the Asian and European commitment is that it may eventually lead to information-sharing on a worldwide basis.
 
In the Beginning
For Robert Kahn, 51 years old, the quest for a nationwide gigabit network began quietly enough. He was trained as an engineer, and, after starting what he thought would be a teaching career at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, decided he should take a year off to gain some ''real world'' experience. He arrived at Bolt Beranek & Newman, a Cambridge, Mass., think tank in 1968, just in time to participate in the design of the ARPAnet, the granddaddy of all computer networks.
ARPAnet turned out to be extraordinarily successful. It has now been replaced by an international web of almost 2,000 networks in 35 countries known as the Internet. In the past year, data traffic on its main pathway, NSFnet, has been 3.2 billion data packets a month and increasing at a monthly rate of 25 percent. The Internet is broadly similar to what Dr. Kahn and others envision as the network of the future. But it is very much slower - and speed will make all the difference, ultimately, in terms of the volume of information that can be easily shared.
It was from the ARPAnet project that Dr. Kahn acquired such strong feelings about network potential.
In 1972, he joined the Pentagon's Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA), where he would work for 13 years, using it as a vehicle to finance what he regarded as innovative research. That experience was to prove useful. Unlike many technology visionaries, Dr. Kahn is a down-to-earth, matter-of-fact person. No wild preoccupation with futuristic images of life now unknown. Instead, he devotes himself to the less flashy, to designing the basic ''plumbing'' for a project, plotting the details of how it would work - and, not incidentally, how it would be paid for.
The political infighting and bureaucratic barriers in Government were said to have taken their toll on him. That along with his realization of the need for broad coalition-building and his views of how money would have to be raised and carefully spent led Dr. Kahn to leave DARPA in 1985.
But the idea of raising enough money for a project as intangible as an information network was not easily accepted at first. ''In the beginning,'' he said, ''it wasn't clear how computer networks were going to be used. A lot of the research community originally thought I had gone off my rocker.'' John Seely Brown, a computer scientist at the Xerox Corporation, said, ''Funding infrastructure in general is hard, but when it's invisible it's even harder.''
And in recent years, Government officials and corporate executives alike have loudly debated the merits of paying for major initiatives to help create or to rescue one threatened institution or high-technology industry or another.
 
Jobs and Accessibility
 But Dr. Kahn argued to all who would listen, pointing out that the value of earlier generations of infrastructure has been easy to demonstrate: Roadways create jobs and move commerce; electrical power grids light the countryside, and the national telephone network is instantly accessible to all.
Now, after several frustrating years of making the rounds at high-technology computer, communications and software companies as well as on Capitol Hill, Dr. Kahn's vision has finally taken hold.
''I give him tremendous credit,'' said Robert W. Lucky, executive director of communications research at A.T.& T.'s Bell Laboratories. ''He had a vision . . . and even though it was a tough sell, he hung in there.''
Dr. Kahn has worked quietly in the background building the new partnership that includes computer giants like the International Business Machines Corporation and Cray Research Inc. and communications companies - the seven regional Bell operating companies and both A.T.&T. and the MCI Corporation - as well as many of the nation's best universities.
Surprisingly, for a figure who learned much of his effectiveness amid the political battling of Washington, he seems to be free of any band of detractors.
''Bob has had to forge working relationships between people who normally don't work together,'' said David Sincoskie, a communications engineer at Bellcore, the research arm of regional Bell operating companies.
''We have to build on what America does best and that rests on our capacity for innovation and on our diversity,'' said Dr. Brown of Xerox. ''The promise in this information highway is to provide a way to let groups of designers work together effectively.''
Senator Albert Gore Jr., Democrat of Tennessee, is one who has listened to these arguments. He has introduced a bill in Congress to provide $1.75 billion over three years to finance a data network that would link the nation's universities and supercomputer centers. The bill is believed to stand a strong chance of passage this year.
 
The Workings
Traditional telephone networks create the equivalent of a circuit, or a wire, between any two callers and must have enough wires to guarantee that most callers at peak hours can reach each other.
Data transmissions from one computer to another are automatically broken up into individual ''envelopes,'' like those sent to the post office, each with a separate address. The network hardware is then responsible for routing all envelopes and making sure they are assembled in the right order at their final destination. But with computers, there are dozens of pathways by which an envelope can be sent; if one pathway is busy, the envelope will simply be sent along another.
For Dr. Kahn, the components of an information infrastructure extend beyond the basics of computers and fiber-optic cables. Like a highway system - which requires gas stations, truck stops, intersections and traffic lights in addition to roadways - an information infrastructure will need specialized resources in addition to simple communications.
Dr. Kahn cites as an example the creation of a library system that would be computerized and connected but would not exist in one centralized computer. Instead, the nation's information would be located in widely separated specialized databases, which would range from yellow-page-type information stored in phone company computers, say, to geological fault figures stored in an oil-company or university mainframe.
A new class of sophisticated tools will have to be developed and used, such as knowledge robots, or ''knowbots,'' as Dr. Kahn calls them. These otherworldly creatures will have ravenous appetites for information. They will be sent on fact-finding missions for humans, traveling at almost the speed of light to the appropriate electronic destinations and searching through appropriate databases. Prototype knowbots have already been created in software designed by scientists at Dr. Kahn's N.R.I. and put to work, experimentally.
In addition, refined computer hardware will have to be produced to handle the communications speed of gigabit networks and the volume of data that will accumulate as knowbots scan all the paper books and research journals on a virtally endless list of topics.
The financial challenges seem scarcely less daunting than the technological ones. Some experts believe that, in addition to the current coalition of support, the infrastructure will have to start early on to help pay its own way. Michael L. Dertouzos, for one, director of the computer science laboratory at M.I.T., believes that the information marketplace will soon begin to grow so quickly that it will spew out revenues.
 
The Critical Mass
He describes applications such as reverse advertising, in which a consumer would demand a specific product or service and the computer network would locate it anywhere in the country. ''If you have small number of these services, it's not exciting,'' he said. ''But once you have a critical mass, it all goes bananas.''
Dr. Kahn and his partner computer scientist, Vinton G. Cerf, have explored a number of financial alternatives, including the possibility of taxing users or computer services. Dr. Cerf looks for parallels in the way in which the Government gave incentives to railroad builders, who received square-mile chunks of land where their lines ran. That might suggest, for example, that a communications company may be willing to lay out large sums of money to help build a high-speed information network - if, in return, it were to receive a franchise on some of the lucrative data services that would result.
''I keep looking for the square mile of the information age,'' said Dr. Cerf.
 
ARPAnet, GRANDDADDY OF THEM ALL
In the late 1960's, a small community of computer scientists with a vision of permitting scientists and engineers to share information instantly and easily, no matter where they were, came together under the Defense Department's Advanced Research Projects Agency. The idea was that, from a desk in Cambridge, Mass., a scientist would be able to use a supercomputer in Sunnyvale, Calif., as if it were in the next room. The result was dubbed ARPAnet.
Having a computer network that served both as a means for instantaneous communication among researchers and an experimental communications laboratory was a revolutionary notion.
Paul Baran, a scientist at the Rand Corporation in Santa Monica, Calif., who had been looking for ways to make telephone networks more reliable in the event of nuclear war, thought to break up digital messages into ''packets,'' each of which could be addressed electronically and sent by whatever route available to its destination.
J.C.R. Licklider, a psychologist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, worked on linking computers. Bolt Beranek & Newman, a Cambridge, Mass., think tank won the 1968 contract to design a network.
The original ARPAnet was built around small computers (terminal interface processors), which handled connections with slow dial-up terminals, and separate message-passing computers, interface message processors. Each IMP would be connected to another IMP on a leased phone line and be capable of sending and receiving at what then seemed like very high speeds. Today's networks routinely carry data at 20 times that speed; tomorrow's, it is thought, will make it 700 times that speed.
The first ARPAnet node was installed at the University of California at Los Angeles in late 1969. By the following year, it had arrived at Harvard and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
ARPAnet became the first computer network in the nation, and in it, each computer was an equal partner. That ''peer-to-peer'' concept remains the fundamental idea in networking.
To be at an ARPAnet site was to be among an elite, and academic job offers were weighed with that in mind. After all, would a research microbiologist accept a job at a school with no microscopes?
 
 THE MOTIVAITONS OF DR.KAHN
In 1985, frustrated with the bureaucratic limitations and infighting inherent in a Government agency, Robert E. Kahn set out to do what no one else was doing in this country.
A year later, he formed the Corporation for National Research Initiatives, hoping to raise $1 billion and to act as cross between the Japanese Ministry of International Trade and Industry (a model of government-private coordination fostering business and technology) and such small-scale, private American efforts as the Microelectronics and Technology Corporation that attempt to ''push technology forward.''
So far, Dr. Kahn's organization has fallen short of its original goal, but he has created an important model for building new infrastructure critical for American competitiveness.
At the Pentagon's Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, Dr. Kahn had guided the financing of computer-science research. Since the 1960's, DARPA had served as a supporter of projects as diverse as research that led to personal computers and inquiries into areas such as artificial intelligence and speech recognition.
But during the 80's, DARPA's freedom to fund pure research was increasingly curtailed by political pressures that dictated that Pentagon-funded research be closely linked to weapon systems.
In response, Dr. Kahn's computer section fashioned an ambitious project, the Strategic Computing Initiative, to design robot tanks and artificial-intelligence systems to help with advanced-weapons deployment.
But many of the nation's best computer scientists resisted the idea of working directly on high-technology weapons.
The strains encouraged Dr. Kahn, scientist by training, Government project manager for more than a decade, into the role of independent entrepreneur with a difference. His company is strictly nonprofit.

HEADLINE: The Executive Life;
Where's the Barbarian? Where's the Gate?

BYLINE: By NANCY MARX BETTER: Nancy Marx Better is a New York-based writer who frequently covers business.

 BODY:
Several months ago, one Harvard Business School student near the top of his class accepted a summer internship with a prominent Wall Street investment bank. Before arriving in New York, he devoured ''Barbarians at the Gate'' and ''Liar's Poker,'' the twin bibles of Wall Street's corporate culture. He braced himself for the industry's frantic pace and for the dizzying whirl of cocktail parties and recruiting dinners he expected to attend.
''I thought I had a pretty good idea of what I was getting into,'' he said. 
From Memorial Day to Labor Day, he crunched numbers and proofread documents. He became fluent in the language of red herrings, pro forma statements and Securities and Exchange Commission filings. He saw most of the things he'd heard about from his friends who had worked on Wall Street - that is, everything but a live deal.
''We kept putting books together on different companies and waiting for a response,'' said the intern, referring to the process of preparing a company for sale. ''But we never closed anything while I was there.''
Indeed, it has been a long, dry summer on Wall Street - the kind where investment bankers have headed for the Hamptons before Friday noon, cellular telephones and laptops in tow but often left untouched. What has been a time of belt-tightening for industry veterans has been one of soul-searching for summer associates - students between their first and second year of business school.
These future recruits were weaned on stories of Mike Milken, Henry Kravis and Bruce Wasserstein. And they still earn as much as interns did before the stock market crash of 1987: about $15,000 for 10 weeks, as much as first-year associates get before bonuses. But their first brush with the high life has been decidedly low-rolling.
''A lot of people went into investment banking in the 80's because they wanted to be Masters of the Universe,'' said a student at Yale's School of Management who insisted on anonymity. (Since the insider-trading scandals, most firms have prohibited junior employees from talking to the press.) ''Now, the reputation of the business has come down to earth. It's hard to be a hero if your firm isn't doing a lot of deals and making a lot of money.''
With mergers and acquisitions - keystones of the business - dampened by a slumping economy and August's devastated markets, few B-school students spent the summer elbow to elbow with corporate captains as they have in the past. Some firms had so little work that interns were put on waiting lists to get assignments. ''At one point there were about 10 people ahead of me,'' said one M.B.A. at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. ''We sat around and watched the World Cup soccer tournament on TV.'' Shearson denies this.
When there was business, it often consisted of ''transaction development'' - drumming up new deals. Other interns worked on restructurings, repairing the mistakes made by the heros of yesteryear, and on Chapter 11 bankruptcy filings.
During their free time, they hit the recruiting circuit - with disappointing results. ''Being a summer associate on Wall Street used to be a three-month-long party,'' said one Wharton student. ''You used to be able to go out every night. It's definitely not that way anymore.''
Gone, for the most part, are the sunset cruises around Manhattan, orchestra-seat tickets to Broadway shows and four-course meals at chic restaurants that firms have traditionally held for recruitment purposes for all summer interns, Wall Streetwide.
Investment banks today are hosting smaller, more subdued affairs. This summer, the Morgan Stanley Group Inc., for one, invited Wharton students for drinks at the Central Park Zoo and Harvard students for billiards at an Upper West Side pool club. That is a bit bland compared with the blowouts it had been known for in the past. In the summer of 1987, before the crash, the firm took a group of Stanford M.B.A.'s to the harness races at the Meadowlands in New Jersey to gamble.
Some firms have cut back on evening functions in favor of power breakfasts in their boardrooms. Other are prescreening candidates before entertaining them. ''It used to be that everyone got invited everywhere,'' said the Wharton student. ''Now they don't want to spend money unless they think you're really serious.''
Robert Scalise, director of career placement at the Harvard Business School, explains: ''They don't want their ability to throw parties to be the reason somebody goes to work for them. Since they're not hiring as much, they want to take a targeted approach instead of a shotgun approach.''
Mr. Scalise says the new recruits are taking a contrarian approach. ''There's a feeling among these students that if you're really good, you can make a difference,'' Mr. Scalise said. ''When an industry's in the pits, they think that's the time to go in. That's why investment banking remains so attractive.''
In general, employers appreciate this attitude. ''The students are much more realistic,'' said Collette Gardner, a vice president at the Bankers' Trust company. ''They're asking about long-term career objectives instead of how much money they're going to make the first year.''
But there are those who miss the killer instinct in new recruits. ''The associates we had this summer weren't as aggressive as those of the past,'' said one mergers-and-acquisitions specialist. ''They didn't have a warrior attitude like we did. The guys who came in with me were ready to bite the head off a chicken if they had to.''

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Accepting the Risk in Forecasting

BYLINE: By PETER SCHWARTZ; Peter Schwartz is president of Global Business Network, a strategic consulting firm in Berkeley Calif., and author of ''The Art of the Longview.''

 BODY:
Tens of billions of dollars were wasted in the 1980's by investing in the wrong future. More will be lost in the decades to come. One of the costliest examples was the collapse of the synthetic fuels industry. Energy companies and the United States Government first spent billions of dollars on the false assumption that oil prices would endlessly rise only to cancel their efforts when prices fell. They failed to understand the oil roller coaster. Now that Saddam Hussein has set off another price rise, we wish we had the option of producing synthetic fuel. There have been other recent forecasting disasters as well.
New ways of thinking and gaining strategic insight can help us overcome the two main obstacles to getting the future right. 
First, most organizations - and individuals - engage mainly in introverted thinking. Their perceptions are shaped by a narrow range of contacts and are mostly reinforced by the limited views of their peers. As people work together they share an unconscious desire to see a favorable outcome as the most likely outcome.
Second, these limits to thinking are further constrained by the desire to have a single-line forecast - the price of a barrel of oil in 1995, for example - or at least a most likely scenario. But the real world is inescapably uncertain. Clinging to the illusion of certainty increases the vulnerability to unfortunate surprises.
Scenario planning is one tool useful for dealing with this problem. Scenarios are simply stories about the way the future might unfold. They emphasize the logic behind events and are not intended as forecasts. They are exercises that can help managers plan and prepare for uncertainty by offering them a glimpse of several different futures. Investors, managers, the military and people in government could have benefited from constructing several different scenarios about Iraq's intentions after the conclusion of its war with Iran.
The Royal Dutch/Shell Group - where I was head of business environment - was ahead of most companies in thinking about the future. Shell anticipated the oil price increases of the 1970's and the collapse of the 1980's. Shell used this information to build new refineries before oil prices rose and to postpone the purchase of new oil fields until prices fell back down. How did we do it?
Shell did not have more facts than anyone else. The same data we had was available to many other companies in the oil industry. Nor did Shell seek a better way of producing a forecast. Rather, Shell's approach was to systematically gather as much information as possible from sources outside the company. This information was then used to produce several different scenarios for the future of the oil and gas industry.
In 1984, before President Mikhail S. Gorbachev came to power, our group at Shell examined the future of the Soviet Union and how it would respond to its mounting economic problems. We decided to look at the Soviet Union because it was one of Shell's main competitors in the European gas market. One of the scenarios took the view that the Soviet Union would undergo radical political and economic reform and end its hold on Eastern Europe. With political tensions reduced, it could gain some competitive advantage in selling gas to Europe. Because this scenario was only one of several, it could be considered seriously.
Many managers, in business and government, prefer the illusion of certainty to the understanding of risks and realities. How can they then be blamed if the forecaster fails? Scenarios that illuminate uncertainty can help management prepare for the future as it unfolds. It is the ability to act confidently with a knowledgeable sense of risk and reward that distinguishes a business executive from a bureaucrat or a gambler.

HEADLINE: MESSAGE FROM SADDAM;
Curiously, a Dictator Forces the Middle East to Ponder Democracy

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
DEMOCRACY has had many strange midwives.
Wars, social upheavals and economic dislocations have all at one time or another given birth to democratic movements. And now maybe the strangest midwife of all has appeared. A bizarre byproduct of Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait is that it has begun to stir a debate - both in the Middle East and in Washington - about democracy in the Arab world. It is still a nascent and unformed debate, and it may lead nowhere, as have other such stirrings in the past. But there is no denying that the Arab nation, which has slumbered through glasnost and perestroika and all the popular revolutions from Berlin to Bucharest, is asking itself some new and fundamental questions precisely because of the storm unleashed by the Iraqi dictator. 
''There is no doubt that Saddam Hussein is the wrong man with the wrong method, but he may have come at the right time,'' said Nawaf Salam, a prominent Lebanese intellectual and Harvard University researcher who watched from his home in Beirut as the Iraqi invasion unfolded. ''What his invasion of Kuwait did was put all the fundamental and forgotten questions in the region on the table. First of all: money. What you could see in Beirut this summer was a whole new awareness of how much oil wealth some of these little gulf states really had amassed. If you asked people a month ago what size were the fortunes of the emirs, they could not tell you. But now people are aware. They talk about $900 billion in petrodollars invested by the gulf states abroad, at a time when Egyptians are hungry, Syrians are bankrupt and Lebanon is destroyed.''
This awarness, in turn, has raised more sharply than ever the questions of who controls this great wealth and why. Said Mr. Salam: ''People are asking, 'Why should 200 Kuwaiti princes control 20 percent of the world's oil?' No wonder that one of the solutions Arabs are talking about for Kuwait is elections. If real elections and a real democratic republic were the outcome in Kuwait, then one could say that this was a welcome crisis. It could transform the whole gulf.''
It may already have done so. Even if Iraq evacuated Kuwait tomorrow, few can imagine the Emir of Kuwait, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah - who fled to Saudi Arabia by helicopter soon after the Iraqis invaded - returning to power with business as usual, with the distribution of wealth in Kuwait the same, with the Kuwaitis who stayed behind to fight and resist saying: ''Please, Mr. Emir, here is your palace back. Thank you. Now we will go back to our tents.'' The poor Arab states, such as Egypt and Syria, which have also fought for Kuwait, will also present their bills for a new distribution of wealth. And if there is change in Kuwait, what will be the spillover next door in Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, Qatar, and the United Arab Emirates, all of which have even more conservative feudal systems?
These questions are no less fundamental for the Bush Administration. President Bush has declared that one of the four objectives of America's intervention in the Persian Gulf is that ''Kuwait's legitimate Government must be restored,'' and he has several times specified that this meant a return to power of Kuwait's exiled tribal monarchs, the al-Sabah family. But that is a position with which many in Congress find themselves increasingly uncomfortable.
Representative Lee H. Hamilton, the Indiana Democrat who is chairman of the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on the Middle East, said: ''I know that I and many of my colleagues are hesitant about lining up with tribal monarchies and identifying our interests with them. I personally would not want to make it one of the United States' objectives that we restore the al-Sabah family. That would put us in conflict with the worldwide trend toward democracy, as well as with our own democratic values. We have to recognize that one of the spinoffs of this crisis is that it is going to put stress on all the traditional monarchies from Jordan to Saudi Arabia.''
In fairness, the al-Sabahs have always been the most progressive of the gulf monarchies. Historically, Kuwait, blessed with the only natural deep-water bay in the Persian Gulf, was a desert outpost whose Bedouin tribesmen made their living from pearl diving and fishing until oil was discovered at the outset of World War II. Its local politics has been dominated by the al-Sabah clan since 1756. The al-Sabahs' ascent and continuation in power were partly products of their own industry and partly products of their cooperation with the British, who installed them as Kuwait's first independent rulers when Her Majesty's Government relinquished its control there in 1961. Two years later, the House of al-Sabah allowed the establishment of a National Assembly to advise it on governing the country. The al-Sabahs also allowed for a relatively free press, which rankled their gulf neighbors. But every time parliamentarians or editors became too obstreperous the Emir would dissolve the assembly or shut down the newspaper. Kuwait's independent Parliament, the only freely elected representative body in the gulf region, was last suspended in 1986.
What Washington should do about the al-Sabahs is not purely a philosophical question. If the gulf crisis continues to move from the battle lines into the diplomatic bazaar, as it has been moving for the last week, it is likely that the fate of the al-Sabahs will become a centerpiece of negotiations. It is easily imaginable that at some point over the next few weeks or months, as economic sanctions really begin to bite, President Hussein could say to his Arab neighbors: ''My brothers, I am ready to withdraw my army from Kuwait, but you don't expect me to leave empty-handed. You know I can't do that. I need some compensation, something to save face.''
No doubt he would ask for an oil well and an island or two. No doubt these would be rejected by the other Arabs and the West. But what if the Iraqi leader asked only for a new ''popular'' government in Kuwait, one more representative of the people and more sympathetic to Iraqi concerns? That is an offer that many Arab governments might leap at in order to defuse this crisis, which, if it comes to war, could topple them as well.
It is clear that such a possibility is already in the back of President Bush's mind. Lately, he has refrained from mentioning the al-Sabahs, and last week he even remarked that whether the Kuwaiti ruling family remains in power is ''a matter for the Kuwaitis to decide.''
''If the Americans insist that the al-Sabahs must return, then what does that say about Washington's committment to democracy?'' asked Samir Khalaf of Princeton University, an expert on social change in the Arab world. ''But if they don't support the return of the al-Sabahs, then how do they justify the preservation of the House of Saud? The al-Sabahs have no fewer palaces than the Saudis. If the only reason the Americans are involved in the gulf is oil, that is bad. I hope it is more. I hope it is to create a political atmosphere there to bolster democracy. I hope that they are at least listening to the voices that Saddam Hussein has inadvertently given vent to.''
But that is a ticklish question. Among the President's four objectives in the gulf there is no mention of promoting democracy. Besides rolling back the Iraqis, restoring the Kuwaiti Government and protecting American lives, the President said, the United States seeks to preserve the ''security and stability of the Persian Gulf.'' In the last 50 years the United States, whatever its oratory, has tended to support democracy when it serves the interests of stability and to back away from insisting on it when it could destabilize an area of national interest. At stake in the gulf is the stability of oil supplies and the need to preserve the sanctity of borders so that the post-cold war world will not devolve into chaos. American troops are not passing out Arabic translations of the Constitution. To expect the United States to begin promoting democracy in the Arab world may be a bit too much to ask.
''Let us be honest, democracy just isn't on the menu in the Arab world today,'' said Fouad Ajami, an expert on Arab intellectual thought at the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies. ''What you have in the Arab world today is either the rule of the monarchs or the rule of the tyrants, the rule of kings or the rule of army officers. With Lebanon gone, there is no democractic 'third way.' In the monarchies like Kuwait, the social contract was that the ruler ruled and the citizen made money and minded his own business. It was not democracy, but it fit these tribal societies. There was a softness to them, a respect for limits, and men led lives of dignity.''
In places such as Syria or Iraq the social contract was quite different. There, Mr. Ajami said, ''the rulers ruled and the citizens cowered for their very lives.'' While the emirs and sheiks just wanted to do business quietly, the Saddam Husseins and the Hafez al-Assads were selling political utopias, Arab nationalist visions, the pursuit of which justified mass murder. In the Syrias and Iraqs, the presidential seals might as well read: Rule or Die. One man triumphs, the others weep.
To think that the debate ignited by the Iraqi invasion could easily overturn either of these systems - the monarchical or the dictatorial - and replace it with pluralistic democracy would be naive. The resources of the modern Arab state to survive in its two basic forms are enormous. Money, overlapping intelligence services, brute force and cunning have produced a remarkably stable generation of Arab regimes: Algeria's President Chadli Benjedid has been in office since 1979, Egypt's Hosni Mubarak since 1981, Saddam Hussein since 1979, Libya's Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi since 1969, Morocco's King Hassan II since 1961, Syria's President Hafez al-Assad since 1971, Jordan's King Hussein since 1953.
But there is a difference in this crisis, and it may yet produce real change. The discontent it has exposed is not simply something cooked up by intellectuals. The crisis has put out of work thousands upon thousands of Arabs - Egyptians, Syrians, Lebanese, Palestinians, Algerians - who had depended on employment in Iraq and the gulf oil states. All have returned home nursing grievances and starved for jobs. Combine their existence with the fact that all the old Arab ideologies - socialism, fundamentalism, Nasserism - have been discredited, and it makes a very potent force for social change.
The other new factor is the unprecedented involvement of the United States in the Arab world. Americans find it easier to support non-democratic governments when they are not fighting and dying for them. That was a big problem in Vietnam. So if shooting starts in the gulf, or even if the United States finds itself deeply and expensively involved there for months or years, Americans are going to begin asking a lot of questions about these regimes for which they are sacrificing. Before this crisis is over President Bush will probably have to have a long talk with America's Arab allies, to let them know that Saddam Hussein has served a warrant on their societies and that while the United States does not expect them to become Jeffersonian democracies overnight, some sort of change is necessary - for their own sakes as well as for Washington's. From that perspective, the Saudis, Egyptians, Syrians and others might wind up more scared of George Bush than of Saddam Hussein.
When Mr. Hussein invaded Kuwait, one of the first things he did was change the name of the main hospital there from the Al-Sabah Hospital to the Saddam Hussein Hospital. He has an affection for buildings named after himself, but then so too did the al-Sabahs. Is the only choice in the Arab world really between these two alternatives, the benevolent monarchs and the cruel dictators? For Americans, such questions have been either nonexistent or tertiary. But for most Arabs on the street, these are the real issues raised by the gulf crisis - not oil prices, not the sanctity of borders and certainly not abstractions about the post-cold war order.
If the Arabs can find a ''third way,'' then the gulf crisis will be remembered by them as a catalyst for positive change. If they cannot, than it will only serve to highlight a region that never changes. The desert poets will recite that the storm came and the storm passed and the Arab East stayed the same.

HEADLINE: What America Did After the War: A Tale Told by the Census

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER

 BODY:
THOUGH foggy as a steamed-up bathroom mirror, the early 1990 census figures released last week offered the country its first look at itself as it emerged from the 1980's: the sagging cities, spreading suburbs, and the southern coasts and the Southwestern states bulging with economic and political muscle.
The legacies of the decade were in many ways similar to those of the 1970's, though Asian and Latin American immigrants gave the population a less homogeneous cast. But the census tends to narrow the demographic gaze to 10-year stretches. It is over the last 40 years that the most profound changes have emerged as America has become a different country, gaining about 99 million people along the way.
Beginning in 1950, a nation of 150,697,000 began to follow the sun. Over the next four decades, it paved 42,798 miles of Interstate highways, bought 300 million cars, and went for a ride. First the South headed north, then the North headed south, but always, the East headed west. 
At the start of the postwar era, America was a land of high-rise cities with farms not far distant. Though the farms were staggering and collapsing from the lingering wounds of the Depression, 23 million Americans - 15 percent -lived on them, and 30 million others lived in communities of fewer than 2,500 people. That was one-third of the country. The vast majority of the rest were urbanites: New Yorkers, Bostonians, Chicagoans, Detroiters, Clevelanders, milling steel and making cars.
In the end, the country's profile was dominated by the suburbs and what came to be called the sun belt. California, whose population was the size of Pennsylvania's in 1950, is now home to at least 29.2 million people, and it is 70 percent bigger than New York, the next largest state.
In 1950, Florida was a marshy expanse of land, home to 2.77 million people - ranking 21st in the country. Last week's preliminary census figures gave it 12.7 million people, which puts it fourth in the nation.
Four decades ago, Texas had about 1.59 million people, slightly more than Oregon. By 1990, the state had grown nearly fivefold, its 16.8 million or more people putting it in third place. Nearly one in five of its residents, or 3.7 million in 1985, was Hispanic, more than double the number 20 years before, the first year the census looked for Hispanics.
Wherever people chose to migrate, the kinds of communities in which they settled quickly began to change.
It was not only rural areas that faded but also the factory towns that once seemed so invincible. The world of ''The Last Picture Show'' began giving way to the world of ''Roger and Me.'' At the same time, new kinds of communities thrived, as the Levittowns were going gray, malls were going bust and retirement communities - designed for 31 million Americans 65 and over - moved away from employment centers, up into the mountains and out to the seashore.
As much as anything, the cold war was an engine of change. Starting in the 1950's, the Interstate highways were built, the better to maintain military mobility. The young were told to stay in school and learn science, the better to beat the Russians in space. The distance between home and work grew, the percentage of high school and college diplomas in the population increased.
The defense and aerospace companies of Southern California - Lockheed, McDonnell Douglas, Hughes Aircraft, TRW - expanded, jobs drawing people drawing new jobs. In 1963, 27 percent of the equipment the Defense Department bought - planes, guidance systems, missiles - was made in California. The state's share of defense contracts dwindled almost to 20 percent in the late 1970's, until President Reagan's Star Wars program helped push it back up to 27 percent in the mid-1980's.
Well-educated Americans were more mobile and California was a good place to move. With the change in the immigration laws in 1965, Asian immigrants - tens of thousands in the 1970's, hundreds of thousands in the 1980's - found California a logical place to go.
It was in the semiconductor industry of Santa Clara County, south of San Francisco Bay, that many first- and second-generation Asian immigrants found a home. According to Lenny Siegal, an economist for the Pacific Studies Center in Palo Alto, about 40 percent of manufacturing jobs in Silicon Valley are held by Asians. About 12 percent of the county's population is of Asian descent.
Over those same years in the rest of the country, the era of the small farmers hastened toward a long twilight. By the end of the 1980's, with tighter credit and droughts, fewer than five million Americans - less than 2 percent - lived on farms. The brief renewal of the 1970's was over, and rural America found itself a land fewer and fewer people wanted to live in.
The new unit of human habitation, the suburb, was instantly recogniz-able to everyone, but almost impossible for demographers to define. Suburbs began in the 1940's as fringe communities around central cities, in something the Census Bureau called a ''metropolitan area.'' In the 1960's, there was as much fringe as city, and still they continued to devour farmland.
Periodically the Census Bureau would change the nomenclature and the contours of metropolitan areas in a futile scramble to capture the swarming suburbs. Nearly four Americans in five now live in metropolitan areas, often in communities that call themselves cities, but have the flat silhouette of the suburbs. After sheltering the biggest generation of children in the country's history, the houses emptied out. After the 1980's fewer people lived in each house and developers enjoyed a boom. Over 40 years, the number of homes grew nearly half again as fast as the number of people.
Put 40 years of life in DeSoto County, Miss., on fast-forward and you can see America turning inside out. In 1950, within the barbed-wire fences that enclosed cotton fields stretching eastward from the Missisippi River, lived 24,599 people. Two-thirds were black. Virtually all were farmers. There was no industry other than the land. Memphis, the nearest big city, was 40 miles distant, another way of life.
The new preliminary census counts give DeSoto County a population of 67,124, not quite triple what it had been. During the 1960's, Interstate 55 pushed south through the county, bringing Memphis with it. DeSoto County is now part of the Memphis metropolitan area. ''When you drive into it, you'd never realize you've gone from one state to another or one town to another,'' said Bill Smith, an economic analyst for the Center for Policy Research and Planning in Jackson, Miss. ''The small farms have been almost wiped out.''
There are still farms but most often the fields are planted with houses. There are small factories making elevators and armored cars, concrete and security lights. The black farmers and some of their white neighbors, Mr. Smith said, almost certainly went north - to Chicago, Detroit, Cleveland, to steel, to cars, to inner cities.
The number of black college graduates went from 125,000 in 1950 to about 2 million in the late 1980's, according to the political scientist Ben J. Wattenberg. As that number peaked, demographers were beginning to pick up the first signs that another generation of blacks was beginning to head back to the South, to work in the expanding service industries.
Other trends, too, paused in their headlong rush. Divorce rates, which almost doubled between 1950 and 1985, began to decline slightly in the late 1980's. Women, while continuing to move out of the home and into the workplace, started having babies again after a decade's postponement.
The number of births, which reached a postwar low in 1974, topped the 4-million mark in 1989, a number nearly equal to the high point of the baby boom in the mid-1960's. A growing number of children are born to interracial couples, currently about 3 percent of all births.
''We are going to be the model for other pluralist nations,'' said Mr. Wattenberg, whose forthcoming book is called ''The First Universal Nation.''
''On balance, this is a great development, although it will cause a lot of turbulence,'' he said. But no more turbulence than the latter half of the century has already brought.

An article last Sunday about the 1990 census misstated the 1950 population of Texas. It was 7.7 million, not 1.59 million.

LENGTH: 1523 words

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
More Oil from more PLaces Could Loosen Gulf's Grip

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
TO many Americans, it's clear enough why Saddam Hussein must be stopped: Such a man cannot be permitted to control the oil lifeline to the world's industrialized nations. But even if Mr. Hussein were to retire to Switzerland tomorrow, the West's dependence on the Persian Gulf - and thus its vulnerability to conflict in the Middle East - would continue to grow.
That is why many analysts believe that as long as the West depends on oil, it would be worth a considerable investment to undercut the gulf region's near-monopoly on oil exports. The most promising sources of competition: Latin America and the Soviet Union, regions with a lot of oil and an urgent need for every extra dollar they can earn from exports.
World oil reserves totaled about 640 billion barrels in 1980, roughly a 30-year supply. A decade later, with new discoveries, reserves of oil in the ground are estimated at a trillion barrels, while world consumption has hardly changed. But paradoxically the Arab noose on oil consumers is tighter than ever. 
In the 1970's, notes Daniel Yergin, the head of Cambridge Energy Research Associates, the West could look forward to fresh gushes of crude from the North Sea, Mexico and Alaska. But in the 1980's virtually all the new finds were in the Persian Gulf; the combined reserves of the two largest consuming nations - the United States and the Soviet Union -have actually slipped by a tenth. Today Saudi Arabia, Abu Dhabi, Iraq, Iran and Kuwait can lay claim to 63 percent of the known remaining petroleum.
Importers could reduce dependence on foreign oil by curbing energy consumption, switching to more secure fuels or redoubling efforts to squeeze oil from spent domestic fields. But the pickins' are not nearly as easy as they once were.
 
The West Cuts Back
Higher market prices, higher fuel taxes and conservation regulation have reduced the amount of energy used per unit of output in the West. America's gross national product has increased by 52 percent since 1973; energy consumption has increased by just 9 percent. But while further energy conservation is certainly possible - a doubling of auto mileage would save America about two million barrels of oil a day - the gains would be costly.
Nor does domestic production offer much hope. Billions of barrels of oil have yet to be extracted from older domestic fields as well as from the few virgin fields left in Europe and North America. But some of this oil is in ecologically sensitive areas and most of the rest would be very expensive to recover.
By the same token, the cheapest and easiest opportunities for fuel substitution have already been exploited. The expansion of coal and nuclear power face daunting political and environmental barriers. And while natural gas is clean, the cost of weaning cars and trucks from oil would be awesome. Replacing or converting 200 million vehicles at an average cost of, say, $5,000 would run to $1 trillion, and that's only the beginning. No one knows how much it would cost to provide the natural gas for even a fraction of a converted fleet.
And without a long-term policy, a short-term plan to curb American consumption and encourage American production, as the Energy Department announced last week, the difference would be minor.
True independence from Persian Gulf oil is thus an impossible dream, most experts acknowledge. What may be possible, however, is to arrest the growth of imports from the region by increasing production in other parts of the world.
Diversification of supply is, in itself, a virtue. The smaller the percentage of oil coming from any one place, the less the risk that war or embargo (as in 1973-74) or revolution (as in 1979-80) could create a damaging shortage. But equally important to Western energy security, asserts Philip Verleger, an economist at the Institute for International Economics, is the development of production capacity in economies with an unquenchable demand for cash to finance domestic growth.
 
Distribution of Oil
Saudi Arabia is already easily capable of doubling the amount of oil it pumps; another big oil discovery would thus be unlikely to increase Saudi exports. Nigeria or Mexico or China, by contrast, need every dollar they can scrounge. Extra capacity there is likely to translate reliably into extra production.
The catch is that oil producers outside the Persian Gulf already have substantial incentives to increase output. The fact that they have not usually means that they cannot - at least not without help from foreign friends, and the West has been reluctant to extend that help on terms exporters will accept.
No real change is in the works - the United States, the natural leader, has yet to indicate its willingness to lead. But ideas for diversifying oil supplies have been discussed at the international lending agencies and the Department of Energy, for decades, and in the wake of the Iraq crisis, attitudes seem ripe for change.
 
The Debt Logjam
Send Money
This year about 10 percent of the remaining oil will be pumped from American and British fields.
Mexico, by contrast, will pump about 2 percent of its oil, and Venezuela only 1 percent. The lower rate of extraction in the third world is in part linked to restrictions by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, in part to decisions to husband resources for future generations. But mostly it reflects a lack of capital and expertise.
State-owned oil companies in Latin America, notably in heavily indebted Mexico, Argentina and Venezuela, cannot borrow from foreign banks to pay for the expansion. Nor do they have the technology to develop offshore reserves.
The World Bank and other multilateral lenders could fill the gap. But they have been reluctant to redirect scarce cash from other projects, arguing that help would be available from private oil companies.
Opposition to direct foreign investment in oil runs deep throughout Latin America, and in Mexico is an icon of the nation's liberation from colonialism. But as one London-based oil executive put it, ''the old demonology is passing.''
The Latin oil producers might well accept foreign partners some day. Western governments might speed the courtship by guaranteeing that private investments in oil would not be lost to expropriation. They might also guarantee a future market by swapping existing debts denominated in dollars for promises to deliver petroleum. A debt-for-oil deal was used by the United States to carry Mexico through a financial crisis in the early 80's.
 
High-Risk Development
Unwanted Oil
Roughly half the oil in Latin America is in Venezuela, and much of that is too heavy to be extracted with ordinary equipment or converted to fuel in conventional refineries.
But Venezuela is not likely to find private investors to put up billions for projects that would not turn a profit unless oil remains in the $25 to $30 range.
Importing countries could ease the capital squeeze by guaranteeing a break-even price for the heavy oil to be delivered a decade hence. If market prices did not hold up, the buyers would of course lose a lot of money. But the importers might still get their money's worth in energy security if the deal were part of a broader agreement committing Venezuela to a substantial increase in production of conventional oil.
 
The Soviet Union
More, Comrade
The Soviet Union is the world's largest oil producer. But it burns most of what it pumps, exporting just one-third of its 12 million barrel daily output. And according to Chuck Movit, an analyst at PlanEcon in Washington, output, which peaked in the late 1980's, is now in free fall: production will probably be no greater in 1991 than it was in 1979.
Reversing the trend would be no easy matter: Soviet oil fields were badly damaged by exploitation in the 1980's. And there is an acute shortage of sophisticated machinery, the consequence of the general decline in Soviet industrial production and a crash effort to increase the availability of consumer goods. So Western capital and technology might make a big difference. Some joint ventures with foreign oil companies are already in the works, and although it is not yet under serious consideration, the way could probably be greased with subsidies and easing transfers on nonmilitary technology.
But as Morris Adelman, professor emeritus at M.I.T. argues, the cheapest barrel of oil in the Soviet Union is the barrel not consumed. Enormous amounts of energy are wasted because there is no incentive to conserve it. Aid to buy energy-efficient equipment might help. It surely would if it were tied to internal price reforms that forced consumers to pay the real cost of the oil diverted from exports.
Any extraordinary effort to increase oil exports from non-Arab sources would require leadership and money from America. ''It's hard to see our Government doing this sort of thing,'' said Daniel Yergin of Cambridge Energy. But then, it was hard to imagine a year ago that President Bush would be sending thousands of Americans to the Persian Gulf to keep Saddam Hussein in the corral.

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
How New England Loved Real Estate and Lost

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

DATELINE: HARTFORD

 BODY:
THE image of New England that was beamed out to the larger world in the 1980's was that of an economy in fighting form, brawny and booming, with high technology and high finance leading the march toward some glorious new era for the country's original industrial heartland.
But hindsight shows holes in that picture. As prosperity has receded across the Northeast, some economists have concluded that what looked like a hearty hybrid of old industry and new was more like a hot-house flower that bloomed briefly, if brilliantly, in an artificial environment of easy money, speculation and unwarranted optimism.
At the core of the revisionist view is real estate. Although it was clear during the peak years of the mid-1980's that developers and construction crews were changing the face of the region - especially in cities like Hartford, where the amount of downtown office space tripled in just 10 years - the prevailing attitude then was that all the building and real estate lending were simply a reflection of economic health. 
For a while, this was the case. The military buildup that began in the late 1970's and the spurt of growth in the computer-industry corridor around Boston heralded a new era. The swelling profits at banks and insurance companies seemed to be another sign, if one was needed, that good times were here to stay.
But in the period that most people would probably identify as the best of times - roughly 1984 to 1988 - New England's economic base, especially manufacturing, was already in decline. The six-state region lost nearly 56,000 manufacturing jobs in 1986 alone, for example, according to DRI/McGraw Hill, an economic consulting firm in Massachusetts.
The effect of those losses, however, was ''masked,'' according to a study recently published by the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, and only became apparent in 1989, when construction fell and overall employment leveled off. Between 1984 and 1988, construction employment alone rose an average of 8.8 percent a year in the six New England states, the study said. In 1986, in an atmosphere where many people believed that the production of ideas, information and services represented the economic future, the region gained a total of 166,000 jobs even while it lost 56,000 in manufacturing.
What was happening, economists say, was the equivalent of forgoing a balanced if boring meal in favor of a plate full of candy bars. Manufacturing jobs make an economy grow, albeit slowly. Real estate, with its effects on law and banking - not to mention the restaurants and car dealerships where people splurged - can make an economy bounce off the walls.
''The last five years of the boom were cooked,'' said Edward Moscovitch, a Massachusetts economist who wrote the study for the Federal Reserve Bank.
What made the influence of real estate harder to track at the time, according to economists and bank regulators, was that so much of the regional economy, in varying ways, had beenpulled into the spiral. In much the same heady way that people discussed the soaring values of their homes, banks expanded their real-estate lending and hiring. Law firms were thriving on all the transactions, and they were hiring, too.
Another contributing factor came from Wall Street. Beginning about 1983, hundreds of small savings banks and savings and loans across the country went public and offered shares on the market. At the same time, however, each had to get higher returns on its investments to stay competitive. That called for real estate lending.
At many banks, the growth in real estate investment dovetailed with other temptations like junk bond trading and mergers. ''There was a dropping of traditional standards,'' said Robert F. Miailovich, assistant director of the division of bank supervision at the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. ''Everything was coming up roses and people forgot certain principles.''
The results of the economy's unmasking can be measured in dollars lost and dreams dashed. Hartford, for example, has lost about 40 percent of its downtown hotel rooms over the last nine months. Across wide stretches of Massachusetts, condominium developments sit empty, some of them abandoned and incomplete.
In New Hampshire, applications for food stamps have jumped 54 percent in the last year, the sharpest jump of any state in the country. A survey about consumer confidence, conducted last month by the Conference Board, a business-backed group, showed that New England residents had the most dismal view about the economy since records began in 1981.
Yet New England has not done a Texas-style bellyflop - a point that many people across the Northeast repeat like a mantra - and economists say the differences between the two areas are as important as the parallels.
Unlike the Southwest, which rode to prosperity on the soaring price of oil in the early 1980's, the Northeast did not see signficant population increases - in part because of high housing prices. According to preliminary census figures, the populations of Connecticut, Massachusetts and New Jersey, for example, all grew by less than 4 percent over the decade, while New York's population stayed about flat.
In addition, the Northeast was already more densely populated than most parts of the country, and had more restrictions on development. Those combined forces, economists say, both prolonged the boom and cooked it all the harder.
Because the population did not grow very much, incomes climbed as employers were forced to compete for workers. The fact that open land was scarce drove up real estate prices as well. In 1980, for example, the median price of an existing home in New England was $67,882, only slightly above the national median. By 1989, the same home had reached $161,000, nearly 77 percent above the national figure.
The development restrictions, which builders say can result in a project taking twice as long to complete as it would elsewhere, may also have have made the overbuilding harder to stop, some economists say.
Human foibles gave the wheel a final spin. ''You can also never underestimate stupidity,'' said Raymond G. Torto, an economist at the University of Massachusetts. ''There was a deal-driven mentality that fed on itself.''

HEADLINE: The Month That Shook the World

 BODY:
In a month that weighed like a year, the crisis in the Persian Gulf has unsettled the conventional axioms of a generation. Until Saddam Hussein seized Kuwait, few imagined that the United Nations could truly unite, that sanctions might really bite, or that Russians and Arabs could join in a collective response skillfully led by President Bush.
Though enormous risks remain, this is an impressive start. The upcoming talks between Mr. Bush and Mikhail Gorbachev underscore how much the world has changed in this first frontal challenge to peace and security in the post-cold war era. 
A month's experience has yielded two precious lessons about the emerging global security system. The first is that U.S. leadership is indispensable to collective action. The second is that international participation and the patient use of international agencies serve the interests of all, and provide a chance to shape as well as heed global consensus.
Iraq's crime was unambiguous: the conquest and looting of a tiny neighbor. By menacing Saudi Arabia as well, Iraq threatened to gain a chokehold on the world's oil supplies, and economies. Saddam Hussein compounded his offenses by seizing hostages, bullying diplomats and proclaiming a holy war against Arab neighbors.
The U.S. is assembling a mighty international force in Arabia. And the U.N. has put together an impressive embargo. Iraq's reliance on oil revenues and its geographical situation make it peculiarly vulnerable to these sanctions. The following are among the sensible markers for sustaining the pressure as the siege continues:
Keep uniting the U.N. Its unanimous resolutions - to condemn Iraq, impose bruising sanctions and authorize use of force to make sanctions stick - are critical to success. They legitimize international action beyond narrow national interests. The U.N. is proving its worth.
Nurture the enforcing coalition. Soviet support for an arms embargo and sanctions against Iraq has helped make Desert Shield a joint venture, gaining the support of Arab states, as well as Turkey, Japan and the European democracies. It will not be easy to keep all together, and there is obvious utility in a direct exchange between Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev. Unity is essential, and so is the principle that the coalition partners share the common burden equitably.
Don't rise to Baghdad's bait. Saddam Hussein seeks desperately to present himself as an Arab underdog pitted against an imperial America and Israel. But his quarrel is with the world, the central truth that Mr. Bush rightly keeps putting in the foreground - despite rising passions over the plight of U.S. hostages.
Give the embargo a chance to work. Hasty Hawks would like to stampede Mr. Bush into an unprovoked strike against Iraq, even before the quarantine takes full effect. But the already growing lines in Baghdad show that the squeeze has a good chance of success. Using massive force now would shatter the anti-Iraq coalition.
Begin now to shape peace terms. This may be the hardest task for Mr. Bush. The U.N. demands call only for unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait, the restoration of its lawful rulers and the freeing of hostages. If Saddam Hussein complies, that would leave his war machine intact, enabling Iraq to resume its aggressions after the siege is lifted.
Prudent conditions for an enduring settlement have to go much further. They need to provide for the destruction of Iraq's chemical and nuclear weapons potential under international inspection, and international policing of guaranteed frontiers in the gulf. Saddam Hussein's territorial and financial claims against Iraq could be submitted to the World Court, and the U.N. also could address issues like the future government of Kuwait. The problem is that these conditions go beyond the present U.N. consensus, and many member states almost certainly would resist them.
Mr. Bush has succeeded in mobilizing a remarkable collective response. But he will have to be at least as skillful in widening the purposes of the enterprise and sustaining world unity. At stake is nothing less than the new world order he and other leaders struggle to shape.

HEADLINE: Riskless Hormone

 BODY:
Bovine growth hormone is the first of many genetically engineered products that promise to enhance agricultural efficiency. But the hormone is meeting strong resistance, based in part on the stirring of unfounded fears. A recent study by the Food and Drug Administration confirms that the hormone presents no risk to human health. 
When injected into cows, bovine growth hormone raises milk production by about 14 percent. The product is opposed by some dairy farmers, who fear so spectacular an increase in production would push less efficient producers out of business.
The farmers have an ally in the Foundation on Economic Trends, which opposes the concept of genetic engineering and has questioned the hormone's safety. Both Wisconsin and Minnesota have enacted a temporary ban on use of the hormone, as has the European Community.
Synthetic bovine growth hormone is made in bacteria programmed with the cow's gene. It is almost identical with the cow's naturally made growth hormone, small amounts of which are present in milk anyway. The traces of bovine growth hormone in milk, whether natural or synthetic, are destroyed in the gut like other proteins. Even if they somehow entered the bloodstream, bovine growth hormone doesn't make humans grow.
The hormone works in the cow by creating a secondary hormone, trace amounts of which are also present in milk. The secondary hormone is identical with its human counterpart, raising the question of whether infant formula made from the milk of hormone-treated cows might be bad for babies, since they could get a larger than normal dose of the secondary hormone. The F.D.A.'s answer is no, because the secondary hormone is present in the same quantities as in mother's milk, and is in any case destroyed in the heating process used to make formula.
Fears about hormones and genetic tinkering have a powerful resonance, but there remains no valid reason for resisting bovine growth hormone on grounds of risk to human health.
All new technologies deserve careful scrutiny, especially genetic engineering because the effects of changing the biological machinery are often hard to predict. But once all reasonable tests have been done, resistance should not continue on the basis of unfounded fears and apprehension. Unless products like bovine growth hormone receive a more informed appraisal, a valuable new technology will be unnecessarily delayed.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Why Moscow Must Walk the Tightrope in Iraq

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''The Soviets: Steady, if Slow'' (editorial, Aug. 24) brings up some doubts about my country's policy toward Iraq. Is Moscow playing a double game in the Persian Gulf? The Soviet leadership has taken a tough stand toward the aggressor, but the decision to keep Soviet military experts in Iraq has given birth to all kinds of speculations. That decision, however, proceeds from a statement by the Soviet Government consistent with the Soviet-American declaration approved by Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d at Vnukovo Airport near Moscow. 
Many have said that the Kremlin should have broken off military contracts with Iraq for aggression against Kuwait and recalled all Soviet military experts. But Baghdad might have viewed this as a signal of Moscow's readiness to use immediate military force against Iraq, and Iraqi authorities could have turned all Soviet citizens into hostages.
The reason the Soviet leadership is not evacuating its military experts is to use the Soviet presence in Iraq not only to obtain safe passage out of the country for many Soviet citizens but also to resolve the crisis by political means. Hundreds of thousands of people would be killed and poisoned with gas in a war for a liberation of Kuwait and foreign hostages. A destruction of Saudi and other Arab oilfields by Iraqi aircraft and rockets would cause great damage to the world economy. But even such losses would not guarantee survival for the thousands of foreign hostages.
Moscow is evidently pressing the Iraqi regime to withdraw its troops from Kuwait immediately and unconditionally, and to free all hostages. It is also trying to bring home to Baghdad the dangerous consequences of a war for the Iraqis. Mindful of the need for using military force against the aggressor, the Soviet leaders prefer the United Nations to be the sole instrument for the accomplishment of this mission.
Indeed, under the United Nations aegis, armed forces of different countries would act on behalf of the world community, put Baghdad in complete international isolation and make it pay for its aggression.
While calling on Saddam Hussein to listen to reason, Moscow also considers the entire situation in the Middle East. The Palestinian extremists voiced their support for the Iraqi dictator and are desperately anxious to act on his side. Such steps could sow terror throughout the region, with United States, Soviet, British and other citizens falling victim to their collective action against the aggressor.
 
EDUARD RYABTSEV
Moscow, Aug. 28, 1990
 
The writer is a Middle East analyst for the Novosti Information Agency.

HEADLINE: A Balanced Budget Would Finish Us Off

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Those of us who are old enough can remember the political battle fought in 1932 between Franklin D. Roosevelt and Herbert Hoover. The main issue was which candidate would best reduce Government expenditures and balance the budget, thus restoring prosperity. Roosevelt, the winner, fortunately did not follow his own campaign position on fiscal soundness, at least not until after he was re-elected in 1936 and then seriously tried to balance the budget. The result: a serious recession in 1937. 
We now know that the nation did not pull itself out of the Great Depression until two things happened: (1) Starting in 1940, we had massive deficits, in contrast to the small ones of the 1930's. (2) We undertook massive military expenditures (that justified the huge deficits and did not clog up the civilian marketplace with overproduced civilian goods).
Each of these justified the other and continued to do so until recently. This formula for prosperity (at the expense of future generations) has continued successful for 50 years. Now, the collapse of the Communist threat and the explosive political campaign for a balanced budget threaten to return us to 1939. We have not solved the problems of the national economy, but learned to live with them.
Contrary to the conventional wisdom of economics and economists, it is my belief that the national budget cannot be balanced, at least not for more than one fiscal year. If we succeed in moving dramatically toward a balanced budget, a major recession will hit us, greatly reducing tax income and increasing Government expenditures through what is left of the ''safety net.'' Success will beget failure. If we come to believe, like Hoover and Roosevelt in 1932 that a balanced budget will cure our economic ills, we will likely move from recession to Great Depression II.
We should remember that government deficits tend to transfer money from those who have it but are not using it to those who want to consume and invest. This is an essential function, and we must somehow learn to live with it, without the dire consequences of multitrillion-dollar debt.
In the words of John Maynard Keynes, there must be a better answer than to leave huge pump-priming deficits to future generations. But remember, Keynes also noted in his definitive economic forecast that ''in the long run, we are all dead.'' So why worry?
 
JACK C. PLANO
Kalamazoo, Mich., Aug. 17, 1990
 
The writer is a professor emeritus of political science at Western Michigan University.
