SECTION: Section 4; Page 13, Column 6; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 764 words

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
A Collective Effort

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker

 BODY:
''The Japanese have a hell of a stake in this,'' said Senator Frank Lautenberg of New Jersey, a liberal Democrat, after a briefing by President Bush on the Middle East crisis, ''and ought to pay a hell of a share.''
At the other end of the political spectrum, Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina said after the same briefing: ''I think it was unanimous that we ought not to pay for this alone.''
In response to this indisputable point, Mr. Bush now has turned to an effort to assure international financial support for the collective effort to curb Saddam Hussein. The obligation of the Kuwaiti emirate, with its vast treasure in foreign banks, and of the rich Saudi princes, is obvious. Japan and Western Europe have more at stake in oil supplies than the United States, and as much in the principle that's invoked - collective security. 
Mr. Bush would not be out of line to ask that these vitally concerned nations share most of the costs of an undertaking in which the U.S. supplies most of the forces and equipment. Why should Americans pledge lives to collective security if others as deeply affected are unwilling to pledge money?
The question was emphasized on the day of Mr. Bush's briefing by the Pentagon's entirely expectable announcement that the cost of Operation Desert Shield, through September, would not be $1.2 billion as previously stated, but $2.5 billion. The history of military cost estimates suggests that even that doubled prediction probably will be surpassed.
The end-of-September deadline, moreover, looks ever more unrealistic, as the prospect of a long military standoff deepens. The allied, mostly American, forces in Saudi Arabia appear to have stymied the possibility - it never was a certainty - of an Iraqi invasion. At the same time, Saddam Hussein has given no hint -quite the opposite - that he's likely any time soon to pull back from his conquest of Kuwait, as demanded by the U.S., the U.N., most Arab nations and most of the rest of the world.
The President appears - at least for now - to be unwilling to push Mr. Hussein out of Kuwait by military force, much less to attack Iraq directly in order to oust him. The desire of Israel, in its own interest, for U.S. offensive action against Mr. Hussein may be understandable; but Mr. Bush could hardly consider such a war in the American interest.
That would scuttle collective security, since a U.S. attack on Iraq would be supported only by Israel. It would damage U.S. backing in Europe and elsewhere and destroy some of the oil-producing capacity supposedly being kept available to the world. Japan and Germany are unlikely to help pay for that.
Such an attack also would shatter the tenuous Arab support for the collective effort, convert the present international resistance to aggression into a U.S. war with an Arab nation, make Mr. Hussein a greater hero in Arab eyes and endanger the thousands of hostages he's holding. Mr. Bush's homefront support might vanish with that of the rest of the world, as Americans found their sons in a real war rather than in Grenada or Panama. Domestic support for a stalemate in the desert will decline also, but probably not as decisively as for a stalemated or losing war, with casualty rates sure to be high.
It's not at all sure, moreover, that the U.S. has the offensive capacity in the region for a quick and successful war. Nor is it clear that the tightening economic noose around Mr. Hussein's neck will not in the long run at least force him out of Kuwait. The economic strategy may take months to work, or to show that it won't. Until one or the other result is indisputable, a unilateral U.S. attack on Iraq would be disastrous.
As for what Mr. Hussein might do, if he remained in power in Iraq even after being forced out of Kuwait - a big if - it probably is unrealistic to hope that he would quietly mind his own business. But a good start has been made on international, including U.N., action toward collective security, which could become the brightest side of a dark situation; a U.S. attack on Iraq would end that hope. Americans and Israelis eager for war with Iraq may consider collective security measures - an international peacekeeping force, for example - inadequate to contain Saddam Hussein; but the achievements of the U.S. and its allies, including the Soviet Union, argue for trying them.
In the new world dawning at the end of the cold war, many approaches once deemed impractical might prove workable. What's now happening in the Middle East may be only the first example. A. M. Rosenthal is traveling.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: September 2, 1990

SECTION: Section 6; Page 26, Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 3495 words

HEADLINE: Seen Any Warbleers Lately

BYLINE: By Ken Emerson; Ken Emerson is Viewpoints editor of New York Newsday.

 BODY:
Chandler S. Robbins, a senior U.S. Fish and Wildlife biologist at the Patuxent Wildlife Research Center, is rattling through the refuge in Laurel, Md., when he brakes his Chevy on a one-lane bridge spanning a creek that is swollen with spring rain. From a drooping branch hangs a nest, and in it sits an olive-brown mite of a bird he quickly identifies as an Acadian flycatcher.
After Robbins gets out of the car, the bird flies off with a perturbed pip! - and no wonder. For through the bridge's girders Robbins pokes an extendible aluminum pole with the rear-view mirror from a child's bicycle affixed to its tip. A dentist could use the device to examine a giraffe's molars. Angling the mirror over the nest, Robbins sees that it's empty, still under construction. So, leaving the bird to its business, he continues on his. 
Six hours later, he has examined and tallied the contents of 16 wood thrush nests, three red-eyed vireo nests and one each belonging to an ovenbird and a Kentucky warbler. Some are empty, many contain eggs and a few hold just-hatched, dime-size, eraser-pink young. (One clutch of precocious wood thrush nestlings, literally early birds on this last weekend in May, has sprouted mole-gray pinfeathers.) None of these nests has been as conveniently close to a road as the flycatcher's. Yet lumbering through thickets and sloshing across streams in high rubber boots has been more exhilarating than exhausting. Robbins will be attending his 50th reunion at Harvard in a week. Even with hearing aids, he can no longer detect the high-frequency lisp of a blue-gray gnatcatcher or the urgent squeak of a blackpoll warbler. But there's still something boyish about him, and it's not just his bushy crew cut and the Boy Scout olive of his overshirt. He loves to tramp though the woods with an adolescent's abandon - albeit with a scientist's sense of purpose.
Robbins - known as Chan everywhere but in scholarly papers - is in the vanguard of biologists who are sounding an alarm that songbirds are imperiled in America, especially in what remains of the forests in the Northeast. ''There is a sickness in the woods,'' the biologist John Terborgh warns in his recent book, ''Where Have All the Birds Gone?''
The malady is not the same one Rachel Carson diagnosed in ''Silent Spring,'' her 1962 book (based largely on data compiled at Patuxent) that led eventually to the banning of DDT. Pesticides still present problems, but these pale beside a new danger -the rapid deforestation of Central and South America, where many birds spend the winter - and an old one that continues unabated: the commercial and residential development of North America, where these migrants rear their young. Moreover, new research suggests that suburbia poses a subtle and insidious threat to many songbirds by enabling predators and parasites to thrive at their expense.
''These birds are getting it on both ends of the line,'' Robbins says, ''in the breeding season and in the winter. The thing that's difficult to answer specifically about an individual species is where is the bottleneck? They're under pressure here, they're under pressure there. Which is worse?''
In 1965, Robbins and other Fish and Wildlife researchers organized the nationwide Breeding Bird Survey (BBS), expanded to include Canada, and the records of volunteer observers (some 4,000 participated this spring) have been accumulating ever since. The computer analysis to which these findings is subjected is arcane, but you don't need a Ph.D. in statistics to decode the bottom line.
Between 1978 and 1987, the number of wood thrushes breeding in the eastern United States and Canada fell at an annual rate of 4 percent. For rose-breasted grosbeaks, the yearly decline was 4.1 percent. North America's two species of cuckoo, the black-billed and yellow-billed, were down an annual average of 5.9 and 5 percent, respectively. The Tennessee warbler is minus 11.6 percent annually; the worm-eating warbler, minus 2 percent; the ovenbird, minus 1 percent.
These figures are not universally accepted, but if the U.S. Census Bureau is having difficulty counting 250 million or so people, imagine the impossibility of tallying accurately the 20 billion birds ''guess-timated'' to inhabit the continental United States every summer.
BBS data indicate that at least 21 species of songbirds that are dwindling in eastern North America fly to wintering grounds in the Neotropics: to Mexico, the Caribbean, Central and South America. (An additional dozen or so songbirds may be declining, but the falloff is not yet statistically significant.) Many migratory shorebirds are in trouble, as well as some migrant songbirds that nest in the West, but the Northeastern woods are the nursery and summer home of the greatest concentrations of Neotropical migrants. Some of these birds, the warblers and tanagers, are our most vividly colored; others, particularly the thrushes, are the most melodious singers. Without flycatchers, our woods would be even thicker with no-see-ums and other nuisances. Were these migrants to disappear altogether, not just the forests but our lives would be impoverished.
By now the deforestation of Central and South America, which is proceeding in some countries at an annual rate of 1 to 3.5 percent, has become a cause that is literally celebre. Everyone from Senator Sam Nunn to Madonna has jumped on the ''Don't Bungle the Jungle'' bandwagon. The pressures of population and economics are devastating Latin America and endangering, many scientists charge, the earth's entire atmosphere as well as the winter habitats of what it is presumptuous to call ''our'' birds, since they actually spend the greater portion of the year in the Neotropics.
Increasing numbers of American biologists are spending their winters in the Neotropics, too, trying to document the damage and to encourage local conservation efforts. Deforestation is their greatest concern, but not their only one. Many dangerous pesticides that have been outlawed in the United States, for instance, are still widely used in Latin America.
On that spring morning at Patuxent, Chan Robbins wore a T-shirt emblazoned with a toucan and the legend ''Belize'' - where he has conducted research for the past three years. Using satellite imagery to identify different habitats, he is comparing bird populations in agricultural and still-forested areas.
Radar scans of flocks of birds migrating across the Gulf of Mexico show a decrease in density, but those that live year-round in the tropics have been hit even harder, according to Robbins. The scarlet macaw, he says, seems to have all but disappeared: ''To see one you'd have to backpack for two or three days and hire a special guide.''
Among migrant songbirds, those that depend exclusively on undisturbed Neotropical forests, particularly those that winter in a circumscribed area, seem to be most at risk. These include the cerulean warbler and the Louisiana water thrush (despite its name, another warbler).
Yet suspicion is mounting that the attrition of Neotropical migrants cannot be attributed entirely to circumstances south of the border - no more than America's cocaine problem can be blamed altogether on Colombia and Peru. That is why Robbins, two Fish and Wildlife colleagues and two summer interns are scouring the woods in Maryland for bird nests. They are comparing the reproductive success rates of birds within the 4,700 acres of the Patuxent refuge to those that attempt to breed within the smaller woodland plots, or ''fragments,'' more characteristic of the densely settled Northeast. The conclusion that their evidence points to is that if it's bad for Neotropical migrants all over, fragmentation is especially injurious to their reproductive health.
''We're gradually building a public awareness,'' Robbins says. ''This whole business of fragmentation - 20 years ago that word was never used - it was wet woods or steep woods or whatever, but woods was woods. Size had no meaning. Now we know that it is extremely important.''
''Ooooh, disgusting!'' Barbara A. Dowell is surveying the wreckage of a wood thrush nest that has been knocked on its side but not quite dislodged from a sapling. On the ground lie one pale blue egg, wet and cold to the touch, a shattered shell containing an embryo and shards of a third egg whose contents have presumably been eaten by an unknown predator.
Dowell, who has been working at Patuxent for 12 years and with Robbins for most of them, is canvassing a 45-acre lot a few miles from the refuge. This fragment is all that remains of what may be the last virgin forest in Maryland. Development in this area, strategically and vulnerably midway between Washington and Baltimore, has been recent and massive. The housing clusters often bear ironically sylvan names like Twelve Oaks (even a Job Corps center is called Woodland).
While scores of oaks and tulip trees still tower in this plot, the leaves of the dogwoods that fill in the spaces between their immense trunks are withered and crumpled - by acid rain, says Dowell. More bird nests than in the refuge seem to have been struck by a blight, too. Since Dowell last checked, numerous wood thrush nests, as well as a Kentucky warbler's, have been despoiled by predators. Locating three cardinal nestlings in a tangle, she sniffs the musky, urinaceous scent of a fox whose den must be nearby and predicts that they're not long for this world, either.
Warblers, no less than wolves, need Lebensraum, but research suggests that a wood lot's size per se is not the only factor that deprives birds of their reproductive edge. It is also the easy access that smaller forests provide predators to the birds' eggs and young within.
These have always been tempting morsels. When Audubon painted blue jays, he portrayed them gobbling eggs. ''See how each is enjoying the fruits of his knavery,'' he wrote, ''sucking the egg which he has pilfered from the nest of some innocent dove or harmless partridge!'' Crows and grackles, as well as blue jays, feast upon eggs and nestlings, and so do raccoons, skunks, opossums and squirrels (not to mention cats). All of these creatures have fattened at the bird feeders and garbage cans of suburbia, where they prosper in greater densities than in deep forest. And when the woods aren't deep - they seldom are in America anymore - the birds that nest there are sitting ducks for opportunistic and increasing populations of predators.
That's the theory, at least, and scientists are still gathering evidence to support it. A question immediately arises, however. If predation is the culprit, why are so many other birds that migrate only as far as the southern states, or not at all, flourishing under the same suburban circumstances? Species such as the tufted titmouse, cardinal and mockingbird have even expanded their geographical ranges.
David S. Wilcove, now the senior biologist for the Wilderness Society, conducted a series of ingenious field experiments with artificial, cup-shaped wicker nests stocked with commercial quail eggs. He set them out in forests of varying sizes, on the ground and in saplings, and he also deposited eggs in makeshift nesting boxes mimicking the tree holes (or ''cavities'') in which birds such as woodpeckers, chickadees and titmice nest. The deeper the woods, his results showed, the less predation. Nests on the ground were looted more frequently than those in trees. And nests in cavities escaped scot-free. Unfortunately, the vast majority of Neotropical migrants construct open-cup nests, and many build them on the ground. Birds that don't migrate such distances tend to prefer cavities and other less accessible nesting sites. Thus, birds that stick closer to home year-round are more secure than Neotropical migrants, even without the feeding stations that enable many of them to survive the winter.
Chan Robbins and his colleagues have been counting bird nests in Maryland for three years, which is not long enough to reach definitive conclusions. But one thing is already obvious to him: ''In the small, isolated woodlands, we're not getting the Neotropical migrants anymore. . . . You just don't find warblers.''
It's a grotesque yet mesmerizing sight, a miniaturized ''Rosemary's Baby'' for real. On a bare branch about 20 feet up an oak tree, a big dingy cowbird fledgling is calling insistently for food. Its cries are answered by a warbler half its size, an adult ovenbird that alights on the branch with a caterpillar in its beak. Approaching timorously, the ovenbird tosses the tidbit down the fledgling's gullet and flies off in a flash, as if in fear that it, too, will be devoured. Twenty minutes later, and as many yards away, a diminutive ovenbird fledgling flutters about the undergrowth, cheeping to be fed, but to no apparent avail.
One usually thinks of parasites as tiny ticks and such, but the brown-headed cowbird is also a parasite, one that threatens many other birds almost as gravely as predators. Indeed, one warbler, the Kirtland's, would probably be extinct by now if Fish and Wildlife and other agencies didn't regularly trap and remove cowbirds from their nesting grounds in central Michigan.
Cowbirds have the nasty habit of depositing their eggs in smaller birds' nests. A young cowbird is large to start with and grows quickly, commanding most of the food brought by stepparents whose natural offspring often languish and die. ''Rowdy little buggers,'' Barbara Dowell calls young cowbirds. One researcher admits that when she encounters cowbird nestlings or eggs, she often casts aside scientific protocol and flings them to the ground.
When cowbirds were largely confined to the Great Plains and the company of bison, so was the havoc they wreaked. But with the felling of the forests and the introduction of mechanized harvesting that leaves behind plenty of grain for cowbirds to consume, their range has extended across the continent.
The open nests of Neotropical migrants are as inviting to these parasites as they are to predators. To make matters worse, most long-distance migrants lack the instinctual ability some short-distance migrants and stay-at-homes, including blue jays, catbirds and robins, have acquired after centuries of experience to recognize cowbird eggs and eject them from their nests.
Cowbirds still seem to be most pernicious in the Midwest - where one researcher concluded from an Illinois study that ''wood thrushes are doing nothing but raising cowbirds'' - and to prefer open country and suburbs to dense woods. That's why the encounter with the ovenbird and the parasite fledgling was particularly dismaying. It occurred deep within the Hawk Mountain Sanctuary in eastern Pennsylvania, where the research director, James C. Bednarz (who now works with a private consulting firm), and an intern were snaring ovenbirds.
Going Robbins one better, Bednarz and his colleagues were not only tallying nests but banding birds - ovenbirds and wood thrushes - within the sanctuary and in outlying forest fragments. The goal is to track individual birds over several years. Will they return to the same spot for several springs? How prolifically will they breed? Will they abandon a fragment in frustration?
Lugging mist nets and poles in an old golf bag, Bednarz was accompanied by Nancy R. Zawada, an urban park ranger from Staten Island. Whenever they heard an ovenbird's teacher-teacher-teacher song (Robert Frost's sonnet, ''The Oven Bird,'' hailed the ''singer everyone has heard''), they would unfurl and string up two 30-foot-long swathes of fine mesh. At the center, where the nets met, they stationed a wooden model of an ovenbird, nicknamed Oppenheimer (the wood thrush decoy is Wendell), and concealed a tape-recorder under leaves. All morning long the songs, live and on tape, volleyed back and forth, like an avian ''Dueling Banjos,'' but not until after noon did an ovenbird actually fly into the nets as it tried to drive its unbudging rival from its nesting territory.
Quickly disentangling the bird, Bednarz and Zawada took several measurements and suspended it, nestled in a navy-blue sock, from a pocket scale (19 grams). After she attached colored bands to each of its legs, Zawada blew gently on the feathers of the underbelly to part them and determine the sex (male, with swollen testes). And, just before releasing the bird, she plucked one of its 12 tail feathers (it's painless, she said, and a replacement soon grows in).
Zawada is conducting an experiment in the little-known field of ptilochronology. Certain bird feathers bear faint lateral bands that indicate 24 hours' growth, much as the rings in a tree trunk record a year's. Squint and wiggle the feather as if it were one of those magic pictures from a Cracker Jack box, and you can just make these bands out. The wider they are, the more daily growth and, presumably, general well-being a bird has enjoyed. By measuring them on birds netted in different habitats, Zawada is administering what amounts to a comparative stress test. Her hope is to determine whether birds are literally more ''stressed out'' in forest fragments than in thick woods.
But the woods atop Hawk Mountain were not very thick this year. In the spring, gypsy-moth caterpillars stripped the oak canopy bare, as they have so many other forests in the Northeast since the Eurasian moth was introduced to the United States in 1869. Several decades of widespread aerial spraying have put a stop neither to the devastation nor to the debate over the effects of such pesticidal programs. One study conducted in a New Jersey state forest indicated that birds declined in abundance by 55 percent after a single aerial spraying and took years to recover.
Gypsy moth infestations are usually periodic, not permanent. The tree trunks on Hawk Mountain (which has not been sprayed since 1969) were studded, as if by rusty nails, with dead caterpillars, and the ground was littered with their squishy remains. They had erupted in such numbers that they had exhausted their food supply and starved to death. The recommendation of many naturalists is to let nature - even if, as in the case of the gypsy moth, it's imported - take its course.
Robbins and many other biologists believe that what threatens bird life is not nature, but mankind, taking its course. Yet a great deal more research must be conducted and completed in both South and North America to determine the extent of the decline and its causes. ''We're dealing with huge numbers of birds and a large geographical area,'' Robbins says. ''Even when we say it's a scarce bird, there are a lot of them out there. How many cerulean warblers are there? Tens of thousands? Maybe 100,000? No one knows. They're not going to disappear all of a sudden.''
Although 9 out of 10 researchers, according to Paul Kerlinger, director of the Cape May Bird Observatory of the New Jersey Audubon Society, would agree that woodland birds are losing ground, some still harbor doubts. Richard T. Holmes, a biology professor at Dartmouth College who has been conducting studies in the White Mountains for 22 years, says he hasn't seen a widespread decline in New Hampshire and questions the Breeding Bird Survey data. However, even Holmes, who also works in the Neotropics, acknowledges, ''I don't think anybody has any good evidence that the Neotropics are important at this stage, but they will be eventually if enough deforestation occurs down there.''
''It could creep up on you,'' warns Jim Bednarz. ''If we wait for 10 years and the songbirds decline by 50 percent, it may be too late to recover.''
''We must strike a balance,'' cautions an article in Current Ornithology, ''between labeling every ephemeral downturn a major population decline (the 'Chicken Little Syndrome') and refusing to accept the evidence for population decline unless it satisfies impossibly rigorous statistical requirements for certainty (the 'Tobacco Lobby Syndrome').''
All the evidence about songbirds so far supports preserving as much forest as possible, in North America as well as the Neotropics. And in large, contiguous tracts rather than small, isolated parcels. What Bednarz calls ''Swiss cheese habitat'' is porous to predation. In order to protect the maximum amount of remaining woodland, the New Jersey Audubon Society is not alone in recommending development policies that promote cluster housing rather than individual lots. It also urges a halt to aerial spraying for gypsy moths and mosquitoes.
Still, the last lines of Frost's ''The Oven Bird'' echo ominously: ''The question that he frames in all but words/Is what to make of a diminished thing.''
''If I had children, I'd be worried,'' says Patuxent's Barbara Dowell. ''Not because people are going to become extinct like the birds, but because of the quality of their life. To me, a minimum quality of life is a wood thrush.''

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: September 2, 1990

SECTION: Section 7; Page 3, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1417 words

HEADLINE: Trump Fights Back

BYLINE: By MICHAEL LEWIS; Michael Lewis is the author of ''Liar's Poker: Rising Through the Wreckage on Wall Street.''

 BODY:

TRUMP
Surviving at the Top.
By Donald J. Trump with Charles Leerhsen.
Illustrated. 236 pp. New York:
Random House. $21.95.
Toward the end of ''Trump: Surviving at the Top'' the reader actually feels something like pity for the hero. This brief, unlikely moment occurs when Donald J. Trump is describing his bizarre dealings with Leona Helmsley. Long ago, he explains, the middle-aged Mrs. Helmsley took an uncommon fancy to him. ''For some reason,'' Mr. Trump writes, ''even though I was not tremendously successful at that time, Leona always liked having me around. . . . I was always asked to be [at her parties] and was always given a seat, usually right near her.'' 
Mr. Trump has already alluded several times to his own sex appeal and has once claimed that ''I've never had any trouble in bed.'' The young and dashing Mr. Trump escorts a fashion model to one of Mrs. Helmsley's parties. Mrs. Helmsley flies into what appears to be a jealous rage. ''How dare you bring that tramp to one of my parties?'' she screams, in the presence of the other woman. ''At first I was shocked,'' Mr. Trump says, ''but then all the things people had been telling me about Leona and her Jekyll-and-Hyde personality started coming back to me.'' From then on Mrs. Helmsley, with her ''crazed personality,'' heaps all manner of abuse on Mr. Trump.
This rare passage in which Mr. Trump seems at the mercy of forces beyond his control ends quickly. The roles reverse when Mr. Trump steamrollers over Mrs. Helmsley in a deal, then fires off a few gratuitous insults of his own. Mr. Trump, once again, is the Conqueror.
Filled as it is with Mr. Trump's usual commercial sadomasochism, ''Trump: Surviving at the Top'' is already out of date. Mr. Trump can no longer afford to insult at will. He can no longer sow salt in the real estate of his enemies. We now know Mr. Trump's business, based as it was on rising property prices and foolish bankers, has collapsed. He is losing money. He is a virtual slave to external forces. With his debts possibly exceeding his assets by as much as $250 million, his bankers watch and advise his every move. He has had to agree, for example, not to spend more than $450,000 a month on his personal expenses. Yet he still insists, like a captured tyrant, that he is in charge.
Reading the scene between Mr. Trump and Mrs. Helmsley, I began to wonder if there isn't something in the Manhattan soil that drives those who wish to control it to distraction; it's not just Mrs. Helmsley who seems to have gone loopy. The book Mr. Trump has presided over (with the writing help of Charles Leerhsen, a senior writer at Newsweek) is full of petty, desperate and often laughable swipes at anyone who has ever dared to criticize Donald Trump. Of a Village Voice reporter, Mr. Trump says that the writer, ''whose last book was a major failure, is still trying to make his name at my expense.'' Of a recent article in Forbes magazine estimating (generously, it turns out) his net worth at a mere $500 million: ''Who can say what these one-of-a-kind assets are worth until they're put on the market? Certainly not some mediocre reporter from Forbes'' (whom Mr. Trump names). Of Garry Trudeau's widely loved ''Doonesbury'' cartoons lampooning Mr. Trump: ''Trudeau's wife, Jane Pauley, is much more talented than he is.''
Mr. Trump's relentless accumulation leads people often to mistake his motive for greed, when what drives the man seems to me to be more a pathological need for control. But control of what? Perhaps there was a time when he wanted to control his business; now he seems merely to want to control the opinion others hold of him. Mr. Trump has come to believe that if he nurtures his fame his business will follow. ''Success,'' he writes, ''so often, is just a matter of perception.'' That may explain why he goes berserk when a journalist tries to tinker with his image, but it still represents an odd and - it now seems - wrongheaded approach to commerce. The man whose first impulse after he buys a building is to change the facade has become nothing but a facade.
In ''Trump: The Art of the Deal,'' Mr. Trump celebrated his shrewdness; in ''Trump: Surviving at the Top,'' he celebrates his reputation. The book is a strained, sloppy exercise in facade restoration. Mr. Trump begins by gluing on himself the best tinsel and chrome that money can buy. There are several photographs in ''Trump: Surviving at the Top'' of Mr. Trump with celebrities (Hulk Hogan!) who don't even appear in the text. Mr. Trump devotes a chapter to his instant friendship with Mike Tyson without ever explaining how it began. The rest of the book is a blizzard of name-dropping. The index starts with ''Ali, Muhammad'' and ends with ''York, Sarah Ferguson, Duchess of.'' In between there are perhaps 10 names not recognizable to readers of People magazine. Under ''V'': ''Vanderbilt family'' and ''van Gogh, Vincent.'' Under ''O'': ''Onassis, Jackie.'' (Perhaps there's a new Trump board game in this: I give you a letter from Mr. Trump's index and you guess who is listed underneath. Pick the wrong name and you're foreclosed upon.) ''Pick the wrong name, and no matter what else you do, you'll never be a hit,'' says the author to explain why he called one of his casinos Trump. He explains a lot more than that.
Another of Mr. Trump's cheap bag of building tricks is simply to tell us repeatedly how widely loved and admired he is. Of a trip to Brazil -a country with which he has much in common, financially - he says only that ''I found Brazil to be a lovely, if economically troubled, country. And I was surprised and delighted that children came running up to me with pencils and paper yelling, 'Mr. Trump, Mr. Trump.' '' He walks down Fifth Avenue and ''about twenty-five perfect strangers wave and shout, 'Hi, Donald,' and 'How're you doing, Donald,' and 'Keep up the good work.' One thing this proves to me is that the average working man or woman is a lot better adjusted and more secure than the supposedly successful people who stare down at them from the penthouses.''
So says the penthouse dweller. And in his case, he's right. ''Trump: Survival at the Top'' is a portrait of an ego gone haywire. He saves the reviewer a great deal of anguish by making a brief foray into the nether regions of his mind. ''I'm not the same person that I was just a few years ago,'' he writes. ''The changes I've undergone . . . are what this book is about.'' In a chapter called ''The Survival Game,'' he suggestively offers a list of once wealthy men, some of whom committed suicide; they are, it seems, his bogy. He compares himself to Howard Hughes. ''As time goes on,'' he writes, ''I find myself thinking more and more about Howard Hughes and even, to some degree, identifying with him. Take, for example, his famous aversion to germs. While I'm certainly not as fanatical as he was, I've always had very strong feelings about cleanliness. I'm constantly washing my hands.''
But he's not exposing himself so much as he is shopping for new identities. Having tried Lady Macbeth on for size, he at last selects another equally implausible shell. He tells us, in so many words, that he has discovered the futility of the possessions he calls his trophies. The best-known of these is perhaps the yacht, now named the Trump Princess, purchased from the arms dealer Adnan Khashoggi (see ''Doonesbury'' for details). Mr. Trump devotes a chapter to the Princess identical in tone and content to the braggadocio in ''Trump: The Art of the Deal'': how brilliantly he haggled for it, how his boat is the biggest, how he made it better and so on.
Then he lobs in this revelation: ''But as much as I've enjoyed it until now, and as impressive as it's been to my casino customers, I think I'm giving up the game of who's got the best boat. . . . It's funny how the boat seemed more appropriate to my life in the past than to my future.'' It's even funnier that this decision comes at a time when he can no longer afford the boat. There's every reason to believe that self-denial is just one more gewgaw for the Trump facade, stuck on to distract us from the cheap construction. After all, the man has built a career gloating over his ability to fool others; ''fool'' comes second only to ''loser'' as Mr. Trump's favorite epithet. The truth more likely is that if his real estate recovers, he'll begin bragging more loudly than ever about his boat. But who then will listen? Only fools.

HEADLINE: Known by the Clothes He Wears - or Steals

BYLINE: By KAREN KARBO; Karen Karbo is the author of ''Trespassers Welcome Here,'' a comic novel about Russian emigres in Los Angeles.

 BODY:

THE SUITCASE
By Sergei Dovlatov.
Translated by Antonina W. Bouis.
128 pp. New York: Grove Weidenfeld. $16.95.
The mark of a book's ability to move, instruct and entertain is the way in which it is read. To say one can't put a book down is not the highest form of praise. It intimates that the prose is dispensable, that there are no turns of phrase worth relishing. A better book is one the reader would love to gulp down in one sitting, but chooses instead to savor. Sergei Dovlatov's new collection of interrelated vignettes, ''The Suitcase,'' adroitly translated by Antonina W. Bouis, fits into this second category. I predict most readers will roar through the first two-thirds of this novel, then, upon realizing there are only a few chapters left, stop reading in an effort to stave off finishing it. The final chapters will be hoarded and cherished, doled out one at a time as a reward after a bad day. 
Like his previous works, ''The Suitcase'' verges on the autobiographical; the title story refers to the cheap plywood case Mr. Dovlatov brought to the United States when he emigrated from the Soviet Union. An inventory of its contents - eight articles of clothing that provide the chapter titles - serves as a springboard for Mr. Dovlatov's laconic, sometimes surreal reminiscences about the acquisition of each article. Mr. Dovlatov is a sly ironist; these stories are as much about love and friendship gone awry, about aborted dreams and helplessness, as they are about hats and shirts and belts.
''The Finnish Crepe Socks'' chronicles an ill-fated black market scheme to unload a shipment of Finnish socks on a Soviet public hungry for foreign merchandise, a scheme Mr. Dovlatov involves himself in to pay off the debts he's incurred trying to impress a girl. ''The Nomenklatura Half Boots'' deals with Mr. Dovlatov's short-lived career as an artist. At loose ends after a short stint with a factory newsletter, he had gone in search of work that posed ''fewer moral doubts.'' ''Friends with pull got me into . . . a decorative and applied arts studio. I became an apprentice stone carver. I decided to 'find myself' in monumental sculpture.'' His first job involved carving a relief depiction of a Soviet scientist for a new Metro station. The boots of the title are lifted from a certain Soviet eminence during the dedication ceremonies.
The novel is reminiscent of a Buster Keaton movie. In each chapter the image of the tall, grim Mr. Dovlatov suffering one Soviet indignity after the next is agonizingly hilarious. After the Finnish crepe socks scheme fails, leaving him with 240 pairs, ''Many things happened. . . . I paid off my debts. . . . Met the girl I eventually married. Went to the Baltic for a month. . . . Began my feeble literary attempts. Became a father. Got into trouble with the authorities. Lost my job. Spent a month in Kalyaevo Prison.
''And only one thing did not change: for 20 years I paraded around in pea-colored socks. I gave them to all my friends. Kept them for Christmas ornaments. Dusted with them. Stuck them into the cracks of window frames. And still the number of those lousy socks barely changed.''
The middle chapters of the book, particularly ''The Poplin Shirt'' -which depicts Mr. Dovlatov's marriage as ''twenty-five years of mutual isolation and indifference to real life'' - are etched with wistfulness. ''Fernand Leger's Jacket'' is a poignant story of a boyhood friendship. ''Andryusha was the son of an outstanding man. My father stood out only for his thinness.'' Leger's jacket is given to Mr. Dovlatov by Andryusha's mother after her husband, the ''outstanding man,'' has died.
''The jacket really was old. If Soviet posters are to be believed, the unemployed in America wear jackets like that.
''Cherkasova looked at me strangely and said, 'that jacket belonged to Fernand Leger. He was about your size.'
 
''I repeated in amazement, 'Leger? The Leger?'
'' 'Once we were very close. Then I was friends with his widow. I told her about you. Nadya went into the closet, took out the jacket, and handed it to me. She said that Fernand asked her to befriend all kinds of riffraff.' ''
Although Mr. Dovlatov's vision is wholly Russian, his voice has a brusque, straightforward American quality. The stereotypic Slavic excesses expected of a Russian writer are notably absent. His heart-rending humor is achieved through the clever juxtaposition of simple sentences, a deadpan delivery worthy of David Letterman and the employment of phrases that translate into tough, monosyllabic English words of Anglo-Saxon origin.
''In the Soviet Union I dressed so badly I was rebuked for it. I remember when the director of the Pushkin Preserve told me, 'Comrade Dovlatov, your trousers ruin the festive mood of our area.' '' Mr. Dovlatov has lived in the United States since 1978. One can only hope he has continued to dress as badly and has the marvelous stories to prove it. America can use a great satirist. This might just be our man.

HEADLINE: We, the Rich

BYLINE: By HARVEY H. SEGAL; Harvey H. Segal is the author of ''Corporate Makeover,'' which will be published in an updated paperback edition in January.

 BODY:

THE BORDERLESS WORLD
Power and Strategy in the Interlinked Economy.
By Kenichi Ohmae.
223 pp. New York:
Harper Business/HarperCollins Publishers. $21.95.
Kenichi Ohmae - arguably Japan's most influential writer on public policy - is unfazed by what George Bush calls ''the vision thing.'' If he harbors any doubts about his formula for achieving greater wealth and personal freedom, none surface in ''The Borderless World.'' His certitude is rhetorically effective, but it ignores some of the obstacles to moving from the here and now to the there and then. 
Europe, Japan and the United States - the triad that Mr. Ohmae calls the Interlinked Economy, or ILE - are home to the richest fifth of the world's population, about a billion people who produce and consume nearly four-fifths of the global output of goods and services. Within the ILE the significance of national borders is being eclipsed by ever-increasing flows of international trade and investment. Despite protectionist barriers (or perhaps because of them), transplanted American and European companies account for some 10.9 percent of Japan's gross national product. Japanese auto makers have about 30 percent of the United States market. And American companies constitute roughly one-fifth of the total corporate capitalization of Europe.
Mr. Ohmae's compelling argument is that the further integration of the ILE is in everyone's interest. Absent import restrictions and xenophobic policies, the optimal location of production, both within and outside the ILE, would lower costs, increase output and raise living standards. Development of new technologies and products, such as integrated microchips, would be accelerated. Poorer countries with gross national products of less than $10,000 per head could hitch onto the ILE engine by abandoning protectionism and opening their doors to imports and foreign investment.
Were he a minimalist painter, Mr. Ohmae (who is the managing director of the McKinsey consulting firm in Japan) would draw nothing but praise. But in the untidy arena of international relations the kind of broad brushstrokes found in ''The Borderless World'' must be supplemented by blueprints. Mr. Ohmae focuses on the Japanese-American nexus while ignoring - save for a cryptic reference to ''the Gaullist French government'' - new protectionist barriers that will almost certainly be erected by the European Community when it moves toward greater integration in 1992. He fails to provide an argument for his assertion that speculation in foreign exchange is a cushion against inflation. And his hostility toward takeovers, leveraged buyouts and corporate restructurings - he misreads them as signs of ''the internal decay of capitalism'' - is neither supported nor shared by his more sophisticated McKinsey colleagues.
But Mr. Ohmae's virtues clearly outweigh his shortcomings. Having been accused of being an agent of the Japanese Government's Ministry of International Trade and Industry, he is unsparing in his criticisms of Tokyo. ''Japan,'' he writes, ''is a bureaucratic country, not a political one. The Diet [the Japanese parliament] plays a minor role compared with the powerful bureaucratic system.''
Nor does he stop with the Japanese bureaucracy: ''No country represents a single value system, and no effort to pretend that it does - or to act as if it does - is both credible and effective. In Japan, for example, Hokkaido may want to become the Switzerland of Asia and a hub for international air travel. Tokyo may want to go its own way. Osaka's interests may lie in becoming the capital of East Asia and not competing with Tokyo. . . . The rest of the population has legitimate doubts about just how far the health of these cities has any spillover benefits for them. . . . Regions pull in different directions.''
What is implied is that conflicts between the interests of governments and those of evolving marketplaces will ultimately be resolved by devolution - the breaking up of countries and the drastic reduction of state power. It's this sort of insight that makes Mr. Ohmae well worth reading.

LENGTH: 1346 words

HEADLINE: The Reluctant Terrorist

BYLINE: By FRANCINE PROSE; Francine Prose's most recent book is a collection of short stories, ''Women and Children First.''

 BODY:

LIES OF SILENCE
By Brian Moore.
197 pp. New York:
Nan A. Talese/
Doubleday. $18.95.
Nothing cheers a writer so little as well-intentioned commiseration for not having attained the vast readership admirers think one deserves. And yet there are certain authors whose gifts so exceed their renown that their situation inevitably inspires this sort of unhelpful puzzlement and indignation.
One such writer is Brian Moore, whose 16th novel, ''Lies of Silence,'' is characteristically first rate. The recipient of major awards in Canada and Britain, Mr. Moore has so far failed to achieve what the pollsters succinctly call ''name recognition'' in the United States, perhaps because his work ranges so widely, from intense novels of sensibility (''The Lonely Passion of Judith Hearne'') to suspenseful, ingeniously plotted thrillers with moral and metaphysical themes (''Cold Heaven,'' ''The Color of Blood''). Perhaps the problem is that Mr. Moore's nationality involves multiple hyphenation -born in Belfast, he has spent much of his life in Canada and now resides in Southern California. Or the problem may even lie with the estimable qualities that are found in his diverse books. This is not, after all, an era of fevered acclaim for the quietly controlled, the intelligent, the spiritually minded and unassuming. 
Paradise for the reader, purgatory for the critic, the plot of ''Lies of Silence'' is one that only a spoiler would reveal - and risk ruining the surprises that detonate throughout the novel like cleverly hidden and elegantly designed incendiary devices. (The notion of ''unbearable suspense'' is, of course, a cliche, but I found that I kept briefly putting down the novel to postpone the moment when I had to face what might happen next.) Set in contemporary Northern Ireland, ''Lies of Silence'' centers on Michael Dillon, the manager of a grand old Belfast hotel, an establishment to which families traditionally come for graduation luncheons and where, on a morning just after the novel begins, a well-known Protestant rabble-rouser is scheduled to address a convention of the Canadian Orange Order. In Dillon's Belfast version of a normal life, the ''Troubles'' and the presence of British soldiers are a daily fact; body checks and bomb threats have come to seem routine: ''A queue of cars was waiting to be admitted to the hotel grounds. Security was tight, for the hotel had been bombed last year. The occupants of each car must get out and go into the adjoining hut for a body search, while the car itself was checked over by the outside guards.''
Dillon is one of those Irishmen one recognizes fondly from the work of Sean O'Faolain, Frank O'Connor and William Trevor; we know, even upon first meeting them, that these men are not destined for great happiness, that even the small pleasures life offers them will sadly come to nothing. As the novel opens, Dillon is tormenting himself over the (one might think) straightforward choice between his shrill, unstable wife and his loving mistress, a young BBC reporter whose imminent transfer to London triggers the first of the personal crises that set the plot in motion.
Although to Dillon these difficulties seem singularly oppressive, they strike us as neither exceptional nor uncommon until, in the course of one frightening night, he unwillingly becomes involved in a violent I.R.A. terrorist plot. Suddenly his domestic difficulties are both heightened and dwarfed by an almost impossible moral dilemma that transforms his private life into the sensational stuff of the evening news. The effect on Dillon is seismic, and soon there are aftershocks -a succession of ethical temptations and decisions that sends him fleeing to London and changes forever his notions of heroism, of the possibility of escape.
Graham Greene has called Brian Moore his ''favorite living novelist.'' Although the two writers are significantly different, Mr. Greene's remark does suggest the affection we often feel for those whose interests and virtues remind us warmly of our own. Like Mr. Greene, Mr. Moore often focuses on men (and in Mr. Moore's case, women) in situations of extreme crisis. Both write brilliantly about how various sorts of spiritual and historical struggles (crises of faith; political, moral, romantic crises) can overlap and complicate one another - and in the end turn out to be separate manifestations of a single human condition. Finally, both Graham Greene and Brian Moore write spare, swiftly plotted fiction that is capable of supporting considerable thematic weight.
So, too, ''Lies of Silence'' has immense tensile strength. One is struck by how austere its sentences are - and yet by how much the novel embraces, how much disturbance it generates without ever stooping to theatrics, how daringly it approaches and eludes the clutches of melodrama. It is possible to read this book purely for the pleasantly unsettling angst its dramatic plot induces. But it is more rewarding to pause and admire its flashes of depth and the nervy way in which Mr. Moore takes textbook-case ethical quandaries (the good of one versus the good of many, the right to a private life versus social responsibility) and uses the techniques of fiction to give them an agonizing, provocative spin. Certain scenes - Dillon's wife's conversation with a jumpy, teen-age I.R.A. volunteer and, later, his own confrontation with a manipulative Catholic priest - can be read as paradigms of how to create tension and surprise while remaining convincing and without contrivance.
Over his long career, Brian Moore has mastered the literary magic trick of making the weighty seem graceful, making the dense and complex seem effortless and unadorned. One hopes that ''Lies of Silence'' will inspire more readers to discover Mr. Moore's earlier work, to experience the range and agility of this fine writer's sleight of hand.
 
'ANY OF US COULD BE HOSTAGES'
''I wanted the book to read like a thriller, but to be something more,'' said Brian Moore of his latest novel, ''Lies of Silence.'' ''I didn't want to do a whole book about Northern Ireland, but I did want to talk about how often ordinary people are taken as hostages, their homes invaded - and the moral choices they're forced to make. I go back to Ireland often and no one ever talks about the hostages.''
Speaking by telephone recently from his home in Los Angeles, Mr. Moore compared life in Northern Ireland with the situation in Kuwait and Iraq. ''We're in a position now where any of us could be hostages,'' he observed, ''and that can create the dilemma of loyalty to family versus saving the lives of others.''
But, Mr. Moore added, both in his book and in real life, the hostages are not the only victims. ''The I.R.A. members who do these jobs are young, poorly educated and disillusioned. Imagine all your life being unemployed and discriminated against. These terrorist groups give them a sense of belonging. It's a way to be big with their peers. It's not that different from the street gangs in Los Angeles, the Crips or the Bloods.''
The parallel is especially clear, Mr. Moore pointed out, since neither the I.R.A. nor the American street gangs have much of a political agenda, beyond getting rid of their enemies. ''There is terrible job discrimination against Catholics in Northern Ireland,'' he said. ''It's like the black situation here; you have to address economic concerns before you can handle the rest of it.''
Yet despite the novel's political overtones, it is also, Mr. Moore said, ''a love story'' - one that raises its own troubling set of questions. ''What happens,'' Mr. Moore asked, ''when a woman gives up her career to marry, and it just isn't enough for her? She can't just pick it up five years later. And what happens when a man chooses a wife mainly for physical attractiveness rather than compatibility?''
There are not necessarily any clear answers to such questions, Mr. Moore said. But his books give him a chance to make readers think about their endless complexities.
SHARON SHERVINGTON

LENGTH: 778 words

HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
Mercedes Gets Smoother by the Mile

BYLINE: By MARSHALL SCHUON

 BODY:
AT first glance, the car in the driveway looks like a new Mercedes. At second glance, it still looks that way. But this silver sedan has been a real nomad since it rolled out of a Florida dealer's showroom back in October 1984.
The car is a 1985 model, a four-door 380 SE, and there are 101,042 miles on the odometer. It would appear that not one of those miles did anything even remotely unkind to the vehicle, and the 380 well might strike a pose when Webster's decides to illustrate the page containing the word cream puff. 
It should be said that the 380 belongs to Mercedes-Benz of North America, and that the folks who run the company in Montvale, N.J., know exactly what they have on their hands and how to make the most of it. The car is so clean that it belongs in a museum, but they are trotting it out to prove what J. D. Power and Associates said last year in a study of vehicle dependability.
In its survey, the California consultancy firm found that owners of 5-year-old Mercedes vehicles cited the fewest and least severe problems during their latest year of ownership. Questions were asked about 89 specific problem areas, and answers were extrapolated into a rating of customer satisfaction.
An average index was set at 100, and a mere dozen makers were rated at that mark or better, with Mercedes scoring 149 to win. That is no great surprise, given the median $47,000 sticker of the company's products, but that very figure is the other reason I have been driving the car.
''There's a logical reason why we're doing this,'' said John Chuhran, a Mercedes spokesman. ''People may want to get into a Mercedes, but they might not have the financial means to get into a new one right away. So what we have done is give them all the features at a less expensive price.'' Sounds suspiciously like a used car, right? Right, but Mercedes has gone a bit farther, and there is now a factory warranty - shorter in duration but similar to the one issued with new cars - on vehicles dating back to 1980. Coverage is at the dealer's discretion and depends both on the automobile's condition and on its mileage.
For cars with less than 75,000 miles, there is a two-year guarantee, and a 12-month warranty is offered on cars showing 75,000 to 100,000 miles. Items covered are the powertrain, steering, suspension, cooling, fuel injection, electrical, brake and climate-control systems, and the buyer has full use of the company's roadside assistance plan.
Mercedes keeps close tabs on the prices fetched by used cars across the country, and Chuhran pointed to two recent studies that show Mercedes holding its value better than any other make. The company publishes average prices for used models every month, and the East Coast figure on the 380 SE in the driveway is $25,365. That is a bit less than the national average of $26,793, but it is still almost two-thirds of the car's $42,730 price when new.
What the money bought five years ago was a five-passenger sedan with a 3.8-liter V8 that fed 155 horsepower to the road through a four-speed automatic transmission. It was the gasoline version of the 300 SD diesel, and it was sold here only in the '84 and '85 model years.
Air bags didn't become standard Mercedes equipment until 1986, but there was big news for '85 with introduction of standard antilock brakes on five of the company's cars, including the 380 SE. Heated outside mirrors also were newly standard, as were the improved central locking and antitheft systems. And the car also was given standard power headrests.
Amazingly, everything on the silver car still works perfectly. The gray leather is crisp and beautiful as ever, and there is that giant black steering wheel with pebbled grain. There is the 160-m.p.h. speedometer and a sunroof that slides open without a murmur. There is a good big ashtray for the unrepentant, and the genuine wood trim still looks like polished plastic.
Like today's Mercedes, the 380 has an accelerator that resists your foot and is thus well behaved until you put your sole into it. At that point, and even with just 155 horsepower, the 3,740-pound car gets down and goes.
On the road, the ride remains solid and quiet, stiff but comfortable, and if there is a complaint, it is that fuel economy is a thirsty misnomer at 16 miles per gallon, city, and 18, highway. With a 23.8-gallon tank, though, the SE will go a long way between stops.
It has already gone a very long way indeed, and while no one is pretending that the 380 is a typical 100,000-mile Mercedes, Chuhran said he believes it's a nice demonstrator of durability. ''It gives you an idea of why we can offer the warranty,'' he said.

SECTION: Section 12CN; Page 1, Column 4; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1134 words

HEADLINE: Turning Humble Materials Into Salable Arts and Crafts

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH

 BODY:
''I don't have a passion for handicrafts,'' admitted the organization's president, Clare Brett Smith, ''but I like what these handicrafts represent.''
She said she also likes the idea that many of the group's ventures use leftovers and scraps. ''It's a bit of New England traditional frugality - use it up and make it do,'' Mrs. Smith said.
The 13-year-old Aid to Artisans operates in 30 countries in Asia, Africa and Latin America. Mrs. Smith said the organization has no grandiose expectations that a handicraft industry will bring prosperity to impoverished villagers. But, she said, the thousands of workers it has trained earn as they produce. 
''What they buy, they buy sensibly - cows or school clothes for their children,'' she said, adding that virtually all of the workers are women. ''They get their teeth fixed or put a new roof on the shed.''
United States Representative Nancy L. Johnson, a Republican of New Britain, said the group provided significant help to women by teaching them new skills and helping them acquire experience as entrepeneurs.
''What's remarkable about Aid to Artisans is it enables women to see their ordinary skills and the ordinary materials around them in a fresh way,'' said Representative Johnson. ''It literally empowers those women to create a new vision about economic power and economic success. Then it is on to the next product and the next market.''
The group's operation is a lean one, housed rent-free at Mrs. Smith's red-brick home, described by architects as ''collegiate Gothic.'' Her husband, Burges, a tennis-court builder, serves as treasurer and supplies business advice; volunteers provide the office help. With no showroom or glossy catalogue, Aid for Artisans displays its samples for buyers twice a year at the New York International Gift Fair, and the orders keep arriving.
The Smiths live surrounded by the crafts they have encouraged artisans to create - bronze statues from Ghana, terra cotta dragons from Indonesia, an embroidered bedspread from Bangladesh. A Pakastani wedding canopy covers the Smiths' pool table. They have wool rugs from Jordan and clay pots from Haiti. A seven-foot coffin from Ghana, shaped like a giant cacao pod, serves as a conversation piece in the dining room.
Aid to Artisans has attracted grants from some of the country's leading philanthropies, including the Ford, Rockefeller and MacArthur Foundations. The Federal Agency for International Development also has financed some activities, like a program in Honduras, where a single product, a clay cherub, has brought a small economic boom to scores of villagers.
The potential of the ornamental cherub first was recognized five years ago by Holland Millis, a product-development specialist for the organization. Honduran women make them at home, using clay dug from pastures outside the village of Yarumela. The figures became an almost instant success when 50,000 were ordered by Dansk and other importers. Mrs. Smith said that earnings from the cherubs or corn-husk flowers go a long way in Honduras, where a one-room adobe house can be built for $250.
 
'Whimsical Market'
Earlier operations to help the Honduran artisans had failed, said Margaret Kronhout, a project-development officer for the Agency for International Development who has served in Honduras for 15 years. ''The United States market for exported crafts is a special one, and it's a whimsical market,'' she said. ''Aid to Artisans succeeded, because it supplied critical support in designing products that would have real appeal.''
Aid to Artisans was established in 1977 by James Blout, after he retired from the World Crafts Council, where he was secretary general for a decade. From his home in Chestnut Hill, Mass., he continues to serve as chairman, publishes a newsletter and works to increase the group's membership. The 450 members help support the activities with contributions ranging from $25 to $5,000.
The organization hoped to stimulate more artisans in disadvantaged communities in the United States, said Mr. Blout, but for each American request for help, the organization receives 50 from abroad.
 
In Hugo's Wake
It gave early help to the Watermark Association of Artisans, a cooperative in Elizabeth City, N.C., which has grown into an association of 450 members, widely recognized as one of the most successful craft groups in the country. It also helped Afghan and Cambodian refugees living in northern Virginia to purchase sewing equipment. In the aftermath of Hurricane Hugo last year, Aid to Artisans gave financial help to basket weavers in coastal towns of South Carolina, where storms tore at local beaches and destroyed their dwindling supplies of sweetgrass.
It is also beginning to work with Hungarian crafters and displayed their embroidery and decorative red-felt pillows at the New York craft show in August. But Mr. Blout said the group's major impact continues to be in the third world.
 
Model of Help
In the craft field, buyers for stores jealously protect their sources of supply, he said, and artisans are also chary about sharing their experience. But Mrs. Smith and Mr. Blout said they want their organization to serve as a model and source of help.
Much of the organization's field work depends on specialists like Mr. Millis and Docey Lewis, a weaver and textile designer who lives in Washington, Conn., when she is not rushing off to Somalia or Jordan on an assignment for Aid to Artisans. Ms. Lewis, a member of the organization's board, works as a volunteer.
Mrs. Smith, trained as a photographer, is the organization's archivist. Legal and tax advice is provided by another volunteer, Tim Lyman, a lawyer in Hartford.
Aid to Artisans works as well as it does, Mrs. Smith said, because there is no hiring and firing to worry about, no promotions and no raises. ''We like to say we're nimble,'' said Mr. Lyman.

Company is based in Farmington (pg. 11) (Steve Miller for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 12CN; Page 1, Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1595 words

HEADLINE: Budget Cuts Are Hitting Home As Schools Open

BYLINE: By CHARLOTTE LIBOV

 BODY:

 
Reforms Are Threatened
Terry Cassidy, executive director of the Connecticut Association of Boards of Education, which represents 150 schoolboards, is also concerned.
''In my 12-year-history with the association,'' he said, ''I have never seen anything which approached the intensity of what's going on in the state now, in terms of budget cuts. You could call almost every school district and talk about budget problems.''
State Education Commissioner Gerald N. Tirozzi is so concerned that he is proposing a $152 million increase in grants to municipal school districts as part of his $1.5 billion state education budget for 1991-92.
Commissioner Tirozzi fears that the severe budget cuts could affect the state's newly adopted package of educational reforms, which include tougher teacher training. 
''The bottom line is if we're raising salaries and increasing class size but laying off beginning teachers, then there's something wrong,'' the Commissioner said.
In many communities, these rising salaries have become the favorite target of taxpayer groups. In 1986, the state poured $300 million into a program to raise teachers' salaries, and that, along with binding arbitration, has pushed the state's average teacher salary to $41,361, among the highest in the nation.
''This is part of a statewide, if not a nationwide pattern of cutting back on education,'' said the Norwalk School Superintendent, Ralph E. Sloan, ''and it is especially severe in Connecticut, where teachers' salaries went up substantially. This is part of the inevitable backlash. People say, 'teachers salaries are up, and what do we have to show for it.' ''
Tight budgets are the norm in both cities and towns, school officials throughout the state said. While this is not a new situation for urban school officials, some of their colleagues in Connecticut's wealthier suburbs are less accustomed to cutting budgets.
In Bridgeport, 30 teachers were laid off and textbook and supply accounts cut, said Richard W. Callahan, the school district's business director. School officials had requested nearly $94 million, an increase of $7.5 million from last year's budget, largely to cover negotiated salary increases, but the schools were allocated $92.6 million by the city, he said.
''The city is in very bad financial shape,'' Mr. Callahan said, ''so there have been a lot of cutbacks and layoffs throughout the city and the board of education.''
This is not as bad as it might seem, because over the past few years, substantial state aid has been funneled into the city, enabling Bridgeport to increase its teachers' salaries, buy supplies and undertake school repairs. But, Mr. Callahan said, ''We'll be in trouble'' if budget cuts continue.
In West Hartford, which has a tradition of offering a wide array of educational programs, the school year will begin without an official budget for the first time in recent memory. A second budget referendum will be held on Sept. 25. For now, school officials are using a $55 million school budget figure, but if that is cut further, it will mean teacher layoffs, said Assistant Superintendent Matthew Borrelli. The original budget proposal was $57.2 million.
As it is, the number of full-time kindergarten programs is down to three schools from 10, and the gifted and talented program is being trimmed. But the biggest change will be in high school athletics, where students will have to pay $15 a sport to participate. Previously, students were not charged.
''It was a difficult decision to make,'' Mr. Borrelli said, ''but the consensuswas that rather than eliminate sports, this would be a shared burden between the community and the schools.''
In Suffield, where residents rejected the town budget three times, about $1 million has been cut from the proposed $11.5 million school budget,Superintendent Bernard J. Ellis said.
''This is the worst year I've had in 23 years as a superintendent. I'd thought I'd seen them all, but this is a new experience,'' said Mr. Ellis.
The high school social worker and two vice principals have been eliminated in Suffield, along with the freshman sports program, ice hockey, and the gifted program in the elementary school. There will be no high school field trips ''unless parents raise the money themselves,'' Mr. Ellis said.
In Windsor, nearly $2.6 million was cut from the school system's $26 million budget request, which meant laying off 11 teachers and 20 teacher aides, said the district's business director, Allan Brockman.
''There is a three-page list of reductions,'' he said, ''running from reductions in textbooks, library books, reductions in maps and globes, reductions in capital maintenance, elimination of a day care program, right through pretty much every program in the district.''
For the first time in many years in Cheshire, no new school building projects will be brought before the voters, said Superintendent John J. Barnes.
''A lot of our proposed school projects were just eliminated and put off,'' he said. ''There are overcrowding problems here, but we failed to convince the public we need to have building additions.'' The town will continue to use portable classrooms at some of its elementary schools, he said.
 
Letting Things Go
In Madison, the town cut $1.1 million from the proposed $20.3 million school budget during ''the toughest year I can remember in 18 years,'' Assistant Superintendent Robert K. Wolfe said.
''We're proud of the fact that we've kept our plants in incredible physical condition,'' he said, ''but we're letting all kinds of things go. Painting, repainting, repaving of parking lots, you name it.''
In Norwalk, the town cut $1.5 million from the proposed $71.4 million school budget.
''We've wiped out our reading consultants,'' Superintendent Sloan said. ''We've reduced guidance counselors, we've reduced staffing at the high schools and we cut back on supplies, materials and maintenance.
''We're in a recession, for all practical purposes, and people are not willing to pay the level of taxes or face increases. Virtually every school system I know took a fair amount of budget cuts. We're all in the soup together.''
 
'A Lot of Wailing'
Wilton residents traditionally are generous in their support of school spending, but this year, for the first time in a decade, there was a referendum, and the proposed $22 million school budget was slashed by $75,000, said Superintendent David S. Clune.
''In the past, we'd get support, but now, there are a number of people in town, including retirees, who see their budgets increasing, and it's difficult for them,'' he said.
In Stamford, some 50 school employees, mostly experienced teachers, will be gone this fall, having taken advantage of an early retirement program whose savings helped the school board cut its proposed $99.8 million budget by $5.3 million, said Allen Grafton, an assistant to the superintendent.
''There was a lot of wailing and gnashing of teeth,'' he said, ''but by the time it got down to it, we survived. But this is the second year in a row we've reduced staff. We're down about 100 people in all. If this continues, you're really going to have an impact on the total educational program.''
 
A Bitter Fight
Perhaps nowhere in the state was the battle over a school budget fought more bitterly than in Region 14, which consists of the two small northwestern Connecticut towns of Bethlehem and Woodbury. There, the battle over the budget required a record seven referendums and escalated into allegations of threats and vandalism. ''It was nothing like I had ever seen before,'' Superintendent Paul Hinckley said.
''The voters were very upset,'' he said, ''which is probably an understatement, over the increase in teachers' salaries, and they were trying to send a message to us.
''Unfortunately, the children saw adults acting like children, with all the name calling that went on,'' he added.
The budget finally passed in August, after a $577,000 cut, which means seven teachers and an assistant principal will be eliminated, he said.
Still, Bethlehem First Selectman George C. Eggert, a school budget critic, maintains the school board's new $11.8 million budget is too fat.
''A lot of us, and I am one, feel that the money is not being well spent,'' Mr. Eggert said. ''There was an awful lot of waste and there still is. I think the schools are overstaffed and some of our teachers are earning too much money. Some deserve it, and some are deadwood.''
Mr. Hinckley is already thinking ahead to next spring when budget time rolls around again.
''I hope everyone comes back with a very positive attitude,'' he said. ''It's a new year, start off fresh, and put what's happened in the past behind us, and go ahead full steam on a new course. In the coming year, our major goal is going to be to pass the budget on the first try.''
First Selectman Eggert would like to do that too, but, he said, ''We'll be looking for a very frugal budget.''
