Copyright 1990 The New York Times Company 
The New York Times

PUB-DATE: September 2, 1990

SECTION: Section 12NJ; Page 1, Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 2117 words

HEADLINE: New Rules On Oil Tanks Intensify Fuel Battle

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:

 
Targets of Gas Companies' Campaign
The natural gas companies, however, while acknowledging that they are indeed trying to persuade customers to switch from oil to gas, say that the targets of their current campaign, which draws attention to the new regulations, are commercial and industrial users. Residents who do switch from oil to gas, they say, do so out of economic and environmental concerns.
The new regulations, scheduled to take effect on Tuesday, are ''just another nail in the coffin,'' said Paul Spatz, owner of the Grant Oil Company in Newark, which serves more than 2,500 oil customers in northern New Jersey. ''Every time a new problem arises, another customer yanks his tank out and converts to gas,'' he said.
But converting from oil to gas may create new problems for homeowners when they stop using their underground storage tanks, heating contractors and tank removal specialists say. 
By failing to regulate abandonment of the smaller tanks, they say, the new regulations perpetuate the current practice of allowing local officials to determine, often on an ad hoc basis, the methods used to close tanks that are no longer in use.
That practice, they say, has resulted in a hodgepodge of regulations that can cause problems for homeowners if abandonment of a tank is not properly completed. An improperly closed tank can corrode because of condensation, for example, and can leak at the bottom or collapse at the top if someone walks over it.
In addition, prospective home buyers, concerned with the potential for problems with an abandoned tank, might require a seller to have the tank removed as a condition of the sale.
''This could be the beginning of the end of our business,'' Mr. Spatz said, referring to the current convergence of factors facing the home heating oil industry. Oil merchants, he said, who have long been subject to price and supply factors beyond their control, are now faced with convincing an increasingly cautious public that oil heat will remain economical.
 
Concern Called Unwarranted
That task is made more difficult, Mr. Spatz said, by customers' heightened yet often unwarranted concern that an underground tank may be a source of problems in the future.
''The fact of the matter is that oil is a more efficient energy source with a higher B.T.U. output than gas,'' Mr. Spatz said. In addition, he said, it would take either many years or a huge jump in the price of oil for a homeowner to recoup the conversion costs, which average about $2,200.
Nevertheless, he said, gas industry advertisements highlighting concerns over underground tanks ''have struck fear in the hearts of homeowners.'' And the new regulations, he said, though not targeted at the smaller tanks, will only intensify that fear.
The regulations, which were mandated by the Legislature in 1986, apply to new and existing tanks with a capacity of 2,000 gallons or more. They require corrosion protection, continuous monitoring for corrosion and systems that guard against spills and overfilling. In addition, any such tank that is abandoned must be removed from the ground in accordance with strict standards set by the Department of Environmental Protection.
''If the abandoned oil tank isn't sealed and cleaned properly,'' said Robert Frezzo, vice president of Frezzo Oil Service Inc. in Union City, ''water can leak in, corrode the bottom, and the next thing you know you have contaminated soil.''
 
Corrosion Could Cause Cave-In
Another danger, he said, is that corrosion on the top of the tank may cause someone walking above the tank to fall through into the empty tank.
On the other hand, he said, if the tank is sealed too tightly, and is empty, it might eventually rise out of the ground in an area that has a high water table.
And finally, Mr. Frezzo said, an empty, improperly sealed tank may be accidentally filled with oil by a dealer who was unaware that the tank was abandoned. Computer-driven automatic filling schedules based upon ''degree days'' make that a distinct possibility, he said.
So even though cleaning and filling an abandoned tank is usually safe if done properly, he said, ''if this were a perfect world every underground tank would be ripped out.''
Though the new regulations require just that for large abandoned commercial tanks, they do not extend to the tens of thousands of smaller tanks in basements and under front lawns in towns across the state. The authority to determine what must be done with those tanks rests with local officials.
 
Disposal Required Sometimes
While most municipalities require contractors to clean, fill and seal abandoned tanks, some require that they be removed and disposed of.
''Anything larger than 550 gallons we want them to yank out,'' said Robert G. Michelin, a fire subcode official for Union City. Smaller tanks, he said, can be cleaned and filled. But in West New York, all tanks, regardless of size, must be removed. Ronald Franco, the township's fire inspector, said West New York also required the soil under the tank to be inspected and tested if it appeared to be contaminated.
''And if we find there's contamination,'' he said, ''we bring in the regional health commission.'' Contaminated soil, he said, would have to be removed and replaced with clean soil at the homeowner's expense.
Mr. Frezzo, who has customers in both towns, said that since there was no consistent policy in effect, prospective purchasers who discovered that there was an abandoned underground tank in a home they were considering buying often required the seller to have the tank removed, ''just to be on the safe side.''
 
Couple Convert to Gas
Robert and Patricia Auth of the township of Union in Union County, though not under such pressure, decided recently to do just that by having their abandoned oil tank removed.
''We figured we would take the thing out and then we wouldn't have to worry about it anymore,'' Mr. Auth said. The Auths converted from oil to gas two years ago and were concerned that Union officials might someday require them to remove the abandoned tank.
Anthony Noce, president of the Environmental Clean-Up and Protection Association, the Verona-based company that removed the Auths' tank, said business had increased recently as a result of concerns like the Auths' and those expressed by Mr. Frezzo.
Mr. Noce said, ''We're getting a lot of calls from real-estate people who can't put the sale through until the tank is cleaned or removed.''
He said that while most towns required that underground tanks be cleaned and filled rather than completely removed, even the cleaning and filling often required considerable work.
To clean a tank properly, he said, workers have to dig down to the tank, cut the top off and get inside the tank to make sure that all the oil is removed. When the tank is clean, it is filled with sand and then covered again with dirt.
 
Average Cost of $1,000
The cost of cleaning an average residential tank, he said, is $1,000 to $1,500. Removal, he said, can cost up to twice as much but is preferred because the soil under the tank can be tested for contamination, an option not available when the tank is only cleaned.
In any event, he said, a consistent statewide policy is preferable to the current practice of letting local officials determine standards because then contractors and homeowners will specifically know what their responsibilities are.
Kenneth Goldstein, chief of the Bureau of Underground Storage Tanks in the State Department of Environmental Protection, agreed that the lack of a uniform policy could lead to confusion.
''I would prefer to have some type of consistent, minimum standard,'' he said. ''But the Legislature decided that certain smaller homeowners' tanks should not be regulated. As a result, we're left with the possibility of 567 municipalities setting up their own requirements.''
Legislation sponsored by Assemblyman William E. Schluter, Republican of Pennington, would provide such guidelines. The bill, Mr. Schluter said, should it pass this year, allows for on-site abandonment if it can be proved that the empty tank will not pose a danger to ground water.
 
'Tanks Leak'
Mr. Goldstein, however, said that if the decision were left to him, all abandoned tanks, regardless of size, would have to be removed. ''Tanks leak,'' he said. ''Even small ones.'' And that sentiment, oil dealers say, has led to the advertising campaign now being waged by the natural gas industry.
Fred J. Sacco, executive vice president of the Fuel Merchants Association of New Jersey, a Springfield-based trade association, said that the natural gas companies had capitalized upon, and indeed encouraged, homeowners' fears about their underground tanks.
''You can clearly see how the government regulations have been a useful tool with respect to their advertising,'' Mr. Sacco said, referring to a recent gas industry advertising campaign that refers to large underground storage tanks as potential ''financial time bombs.''
''It's some pretty scary stuff,'' Mr. Sacco said, ''and they have used it to extend those fears to homeowners. It's clearly a scare tactic.''
 
Profit Set by State Agency
The fuel merchants' resentment is further heightened by the fact that gas companies, as public utilities, are entitled to a profit set by the state's Board of Public Utilities, that profit being determined after allowing for certain expenses.
James Divine, executive director of the Metropolitan Energy Council, a Norwood-based association of 750 fuel dealers in the New Jersey-New York-Connecticut area, said that as a result, gas companies had an unfair advantage over fuel dealers.
''Their advertising, being a cost of doing business, is built into their rate base,'' he said. As a result, he said, those costs are passed directly to customers. And that, he said, allows the gas companies to spend more than four times the amount that fuel dealers spend for advertising and still generate a profit.
As is the case with most public utilities, he said, the gas companies do not have to spend any of that money advertising against other gas companies. Fuel dealers on the other hand, he said, spend millions of dollars each a year just advertising against one another.
That, however, does not seem to trouble the gas industry.
 
'We're Not Shy About Advertising'
''We're not shy about advertising the benefits of natural gas,'' said Neil Brown, a spokesman for the Public Service Electric and Gas Company in Newark, one of the state's largest utilities. ''And we are not shy about pointing out some of the problems with oil heat,'' he said.
Mr. Brown acknowledged that some of the company's recent advertisements strongly addressed the safety aspects of underground tanks, but said that such advertising was limited to the industrial and commercial markets.
''I'm not aware of any advertising of that kind directed at the residential market,'' he said.
Responding to fuel dealers' contentions that customers ultimately pay for such advertising, Mr. Brown said that while such expenses were indeed included in the rate base, they must be approved by the Board of Public Utilities.
In addition, he said, ''It's a pretty sure bet that the advertising costs incurred by oil distributors eventually find their way into oil prices as well.''
In any event, it appears that the state's oil merchants are fighting an uphill battle. According to statistics compiled by the American Gas Association in Arlington, Va., there were approximately 105,000 oil-to-gas conversions nationwide in 1989; almost 17,000 of those were in New Jersey.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY OPINION;
Cutting Down On Trash

BYLINE: By JUDY KEENAN; Judy Keenan is natural resources director of the League of Women Voters of New Jersey.

 BODY:
Logically, reducing the amount of garbage we generate should be primary, but legislation in this area is too often misguided because it is promulgated on a lack of knowledge, or disincentives. Two examples of this type of legislation are requiring the use of recycled newsprint with no understanding of the international market forces that drive the paper economy or the limited number of paper recycling mills, and higher taxation on single-use items, like disposable diapers or microwavable individual packaging, penalizing the consumer.
Recycling was sold initially as a moneymaker for municipalities. Now the market for newspapers has fizzled, and many towns are paying to take these recyclables away. 
True, recycling still reduces the money we have to spend to export materials to landfills, but that is an economic abstract that is difficult to sell to the public.
Recycling was the ''glamorous'' part of the solid-waste problem. We could all do it with not a lot of inconvenience and applaud our efforts. But recycling is losing its glamour. We're still left with hazardous household waste to dispose of, drop-off sites and centers are closing because they are in residential areas where neighbors object, and it's costing us money.
Incineration presents more controversy. We have scientists saying it is perfectly safe, and scientists saying it is lethal. Will six regional incinerators be any less detrimental than 18 smaller ones when we factor in the truck emissions going to the regional sites? Is the Warren County facility a good model or a good lesson? Once we burn, where will we put the ash?
Landfills are dwindling, and the states we export to are indicating a reluctance to continue taking our garbage. The Federal Government says we cannot dump sewage sludge in the ocean, so we have to dispose of it on land. Many fear that it will leach into our water supply. We cannot compost all our solid waste because of all the hazardous and nonbiodegradable products we use.
And so we come to source reduction. We can reduce solid wastesignificantly, but not without changes. As consumers, we would have to give up many conveniences we are accustomed to. Can we as a society forgo polystyrene cups, disposable diapers, one-use packaging?
The manufacturers and distributors of the products focus their research and development on marketing, firmly convinced that consumers want their products. Until we send a clear message demanding environmentally friendly products, all the talk about new product development will not coalesce into tangible results.
Source reduction should be an integral first step in the solid-waste hierarchy, but it can happen only when we are concerned enough to place our environment before our convenience. When we do that, environmentally friendly products will be invented out of economic necessity. Are the policy makers and the people willing to get to the source and take the first step together?

HEADLINE: Northeast Notebook: Middlebury, Vt.;
Inns Facing Tougher Times

BYLINE: By Kent Shaw

 BODY:
For Martin and Marcia Schuppert, buying the 180-year-old Waybury Inn last month - the one shown on the long-running Bob Newhart television show - was something of a dream come true.
Mrs. Schuppert's parents, Bud and Betty Greene, owned the inn for 12 years before selling it in 1980. And Mr. Schuppert, a life-long restaurateur, got his first job, as a teen-age busboy, in the 14-room hostelry tucked into a grove of maples on Route 125. 
As enthusiastic as the couple is, industry observers warn that keeping a country inn profitable may be a daunting job. Regional economic downturns, changing tourism habits and a weak real estate market are putting pressure on the Vermont hospitality industry.
''People have stopped going to inns in droves,'' said William Oates, a broker specializing in inn acquisition and operations. The Vermont Lodging and Restaurant Association recently reported level or declining occupancy rates and room and meal tax receipts around the state.
''We're in a precarious position,'' said Daniel Pudvah, the association's executive vice president. ''There's a lot of thinking that the worst part has yet to hit Vermont.''
Prices of Vermont inns, which tripled in the 80's, have leveled too, and brokers say more are on the market now than ever.
The Greens bought the Waybury Inn in 1968 for $98,500 and sold it in 1980 for $248,000; it sold for $775,000 in 1987 and $827,000 this summer.
Single-room rates, averaging about $60, have stayed steady for two years and Mr. Pudvah said travelers commonly switch inns for price differences of only a few dollars. At the same time, he said, inn owners are being pressured to offer more amenities.
Zeke Church, a consultant for Baron Resources Corporation of Avon, Conn., says that the company, which once targeted 100 New England inns for acquisition, has ceased looking for properties.
The ineptitude of the Newhart cast makes good comedy, but the reality is that successful inns are moving into the hands of well-trained professionals. Mr. Oates said his bi-monthly seminars draw, not the older couples he used to see, but 30-ish people, often with business degrees, seeking careers.
Sales of Vermont inns during the real estate boom of the 80's often were to couples who enjoyed spectacular capital gains on homes around New York or Boston. No longer, he said.
The Schupperts say they are ready to invest in improvements, and will begin offering ski and bicycling packages. They also plan to overhaul the inn's menu and make the 144-seat restaurant profitable on its own.

HEADLINE: Census Workers Remember Resistance and Lies

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO

 BODY:
''The managing agent wouldn't know if there were three people in the apartment or one,'' said the worker, an unemployed manufacturing executive in her 30's who spoke on condition that only her first name, Judy, be used. ''Sometimes people are subletting without telling the people in the building.''
In the South Bronx, Ada B. Gonzalez, 50 years old, said she knocked at a single-family house where the owner appeared to be renting to two other families with several children. She was introducing herself to one of the families, she said, when the owner came out of a separate entrance and told her that only one family, his, lived in the house. 
''I couldn't put them down as just people,'' she said. ''I had to interview the families or he had to give me the information.''
Rough 1990 census figures released last week showed New York City with a population of 7,003,179, or 38,460 fewer residents than in 1980. The estimate confirmed the worst fears of city officials, who have charged that a count based on finding people and asking them questions cannot be accurate where thousands fear the Government, move frequently, do not speak English or will not cooperate for other reasons. A Million More Than Recorded? City officials believe that the city gained population during the 1980's, and said last week that they believe that New York has at least a million more people than the rough census figures show. Other cities across the country, like Houston, Philadelphia and Atlanta, have complained that they, too, were seriously undercounted.
Unwillingness to cooperate and the inability to find some residents are factors the Census Bureau took into account in its instructions to the more than 200,000 workers dispatched across the country in April to count people who failed to return their census forms by mail. The workers were required to make six attempts to contact a household. As a last resort, they were to obtain basic demographic characteristics from a reliable third party like a building superintendent or a neighbor.
But as the workers diligently conducted interviews and filled out census questionnaires, some said they often suspected the accuracy of the information they were given. In New York City, where enumerators had to visit more than one million households, sources frequently lied or simply did not know enough, the workers said.
Although common sense sometimes accounted for their skepticism, the workers said that many times they also had evidence that they were not getting correct answers. In the Bronx, Ms. Gonzalez said, she came across an apartment where an occupant conceded that 10 people shared the household but would provide data on only three. The others, the occupant said, were illegal aliens and feared deportation. They did not believe that the information would be kept confidential, and she could not find anybody who would vouch for their existence, she said. #7 Percent From Outside Sources In New York City, census-takers were forced to go to outside sources for data more often than in any other part of the country, Census Bureau officials said. As of July, about 7 percent of all occupied housing units counted were counted on the basis of data from someone other than an occupant, compared with a nationwide average of about 3 percent, the officials said.
The General Accounting Office reported in July that in some areas, like the southwest Bronx and northeast Manhattan, 10 to 14 percent of the count of households came from what it calls ''last resort information.''
''In the beginning, during the first six weeks, my crew leader wouldn't even accept last resort,'' said Judy. ''But I did a lot of them in the last two weeks of June, just because I had to do things quickly.''
Although it is illegal for a managing agent or doorman to refuse entrance to census workers, it happened to her at least once, Judy said.
The law provides for fines, but all that happened was that a census official sent a letter to the managing agent pointing out the law.
''It's not like they sent a marshal with me,'' she said.
Because it was late in the count, her boss told her to just get what she could from the managing agent, she said.
In written testimony to the House Subcommittee on Census and Population last month, Bureau Director Barbara Everitt Bryant acknowledged that information is less reliable from third parties. But she argued that the actual population count ''will not necessarily be jeopardized.''
Census-takers disagreed. Benjamin Flores, 42, whose census beat included the Williamsburg and Greenpoint sections of Brooklyn, said he filled out many forms from information from the offices of public housing buildings. But he said many tenants live in the buildings without the knowledge of these offices.
Mr. Flores said he was also skeptical of some of the information he obtained from neighbors.
''How correct can they be? Sometimes they are 100 percent correct and sometimes they're not,'' he said. ''I don't think we counted everybody. I really don't.''
The potential for inaccuracies was no less severe in more upscale neighborhoods. In Battery Park City, ''a good 50 percent'' of the information for thousands of units in the neighborhood came from doormen, said Lester Chang, manager of the South Manhattan district census office.
 
The Means of Last Resort
''It's not the best,'' he said.
Mr. Chang, whose district also included the Lower East Side, said his workers found less cooperation among the most affluent. ''The wealthy gave us the toughest problem,'' he said. ''The perception is that they don't need the count because they don't need the money. In the projects, people were cooperative but they shielded the second family in the unit.''
Workers said they used the last resort methodology more frequently in the later part of the canvassing, which ran between April and June. Many said they were up against deadlines and in retrospect believed they were not given adequate time to do the job.
''It's not impossible, but it'd take longer to perform the job,'' said Russell Jones, 26, a student at Fiorello H. LaGuardia Community College in Queens, who worked in the Bronx. ''They should do it in a whole year.'' City officials are now comparing the Census Bureau's count of housing units in New York City with their own list, which is derived from records from Consolidated Edison, the Housing Authority and the city's building and real property files, among others.
City officials, contending that even in units the that bureau counted it missed many people, said the extent of an undercount will be known only after the bureau completes a post-census survey to determine whether a statistical adjustment is needed.
John J. Connolly, assistant to Dr. Bryant, said the preliminary counts are subject to change. He said the bureau has continued to recanvass, looking for new housing developments and into neighborhoods where it suspects people might have been missed.
In addition, he said, 24 census district offices nationwide, including several in New York, will recheck areas where a high number of households were reported to have only one occupant on forms filled out by census-takers late in the enumeration.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1545 words

HEADLINE: In Rising Debate on Poverty, The Question: Who Is Poor?

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2

 BODY:
Though Ms. Carter thinks the answer is clear - ''I am poor,'' she said, without reservation - her situation illustrates some of the problems with the nation's method of calculating poverty. The measure is widely considered outdated, and in recent months Congress and the Bush Administration have begun steps that could lead to its revision.
 
Measurement Born in 60's
The current poverty line stems from a crude measure, fashioned in the 1960's, that simply multiplies a minimum food budget by three. The resulting figure has been raised every year to account for inflation, but it does not reflect things like changes in family spending patterns or regional differences in the cost of living.
Recognizing the problems with the current definitions, the Administration recently completed an internal study that outlines dozens of possibilities for refining the formula and says it is impossible to tell whether the number of people counted as poor would rise or fall as a result. 
While the debate about how much of the nation is poor might seem esoteric, it has important consequences. The poverty line helps govern eligibility for billions of dollars in benefit programs. It also helps guide assumptions about the nation's economic soundness and social fairness, which are particularly important if the country is heading into a recession.
''It matters because among other things it's one of the fundamental measures of the health and decency of our society,'' said Representative Stephen J. Solarz, Democrat of Brooklyn, who is among those unhappy with the current measure. He said the country was ''flying blind,'' not knowing whether it was counting too many people or too few as poor.
While all definitions of poverty are subjective, any changes in the definition that would increase poverty rate could bring pressure for increased spending on social welfare programs. Those changes could also affect the nation's understanding of who the poor are. A modest increase in the poverty line, for instance, would significantly raise the number of elderly who are considered poor.
 
Political Implications
''It makes all kinds of difference who is poor as to how we react to it,'' said Representative Lee H. Hamilton, Democrat of Indiana, chairman of Congress's Joint Economic Committee, who added that the nation is underestimating the number of poor people.
The Administration study recognizes that any new poverty measurement would have political implications, cautioning that it must be ''at least as publicly acceptable as the present measures.'' The study was conducted as part of larger review of the quality of economic statistics, being led by Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers.
The report was presented to Mr. Boskin in August by a group that included representatives from seven Federal agencies.
The subgroup has since identified five aspects of the poverty line that it considers priorities for further research. No decision has been made over whether to finance the research, which is estimated to cost $2 million to $3 million.
The most recent figures from the Census Bureau, from 1988, estimated there were 31.7 million poor people in the United States, or 13 percent of the population.
A change in the poverty line would not necessarily change the number of people who receive Federal benefits, since the Government could alter the eligibility rules.
 
More Study Is Proposed
In June, Congress's Joint Economic Committee held hearings on the poverty line, and the House of Representatives has voted to give $600,000 to the National Academy of Sciences to study the issue. The proposal is now before the Senate.
Experts say that these steps, while modest, indicate more willingness to address the problems of the poverty line than at any time in at least the past decade.
While the interest arises in large part from the complaints of professional economists about technical aspects of the poverty measure, some say it is also part of a larger pattern of renewed interest in the problems of the poor.
''Increasingly, politicians, and I think the public as well, are coming to recognize that some people have been left behind,'' said Patricia Ruggles, an economist with the Joint Economic Committee and author of a book on the poverty line.
 
Any Changes Are Years Away
Nonetheless, it would be politically difficult for any Administration to change the definition of poverty, and members of the Congress and Administration say that even if such changes were made, they are several years away at the least.
The re-examination of the issue is occurring after a decade of Republican rule, in which economic fairness has been a major issue. Richard Schmalensee, a member of the Council of Economic Advisers, said that if large numbers of people were newly defined as poor, ''the other side will say, 'Aha, we told you the Administration was hiding the number of poor people.' ''
''And if you come up with a lower number,'' he continued, ''they'll say, 'See, the Administration is hiding the number even more.' ''
The current formula for estimating poverty has its quirky origins in the work of Mollie Orshanksy, then an obscure civil servant who began researching poverty in the early 1960's as part of her work for the Social Security Administration.
She took the Agriculture Department's cheapest recommended food plan and multiplied it by three, since research showed that the average family then spent a third of its income on food. Her resulting figures, which varied according to family size, were officially adopted in 1969. Since then, those original figures have simply been raised annually to account for inflation.
 
Charges of Overestimate
Among the reasons that some people think this method overestimates the extent of poverty in America is that it does not count as income the non-monetary benefits that many low-income people receive, like food stamps, subsidized housing, Medicaid or Medicare.
An experimental measurement by the Census Bureau that did count these benefits would have reduced the 1988 poverty rate from its official level of 13 percent to 10.5 percent.
While these criticisms suggest that there is less true poverty than reported, other critics argue that there is more.
Ms. Ruggles, the Congressional economist, said the current formula set the poverty line unrealistically low because it was based on outdated spending assumptions. While 30 years ago, the average American family spent a total of three times its food budget, she said, it now spends five times that amount, largely because of increases in the cost of housing and child care.
She argues that a formula based on housing rather than food would raise the poverty line about 50 percent.
Some critics argue that the eligibility rules for Government benefits implicitly recognize that the poverty line is too low. For example, families are eligible for food stamps if they earn less than 130 percent of the poverty line. Pregnant women and children younger than the age of six are eligible for Medicaid if their families earn less than 133 percent of the poverty line.
In addition, critics cite poll data that suggest most Americans intuitively would set the poverty line at a higher rate. A Gallup poll conducted in 1989 and released this summer by the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities and the Families USA Foundation, a nonprofit advocacy group for the elderly, asked 3,511 Americans for their definition of poverty for a family of four. The average given was $15,017, rather than the official standard of $12,092.
Daniel H. Weinberg, Chief of the Census Bureau's Housing and Household Economic Statistics Division, said the five priorities recommended for Administration research are improving the evaluation of non-cash benefits, developing a new measure of spending needs, finding ways to account for tax burdens, reducing the underreporting of income and changing the adjustments for family size.
Ms. Carter, the Milwaukee widow, finds the definition of poverty less complex than the experts. She said that after paying for rent, groceries, utilities, a student loan and bus fare each month she has about $60 left. With this, she tries to buy clothes, medicine and entertainment for her children.
At the end of August, she was waiting for a paycheck in order to fill a prescription to treat her son's eye infection. ''Even if the prescription just cost a dollar,'' she said, ''I don't have the money.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Caroline Carter, right, a Milwaukee widow, with one of her two teen-age children, Shenita. ''I am poor,'' Ms. Carter said. But her annual salary of $13,800 is more than the Government's official poverty line of $10,560 for a family of three, a figure some economists say is too low. HEADLINE: Uninsured Drivers Create Other Kinds of Wreckage

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 2

 BODY:

 
Big Cities Hardest Hit
In 19 states the increase in these kinds of accidents ranged from more than 50 percent to 220 percent. The biggest problems occurred in major cities, officials said. In Los Angeles, uninsured drivers cause about one of every four accidents involving injury. In Philadelphia, Miami and Denver, the figure is one in three.
''This is an extremely serious situation all around the country,'' said David N. Levinson, Delaware's Commissioner of Insurance. ''Our opinion polls indicate that the folks are more upset about uninsured motorists than any other problem we asked about, including taxes.'' He said that one-third of the 540,000 vehicles in the state were not insured and that total claims involving uninsured drivers had increased from $200,000 in 1978 to $10 million in 1988, the latest year for which figures were available.
Many states, including New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, require drivers to insure themselves against bodily injury caused by hit-and-run accidents or accidents with motorists who drive illegally without insurance. 
Experts say the growth in insurance premiums is at least partly responsible for the increase in the number of uninsured drivers. ''The number of uninsured vehicles increased faster in certain areas where insurance costs rose more quickly,'' said David L. Unnewehr, research director at the Insurance Research Council, a trade association that recently analyzed accident claim data involving uninsured drivers from 1976 to 1986.
 
New York Fares Well
Uninsured drivers in New York City caused 8.5 percent of all serious accidents in the lowest percentage of 15 cities studied by the council in 1986. ''New York's mandatory insurance law is enforced somewhat more than other states,'' Mr. Unnewehr said, ''but we didn't get real deep into the reasons why New York had a lower percentage than the other cities.'' His study found that the number of serious accidents caused by uninsured drivers in the state was half the national average, even though the number of those accidents almost tripled, to 6.3 percent in 1986 from 2.3 percent in 1976.
Other states that also saw at least a doubling in the rate of serious accidents caused by uninsured drivers were Idaho, North Carolina, Tennessee, Wyoming, Delaware, Georgia, Minnesota, Mississippi, North Dakota, Colorado and Utah.
The clamor over insurance rates has prompted Pennsylvania and a dozen other states to step up enforcement of their mandatory automobile insurance laws in the last 12 months.
 
Insurance Industry Blamed
But Mr. Levinson and consumer advocates say most of the new enforcement efforts are inadequate, and they accuse the insurance industry of blocking more stringent enforcement measures. They complain that the industry is content to collect the total cost of the nation's automobile insurance from a decreasing pool of customers as a way to keep administrative costs down and profits up.
''The industry would rather collect $750 from you, $750 from me and nothing from a deadbeat who doesn't want to carry insurance,'' said Mr. Levinson. ''The industry doesn't gain anything by collecting $500 from you, $500 from me and $500 from the other guy; it's $1,500 either way.''
Insurance industry spokesmen acknowledge that companies oppose mandatory auto insurance laws and some stringent enforcement measures proposed by the states, but they contend that the companies are taking the consumer's side in these matters. ''The industry does not want to be in the position of saying somebody must buy insurance before he feeds his children,'' said Shirley M. Nagelschmidt, a spokeswoman for the Alliance of American Insurers, a trade group.
Mr. Levinson complained that the insurance industry had fiercely opposed legislation in Delaware this spring that would have required automobile owners to paste color-coded stickers on windshields as proof they had paid for insurance. ''I have never seen a lobbying effort like it in my life,'' Mr. Levinson said of the defeated proposal.
Ms. Nagelschmidt said the industry had opposed the sticker legislation because the procedure would inconvenience consumers and increase costs. ''It smacks of a lot of paperwork,'' she said.
 
Human Side of Debate
There is a very human side to the debate.
''The minimum insurance costs $600, and that wasn't feasible,'' said a 23-year-old woman in San Francisco, who drives a 1978 Volvo without insurance or registration and spoke on the condition that she not be identified.
She works at a nonprofit civil rights organization as an intern, earning $8.50 an hour. This year she was fined $278 for driving without insurance or registration, but she did not have money to pay it. She said she continued to drive illegally, primarily because she does not feel safe using public transportation at night. If she caused an accident, she said, she would hope to cover the other party's expenses by selling what remained of her car, purchased two years ago for $2,000.
Last year, Joseph H. Wood, a 23-year-old resident of Philadelphia, said he bought a 1985 Nissan Stanza for $6,000. Insurance companies quoted premiums that ranged from $5,552 to $8,000 for a basic policy; he moved to a suburb, King of Prussia, where he was able to buy a policy for $2,593. ''It is outrageous,'' Mr. Wood said. Profile of Uninsured Industry surveys indicate that most people who do not buy automobile insurance are young, unmarried men, who face the highest insurance premiums of any group, and who tend to have low incomes and few assets. It is also the group with the highest rate of accidents. Half the uninsured vehicles are owned by people who are unemployed, employed part time, retired, students or homemakers, according to a 1988 study by the Insurance Research Council. One-third of uninsured drivers earn less than $5,000 a year, and another third of those drivers earn less than $15,000 a year.
A recent Temple University survey showed why Philadelphia has among the highest automobile insurance rates in the nation. Prof. Paul Seidenstat's economic students recently surveyed 310 Philadelphia residents by telephone; one-third said their cars had been stolen or vandalized in the last two years and nearly 60 percent said they knew people who drove without insurance.
Pennsylvania and a dozen other states are increasing efforts to enforce mandatory insurance laws or stabilize insurance prices, or both. On July 1, a new Pennsylvania law took effect that requires insurance companies to roll back rates by as much as 22 percent. It requires the mechanics who perform annual safety inspections to withhold windshield stickers from drivers who do not have insurance cards.
On June 1, Massachusetts opened a computer link between the State Registry of Motor Vehicles and insurance agents to deal with about 250,000 residents who make down payments on insurance policies to obtain registration and then cancel their policies immediately after obtaining their registration cards. Under the new system, the registry provides local police officials with a weekly list of vehicles that lack insurance. The police can issue citations for fines of as much as $5,000, and they can keep the fines as incentives for doing the work.
In New Jersey, Gov. Jim Florio announced this year that the state would make greater efforts to track down its estimated 600,000 uninsured drivers and to revoke their licenses and registrations. And in the last 12 months, half a dozen states have greatly increased penalties for driving without insurance. A driver without insurance in Hawaii, for example, faces a $1,000 fine for the first offense and a $3,000 fine for each subsequent offense.
But consumer advocates say that without affordable insurance premiums, mandatory insurance laws will not solve the problem. Even in Hawaii, where 7,020 welfare recipients receive free auto insurance under a state program, insurance officials said about 110,000 of the 600,000 automobiles in the state had no insurance in 1988.
 
Proposal to Cut Premiums
One consumer advocate, J. Robert Hunter of the National Insurance Consumer Organization, says there was a sure way to reduce insurance premiums and make everyone buy insurance: have insurance companies bid competitively to provide basic coverage for all the vehicles registered in a state, and then have the state collect premiums at the gasoline pump, in the form of a surcharge.
Apart from Hawaii's subsidy program, only California has come close to approving a law that would make insurance affordable for low-income families. State insurance officials in California estimate that 25 percent of the 16 million passenger cars in the state are uninsured and that perhaps half the automobiles in Los Angeles are uninsured.
The California legislation, which failed last spring, would have required insurers to offer a $180 no-frills policy as part of an insurance overhaul. The insurance industry and consumer groups supported the bill, but trial lawyers did not. They said the legislation, which was based on a no-fault system that would eliminate most litigation, would have infringed on people's right to compensation for pain and suffering.
The legislation is to be reintroduced next year. ''The only thing that will correct the uninsured motorist problem is putting the price of insurance down,'' said Richard J. Roth Jr., an assistant commissioner of the California Insurance Department.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
IRAQIS ARE LIMITING PURCHASE OF FOOD

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 2

 BODY:

 
Will Be Self-Sufficient
Nearly a month after the sanctions were imposed, Mr. Hadithi asserted that ''food is available and we are determined to live off our local products.''
Iraq has relied heavily on imports in the past, and the United States is counting on the sanctions to force concessions. But Mr. Hadithi said, ''We are determined to resist the embargo'' in which American warships are interdicting vessels sailing to or from Iraq with oil or other supplies.
In separate meetings with a handful of foreign journalists, Mr. Hadithi and Latif Nasif Jasim, the Minister of Information and Culture, reiterated Iraq's desire to avoid war, but they seemed to offer little hope of compromise. 
Western diplomats said early in the day that they expected an Air France plane to take several hundred more foreign women and children out of Iraq, but the flight was eventually canceled. The reason was not immediately clear.
On Saturday about 700 foreign women and children, who had been held here and in occupied Kuwait to deter a United States military attack, flew to Asia, Europe and the United States after their three flights had been delayed for about six hours.
They were the first of several thousand foreigners, including many Americans, to leave Iraq since President Saddam Hussein blocked their departure several weeks ago. Asked if there were plans for additional women and children to leave, Mr. Hadithi said: ''Women are free to leave; men are not.''
 
Antidote to Annihilation
The reason, Mr. Hadithi said, was that ''the American Administration is threatening Iraq with death and distruction.''
He offered no details on how the remaining women and children would be leaving the country. Because of the embargo, only Iraqi Airways is using Saddam International Airport here. It is flying two heavily booked flights a day to Amman, the capital of Jordan, Iraq's closest political and economic ally.
Iraq refuses to refer to the foreigners as hostages. Many of the women who left on Saturday night said the Iraqis had treated them politely while they were being detained. But the women said they had lived in terror, and worried now about the fate of husbands and fathers left behind.
Though the threat of war hangs over Baghdad, few soldiers are visible on the streets of the sprawling city of four million people on the banks of the Tigris River. Shops and offices are functioning, and some people interviewed on the streets insisted that they were not worried.
 
'We're Used to War'
''We're not afraid,'' said a pharmacist who looked in her mid-40's. ''We fought a war with Iran for eight years. We're used to war. We want peace, but we're used to war.''
Standing beside heaps of carrots, cucumbers and onions at a neighborhood vegetable stall, Mahdi Katim said: ''People know from experience that they can't just sit around and be afraid of war.
''Otherwise,'' he said, ''they'd go crazy. People just go on with their lives.''
Mr. Jasim, the Information Minister, said Iraq was looking for ''a signal'' from the United States, ''a guarantee that there will be no war.'' But he said Iraq was adamant on the question of Kuwait.
''We will never make a deal about Kuwait with Mr. Bush,'' Mr. Jasim said.
He complained that President Bush had not seriously considered proposals put forward by President Hussein.
Reasserting longstanding Iraqi claims, Mr. Hadithi said that Kuwait ''is part of this land,'' adding that it ''has come back to the motherland.''
 
Personal Attack on Bush
Mr. Jasim also charged that President Bush had personal investments in Saudia Arabian oil and had sent in American troops to drive up prices for his own profit.
''We challenge him to say no if this isn't true,'' he said.
Referring to Iraq's food supplies, Mr. Jasim said: ''Our condition is not very bad. It is good.''
''We can live on the simple things,'' he said. ''We only need bread and water, no more than that.''
According to the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization, Iraq imports nearly all its sugar and cooking oil and most of its rice, corn and wheat. American officials said late last week that conditions had become severe enough that the Iraqi Government was limiting the quantities of food released to stores from stockpiles.
 
Heavy Rain, Iraqi Explains
But Mr. Hadithi said Iraq had increased its production of rice and wheat in recent years and that crops being harvested now had benefited from particularly heavy rain. He said the distribution of food under the program was being organized by local officials of the ruling Baath Party.
''We have a war-tested society and a war-tested economy,'' he said. ''So even if we have to eat mud, we can resist the pressure and not kneel down to any power.''
Owners of two grocery stores said they had been told that they would be required to limit purchases of rice, sugar, tea, cooking oil, baby food, detergent and hand soap.
Iraqis said some food items had become hard to find in shops lately, but they insisted that this was the result of hoarding.
 
Shopping for Baby Food
A woman said some kinds of European-made baby food were scarce. ''But if you go from one store to another,'' she said, ''you can find it.''
Another woman said she had encountered no shortages. ''The opposite is true,'' she said. ''I'm not hoarding and I don't really think about war. Iraqis will help each other and, God willing, our President will solve the problem.''
Several people said they felt that the United States did not understand Iraq's position. Among other things, one man said, there had been no reason to suspect that Iraq was preparing to invade Saudi Arabia after its takeover of Kuwait on Aug. 2.
''There's no way Iraq would ever take over Saudi Arabia,'' the man said. ''We're brothers. We live the same way. We wouldn't take them over.''

LENGTH: 755 words

HEADLINE: Mideast War Fear Does Not Deter Soviet Jews From Going to Israel

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Sept. 2

 BODY:
Despite predictions here to the contrary, the Persian Gulf crisis seemed to have little if any effect on the immigrants' plans. Through the month, many Soviet Jews interviewed in Israel and in the Soviet Union said they were more concerned about the growing anti-Semitism at home than about the prospect of conflict in Israel.
 
'Only Problems' in Russia
''In Moscow, there was no future for us, only more problems,'' Oleg Kostavar, who moved here early this month, said soon after his arrival. ''But here, we can defend ourselves. We are not worried.'' 
Gad Ben-Ari, spokesman for the Jewish Agency, the large quasi-governmental organization with a central role in immigration matters, said, ''We can conclude that the predictions of immigration problems because of the security situation here, or because of hardships in the absorption process, did not come about.''
But in an interview today, Uri Gordon, who runs the agency's Department of Immigration and Absorption, suggested that the Persian Gulf crisis may damage the Soviet Jewish immigration program from another angle: fund-raising.
And it has helped spawn a controversial proposal here: While Israel asks American Jews to donate hundreds of millions of dollars to the absorption effort, even as the gulf crisis pinches the American economy, perhaps Israel should ask its own citizens to make individual contributions to the effort beyond what they pay in taxes.
 
Overseas Pleas Grow Louder
Israel's foreign fund-raising requests have dramatically grown over the last year. Last October, when 1,500 Soviet Jews moved here, the goal was to raise $100 million over a five-year period, almost all of it from American Jews.
By February, the number of immigrants had swelled to more than 5,000 a month, and so the fund-raising target was raised to $200 million a year for three years. Then in June, when 11,000 Soviet Jews arrived here, the target was changed again, to $300 million a year over the next two years.
Now, 150,000 to 250,000 Soviet Jews are expected to arrive here during each of the next several years, and Mr. Gordon said the Government estimates it would need $22 billion to absorb them - ''more than half of Israel's gross national product.''
As a result, he added: ''I very much hope that the fund-raising figure can be raised again. Every night, we are seeing four or five planes coming in from Budapest, Warsaw and other places.''
But now, with growing economic problems in the United States as a result of the gulf crisis, even the present forecasts may be thrown into doubt.
''The gulf crisis - this is a subject of trouble for us,'' Mr. Gordon said.
 
Self-Help Recommended
Partly as a result, Mr. Gordon has begun to raise a controversial and unpopular idea here: For the first time, the Government should ask Israelis to give.
In a proposal he offered to immigration and absorption ministers late last month, Mr. Gordon wrote: ''It must be understood that if we intend to absorb this wave of immigrants, we shall have to lower our collective standard of living. There is no choice but to place some of the absorption burden on Israel's citizens.''
He proposes tax increases and budget cuts. These ideas have been greeted with howls of complaint, even though there is broad support among Israelis for the increased Soviet immigration as a means of strengthening the nation. So far, Mr. Gordon said, no one in Government agrees with his idea that Israelis should be asked to give anything to help absorb the new immigrants.
As the fund requests to Americans continue to rise, he worries that American Jews might begin to grow resentful, knowing that they are being asked to dig deep into their pockets for a country whose own citizens are not being asked to give much.
''But people here tell me, 'We serve in the army. We give a lot,' '' Mr. Gordon said, shaking his head. ''I say charity has to begin at home.''

LENGTH: 1306 words

HEADLINE: Khmer Rouge Move Their Refugees

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ARANYAPRATHET, Thailand, Sept. 1

 BODY:
Thai officials have done little to hinder this informal repatriation, relief officials say, and in many cases have helped it. ''How can we stop Cambodians from returning home to their native land?'' a Thai officer said, admitting that Thais were tired of the 250,000 or so Cambodians, many displaced by the Vietnamese invasion of December 1978, who are living on Thai soil.
 
Similar Attempt in 1988
In late 1988, the Khmer Rouge tried to move 15,000 refugees under its control over the border into Cambodia, to take advantage of a gradual Vietnamese troop withdrawal, but concentrated shelling drove the refugees back. The vast bulk of Vietnamese troops left Cambodia 11 months ago, however, and the Khmer Rouge have made significant military gains since then. 
The two non-Communist factions of the Cambodian opposition coalition have also moved some 10,000 refugees each from United Nations-run camps over the border into their own ''liberated zones,'' the United Nations and relief officials say. But in large part because of their comparative weakness militarily, these non-Communist zones are just over the border, almost directly opposite their main camps inside Thailand, so it is easier to provide some food and shelter. Those who are wounded or become very ill have less far to go to reach main camp hospitals.
For example, the officials say, the faction of Prince Norodom Sihanouk, whose main camp is at Site B, has set up its camp, Tatum, directly opposite Site B in Siem Reap Province of Cambodia. ''There's not much medical care, but the numbers and the distances are not so big, so the Sihanoukists can take more care,'' a relief official said. ''Living conditions are pretty bad, nonetheless.''
The officials also criticize the Sihanoukist administration of Site B for some of the same practices long followed by the Khmer Rouge: the militarization of the camps, schools and justice and the recruitment of those as young as 12 years old for military training and portering of ammunition to troops inside Cambodia. Sihanouk spokesmen deny such practices, but senior relief officials and some Western diplomats say they do occur.
 
Corruption Called Rife
The officials say graft and corruption are rife in the camps, Site 2 and Sok Sann, of the other non-Communist faction, the Khmer People's National Liberation Front, led titularly by a former Prime Minister, Son Sann. There is a particularly large market in uniforms, medicine and weapons provided by the non-Communist countries of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations and the United States, which directly provides only nonlethal aid. But when forced recruitment from these camps became a problem, relief officials said, American Embassy officials were able to get the Liberation Front to stop it.
Even in the Khmer Rouge camps, the officials say, there is now more porousness and business activity. About 1,000 people every day leave both Site 8 and Site K to cut logs inside Cambodia or to mine for gemstones, to sell to Thai traders. The proceeds, the officials assume, go to the Khmer Rouge.
But the officials say the day-to-day life of those still living in the open, United-Nations run camps of the Khmer Rouge - Site 8, Site K and O Trao - is relatively placid. United Nations officials in particular praise the cooperation of the Khmer Rouge camp administrators, who in the last year have allowed more access to Western hospitals and even Thai television and videos.
But the officials acknowledge that these camps are showplaces, and that the life of the ''hidden'' camps is different. ''They have to play the game of show camps, so they play it,'' a senior relief official said. ''I don't think the leadership changes at all. The Khmer Rouge are very strong mentally and disciplined compared to the others. They try to find a way to sell themselves to the stupid Westerners. They show an accommodating, obedient face. But they persist in time, and they know all our faults, while we are allowed to know few of theirs.''
 
Treatment Is Discriminatory
Still, the official said, it is possible to know something of what goes on behind the curtain. ''Our people are in the camps eight or nine hourse a day, and finally people come and talk, and they tell similar stories.''
They tell of the division of people into those useful for the war and those who are not; those whose husbands or children are fighters and those who are not; those who are trusted and those who are not; those who are allowed to re-enter the world of the Westernized camps for treatment, and those who are not; and those who are treated like human beings and those who are not, used instead like pack animals to carry weapons, food and equipment.
Mysteries remain, of course, the officials say, and there is no question that the Khmer Rouge demand considerable allegiance from their fighters and their families, who make up the bulk of the refugees who have been moved inside Cambodia from the hidden, militarized camps to which the United Nations never had access.
All the Khmer Rouge's hidden camps around Site 8, containing between 30,000 and 50,000 people, have been shut down and moved into Cambodia, the officials say, as well as most of the hidden camps around O Trao, involving up to 20,000 more refugees. Late last year, the entire United Nations-run camp of Borai disappeared, its 4,500 inhabitants decamping one day for Cambodia.
 
Camp Population Declines
Recent head counts in the open camps - arranged by the United Nations with as short notice as possible to reduce the number of soldiers claiming residence and ration books for the free rice and fish - have also shown a decline in the official populations of Khmer Rouge camps. In O Trao, the numbers have gone from 19,520 in June to 11,500 now; in Site K, the numbers have fallen to 8,000 from 11,500; in Site 8, the main show camp, the numbers have remained essentially stable, with 37,000 counted this week compared with 37,900 in June.
Officials say the decline is due to two factors: the movement of thousands of residents, mostly relatives of soldiers, into Cambodia, and the elimination of the hidden camps, whose population lived close enough to swell the census of the open camps.
Many of those repatriated now live in three Khmer Rouge camps: Nong Phru, inside Cambodia directly south of Aranyaprathet; Samlot, near Site K in Battambang province, and Koh Kong, farther south in Koh Kong Province.
''These are among the most malarial regions in the world,'' a senior relief official said. ''For those who now live there, the situation is very bad, with little food, lots of malaria and no permission for most to be treated. The mortality of children is very high.''

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: THAILAND (96%); CAMBODIA (96%); SOUTH-EASTERN ASIA (79%); UNITED STATES (79%); ASIA (79%); 

COMPANY: UNITED NATIONS (83%); UNITED NATIONS (83%);

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
A Summit Respite

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., Sept. 2

 BODY:
Administration officials said Mr. Bush's strategy is to avoid military engagement and wait for the worldwide trade embargo to bite deeply into Iraq's supplies of food and military equipment. In Baghdad, an Iraqi official acknowledged today that the country is starting to limit its purchases of staple foods.
 
A Break From Talk of War
Even though Mr. Bush did not put great hopes in the mission to the Middle East by the United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, Bush Administration aides welcomed it as offering a weeklong hiatus from talk of war.
Similarly, the White House seems to be calculating that the prospect of a summit meeting with Mr. Gorbachev will keep the world's attention focused on diplomacy for at least another week. The convening of the fall session of the United Nations General Assembly on Sept. 17 should provide another breathing spell. 
This is not to say that Mr. Bush or Mr. Gorbachev view the trip to Helsinki merely as an elaborate photo opportunity.
Although Mr. Bush asked for the meeting and clearly has more at stake, the Soviet President also stands to benefit. The meeting will give Mr. Gorbachev a chance to respond to misgivings expressed by some Soviet officials about American military operations in the Gulf, and to remind a people distracted and strained by economic hardship that Soviet power remains critical in world affairs.
 
Arms Issues to Discuss
Mr. Bush said on Saturday that the two leaders had business to conduct on issues other than the gulf. Administration officials said they hoped the meeting will give a final impetus to a treaty on reducing conventional armed forces in Europe that both countries hope to sign in Paris this fall.
Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who chairs the Senate Armed Services Committtee, said today on the NBC News program ''Meet the Press'' that negotiations on the treaty had ''bogged down.''
''Not that we won't reach an agreement,'' he said. ''But it is becoming more and more difficult unless we get some guidance from the top.''
Indeed, there are goals in the Persian Gulf that Mr. Bush might be able to achieve in the discussions with Mr. Gorbachev. Mr. Nunn suggested, for example, that Mr. Bush press him to withdraw Soviet military advisers from Iraq.
The Soviet advisers have become a political irritant to Mr. Bush, with their presence drawing complaints from his conservative supporters. Mr. Nunn said a withdrawal of the advisers would also send ''a strong message to Saddam Hussein that the Soviets not only are cooperating, but they're going to help begin to deny him the ability to wage war.''
 
Keeping Expectations Low
One should not underestimate the ability of these two leaders to take dramatic and unexpected action. But Mr. Bush and his aides have gone out of their way to lower expectations that he and Mr. Gorbachev can make a significant breakthrough on the gulf crisis.
Administration officials said Mr. Bush is anxious to discourage any impression that the summit meeting is an attempt by the two nuclear superpowers to impose their own solution.
And there is little action the Soviet Union is likely to take now, they said, beyond the strong support it has already given Washington in a region where the two countries have historically been adversaries.
''The Soviets clearly are reluctant to commit military forces,'' one Administration official said. ''They are on the threshold of historic internal decisions, and I don't think they want to create any controversial foreign commitments.''
Mr. Bush has said he is not seeking out Mr. Gorbachev as a potential mediator in the Gulf crisis. But Administration officials said the Helsinki meeting would give Mr. Bush a chance to satisfy himself that there is no division between Washington and Moscow on the issue of the Persian Gulf. An 'Arab Solution'? ''They have been expressing high hopes about an Arab solution,'' one official said. ''That's fine if it means a solution based on U.N. resolutions. If it means an Arab solution based on something less, then we part company. Bush and Gorbachev can talk about that.''
There were conflicting signals from Moscow last week about its attitude toward the American military presence in the gulf.
Deputy Foreign Minister Aleksandr M. Belonogov complained there were no guarantees that the United States would withdraw its military after the immediate crisis ends. But Mr. Gorbachev said later that he supported the military deployment.
Bush Administration officials said they were confident that Mr. Gorbachev was expressing the true Soviet position, and they insisted that the Soviet statements were unrelated to Mr. Bush's request for the meeting.
But one official said, ''If some sort of joint statement is issued or common themes are enunciated, it will certainly show the Iraqis that they are deluding themselves if they think they can play Moscow off against Washington.''
 
Hoping to Stiffen Support
A senior official said the United States hoped that by denouncing Mr. Hussein and reiterating their support for the United Nations sanctions, Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev will stiffen the resolve of any country that might be wavering in its commitment to the trade embargo against Iraq.
Mr. Bush and his advisers have been looking for dramatic ways to bolster the embargo, officials said. One way is by sending Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady abroad this week to seek aid for countries whose economies are suffering because of the embargo.
But Mr. Bush, who believes strongly in his own abilities as a diplomat and in the power of direct contacts among world leaders, also wanted to do something personal, officials said. With other business to discuss and the timing so favorable, a summit conference with Mr. Gorbachev seemed to offer that opportunity, they said.
The meeting will also give Mr. Bush a chance to explore ways in which he and Mr. Gorbachev can turn their newfound confluence of interests in the Middle East into a broader, long-range policy, officials said. They plan to talk, for example, about prospects for cooperation on Cambodia and Afghanistan.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Japan Sending Vehicles and Housing for Military Effort in Gulf

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 2

 BODY:

 
Sacrifice by Auto Makers
''The auto companies are very forthcoming and willing to suffer tremendous financial losses to cooperate with this scheme,'' Mr. Okamoto said.
The new details about Japan's shipments were offered by officials who said they were alarmed by what seems to be a growing impression among Americans that the Government of Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu has not done enough to aid the military efforts against Iraq.
After weeks of wrestling with the problem, Mr. Kaifu announced last week that Japan would send food, medical supplies and refrigeration equipment to the Middle East. He said Japan was also assembling a large financial aid package for Turkey, Egypt, Jordan and other countries hit hard economically by the outbreak of the Persian Gulf crisis. 
President Bush praised Japan for its contributions, but United States officials were privately more critical. Members of Congress, commentators and newspaper editorials have begun accusing Japan of shirking its responsibilities in the multinational effort against Iraq.
Mr. Okamoto said he felt that American distrust of Japanese efforts and motivations constituted the gravest turn in relations between the two countries in many years. He described past confrontations on trade as ''pseudo crises'' compared with what is happening today.
 
U.S. More Satisfied
The aid from Japan still falls short of the original American requests. But United States officials said today they had no choice but to accept Japan's contention that because of its Constitution, it cannot supply lethal or combat-related equipment to the Middle East.
It appears that Washington, after expressing disappointment at Japan's failure to provide direct military aid, is now increasingly satisfied that Tokyo is genuinely trying to supply as much material as possible to aid the military indirectly.
It is still possible that Japan's plans could go awry. Officials in Tokyo said they were worried about delays in obtaining specific budget approval and the possibility that ship and dock workers will refuse to transport or load materials bound for a war zone.
One hitch has already occurred. Japanese officials said they had run into difficulties in seeking approval from airlines to transport military-type equipment and vehicles. The items will therefore arrive in Saudi Arabia by ship.
 
Airlines Mindful of Hostages
Airline companies have objected to sending anything even remotely construed as military, in part because some of their flight crews have already been taken hostage in Iraq.
It is also proving difficult to get engineers to volunteer to go the war zone to service Japanese equipment, officials said. Citing its postwar Constitution, which bars Japan from taking part in any use of force except for self-defense, Tokyo says it cannot order non-military or military people to the front.
Nevertheless, Japanese officials say they are doing a lot. ''It is unfair that Japan's role is so downplayed in America's mind,'' Mr. Okamoto said. He added that Tokyo hopes to change that impression before Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady arrives later this week on a mission to secure more aid.
Mr. Okamoto cautioned that Japan could under no circumstances increase its $1 billion pledge, even if war breaks out.
 
What Tokyo Declined to Do
Mr. Kaifu originally had emphasized that only food, medical supplies and water could be sent from Japan or aboard Japanese vessels and planes. He said these restrictions were imposed by Japan's Constitution.
The Prime Minister also rejected what his aides said had been an American request for minesweepers, frigates, military tankers with mounted guns, or C-130 transport planes, and for a Japanese airlift or sealift of weaponry or ammunition.
In recent days, however, Japanese and American officials have said they feel Tokyo is making an effort not to define things too narrowly, and to include equipment that could definitely aid the military effort though not in a direct or conspicuous way.
A senior American official confirmed tonight, for instance, that Japan had quietly begun trading lists of equipment with the United States Joint Chiefs of Staff in Washington to determine which items could meet American military needs and still satisfy Japan's direct ban on military aid.
 
Checking Inventories
The Japanese Ministry of International Trade and Industry has begun a survey of inventories at Japanese companies to determine what could be sent immediately or in the coming months.
Tokyo is encountering delays and difficulties in fulfilling other parts of its pledges, Japanese officials acknowledged. For instance, although Japan has pledged to make a direct monetary contribution to the stationing of armed forces of other countries in the Middle East, there is no legal entity to which it can write a check and send the money, they said.
For more than a week now, the Government and the giant airline it once controlled, Japan Air Lines, have been engaged in a behind-the-scene struggle over whether to send cargo planes full of supplies to American troops in Saudi Arabia. In heated meetings, the airline's executives resisted the Government's entreaties, declaring that it would carry only food, water and emergency medical gear to the troops.
Japan Air Lines was concerned that 23 of its own employees were among the hostages being held in Iraq, and it feared retailiation if the airline was publicly identified as airlifting supplies to the military buildup.
 
Controlling Corporate Giants
The dispute raises questions about Japan's renowned ability to quietly control the nation's corporate giants, moving government and industry in lockstep. The crisis in the the gulf could give rise to a new perception of the limits to Japanese power.
Industry here threw itself unquestioningly into the war effort in World War II, and in the process became a target of Allied bombs and later, public criticism.
This time, as one airline official put it, ''we had little interest in becoming Japan's surrogate air force.''
But that is exactly what Tokyo was seeking. By law and tradition, Japan's own air force is prohibited from flying abroad. Although the Japanese Defense Agency sought last week to reinterpret those laws to allow at least some limited Government action, its officials conceded that the military could not bring cargo to the Gulf even if it wanted to: Japan's ban on offensive weapons has prevented its forces from obtaining long-range planes with the capability to refuel in mid-flight.
