SECTION: Section 1; Page 5, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1852 words

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Throughout the Middle East, Iraq's Challenge Redraws the Political Lines

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, Sept. 1

 BODY:

 
The Design of a New Reality
But the abrupt Iraqi takeover of Kuwait shattered all this.
The invasion made clear the unbounded ambitions of Mr. Hussein, a hard man who entered politics as a teen-age gunman and whose propaganda projects him in the guise of near-mythic Middle Eastern conquerors from Nebuchadnezzar to Saladin.
Rallied by Egypt and Saudi Arabia, a dozen Arab countries - a bare majority of the 21-member Arab League - dropped the screen of decades of slogans and speechmaking to admit that their interests lay with the West. Many feared for the continued existence of their own narrowly based governments in the face of the Iraqi threat.
The notion of Arab brotherhood was shattered at the landmark Arab League summit meeting here last month; it split the Arab world by endorsing the presence of foreign troops in Saudi Arabia and the dispatch of Egyptian, Moroccan and Syrian forces to give it an Arab face. 
 
Crossing Borders and Ideological Lines
But the map of the Arab world is not merely one of nation-states. A swirl of traditions, ideas and emotions cross the artificial lines of the borders. Dynastic and tribal traditions hold sway in some countries, revolutionary ones in others.
There is a long political struggle between the old idea of Islam as the region's unifying force - an idea that dates to the wave of Arab conquests for the new religion in the seventh century -and the newer ideology of secular, Pan-Arab nationalism.
There is the fabulous oil wealth of the rulers of the gulf and the grinding poverty in much of the Arab world. And there is the issue of Israel and the Palestinians, the test by which Arab leaders try to demonstrate their legitimacy.
Here is how the map looks a month into the conflict:
Arrayed solidly against Iraq are Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Syria, Morocco and the oil shiekdoms of Qatar, Bahrain, the United Arab Emirates and the exile government of Kuwait; all have some military involvement. Lebanon, Djibouti and Somalia also voted for the Arab League resolution.
Uneasily tied to Iraq are Jordan and the Palestine Liberation Organization. Their respective leaders, King Hussein and Yasir Arafat, have been desperately trying to float peace proposals. Yemen, too, appears sympathetic to Iraq. But both Jordan and Yemen have said they would honor the United Nations embargo against Baghdad.
Algeria, Tunisia and Mauritania are on the sidelines, unlike Morocco, but they lean toward Iraq. Considerable popular sentiment sees Saddam Hussein as a kind of Robin Hood, and the leaders of these three North African countries have denounced the American military presence. The countries did not attend the meeting of the Arab League foreign ministers last week at which the dozen states lined up against Iraq demanded that it not only withdraw from Kuwait but pay war reparations.
 
Qaddafi, the Libyan Wild Card
Libya is, as usual, somewhat of a wild card. The mercurial Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, like King Hussein and Mr. Arafat, has been trying to come up with an initiative to give President Hussein a face-saving way out. He has criticized the taking of foreign hostages by Iraq, but today he said he would not obey the United Nations-imposed embargo on food shipments to Iraq.
Here are the interests of the major players, and the influences upon them:
For those countries allied against Iraq, the most important issue is self-preservation and fear or hatred of Saddam Hussein.
Egypt and Saudi Arabia, along with Jordan, had been major backers of Iraq during its eight-year war with Iran, seeing Mr. Hussein as a bulwark against Islamic fundamentalist revolution. Kuwait, too, had given billions of dollars of oil revenue to Iraq; its policies involved considerable risks with its own Shiite Muslim minority.
Egypt has been the Arab country most closely aligned with the United States, since Anwar el-Sadat concluded a separate peace with Israel in 1979. Egypt receives more than $2 billion a year in American foreign aid -the largest sum for any country except Israel - and cooperates with the United States in military and other areas.
Morocco, where King Hassan II is the chief Sunni Muslim religious figure, also has ties to the West. King Hassan has even served as a go-between with Israeli officials.
 
A Kingdom Feels the Threat
Saudi Arabia, which controls more than 40 percent of the world's oil supplies, is a kingdom in which strong orthodox Sunni Islam blends with a puritanical streak of fundamentalism as practiced by the Wahabi sect; most important Government offices are held by the many princes of the House of Saud. The Government has strong ties to the United States, but it has long preferred to keep them discreet.
The Saudis felt directly threatened both by Mr. Hussein's takeover of Kuwait and by his verbal attacks on the decadence and greed of oil-rich rulers. These attacks have struck an emotional chord among the vast number of poor people in the Arab world.
There was similar fear among the wealthy Persian Gulf sheikdoms, particularly in the United Arab Emirates, which Baghdad had singled out along with Kuwait for exceeding its oil production quota and thus lowering prices. The Emirates, Qatar, Bahrain and Oman are all providing installations for Western troops. Some had done this in the past but preferred to pretend they weren't there - for example Bahrain, where there is a United States naval headquarters and a ''secret'' airfield.
Syria presents one of the most remarkable changes in the political map. Long considered an implacable foe of the West and shunned as a harbor for terrorists, Syria is now sending a token detachment of troops to stand with the Americans in Saudi Arabia, a gesture that prompted a telephone call of thanks from President Bush to President Hafez al-Assad.
Mr. Assad, a crafty maneuverer in the shifting alliances of the Middle East, has long been a bitter rival of Saddam Hussein. At a stroke, he moved Syria from isolation within in the Arab world into the center of events.
''Like the rest of the Arab rulers, Assad fears the destabilizing effect of Saddam on the region as a whole,'' said a Western diplomat in Damascus. ''He is a threat to all regimes. He increases the risk of war and the risk of Israeli involvement. Saddam can polarize the Arab world. He is trying to appeal to Arab frustrations, Arab nationalism over the heads of the rulers.''
The Syrian and Iraqi rulers head rival branches of the Baath Party, which espousees a modern socialist, secular pan-Arab ideology. In practice the two leaders are nearly identical dictators who rule through their secret police, although Mr. Hussein is now regarded as more merciless.
 
Iraqi Appeals to Tradition
President Hussein's secularism appears to be waning. During the war against Iran he had himself pictured making his devotions on a prayer rug and lately he has called on Muslims to rise up against ''infidel'' American troops who he says are defiling Islamic shrines in Saudi Arabia. He recently had his genealogy traced, and it was announced that a diligent search of birth records in Takrit revealed that the President was a direct descendant of the Prophet Mohammed.
In Lebanon, as always a microcosm of the Middle East killing fields, the Government is under the thumb of Syria but a rump government of Maronite Catholic hard-liners has been plentifully supplied with arms by Iraq. These Lebanese, with long practice as smugglers, could be a major help to Iraq in puncturing the international blockade.
Of the few players linked to Iraq, Jordan is perhaps in the most complicated and difficult position.
 
A Nation's Weakness and a Ruler's Fear
Its King, Hussein, who has long had ties to the West, rules a weak buffer state and now finds himself trying to defend the Iraqi President, whom he has lauded as ''an Arab patriot.'' But his attempts to mediate with the United States and Britain have been received icily.
The King's major concern is to preserve his Hashemite dynasty, which in its Jordanian form is a Western-engineered monarchy with a relatively short history. His greatest fear is that Israel will expel Palestinians from the occupied West Bank and in so doing destabilize Jordan, which is already roughly 60 percent Palestinian. In Amman, portraits of Saddam Hussein are now taped side by side with the King in many shop windows.
The King's great-grandfather was the Sharif of the Hejaz, the guardian of Islam's holiest site in Mecca in what is now Saudi Arabia. That Sharif Hussein and his sons were enlisted by the legendary T. E. Lawrence, the British Army officer and writer better known as Lawrence of Arabia, to lead the Arab revolt against the Ottoman Empire in World War I. King Adapts an Old Honorific But they were ousted in 1926, amid charges of corruption, by the Islamic fundamentalist of the day, Ibn Saud, the founder of the current Saudi dynasty, who swept out of the desert with his Wahabi warriors. The British, meanwhile, were setting up Hashemite dynasties in Trans-Jordan and Iraq. The monarchy in Baghdad was overthrown in 1958.
About a week ago, King Hussein instructed his inner circle to address him as ''Sharif,'' and he now uses the title in official statements. This has raised eyebrows among diplomats, who speculate that the King hopes to return to his family's past glory.
The King was deeply shaken by an outbreak of rioting a year ago against government corruption, in which much of the protest was in Bedouin areas, his traditional stronghold. Since then, he has adopted the populist oratory of Saddam Hussein; in February, at a meeting of the Arab Cooperation Council in Amman, he made an impassioned plea against the decadence of the oil sheiks. He is said to be personally friendly with Saddam Hussein.
The P.L.O. chairman, Yasir Arafat, who had drifted toward Iraq as the emerging power in the Arab world, finds himself in an uncomfortable position. A large part of the frustrated mass of Palestinians in Jordan and in the Israeli-occupied territories have given emotional support to Iraq, but Mr. Arafat has alienated his financial base, which is in Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and other gulf countries.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 7, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1455 words

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
The Oilfield Lying Below the Iraq-Kuwait Dispute

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES

 BODY:

 
Percentages Set by Formula
Oil formations frequently run be neath political boundaries, whether they involve unfriendly leaseholders in West Texas or neighboring Arab states, and procedures have existed for years to settle disputes that arise. Typically, participants in the same field share both production costs and revenues, using a formula that sets percentages of ownership.
But Iraq refused to negotiate with Kuwait on such an agreement. So Ku wait produced oil from Rumaila with out any agreement, and then adopted a policy of producing far more oil than it was allowed under the quota system of the Organization of Petroleum Export ing Countries. That policy became an other sticking point in relations with Iraq, which contended that the over production depressed oil prices and revenues for all OPEC members.
Iraq had produced oil from the field before it went to war with Iran. Of a total of 615 wells in Iraq, 225 were in the Rumaila field, according to 1986 fig ures, the latest available, from John S. Herold Inc., an oil industry consulting firm in Greenwich, Conn. 
 
Field Mined During War
But during the Iran war Iraq mined its giant share of the Rumaila field to keep it from falling into Iranian hands, Western political experts say. Kuwait stepped up its total oil production, cap turing some of Iraq's customers and pumping millions of barrels from the Rumaila field. After the war with Iran ended in a cease-fire in 1988, Iraq re sumed drilling in Rumaila.
Iraq's dispute with Kuwait, has its roots in Britain's decision in 1899 to es tablish Kuwait as a British protector ate. The Kuwait royal family had ruled the area since 1756, but Iraq still con sidered it part of its southern province, The dispute flared again more than 30 years ago, shortly after oil was dis covered in 1953 in Iraqi territory in the huge Rumaila reservoir. After the Arab League of States established the Kuwait-Iraq border two miles north of the southern tip of the oilfield, Kuwait erected oil rigs on its own territory and drilled into the rich pool below. Kuwait has never disclosed how much Rumaila oil it has pumped. $2.4 Billion Claim by Iraq But President Saddam Hussein says Kuwait owes Iraq $2.4 billion for oil taken from the field. In addition to as serting that Kuwait owed Iraq for the oil it had produced, Mr. Hussein told an emergency meeting of the Arab League in May that excessive supplies of Kuwaiti oil in the world market in the last two years had undermined OPEC production quotas and de pressed world oil prices. He said that action cost Iraq $14 billion a year, or far more than Kuwait had lent Iraq during Iraq's confrontation with Iran.
His remarks to the Arab League's closed session were reported by the Middle East Economic Survey in an issue that reached American experts after the invasion of Kuwait.
Sounding the alarm over Iraq's mounting grievances against Kuwait, Mr. Hussein told the Arab League that ''we cannot tolerate this type of eco nomic warfare,'' and added, ''We have reached a state of affairs where we cannot take the pressure.''
 
Assertions Rejected
In a memorandum to the Arab League dated July 19, Sabah al-Ahmad al-Jabir al-Sabah, the Foreign Minister of Kuwait, rejected Mr. Hussein's as sertions about Kuwait's production from the Rumaila reserves. ''Kuwait has produced oil from wells within its territory south of the Arab League line and far enough away from the interna tional borders to conform with interna tional standards,'' he wrote in the memo.
The Kuwaiti royal family did not re spond to a request made Friday to a spokesman in Taif, Saudi Arabia, where the family is in exile, for com ment on Kuwait's production at the Rumaila field.
Kuwait's overall production in 1989, an average of 1.8 million barrels a day, exceeded its OPEC quota by 700,000 barrels. The Kuwaiti Government's hope was to force Mr. Hussein to the bargaining table, and then extract from him a border truce that included Rumaila drilling rights, as well as a non-aggression pact. Instead, Iraqi troops invaded Kuwait and drove its ruling family into exile.
 
'Economic Warfare'
Henry M. Schuler, director of the energy security program at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington, said that, from the Iraqi viewpoint, the Kuwait Government was ''acting aggressively - it was eco nomic warfare.''
''Whether he's Hitler or not, he has some reason on his side,'' Mr. Schuler said of President Hussein. He added that American officials needed to ap preciate the economic and psychologi cal significance the Rumaila field holds for the Iraqis and why Kuwait's exploi tation of Rumaila, in addition to its high oil output in the 1980's, was an afront to the Iraqis.
''It's not just the emotional man in the street in the Arab world who finds the Iraq case appealing,'' he said. ''So do many of those who are thinking, in telligent people. If the Iraqi people feel they are the victims of aggression, and that their legitimate claims are being stifled now by American intervention, they will hang in there a lot longer than if that were not the case.''
Some Middle East experts dismiss Iraq's complaints about Kuwait's ac tivities in the Rumaila field. They say Mr. Hussein has voiced these and other charges to justify a long-held desire to plunder Kuwait's financial wealth and give his nearly landlocked country con trol of more than 200 miles of Persian Gulf coastline.
 
'Only a Smokescreen'
''The issue of oil taken from the Rumaila field is only a smokescreen to disguise Iraq's more ambitious inten tions,'' said Marvin Zonis, a professor of political economy at the University of Chicago's Graduate Business School. ''The Iraqis will claim anything to jus tify the incorporation of Kuwait.''
Some Iraqi officials have accused Kuwait in the past of using advanced drilling techniques developed by Amer ican oilfield specialists to siphon oil from the Rumaila field, a charge that American drillers deny, noting that the oil flows easily from the Rumaila field without any need for these techniques.
The Kuwait Petroleum Corporation, with headquarters in London, acquired American drilling expertise when it bought the Santa Fe International Cor poration in 1981 for $2.4 billion. Santa Fe, based in Alhambra, Calif., has separate divisions that specialize in oil field drilling and rig operations, pri marily in offshore areas around the world, as well as in exploration and production, mostly in the Gulf of Mexi co, Texas and Louisiana.
 
Six American Workers
John J. Mika, Santa Fe's vice presi dent of administration, said six Santa Fe employees, all Americans, were among the oil workers captured by Iraqi troops in the early moments of the Aug. 2 invasion. All of the men were believed taken to Baghdad, he added.
The Santa Fe employees worked on several rigs ''immediately adjacent'' to the Iraqi border, Mr. Mika said. He added that he was unaware of any well that might have utilized the ''slant'' drilling technique along the Iraqi bor der.
W. C. Goins, senior vice president of OGE Drilling Inc., a Houston company that provided oilfield supervisors and workers for Kuwait in the same area, said he was ''positive'' all of the wells his employees drilled and operated ran vertically down to the Rumaila pay zone. ''That field crosses the border in north Kuwait,'' he added. ''Iraqis were drilling on one side, and Kuwaitis on the other side.''
He said that Iraqi border guards would come over to the Kuwaiti oil wells occasionally and shared the rig workers' lunches - but under Kuwaiti law the workers were not allowed to drink the beer that the Iraqis brought with them, to the Iraqis' delight.
Now those lunches are a thing of the past. Of the 18 Americans employed by OGE in Kuwait, six have been missing since the invasion. At least two were ''taken to Baghdad right away,'' Mr. Goins said.

HEADLINE: Providence Journal;
Return Of a Felon Who Once Was Mayor

DATELINE: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 30

 BODY:
First elected in 1974 at age 33, the tough, boyish-looking lawyer quickly settled union contracts for city workers and helped clean up crime-ridden neighborhoods, at times patrolling on a horse with mounted police officers. He developed an intensely loyal following.
But in 1984, even loyalists knew there was trouble. Given a suspended sentence in the assault by lighted cigarette, log and ashtray of a man he said was having an affair with his estranged wife, Mr. Cianci became a convicted felon and by law had to resign. Supporters wept when he announced he would step down. 
At the same time, a corruption scandal was beginning to break open. The Mayor, who said he was unaware of illicit activities, was never charged with any wrongdoing. But more than 30 city workers and contractors were indicted on charges ranging from conspiracy to fraud. Sixteen of those people went to jail.
Since 1985, Mr. Cianci has dominated the afternoon airwaves as host of a radio talk show on WHJJ-AM in East Providence, giving him a chance to express his views on issues like taxes and crime.
As for his own run-in with the law, Mr. Cianci dismisses it as ''ancient history.'' The assault, he says, ''was a mistake, and I have paid for it in a very public and a very private way.'' As for the corruption audit of his administration , Mr. Cianci testily instructs an inquirer to walk over to the Rhode Island Historical Society for ''that kind of information.'' The provision of the City Charter that requires a convicted felon to resign does not bar felons from running for office.
While his unfavorability rating hovers around 50 percent, polls show that 28 percent of the voters favor Mr. Cianci as the one to run the capital of Rhode Island, a state long known for scandals and shady politics.
Dubbed ''Rogues' Island'' in its early days as a colony, Rhode Island was infamous for offering haven to pirates. The state's scandals span in scope from open vote buying in the 1750's to the 1985 trial of Claus von Bulow, a Newport socialite who was acquitted after two trials on charges of trying to murder his wealthy wife.
In recent years, Providence has been the New England headquarters for organized crime.
But scandals aside, much of Mr. Cianci's appeal, voters say, is his reputation for having revitalized neighborhoods and cut urban crime during his previous tenure. During the 1980's, Providence, like many other Northeastern cities, underwent an economic renaissance.
''There is an experience quotient that has to be pegged against purity of soul,'' said Rosalind Rustigian, 38, who sold Mr. Cianci the oriental rugs that lie in his posh carriage house on the corner of Power and Benefit Streets.
But for Irwin N. Becker, a local resident, a victory by Mr. Cianci ''would be a great embarrassment'' for a city trying to attract business and respect.
''He ran city government into the ground,'' said Mr. Becker, executive director of Elmwood Neighborhood Housing Services, a neighborhood organization financed by the city.
''He spent a lot of money on the neighborhoods, but he'd throw money at the neighborhoods without a lot of policy,'' Mr. Becker added, referring to several community programs that were closed after a Federal audit.
Paul V. Jabour, a Democratic candidate for mayor, said, ''I think you dispel any support for Cianci if people want to look forward to the future.''
Yet Mr. Jabour and the other three candidates vying to win the Democratic primary know that Mr. Cianci will be a formidable candidate in the final campaign.

HEADLINE: As the Need for Harmony Grows, Labor Talks Lose Stridency

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 2

 BODY:
The float was that of the United Automobile Workers' Local 160, normally one of G.M.'s most militantly anti-management groups.
Meanwhile, at G.M. headquarters, company and union bargainers were debating a proposed three-year contract. G.M. has been chosen by the U.A.W. as the focus of its negotiation strategy. The current contract expires Sept. 14, after which the union could decide to strike the auto maker.
But the halls outside the negotiating rooms this year have been unusually free of the posturing by union leaders and executives that in years past conveyed a sense of impending crisis. The reason for the quiet: Union leaders say G.M. has made some very generous initial proposals. Both sides also say the triennial bargaining ritual has matured. 
''There is a greater need for labor and management cooperation; most people in those organizations recognize that,'' said Howard D. Samuel, president of the industrial union department of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. ''Unions can grow on that basis.''
There are several reasons why no one wants a strike. At one time, automaking, steelmaking, trucking and other components of the economy were virtual oligopolies. Labor contracts between companies and unions established labor costs across an entire industry. Today, nonunion and foreign companies are influential players, so costs depend on what those companies are doing, too.
Moreover, certain labor costs, like medical benefits and holidays, have become institutionalized and are not subject to much change in each new contract. Finally, gloomy predictions for the economy and employment help everyone focus on reaching an agreement.
 
Thinning of the Ranks
The past decade, to be sure, has produced its share of grief for organized labor. The Reagan Administration broke the air traffic controllers' union. Strikes against Eastern Airlines and Greyhound pushed the companies into bankruptcy instead of helping the workers' lot. The union movement lost hundreds of thousands of members.
But the Labor Department under President Bush has taken a more active interest in mediating impasses like the United Mine Workers strike against the Pittston Coal Group, Mr. Samuel said. And the rising tide of global economic competition has encouraged American companies and work forces to accommodate one another in the interest of survival.
Unions suddenly have a big stake in harmony. While union membership over all has increased in the past decade, according to the A.F.L.-C.I.O., the American work force has grown much faster. Thus, a smaller proportion of workers is being represented. The autoworkers' union has lost a third of its members, shrinking to less than a million from nearly 1.5 million. And the union has lost key organizing battles at Japanese plants in this country because many workers do not like the confrontations with management.
 
The Workplace Changes
At the same time, labor and management at many factories have been trying more and more to cooperate with one another in the interest of improving quality and productivity, and of lowering costs. Time clocks have been junked. Workers have agreed to do tasks outside their job descriptions. Foremen have ceded traditional prerogatives of authority to hourly workers.
Ultimately, the goal has been trust: Managers trusting hourly workers to strive for quality and productivity; hourly employees trusting managers to forgo feathering their nests with lavish pay and benefits, and to forgo the short-term profit gained by subcontracting work to nonunion or offshore companies.
In the auto industry, Big Three executives and union leaders this year are trying to find a way to guarantee job or income security for current hourly workers. The union believes G.M. is about to offer a version of lifetime employment for current workers, but the company will want increased flexibility to reassign workers and to close some plants. The company has been quiet about its plans.
Analysts have said global competition puts the pressure on G.M. - and on all United States companies facing worldwide competition - to maintain amicable, constructive relations with hourly workers. Without a skilled, motivated work force, modern manufacturing techniques do not work well.
That is why executives may be going out of their way to encourage good will by personal example, as in helping with a parade float.

PUB-DATE: September 3, 1990

SECTION: Section 1; Page 20, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 569 words

HEADLINE: Strikebreakers and Other Threats

 BODY:
These threats challenge America's reputation for fairness as well as its aspirations. Many workers feel they're sliding helplessly down a slippery slope. Their struggle is a national concern.
Productivity in the U.S. is sluggish by historical standards and by comparison with America's major allies. That's why wages, relative to inflation, have stagnated since the early 1970's. If output per worker doesn't rise, neither can wages. This lackluster performance is due partly to bad management and weak corporate investment. 
But a key part of the problem is an influx of workers out of high school who are ill prepared to handle the demands of modern jobs. These unskilled, nonunion workers suffer a lifetime of meager earnings. And the earnings gap between skilled and unskilled workers is higher than ever.
More is at stake, however, than the plight of individuals. If poorly educated workers were better trained, everyone else would share the benefit of the extra productivity. Western European countries have established successful systems for training workers who lack a college education. The U.S. is alone in doing nearly nothing.
Union workers face a different peril. The percentage of American workers belonging to unions has fallen by half over the past two decades; it now hovers around 17 percent. Some of the forces behind the decline, like the tilting of economic production toward services and away from manufacturing, are beyond the control of public policy.
But part of organized labor's plight is firmly under Congressional control. Laws that restrict employer opposition to union organizing are weakly enforced and only light penalties are imposed. And employers have recently perfected techniques to unravel contracts by first inviting strikes, and then replacing strikers with permanent hires.
At risk is the fabric of collective bargaining that has been woven since the 1930's. This risk may not appear grave to those who view unions as little more than anti-competitive cartels. By artificially driving up wages and prices, unions eliminate jobs and exploit consumers. But they can also improve morale and productivity and set an enviable model for unorganized workers. Unions are about governance, empowering workers to voice discontent and protect themselves against capricious managers.
The precipitous decline of unions threatens to throw away the good along with the bad. The challenge for public policy is to encourage worker participation in workplace governance without encouraging anti-competitive wage hikes.
Revising Federal labor laws to re-balance power between employers and unions might be necessary; incentives for nonunion employers to incorporate more worker control might also be effective. None of this need threaten consumers if the economy remains open to foreign competitors. Low-cost imports put a firm brake on anti-competitive contracts.
American workers turn out more total goods and services than anyone else. For that reason, on this Labor Day, they deserve celebration. But the advantage is quickly eroding. For that reason, American workers also deserve careful nurturing.

HEADLINE: Immigration Bill Adds Few Skilled Workers;
Unskilled Also Needed

 BODY:
Working women, now subject to constant anguish over the near impossibility of finding adequate care for family members, would be in an even worse situation. Professional women with demanding schedules will be hardest hit, because institutional care, when available, often does not meet their needs. 
There are constant reports that women will be called upon to take on more highly skilled and professional jobs, but virtually no mention of who will provide the support services that allows them to work and have care for their children and elderly and handicapped family members. Other industries employing low-skilled labor will also be hard hit and will contract, eliminating jobs for American workers.
The Department of Labor has calculated that 42 percent to 44 percent of all applications for employer-sponsored immigration would be eliminated under the Senate bill. Most of the increase in requests for alien workers is for low-skilled and unskilled workers, even despite a minimum four-year wait for them.
Since there were 44,238 applications in fiscal year 1988, 58,242 in fiscal year 1989 and, it is estimated, 46,594 in fiscal year 1990, this means that many thousands of jobs would go unfilled each year, and American employers would have no way to fill them. Smaller businesses will be most severely affected, and perhaps forced to close.
Nearly all studies indicate that immigration is beneficial to our economy and that immigrants create jobs for Americans, rather than take them away. Our current policy is much too restrictive and hurts American workers.
 
CAROLYN ANN KILLEA
Washington, Aug. 15, 1990
The writer is an immigration lawyer.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Labor Is Hoping Dinkins Support Pays Off Soon

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
Today, Mr. Dinkins is again to march with other dignitaries at the head of the parade. Except for last month's angry confrontation with correction officers and their union, his relationship with labor leaders has remained amicable. Contract negotiations that are likely to intensify over the next few weeks, though, will not only determine the future of that relationship but will also further define Mr. Dinkins's mayoralty - perhaps even more sharply than his largely successful grappling with a vast budget gap did earlier this year.
His challenge is to balance the diminishing but enduring concern in some quarters that he will profligately reward organized labor against the enduring but perhaps diminishing expectation among some workers that they will fare better in bargaining with a friendly administration - even one that inherited huge deficits, imposed $800 million in additional taxes and faces demands that it hire more police officers. 
''There aren't major philosophical differences between the parties,'' said Eric J. Schmertz, Mr. Dinkins's Commissioner of Labor Relations. ''The question is what can be afforded in this economic environment. Certain expectations are not going to be realized.''
Money is undeniably the dominant theme. Subplots include competition for primacy among some labor leaders, a rivalry that might work to the Mayor's advantage.
Barry Feinstein, whose Local 237 of the teamsters represents about 10,000 city employees, has been maneuvering to set the contract pattern by settling before Stanley Hill's District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, which represents 140,000 workers, and Sandra Feldman's United Federation of Teachers. The cost of wages and benefits in the first contract reached often becomes a model for subsequent settlements.
Ms. Feldman bargains separately with the city's Board of Education, which faces a teacher shortage. Contracts with the teamsters and most other unions expired June 30; contracts with District Council 37 and the teachers run out Sept. 30.
Mr. Feinstein, Mr. Hill and Ms. Feldman endorsed Mr. Dinkins last year. Now, they hope to win as much as they can for their members without embarrassing the Mayor whom they helped elect.
During his campaign, Mr. Dinkins joined private hospital workers in pressing for higher wages. He briefly considered trying to get some teeth extracted from the state's Taylor Law, which prohibits strikes by public employees. Later, he appointed Mr. Schmertz, a mediator whom former Mayor Edward I. Koch had opposed as pro-union.
But Mr. Dinkins also took steps to demonstrate his moderation. And some fiscal conservatives were confident that, regardless of his political debt to organized labor, he would be constrained by the city's deteriorating fiscal condition. Even before the election, he acknowledged as much himself. ''You can't bargain away what you don't have,'' Mr. Dinkins told one union audience.
Officially, what Mr. Dinkins put aside this year was enough to finance a 1.5 percent wage increase, which nobody considers realistic. Each additional percentage point would cost the city roughly $100 million, which means that merely keeping pace with inflation, estimated this year at about 6 percent, could require about $450 million more than the Mayor has allocated. That too now seems unrealistic.
The last round of bargaining, under Mr. Koch, mostly produced three-year contracts with annual pay increases of about 5 percent. Initial contract costs can be reduced by delaying larger raises until later years. Firm agreement on productivity gains, whose savings are sometimes illusory, might satisfy outside fiscal monitors. Workers disappointed by proposed raises might be mollified by an empathetic Mayor's offer of benefits and seemingly arcane work-rule revisions, whose price might not be reflected immediately.
''It may well be that I'll have to tell some of my friends they cannot have the things they want,'' Mr. Dinkins told potential contributors from Wall Street last year. ''But they'll take it from me.''
New Yorkers are about to find out how he meant that.

LENGTH: 1274 words

HEADLINE: Holiday Blends Summer Into Fall, but Who's Ready?

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: POINT PLEASANT BEACH, N.J., Sept. 2

 BODY:
Already, the light fell differently on the ocean, itself churning and crashing with the fierceness of the fall hurricane season. Bathing suits and sandals were on sale for 50 percent off. College-bound waitresses and lifeguards were in short supply. The Giants edged out the Yankees in conversation.
As fireworks exploded over the moonlit beach Saturday night while a local orchestra belted out Tchaikovsky's ''1812 Overture,'' concertgoers huddled under sandy blankets for warmth. 
All in all, people reported that the summer was good to them. Charlie Fernandez, a 22-year-old teacher, saw the Grand Canyon, and Katie Balsam, 16, went to Eastern Europe, helping to renovate a Protestant church in Poland and toting home 10 chunks of the Berlin Wall.
Brian D'Zio, 17, asked out Melissa Vitale, 15, right before she took a swing in the batting cages on the boardwalk here, and at first she was hysterical with laughter but then she said yes. Andy Koenig, a 26-year-old lifeguard, with a Playboy-bunny pendant dangling from his gold chain, had the kind of summer a lifeguard should have. ''There's this one girl who's pretty much head over heels for me,'' he said.
Jeffrey Warrick stubbed his first toe, uttered his first words (light, daddy, dog) and chased his first wave. In July, 6-year-old Ames Tebele caught his first fish, a 16-inch fluke, which was ''the biggest one of the day that day,'' his father, Eddie, pointed out.
 
A Timelessness
In many ways, this could have been any Labor Day weekend in recent history. There was a timelessness in the squeals of children playing dare with the ocean, in the inward contentment of older women doing the crossword in the shade and the skillfulness of teen-agers playing Skee Ball in the arcades.
But hints that this weekend marked the climax of the Summer of 1990 on the Jersey Shore, and not the Summer of '42, flashed across Point Pleasant Beach.
Among the dozens of advertisements and bulletins tugged across the sky by seaplanes were ''Tax Revolt Rally in Trenton'' and ''Sort It Out Before U Set It Out - Recycle.'' Stuffed Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtles and Bart Simpson dolls, the cartoon characters of the season, were the preferred prizes in game booths. Jerry Longo, 6, of Wanaque, N.J., convinced his father to put a dollar on the diamond in a game of chance 10 times so he could win Donatello, his favorite turtle. ''We have a whole Ninja trunk at home,'' his mother said.
 
'No One's Spending Money'
Bottled water, condoms and suntan lotion (No. 15) were the best sellers at the Ocean Avenue Deli, reflecting concern about drinking water, AIDS and the sun's ultraviolet rays. Though no pollution soiled the beach this summer, business was anything but brisk.
''There are a lot of people around, but no one's spending money with the shape of the economy,'' said Patricia Minovich, the delicatessen owner, adding that after Monday she would cut her newspaper orders back by 75 percent.
If anything put a sobering spin on the weekend's overall frivolity, it was the continuing conflict in the Persian Gulf. The concert Saturday was dedicated to peace in the Middle East.
In the afternoon on Saturday, as the wind picked up and members of the Orchestra of St. Peter by the Sea fastened sheet music to their music stands with clothespins, the conductor, the Rev. Alphonse Stephenson, explained why he chose Beethoven's Fifth Symphony as the centerpiece of that night's concert.
The symphony's opening notes, ''bom, bom, bom, booooom,'' are similar to the ''dot, dot, dot, dash'' of Morse code, for the letter V, used to symbolize victory in World War II. ''Peace is the ultimate victory,'' he said.
Thousands of people assembled on the beach in front of the stage in lawn chairs and on blankets as the sky turned from pale blue to deep lavender. Among them were June and Tom Price of Oakhurst, N.J., who were there with a dozen friends between the ages of 56 and 75, surrounding a silver-plated ice bucket and candelabra.
 
A Call From Oman
A month ago Friday, the Prices' 32-year-old son, Michael, an aircraft commander in the Air Force, left for the Middle East. A few days ago, they received a call from Oman - a package of Band-Aids, powder and oatmeal cookies had reached him.
Toward the end of the concert, the orchestra ran through the military airs of the various armed forces. ''When I heard the Air Force music,'' Mrs. Price said, ''I just wanted him home.''
For 20-year-old Justin Carroll of Easton, Pa., who prowled the boardwalk with two friends, the Persian Gulf crisis had cast the summer in an uncomfortable edginess. As he heard of tens of thousands of men his age going to distant, hostile sands, he was reminded of childhood's ephemeral quality.
''I'm kind of worried,'' said Mr. Carroll, a student at Long Island University. ''What happens after the reserves all leave? Then all those innocent men getting drunk and having a good time might have to go, too, and for something as trivial as oil.''
''Canada won't take you, and I don't know if I want to go to Mexico,'' he added, ''but I have a passport and I'm ready to leave.''
 
A Time for Patriotism
But the my-country-right-or-wrong brand of patriotism was in full bloom elsewhere, making the holiday feel more like the Fourth of July than Labor Day.
At the concert, a cherry-picker rose slowly behind the orchestra as the ''1812 Overture'' began, directing a spotlight on an American flag whipping in the wind on the beach. Red-white-and-blue bunting hung over the stage, and while the musicians swung into ''God Bless America,'' ''Stars and Stripes Forever'' and ''When Johnny Comes Marching Home'' during the fireworks finale, a faint chorus from the concertgoers grew louder.
With an American flag emblazoned on her T-shirt, hidden beneath the stars and stripes of her sweater, Barbara Ryan, 46, of Point Pleasant Beach, declared: ''I'm patriotic, that's it. I can't think of any other place on this earth I'd rather be.'' She meant both America and Point Pleasant Beach, where she has lived since 1955.
As she does on every Labor Day, she privately looked forward to the departure of the tourists whom she and many other natives call ''bennies,'' since they are at once beneficial to the area's economy and benefit from the area's invaluable natural resource -the ocean.
The tourists cause Point Pleasant Beach's year-round population of 6,000 to swell to 50,000 in the summer, bringing gridlock traffic to its narrow streets. ''After this weekend, we'll get our town back,'' she whispered, so that none of the bennies could hear.

HEADLINE: In Race for Comptroller, Rivals With Same Foe

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Sept. 2

 BODY:

 
Regan Is the Target
Both candidates are aiming their rhetorical fire at the Republican incumbent, Edward V. Regan, who is seeking a fourth term in the November general election. They portray him as ineffectual in his role as the chief fiscal officer of the state and unprepared, in Ms. Bellamy's words, for the ''tough times'' that the state is facing in an economic downturn.
The tepid primary campaign has drawn little public attention so far, perhaps in part because the responsibilities of the comptroller do not appear to be particularly well understood by the average voter.
''This is not the kind of office you dream about holding someday when you're a kid,'' Mr. Spano conceded. 
But if money is important, the comptroller has an important job. The comptroller not only acts as the chief fiscal watchdog for the state but also is the sole trustee of the $47 billion of assets in New York's public employee pension fund, one of the largest in the world.
 
A Reluctance to Attack
Mr. Spano has been reluctant to attack Ms. Bellamy, perhaps because several top Democratic officials are known to have warned him that they do not want to see her hurt for her expected contest against Mr. Regan. These officials have also told Mr. Spano that such actions might jeopardize their willingness to support him in future bids for office.
Another reason the race has remained so genteel has been the dearth of broadcast advertising. Mr. Spano seems to have little money for it, and Ms. Bellamy is clearly guarding her war chest for the general campaign against Mr. Regan.
Ms. Bellamy, who is on leave from her job as an investment banker with Morgan Stanley & Company, has gathered about $700,000 in contributions so far, according to filings with the State Board of Elections. Mr. Spano has collected $160,000, but his debts already outstrip the $30,000 in cash he has on hand. With polls showing Ms. Bellamy with greater name recognition than Mr. Spano, she is likely to benefit from the low-key nature of the primary campaign.
The Spano campaign did receive one shot in the arm last week, in an endorsement by The Amsterdam News, one of the most widely read newspapers among blacks in the New York metropolitan area. Ms. Bellamy, who ran unsuccessfully for mayor in 1985 after two terms as Council president, has been perceived as having overwhelming support in New York City.
The Amsterdam News editorial said the newspaper had the ''deepest respect and admiration'' for Ms. Bellamy, but said Mr. Spano had come down ''on the side of right and the N.A.A.C.P.'' during the controversy over desegregation in Yonkers.
 
Fiscal Experience
Ms. Bellamy, who is 48 years old, served as a state senator and Council president during New York City's fiscal crisis in the mid-1970's, experiences she stresses when she describes herself as someone who has ''been there'' in tough economic times.
Mr. Spano, 54, emphasizes his management and administrative skills as the Westchester County Clerk over the last eight years, as well as his background as a public-school teacher.
Both candidates say they favor establishing an official board, as opposed to the advisory panel now in place, to help decide on how to invest state pension funds. Both have also called for moves toward divesting the state's holdings of stocks in companies linked to South Africa.
Regardless of who wins, one important question is how fervently Gov. Mario M. Cuomo will work to help the Democratic nominee try to topple Mr. Regan.
Some state lawmakers have wondered whether Mr. Cuomo secretly prefers having a Republican comptroller to use as a foil against Democrats pushing him to increase spending for a variety of programs. Mr. Cuomo often invoked Mr. Regan's fiscal cautions this past year during a protracted struggle over the state budget, and he told reporters that Mr. Regan ''does not have a dishonest bone in his body.''
 
Other Questions
There are also questions about whether Mr. Cuomo, who is not noted for having a forgiving nature, has yet come to overlook the fact that Ms. Bellamy supported Mayor Edward I. Koch when he ran for governor in the 1982 Democratic primary against Mr. Cuomo.
Mr. Cuomo dismisses these questions as nonsense and says he is eager to see Democrats in top positions all over Albany.
There is also a theory afoot that many voters have simply become accustomed to the idea of a comptroller and a governor coming from opposing political parties; for example, Nelson A. Rockefeller, a Republican, had Arthur Levitt, a Democrat, looking over his shoulder as the Comptroller during Mr. Rockefeller's entire 15-year tenure as Governor.
Both Mr. Spano and Ms. Bellamy dismiss this concept, saying criticism of a Democratic governor from a fellow Democrat would carry more weight than criticism from a Republican, especially the incumbent Comptroller. Mr. Regan has been ''a flyweight, not a counterweight,'' said Jon Lukomnik, Ms. Bellamy's campaign manager.
 
Main Ammunition
The main ammunition for the Democratic nominee is expected to be the criticism Mr. Regan has received from many quarters, including the State Commission on Government Integrity, for systematically soliciting campaign contributions from Wall Street firms and others that do business with his office.
But that strategy could cut two ways. In response to reporters' questions after the half-hour television debate here Thursday, Ms. Bellamy found herself defending her own aggressive fund raising, including her acceptance of $38,000 from Carl C. Icahn, the corporate raider. That is the largest contribution to any statewide candidate this year.
''The issue is not taking the money,'' Ms. Bellamy said. ''The issue is the quid pro quo. And anybody who knows Carol Bellamy knows that's not the way I do business.''
Mr. Spano, meanwhile, said he ''might have a problem'' with accepting large contributions from people who do business with the comptroller's office. But, he added, appearing somewhat downcast, ''No one has offered me a large donation, so I don't have to face that problem.''

HEADLINE: New Jersey Spending Law Alarms Cities

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOBOKEN, N.J.

 BODY:
Other costs newly covered are those for liability insurance, recycling, water supply systems, police vehicles, equipment for 911 telephone emergency systems and mandated state and Federal programs.
 
Cuts in Services Anticipated
Local officials fear that the state's lumping of these costs into the portion of a municipal budget that can grow by only 5 percent will force cuts in other areas of the budget. Because the law is so new, few officials have started looking for savings yet. But they fear cuts are inevitable. 
Here in Hoboken, for instance, about $25 million of its $40 million budget for 1990 is exempt from the 5 percent ceiling. For the 1991 budget, Hoboken will have only about $7.7 million in exemptions, said Edwin J. Chius, Hoboken's Business Administrator.
Like his counterparts around the state, Mr. Chius is just starting to look for savings to comply with the new law. Most likely, he said, they will come from the Police and Fire Departments, which consume about 62 percent of Hoboken's budget.
''We'll lay some off if we have to,'' he said.
When the Governor signed the law on Aug. 20, he said it would help control homeowners' property taxes and put ''discipline and accountability back into the government vocabulary.'' The measure goes into effect Jan. 1, the same day that New Jersey's 567 municipalities begin their new budget year.
 
New Budgets in Doubt
Budget preparation has just started in most communities, and officials say they are still immersed in studying the fine points of the toughened ceiling law and thus unable to speculate, except broadly, about its impact.
Generally, they say, any property tax savings will most likely come at the expense of existing services, like police, fire and public works, unless the state increases aid to municipalities.
''If additional money is not forthcoming, it could have a catastrophic impact on health and welfare services,'' said William G. Dressel, assistant executive director of the New Jersey League of Municipalities, a lobbying group for the 567 municipalities. He foresaw ''a hue and cry not only from town officials, but the tax-paying public, because essential government services will have to be curtailed.''
Mr. Dressel and other league officials plan to meet with the Governor on Sept. 4 and appeal for more state aid and the restoration of some of the exemptions lost under the ceiling law.
 
Local Official Nettled
The Governor's second justification for the broader law - the need for local fiscal accountability - has rankled officials. Mr. Florio, a Democrat, signed the measure in Manchester, a retirement community in Ocean County, as the state intensified an investigation into fiscal mismanagement by a Republican administration. Local officials say the Governor's choice of Manchester as the bill-signing setting was unfair.
''It makes every town look like its fiscally imprudent,'' said James Davy, Town Manager in West Milford and president of the New Jersey Municipal Management Association, a group of town administrators. ''A cap law would not have prevented the type of fiscal impropriety that occurred there.''
Mr. Davy and other local officials complained bitterly about state policies and mandates that either reduce local revenues or force spending increases exceeding the ceiling law's 5 percent limit.
Former Gov. Thomas H. Kean siphoned off for state use millions in utility tax revenues once earmarked for municipalities, and Governor Florio has continued the policy, they say. Millions more in local school aid has been withheld by the state government in the last decade. Municipal costs for state health benefits have just gone up 25 percent, and the cost of pension plans for town workers has risen 20 percent, officials complain.
 
Garbage Costs Outpace Inflation
In the late 1980's the state shut regional landfills in North Jersey and ordered household garbage generated by about half the state's population shipped out of state, sending local taxes for garbage disposal soaring.
West Milford's annual garbage disposal budget has grown from $150,000 to $2 million in five years because of the state policy, Mr. Davy said. Dozens of other towns have had similar increases. Under the state's series of laws restricting local spending, first imposed in 1976, garbage costs were exempt from the 5 percent ceiling, but no longer.
''Items like garbage were outside the cap for good reason - they exceeded the inflationary index,'' said Borough Administrator Nicholas C. Saros in Ramsey, where the garbage disposal budget has jumped from $300,000 to $1.3 million since 1985. ''Nobody in the state has ever given us any long-range planning on what garbage costs will be.''
In neighboring Wyckoff, Borough Administrator Robert Shannon, has asked department heads to start examining their mandatory budget costs and their discretionary programs, like leaf collection, staffing for the Police and Public Works Departments, recreation, ballfield maintenance and activities for the elderly.
''I've asked them what discretionary programs can be affected without affecting quality of life,'' Mr. Shannon said.

HEADLINE: Johnson & Johnson Looks Abroad

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J.

 BODY:

 
Scrambling to Sell More
And as harried national health planners crack down on drug prices around the world, profits are squeezed and the companies must scramble to sell more.
The increasing attention to globalization in the industry can be traced at Johnson & Johnson through Hismanal, a non-sedating antihistamine that is the company's fastest-growing drug in the United States. The drug, discovered and developed at Janssen Pharmaceutica, the company's unit in Belgium, is now sold in 116 countries.
In the past, Johnson & Johnson often chose to license a drug to companies overseas in return for royalties that could be rather thin. In Japan, for example, Hismanal was licensed to the Mochida Pharmaceutical Company in 1985. But licensing drugs and the consequent diluting of profits is no longer the way to go. ''Today we would keep Hismanal,'' said Robert N. Wilson, a Johnson & Johnson vice chairman who heads the pharmaceuticals-diagnostics division. 
 
Joint Venture in Japan
Indeed, the company has chosen to sell new products through its own growing sales force abroad. Building a presence in Japan, Johnson & Johnson has acquired a majority stake in a joint venture with the Kyowa Hakko Kogyo Company, the ninth-largest Japanese drug company, to sell a half-dozen drugs now awaiting approval by the Japanese Government. The joint-venture company, Janssen-Kyowa, will have 300 to 350 salespeople by the end of the year, Mr. Wilson said, and will grow even bigger as new products are approved for sale there, to 500 to 1,000 salespeople. Johnson & Johnson has also added about 400 pharmaceutical salespeople in Europe in the last two years and more than 350 in the United States.
With its increasingly international sales force, the company is pushing new products through regulatory pipelines and into pharmacies in every major market faster than ever before.
Johnson & Johnson divides its global business into three parts: one-third is prescription products like Hismanal and oral contraceptives; about 40 percent is in consumer products like Tylenol and baby shampoo, and the rest is professional products sold mainly to hospitals. Half of the $9.8 billion in total sales in 1989 and 60 percent of the $1.5 billion in pretax profits were generated outside the United States. Worldwide sales were $5.66 billion in the first half of 1990, up 17.1 percent from the corresponding period a year ago. Pretax earnings were $902 million, down four-tenths of a percent, reflecting a write-off of $140 million on assets and operations in Latin America, primarily because of economic turmoil in Argentina.
 
No. 8 in Pharmaceuticals
Pharmaceuticals is Johnson & Johnson's most profitable and fastest-growing business. It is already the eighth-largest pharmaceutical company in the world, with $2.7 billion in drug sales last year.
Scientists at Johnson & Johnson's Belgian and American research laboratories are developing products the company hopes will help it break into the lucrative antibiotic and cardiovascular markets. Sixteen percent of drug revenues - or about $430 million - was plowed into pharmaceutical research and development last year. Johnson & Johnson has also joined with Merck & Company, the world leader in pharmaceutical sales, in a 50-50 venture to develop over-the-counter versions of Merck drugs.
The company's pharmaceutical research is divided equally between its Belgium-based Janssen unit and its Robert Wood Johnson Pharmaceutical Institute in the United States. Janssen, which was acquired in 1961, is a research powerhouse that has discovered 75 new drugs, perhaps more than any other pharmaceutical discovery group, since it was founded in 1953 by Dr. Paul A. Janssen.
 
Pressure to Roll Out Products
But the double-digit increases in the drug industry's research spending are intensifying the pressure to realize prompt returns by rolling out new products worldwide. ''Competing overseas makes the difference in reaching the break-even point on the financial curve,'' said Harvey E. Bale Jr., a senior vice president with the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, a trade group.
A breakthrough drug can cost at least $200 million and take 12 years to reach the market. Competing research companies, meanwhile, are quicker than ever in finding ways to improve important new drugs and grab a piece of the action.
''With computers and chemistry, scientists can go around patents much faster now,'' Mr. Larsen said. ''Within a year or two, you usually have somebody else right on your heels.''
At Merck, research is maintained in all the major therapeutic fields. ''When a breakthrough comes in science,'' said Dr. P. Roy Vagelos, Merck's chairman, ''you have to be ready to jump on it.''
 
Rankings in Three Markets
Although most major health-care companies are sharpening their global tactics, Johnson & Johnson is one of a handful big enough to sell its own products throughout the $130 billion worldwide pharmaeutical market. Merck was the only company to make the top 10 in drug sales last year in all three major markets: North America, Europe and Japan.
Johnson & Johnson was fifth in North America last year and 13th in Europe, and is coming up rapidly in Japan, where until recently its products were licensed out to Japanese companies.
The accelerating pace of global competition was one reason Merck cited when it recently announced a joint venture with E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company. They plan to build on Du Pont's drug research and Merck's development and marketing prowess in Europe and the United States.
 
Growth of Mergers
As the race speeds up, mergers and acquisitions have multiplied. Rhone-Poulenc S.A., a French chemical company, merged with the Rorer Group Inc. Hoffmann-La Roche, a unit of Swiss-based Roche Holdings Ltd., is buying control of Genentech Inc., a South San Francisco-based biotechnology company, for $2.1 billion. Beecham P.L.C. of Britain merged last year with the SmithKline Beckman Corporation, based in Philadelphia, to form SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. And the Bristol-Myers Company merged with the Squibb Corporation to become the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company, second largest in world drug sales.
European companies will be increasingly looking for ways to expand in the United States as falling European trade barriers open their home markets to products from countries with lower production costs, like Greece, said Mary Jo Veverka, a vice president with the consulting firm Booz, Allen & Hamilton Inc.
''Globalization in pharmaceuticals is just beginning,'' said Norman C. Selby, a partner with McKinsey & Company, the management consulting firm. But he warns that medium-size American drug companies like the Schering-Plough Corporation and the Warner-Lambert Company's Parke-Davis Group may be swallowed up if they cannot grow big enough in global markets.

HEADLINE: Steel Unit Of USX For Sale

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH

 BODY:

 
Weakness in the Industry
But Mr. Corry said he did not expect such a sale to occur soon because of weakness in the industry.
From interviews with associates and institutional investors in touch with him since the high-pitched proxy battle with Mr. Icahn, Mr. Corry appears more than willing to do away with the steel division of a company known during most of its history as United States Steel.
These people say USX would probably sell the division to a large steel producer abroad or spin off the company in a public offering, retaining at most a small stake. The company would keep its vast oil-industry holdings. 
Analysts say that, besides British Steel, another possible purchaser is the Pohang Iron and Steel Company of South Korea, which operates a venture with USX in Pittsburg, Calif. Pohang officials have declined to comment on the matter, as did those of British Steel.
 
Divestiture Called Disruptive
When USX was fighting Mr. Icahn's proposal, Mr. Corry called a divestiture unecessary, disruptive and filled with negative tax implications.
Until the end of the year, USX has the benefit of millions of dollars in tax-loss carry-forwards from the days in which the company lost money in its steel business. The company is allowed to use past losses to reduce its tax liabililty.
Mr. Corry wanted the benefits to help reduce the tax liability of the entire corporation. But the benefit expires at the end of the year; after that, a sale of the steel division would not have an adverse tax impact.
Still, some analysts and investors wonder why the company is considering selling the steel operation. After the depression in the steel industry in the early 1980's, USX has been one of the nation's premier steel producers, leading the industry in profitability and efficiency.
In the second quarter, USX led the industry with operating profits of $28 a ton. The Inland Steel Company, with the next-best record, had an operating profit of $24 a ton, and the Bethlehem Steel Company, the nation's second-largest producer, posted $13.
After losing hundreds of millions of dollars during the downturn in the steel industry between 1982 and 1986, USX's steel business, after being slimmed down, went on to become the company's primary profit maker in 1988, providing $501 million in operating earnings, compared with $475 million from USX's energy businesses.
 
Concerns Over Outlook
But executives within USX question how long that can continue, saying that steel is a capital-intensive business requiring huge financial resources to remain competitive. Moreover, competition is intensifying from steel-producing countries that are working to develop technologies to cut production costs and operate in ways that are less environmentally hazardous.
USX's divesting itself of the steel division would greatly alter the competitive dynamics of the industry. If sold in a public offering, the steel unit could not then rely on the company's Marathon Oil or Texas Oil and Gas operations to provide cash when conditions in the steel industry worsened.
On the other hand, a sale to one of the foreign giants of the industry, with huge resources, would give the steel division significantly more financial muscle than its domestic competitors have.
Associates within USX said Mr. Corry thinks the steel operation will bring a better price when market conditions within the industry improve. Reflecting a downturn in the automotive and construction industries, steel prices have sagged since 1988, the industry's banner year. Flat-rolled sheet steel, a mainstay that goes into everything from appliances to automobiles, is now selling for about $360 a ton, compared with $410 a year ago.
Although efficiency has improved and costs have been cut, profits have fallen for the first half of the year throughout the industry.
''Right now, Chuck doesn't feel any strong pressure to do anything about the status of the steel business,'' said a USX executive, who insisted on anonymity. ''But when the conditions in the industry improve, which he expects to happen next year, look for something then.''
Mr. Corry did not discuss a sale during Mr. Icahn's challenge because ''he thought the timing was wrong,'' said Christopher Plummer, an analyst with the WEFA Group, an economic forecasting firm in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa. ''The market was still heading downward during the Icahn situation. And USX would not be in the best position to sell assets.''
In his first year as chairman, Mr. Corry has been much less likely than his predecessor, David M. Roderick, to discuss the company with reporters. The longtime USX executive, 57 years old, was the chief architect of the company's turnaround in the mid-1980's and has long advocated bolstering the energy holdings.
The disposal of USX's steel business would complete a transformation that began in 1982, when the company bought the Marathon Oil Company. Four years later, USX bought the Texas Oil and Gas Corporation.
 
Moving Ahead After Icahn
With the battle against Mr. Icahn now behind him, Mr. Corry is concentrating on building the energy side of USX, saying that Marathon will be the centerpiece.
Although management prevailed in thwarting Mr. Icahn's proposal, executives within USX said the proxy battle made it clear that sympathy had grown for the central premise advocated by the New York investor: that the value of the company's stock would increase if USX were split and shares were issued in two separate companies.
''A spinoff would help to illuminate the values of the two parts,'' said Martin D. Sass, head of M. D. Sass Investors Service Inc., a money management firm that owns 647,000 shares of USX.
Mr. Icahn, who owns 33.9 million shares, declined to be interviewed for this article.
 
Contract Talks Set for Fall
USX, which now has a lower-cost labor contract than most of its competitors, faces what could be a difficult round of contract negotiations this fall. Most of the large steelmakers signed new contracts with the United Steel Workers a year ago -settlements that USX management says are too costly.
The United Steel Workers, whose agreement with USX expires in January, will soon begin fighting for an accord similar to those won at Bethlehem, Inland, Armco Inc. and the LTV Corporation.
''But once the contract talks are over and the market improves,'' said an institutional investor who insisted on not being identified, ''USX will begin to complete its transformation.''

HEADLINE: Uphill Test Is Predicted For the Dollar

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The dollar rallied some from its lows at the end of last week and closed on Friday at 1.5755 marks and 143.80 Japanese yen. But much of the buying was in a thin market and was done to prepare for the long Labor Day weekend; the gains could be quickly undone this week. And the rally still left the currency well below the levels before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2.
The first event that could move the dollar will be the testimony of Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, before the House Banking Committee on Sept. 13 and before the Joint Economic Committee on Sept. 19, when his topic will be the nation's economic outlook. 
Traders, portfolio managers, analysts and economists around the world will be listening for any hint of how the chairman wants the Fed to deal with its choices, which include easing interest rates to head off or soften a recession, standing pat, or raising rates to counter the inflationary shock from the oil-price increase. Higher rates would support the dollar.
But the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and the American military response have created the biggest problems -and unknowns - for the dollar.
The jump in oil prices and the rise in military costs for American forces in the Persian Gulf have undermined hopes for a significant cut in the Federal budget deficit. At the same time, the costs have raised the estimates of the deficit for fiscal year 1991 substantially, pushing it toward the $300 billion range when counting the cost of the savings and loan bailout.
 
Difficult Budget Talks
The talks between the Bush Administration and Congress on the deficit have already been difficult, despite the President's decision to consider some tax increases. With higher oil prices, one possibility for a tax, an energy tax, seems less likely. And with the economy slowing or even entering a recession, tax increases will be very hard to get through Congress.
When the budget negotiations begin anew this month, the financial markets may be greatly disappointed. ''The thing that could precipitate a sharper drop of the dollar is if people lose confidence in American economic policy,'' said Nicholas Sargen, director of bond research at Salomon Brothers Inc. in New York.
Some jolts are also likely from abroad. After Oct. 3, the Bundesbank is expected by many analysts to be faced with annual inflation in the 3 percent range. The betting is that interest rates will be pushed higher, helping to slow the economy to fight inflation, to keep the mark strong and to attract foreign investment to help raise the capital that East Germany needs.
At the same time, the Japanese central bank, the Bank of Japan, will consider its next move on interest rates. It raised its official discount rate to 6 percent, from 5.25 percent, on Thursday, after interest rates in the markets rose to more than 8 percent.
In September, the bank will receive data on capital investment and the second-quarter gross domestic product, which it will weigh in deciding whether interest rates will have to be pushed higher. The expectation now is that they will move again.
 
Decline in Value
The moves would widen the differential in interest rates between the dollar and the foreign currencies, which will diminish the value of the dollar by attracting investors to the mark and the yen.
The dollar could get a lift from one unexpected area. Investors could still choose the dollar as a safe harbor if full-scale fighting broke out in the Persian Gulf. So far in the crisis, investors have fled to other currencies as havens. In fact, the dollar is weaker than before the invasion on Aug. 2.
 
Strong Start in 1988
In 1988, the dollar came into the autumn strong, bulging beyond the ceilings set for it by the United States and its economic allies in the Group of Seven. But concerns about the Government's inability to deal with the Federal budget deficit and uncertainty about George Bush, who was elected President that fall, pushed the dollar down by 4.3 percent against the mark and by 7.9 percent against the Japanese currency.
In 1989, the dollar again rallied in the summer and came into the fall with gusto. But at the meeting of the International Monetary Fund, the United States and its allies made clear that they thought the dollar was too strong. The West Germans raised interest rates, which weakened the dollar by diverting investors to the mark. Then American and foreign stocks dropped suddenly on Oct. 13, bringing the dollar lower.
The Berlin wall fell and Eastern Europe began opening up, attracting capital to Europe and weakening the dollar even further. By year's end, the dollar was down by 14.2 percent against the mark, although it managed to hold against the yen, dropping by only 1 percent.
The fall of 1986 was an exception, as the central banks moved to support the dollar because they thought it was falling too far too fast.
Now the autumn of 1990 is at hand, and the question is whether it will prove the exception or the rule.
