HEADLINE: Washington's Mood Worries Detroit

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 2

 BODY:
Rising oil prices make passage of stricter fuel-economy standards more likely, although not inevitable, according to auto makers. The mere discussion of the idea worries them. For several years, American auto companies have relied heavily on the fat profit margins on full-size cars to buttress their dwindling earnings.
''Any time people get emotional, you can get a knee-jerk reaction that isn't thought through,'' said Joel Pitcoff, a sales and marketing analyst for the Ford Motor Company.
Japanese auto makers oppose the bill as well, but for a different reason. The bill proposes a gradual percentage increase in each company's fuel-mileage average. Since Japanese-made autos are already more fuel efficient than those of American companies, raising their fuel-economy levels by a set percentage would force them to attain a higher standard than their American competitors. 
The Persian Gulf crisis has also rekindled a longstanding public debate over who should bear the responsibility for reducing imports of oil.
Conservation and environmental groups supporting the Senate bill, which is sponsored by Richard H. Bryan, a Nevada Democrat, favor tightening efficiency standards for cars, which they believe will force auto makers to develop various energy-saving technologies. Fuel conservation was being urged by these groups even before the Iraq crisis as a way to alleviate global warming.
They point out that the current rules on fuel economy have not forced anyone to do without big or powerful cars, as some auto makers had predicted when the corporate-average fuel-economy standard was developed after the energy crisis in the early 1970's.
 
Opposition From the Auto Makers
The auto makers, with support from Administration officials, oppose a tighter Federal fuel-economy standard. Last month, Energy Secretary James D. Watkins introduced a ''short-term strategy'' for stabilizing oil markets by raising domestic production and encouraging conservation. He suggested that the Government should not bog down stabilization efforts by trying to revise the fuel-economy standard and other issues that are bound to involve lengthy debates.
For their part, auto makers contend that further big gains in energy efficiency are not possible without limiting the selection of cars that Americans have grown accustomed to having.
Yet, as long as gasoline remains relatively cheap and readily available, they argue, drivers will not buy highly efficient vehicles in great number. Indeed, fuel is now so cheap on a historical basis, when adjusted for inflation, that even the recent run-up in prices is not financially significant for most drivers, they say.
''Fuel prices have gone up only 15 to 20 cents a gallon, and the principal effect of that on car buying is short term,'' said George Eads, chief economist for the General Motors Corporation.
But analysts agree that much higher prices or a fuel shortage would sharply reduce sales of big cars.
Auto makers argue that if the nation wants to be less reliant on foreign oil, lawmakers should pass some type of energy tax to raise the price of fuel, which would in turn stimulate consumer demand for fuel-efficient vehicles. The industry has no consensus on precisely what type of regulation it wants, but an energy tax is not likely to win wide support in Washington.
The Chrysler Corporation and Ford support a tax specifically on gasoline, although Ford stipulates that the proceeds should be used to reduce the Federal budget deficit. G.M. has opposed a gasoline tax but favors a broader tax on all forms of energy. G.M. and Ford are both against increasing the corporate-average fuel- economy standard. Lee A. Iacocca, the chairman of Chrysler, is not, but he says an increase to 40 miles a gallon is too great.
Auto executives dismiss the argument sometimes advanced by conservation groups that the auto makers possess energy-saving technology but refuse to put it on the market because of the high cost of doing so.
''Everyone thinks there's something on the shelf we're withholding,'' said Edward Mertz, vice president in charge of G.M.'s Buick division. ''The problem is plain old physics. We would have to take cars out of production'' if fuel-efficiency requirements became too stringent.
 
Two-Ton Buick Roadmaster
Mr. Mertz was speaking on Tuesday in Novi, Mich., at the introduction of Buick's 1991 models. Among the new cars scheduled to appear in the coming year is the Buick Roadmaster, a two-ton behemoth that is bigger and heavier than most cars Buick has built in the last two decades.
The average fuel efficiency of new domestic cars increased sharply between 1980 and 1988, but has declined slightly in the last two years as consumers have chosen bigger cars. To improve fuel efficiency without sacrificing power or comfort, auto makers say, they must overcome many technical hurdles caused by the potential fuel-efficiency, safety and clean-air regulations, which are costly and often conflict with one another.
For example, safety devices like airbags are required by law but add weight and reduce fuel efficiency. Two-stroke engines generate more horsepower for their weight than four-stroke engines now in use in cars. But their emissions will not meet standards included in a proposed clean-air act now pending in Congress.
Martin Zimmerman, Ford's chief economist, said the cost of meeting higher fuel-efficiency standards, clean-air rules and other Federal regulations at the same time would be much more expensive than if the standards were met separately.
 
Not Enough Engineers
Richard Donnelly, the head of G.M.'s engine division, said he could not find enough engineers and scientists with the necessary skills to work on the various regulatory projects.
Still, many weapons remain in the industry's fuel-efficiency arsenal. G.M. says the average fuel efficiency of its cars has improved 130 percent since the mid-1970's, and Mr. Mertz of Buick believes the improvements will continue, albeit at a reduced pace, as engineers take pounds off various components by developing lighter materials.
Thomas Kowaleski, a Chrysler spokesman, said the auto maker produces about 300,000 four-cylinder engines a year but could triple that number if the demand increased. ''We're working on projects like the two-stroke engine, but we want to make sure technology is perfected before we introduce it,'' he said.
''No one wants to have trouble merging on interstates,'' he said, referring to the problems that many cars had in the early 1970's when clean-air requirements led to engines that did not work well or provide much acceleration.
Much of the theoretical basis for Senator Bryan's bill - which assumes that auto makers can come up with technical answers for problems of efficiency without radically changing how cars perform - comes from Deborah Bleviss, executive director of the International Institute for Energy Conservation.
 
'No One Wonderful Technology'
Ms. Bleviss, a physicist by training, argued in a book published in 1988 that technologies like two-stroke engines, lighter-weight materials, electronic engine controls and continously variable transmission - a high-efficiency replacement for automatic transmission - hold great promise.
''There's no one wonderful technology'' that would enable auto makers to average 40 miles a gallon, she said. ''When Detroit says the two-stroke engine can't meet emissions requirements, you have to take that with a grain of salt. It's in Detroit's interest to say that.''
But Ms. Bleviss said a stringent fuel-economy standard must be accompanied by other laws to dampen demand for fuel, as well as by Government-sponsored research to help with the burden of developing new technologies. Rather than an energy tax, she said, she leaned toward auto registration fees on a sliding scale based on the vehicle, and sales taxes that provide an incentive for fuel efficiency.
David Cole, a professor at the University of Michigan in charge of transportation studies, says auto makers would have trouble ''technically and financially'' in meeting a 40-mile-a-gallon standard.
''With energy ridiculously cheap, there are still questions as to whether customers would accept vehicles that would satisfy this law,'' Mr. Cole said. ''They just might decide to get themselves new politicians.''

LENGTH: 1226 words

HEADLINE: Savings Units' Boards Hurt by U.S. Suits

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2

 BODY:
''It is almost impossible to find new directors,'' said Brian Smith, executive vice president of the United States League of Savings Institutions, the industry's largest trade group.
''The first line of defense is the quality of directors and managers,'' he said. ''And to the extent it is more difficult to get sophisticated business judgment on the board of an institution, you can have a perverse return to the very condition regulators are concerned about - domination by a single chairman of the board or group of officials whose actions go unchecked.''
Federal regulators disagree that their actions will have a negative impact on the industry. They say they are simply pursuing every channel they can to reduce the cost of the savings and loan rescue, and that holding directors accountable will lead to stronger management. 
Armed with vast new powers from the savings and loan bailout law, regulators can impose civil penalties of up to $1 million a day covering periods in which directors and officers are deemed to have violated banking laws. While the regulators say their new-found toughness is meant to fulfill their responsibilities to recover the maximum amount of money lost by failed institutions because of mismanagement, they add that it also serves to put directors on notice that they must take their responsibilities seriously.
''I want to be sure that everyone who bears responsibility for losses are paying what they ought to pay,'' said Mark I. Rosen, Deputy General Counsel for the F.D.I.C.
F.D.I.C. officials say they have recovered $300 million this year from failed financial institutions.
The agency will soon file its most notable case, a $200 million negligence suit against Neil Bush, the President's son, for his role in the $1 billion collapse of the Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association in Denver.
 
Worries Over Insurance
The Federal litigation is worrying insurance industry officials, who say the regulators' actions could drive them out of the business of underwriting director and officer liability policies. Moreover, they say that the price of the policies, particularly for smaller banks, is soaring, and that a growing number either cannot get coverage or cannot afford it.
But these officials are primarily concerned that the Government is looking to the insurance industry as a source of capital to pay some of the cost of the savings and loan rescue.
''Everyone wants to reduce the loss and is looking for all of the assets they can recover, so they say, 'Why not go after the insurance industry?' '' said Richard Cartland, president of Executive Risk Management Associates, a unit of the Aetna Life and Casualty Company that specializes in director and officer liability insurance. ''But we are not a utility that can be used as a backup to the deposit insurance funds.''
It is primarily the insurance companies that end up paying the most in successful suits brought by the F.D.I.C. In one case this year, the agency won a $70 million settlement from an insurance company.
 
A Different Era
Being a director of a bank or savings and loan association in the climate of stable interest rates and modest inflation of the 1960's was once an easy task that required a modicum of attention at monthly board meetings. Most outside directors came from the ranks of local business executives and boards were largely rubber stamps for the decisions of management.
''Often, when I would go on bank closings, I would talk to directors and they would say, 'Gosh, I didn't even attend the meetings. I just voted the way we were supposed to vote,' '' said one regulator who insisted on not being identified.
But inflation and interest rates began to gyrate in the mid-1970's, just as the Government removed many of the restrictions on banks' activities. The complexities of banking caught many in management by surprise. Not only did entire institutions turn sour, but so did the lives of many of their outside directors.
 
One Director's Story
Richard O. Jacobs, a lawyer with Riden, Earle & Kiefner in St. Petersburg, Fla., is perhaps typical.
As part of a team of local business executives who founded the Park Bank of Florida in the Tampa Bay area in the late 1970's, Mr. Jacobs was a director who watched the institution grow into a $500 million bank, one of the state's largest.
He said he trusted the management, knew them and had little indication that anything was wrong until early 1986, when the bank began to collapse from bad real estate loans. In the end, the failure created a $300 million loss for the F.D.I.C., and Mr. Jacobs, along with the other directors, was eventually sued by the agency for $30 million.
Mr. Jacobs said his personal loss from the failure and ensuing litigation was $3 million, that legal fees in just the F.D.I.C.'s case totaled $2 million and would have been double that had the bank's insurance company not agreed to settle.
 
A New Reality
The new powers given to regulators last year by the savings and loan bailout legislation are slowly making banking officials adjust to new realities. Though the agencies do not impose stiff penalties often, simply having the authority has intimidated many in the industry, some bankers said, making many directors wonder if it is worth the risk of serving on boards.
Regulators and banking industry experts counter that there is a way for bank directors to protect themselves: become more involved in the workings of the bank, spend more time reviewing the organization's operations, object publicly when problems arise and even resign or inform regulators of the problems.
 
An Educational Campaign
The industry has begun an aggressive educational campaign, warning directors that they need to spend more time familiarizing themselves with the banking business.
Mr. Jacobs has proposed that directors be required to pass a test demonstrating that they understand banking, and Representative Chalmers P. Wylie, Republican of Ohio, introduced legislation earlier this summer that would require the regulatory agencies to establish mandatory educational programs for bank directors.
But many experts agree that much depends on the willingness of the insurance industry to continue underwriting director and officer policies. The industry is concerned because the regulators have sought to hold insurance companies liable for damages even when their policies have stated that cases brought by regulators are not covered.

HEADLINE: Stocks Firm In Tokyo

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: TOKYO, Monday, Sept. 3

 BODY:
''Because of the Labor Day holiday in New York, many people don't know what sort of attitude to take to the market,'' said Daniel Marull, a trader at Sanyo Securities here. ''We had good volume for the past four days, but it will be very weak today.'' 
The Nikkei index of 225 issues gained 60.55 points, or less than one-half a percent, to end the morning session at 26,038.92. In the first 10 minutes of trading, the index rose 121.30 points, to 26,099.67. The Nikkei in gained 308.41 points on Friday.
In other trading, the dollar opened lower against the yen, the Swiss franc and the British pound, but unchanged against the West German mark. Dealers expected quiet trading because the New York markets are closed for the Labor Day holiday.
The dollar opened at 143.40 yen and 1.5760 marks after closing at 143.75 and 1.5760, respectively, in New York on Friday. The dollar had ended trading here on Friday at 144.50 yen and 1.5635 marks.
Dealers here are focusing on how the United States Federal Reserve and the West German Bundesbank will react to last week's three-quarters of a percent rise in the Bank of Japan's discount rate, to 6 percent.
Some dealers said they expect the Fed to ease its Federal funds rate this week. The Bundesbank's regular council meeting is scheduled to be held on Thursday.

LENGTH: 958 words

HEADLINE: 'Micro Bankers' Help The Poor Make Money

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:

 
Looking for Investors
Its founder and chairman, Anthony Stevens, a Harvard business school graduate, said he hoped Micro Enterprise could turn a small profit in a couple of years.
To do that, Mr. Stevens said, the company must prove it can make money by lending to grass-roots entrepreneurs - the seamstress who cannot afford a sewing machine or the fence builder who needs shovels.
''We're stepping into it fairly carefully at this point, but it is considerably more than a hobby,'' said Mr. Stevens, who is on leave from Citicorp, where he was vice president of the private banking division. ''This is, for me, the most important thing in my life.'' 
Mr. Stevens is handling much of the work himself at no pay.
 
Other Micro Banks
Nonprofit micro banks have had success making loans that traditional banks might consider too risky. In Chicago, the Full Circle Fund, had 100 percent repayment on the 24 loans it granted in the last 18 months. In Canada, the First People's Fund said it had not had a default on any of its 120 loans since 1987. The fund serves three Indian reservations in Ontario. In North Carolina, Arkansas and South Dakota, similar projects appear to be working. And on the Cherokee Nation reservation in Tahlequah, Okla., officials are also starting a micro-lending agency.
But some experts say there is little evidence that such a bank can make money.
''It's only in the realm of hope right now,'' said Jeffrey Ashe, a micro-lending expert in Boston who is planning micro banks in New Hampshire, Vermont and Massachusetts. ''You've got to have some social vision for doing this. This is not the best way to make money - making thousands of tiny loans.''
Scores of micro banks have had success bolstering the economies of villages in poor countries throughout the third world.
But ''it's very easy to pick a success story and say this is the answer,'' said David Fredrick, a specialist on Bangladesh at the State Department's Agency for International Development. ''That's not to say it's not a good thing, but its relative utility in the U.S. might not be that important.''
 
Bank Started With a $6 Loan
Like many micro banks, Micro Enterprise is modeled after the Grameen Bank in Bangladesh, which was begun 13 years ago with a $6 loan from the founder's pocket. It now lends more than $6 million a month.
Like the Grameen Bank, Micro Enterprise is starting small, seeking a 1 percent return on its original investment of about $30,000. Mr. Stevens said he believed the bank could attract additional investors once it shows itself to be a profitable enterprise.
If the bank can attract 300 borrowers and a return of about $150 in interest for each $1,200 loan, Mr. Stevens said the company could afford a 2 to 3 percent default rate and still turn a small profit.
Micro Enterprise is trying to keep overhead to a minimum. The company operates out of rent-free offices in a law firm. Advertising is primarily word of mouth. For every 300 borrowers, the company plans to hire a loan officer who will be paid about $20,000 a year. The company predicts it will issue 25 more loans by this winter, bringing to 27 the number of loans in its portfolio. Eventually, it hopes to accept deposits.
 
Use of Peer Pressure
Central to Micro Enterprise is an element common to all micro-lending agencies - peer pressure. While loans are made to individual entrepreneurs, each person is in a group of four or five who are in line for similar loans. If one person fails to pay on time, loans for the whole group are jeopardized.
''We tried doing individual loans for micro projects, but it was a disaster,'' said Gerald Sherman, executive director of the Circle Banking Project of the Lakota Fund, which serves the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation in Kyle, S.D. ''We had a 100 percent delinquency at one point with the individual loans. Now it's about 1 percent.''
In addition to help from their lending groups, borrowers at Micro Enterprise receive training in budgeting, finance and marketing. Of 100 people who sought loans last year, Mr. Stevens said, only five completed the three-month series of courses. Those who do not complete the courses cannot receive loans.
''We think that even very small people should have access to capital,'' said Mr. Stevens, whose tiny company has three other partners. ''If they're willing to put in the effort, that's the equity - their willingness to come in and learn and commit their time and emotional energy.''
 
Loans vs. Welfare
Some critics, however, say group lending programs alone will not provide enough help for the poor.
''Are we creating working poor who are going to be self-employed and not be much better off than they were on welfare?'' asked Coralee Smith Kern, the editor of Cottage Connection, a newsletter for small-business owners.
The critics note that welfare at least provides medical care.
Alex Counts, who spent a year studying with Muhammad Yunus, founder of the Grameen Bank, agrees that medical care is important. ''But,'' he said, ''I think you need to ask the question: Does it make no difference if someone is working in a fledgling business just above poverty but still has the dignity of owning one's own business?''

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
Hopes Fade as Output Of Oil Lags in China

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HONG KONG

 BODY:

 
'Severest Financial Crisis'
''All of the energy industry, including oil, is facing the severest financial crisis in the history of Communist China,'' said David G. Fridley, a research associate who covers China's energy industry at the East-West Center in Honolulu. Mr. Fridley estimates that every Chinese oilfield is running a financial deficit and in 1989 those losses totaled 3.9 billion yuan, or $830 million, a 3,000-fold increase since 1986.
Part of the industry's poor showing has to do with China's domestic oil prices, which have been so low that there is hardly any money to pay for oil development. Mr. Fridley said that adjusted real prices had dropped to about $2.05 a barrel, from a base price in 1980 of $9.14.
When China opened its economy to Western companies nearly a dozen years ago it was hoping foreigners would help tap its supposedly huge oil reserves. American oil companies were among the first commercial adventurers in China, and not only did they come with enthusiasm but also with patience, a willingness to take risks and deep pocketbooks. #33 Contracts Signed According to the United States-China Business Council, American oil companies have so far signed 33 contracts worth $1.09 billion, or about a quarter of all American contractual investments in China. 
While eager for such funds, Chinese leaders were also caught in a battle between pride and practicality. Many realized that exploration and development could best be done with foreign help, but they also thought that as a matter of national honor the foreign role should be tightly circumscribed. The result was that while foreign companies were allowed to offer technical services, they were confined mainly to offshore sites, where exploration is expensive, if they wanted to drill themselves.
The Government had high hopes for offshore drilling, but there now appears little likelihood of meeting its goals, which called for increasing oil production fivefold from 1990 to 1992, to 36.5 million barrels. The Government also opened parts of southern mainland China to foreign exploration, but Western oil companies have expressed little interest in those areas.
''Foreign euphoria for China's offshore potential has evaporated somewhat because there has been no significant find,'' said a Western oil executive who spoke on the condition that he not be identified. ''China is not in the same league as Saudi Arabia, Iraq or Iran.''
 
Opening of Areas Awaited
Most oil companies are waiting for China to open new areas, particularly in the western hinterlands of Xinjiang Province. Geological formations in the Tarim Basin, a huge desert where the temperature rises above 120 degrees, suggest oil reserves that could be in the billions of barrels. The Chinese are already extracting oil from the Karamay fields in Xinjiang, and they recently completed drilling 24 exploratory wells in a promising area of the Tarim Basin, according to the official China Petroleum News.
So far, despite the financial pressures, Chinese leaders have not welcomed foreign risk capital to Xinjiang. For a small number of companies, the waiting has been ameliorated by modest discoveries of oil.
For instance, the Amoco Corporation is negotiating a production contract for a fairly sizable oilfield it discovered in 1987, and although it will have to descend 1,000 feet to extract the oil, the company is enthusiastic enough to have signed another contract last month to explore another site.
 
New Consortium Formed
And this month, Chevron and Texaco will start production under a consortium they have formed with an Italian concern, AGIP, and a Chinese partner. In a few months, they expect to be filling 20,000 barrels a day, which is expected to grow to 60,000 by 1992. By comparison, China's largest oilfield, at Daqing, produces more than a million barrels a day.
''For us, it's not significant, but for the Chinese it is,'' said Edward C. Chow, manager of Chevron's Beijing office. The new production will be the first major well operated by a foreign consortium in the South China Sea.
''That's the game we play,'' he added. ''But in order for the Chinese to retain the interest of the international petroleum industry, they need to open up more areas for foreigners.''
Some companies have successfully pursued other directions in the energy business. ARCO and its partners have discovered significant natural gas reserves near Hainan Island in the south, and the Royal Dutch/Shell Group is evaluating the feasibility of building a large refinery in southern China.
 
Overtures Generally Resisted
But the Chinese have generally resisted overtures from foreigners to help extend the life of the country's existing oilfields, notably at Daqing. The virtue of self-reliance is often still referred to as the ''spirit of Daqing,'' from a campaign in the 1960's when the Chinese insisted upon devloping the large oilfield on their own.
The result is that China's oil production has leveled off. After nearly a decade of steady incremental increases, Chinese officials say oil production this year is expected to remain flat, at about 2.8 million barrels a day.
''The mature fields are basically showing a mature phase,'' said a Western oil specialist who insisted upon anonymity. ''It's a plateau situation that may last for a while.''
 
Heavy Reliance on Coal
China relies heavily on coal, and oil represents only about 18 percent of its energy consumption, according to statistics of the British Petroleum Company. Moreover, China is still a net exporter of crude oil and for the most part is likely to be insulated from an oil crisis stemming from events in the Middle East, Chinese oil executives said.
But as China's economy expands and as it raises its capacity to refine oil, China's imports of crude oil will rise. Many industry specialists believe that if such a trend is allowed to continue, China could become a net importer by the mid- to late-1990's.
''Financial and economic pressure is what's going to lead them to say, 'O.K., guys, come in and help us develop the Western oilfields,' '' said Mr. Fridley of the East-West Center.
 
Exports Down 5.9 Percent
The statistics are already sending out a warning. Exports of crude oil for the first half of this year dropped by 5.9 percent from the comparable period last year, to 418,000 barrels a day, while imports from overseas to non-producing areas rose 140 percent, to 77,000 barrels a day, according to Chinese statistics.
''We all see China importing oil in the latter 1990's because there will be a lack of oil,'' said Donald Clift, manager of the Beijing office of British Petroleum, which has invested more than $150 million in oil exploration in China.
''Even if you started right now, there isn't time enough to get everything going by the mid-1990's,'' he added. ''The dilemma China will find itself in is that if its economy is going to continue to grow, even at a modest rate, there needs to be an increasing amount of imports. The question is: Can it afford oil imports? Can it not afford them?''

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
Polish Arms Makers Adjust to Peace

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOLECHOWO, Poland

 BODY:
The economic forces that pushed Pressta into new lines of business are buffeting the world's arms industry, particularly companies in Eastern Europe that earned hundreds of millions of dollars in the 1980's selling to the countries of the Warsaw Pact and to combatants of various political stripes. Polish officials now disclose that their customers even included members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
Those markets have largely collapsed. Despite the military moves in the Persian Gulf, the number of nations that are buying weapons has dropped significantly. In addition, the reshaping of the superpowers' military strategy in Europe - from an offensive to a defensive posture - has created surpluses of weapons both in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. 
 
Tough Times for Arms Sales
''Forget about what is happening now with Iraq,'' said Samuel Cummings, the president of Interarms, a company that arranges weapons deals from offices in Britain and Alexandria, Va.. ''It is a terrible time for the arms business, East and West.'' For instance, Mr. Cummings estimates that Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union have 40,000 surplus tanks.
The public stances taken by the countries on this issue reflect their differing viewpoints. In Czechoslovakia, for example, the Government of President Vaclav Havel says its decision to withdraw from the arms business was a matter of morality. But here in Poland, officials see it as a straightforward example of the sort of market economics they are trying to foster.
Figures for tank production in Poland illustrate how much the world's geopolitics has shifted. The Bumar-Labedy factory, which makes all of Poland's tanks, has trimmed its output from 250 annually in 1986 to 100 this year; only 30 are expected to be produced in 1991.
Separately, officials at the Ministry of Trade disclosed that it was now unclear whether Poland would ever manufacture large quantities of a jet fighter-trainer, the I-22, which had been intended to raise hard currency through sales to third world nations.
 
Exports Decline
The latest Government estimates predict that Poland will realize only 55 to 57 percent of a projected $2 billion in military sales to the West for the years 1986 to 1990. Exports to the Soviet Union and Eastern European neighbors will be off 25 percent for the same period, the Government said.
Ryszard Jankowski, the director of the Bumar-Labedy tank factory in the southern region of Silesia, said his company was struggling to remake itself. Bumar has produced civilian products like heavy construction cranes for years, but the bulk of its profits came from the sale of tanks.
Mr. Jankowski estimated that tank purchases by the Polish Army had shrunk to one-fourth the levels of 1986. A Polish official disclosed that the factory had dozens of unsold T-72 tanks, and he said the problem had persisted even after the asking price was sliced to less than $1 million, from $1.3 million.
''Our exports have radically decreased,'' Mr. Jankowski said. ''This year, it's mostly the production of spare parts and a few sub-systems. There is much lower demand among the post-Socialist countries.''
He added, ''The Germans, for example, won't be buying anything; soon they'll have Leopards,'' a reference to the West German battle tank.
Mr. Jankowski said his company now uses a glossy English-language brochure to promote sales of the T-72 tank. Earlier versions were written only in Russian. He declined to identify any of the countries to which he is marketing the tanks, but told a visiting reporter: ''If you can find a good customer, we can discuss the commission.''
 
Salaries of $100 a Month
The 9,500 workers at Bumar-Labedy are feeling the pinch. Just a few years ago, they were among the highest paid in Poland. Now, they earn the national average, a little more than $100 a month. Mr. Jankowski said 1,000 jobs had been eliminated through attrition, but he added he hoped to forestall further layoffs by generating new civilian business.
Mr. Jankowski said the company wanted to expand civilian lines, like the production of construction cranes, as well as develop new ideas, such as a cooperative venture with the Soviet truck maker Kamaz or the possible manufacture of a West German-designed tractor under license.
In its best years, Mr. Jankowski said, the factory earned tens of millions of dollars. Until now, he insisted, it has received no Government subsidies. Mr. Jankowski said the tank production lines would be kept open, even at a loss, because Poland must retain the ability to make its own weapons.
The conflict in the Middle East offers no respite for the Polish arms industry. Poland's Parliament recently passed laws barring military sales to any nation involved in a war or terrorism. Even before the United Nations voted to impose an economic embargo of Baghdad, Iraq had been added to the list of countries.
 
Iraq Had Been a Customer
Iraq had been a leading customer for Poland, buying hundreds of millions of dollars in arms. Many of Baghdad's most sophisticated Soviet-designed tanks, the T-72's, were made in Poland.
Stanislaw Amanowicz, a senior official in the Ministry for Foreign Economic Relations, said 30 to 50 percent of the country's annual earnings from the arms trade had come from Baghdad, which had paid for $500 million in past purchases with oil deliveries. Those shipments have been halted by the United Nations sanctions.
Under the Communist Government, Poland pursued what could be called an eclectic policy that seemed more motivated by profits than ideology. A Polish official disclosed in a recent interview that Polish-made tanks were secretly sent to both Iran and Iraq during their eight-year war.
Jan Majewski, the Deputy Foreign Minister, said none were sent directly to Teheran, but added that ''I wouldn't exclude such a possibility'' of their having been transferred from other countries to Iran.
It was disclosed during the Iran-contra investigations that Poland secretly sold weapons to the Nicaraguan rebels, backed by the United States, that were fighting to overthrow the Sandinista Government.
Mr. Majewski said he was startled recently by a list of countries to which Polish manufacturers sold military equipment in 1989, the last year of Communist rule. It included Western countries like Britain, Finland, Austria and Belgium, he said.

HEADLINE: Congress Returning to Its Tasks With No Sign of Budget Accord

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3

 BODY:
Hundreds of thousands of furlough notices have been sent to employees of Federal agencies planning for automatic cuts if Congress does not meet its mandated deficit targets, and many members predict that Congress will have to return for its first post-election session since 1982.
In The Times/CBS News Poll, only 31 percent of the 1,422 adults interviewed by telephone from Aug. 16 to 19 said there was a serious effort to reduce the deficit; 59 percent said there was not, an increase of five percentage points from the previous survey in May.
 
Blame for Lack of Progress
Aside from the 35 percent who blamed Congressional leadership for the lack of progress, 7 percent blamed the President and 14 percent blamed both the leadership and the President.
The survey also found that 44 percent did not approve of the way Congress handled its job, and significant numbers said they believed that many lawmakers were financially corrupt. The poll has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points. 
Representative Thomas S. Foley of Washington, the House Speaker, and Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Democratic leader, said the finger-pointing at Congress was taking place because Presidents, by the nature of their office, are better able to rally public support, especially at times of international crisis.
But in interviews over the weekend, both leaders insisted that the turmoil over the gulf and the economy would complicate, but should not cripple, the budget negotiations.
Cuts in military spending for the fiscal year 1991 may not be as deep as planned, they said, because of the Middle East mobilization. Even so, with the reduced tensions among superpowers, there was still plenty of room to trim the military budget over the next five years, they said.
''The Middle East is a new and central reality, and it will affect the budget talks to some degree,'' Mr. Foley said. ''But it would be a mistake for us to abandon all efforts to deal with the deficit now.''
 
'Heightened Sense of Urgency'
Mr. Mitchell said the Middle East hostilities had created ''a heightened sense of urgency'' about the budget. But he added, ''I don't want to minimize the difficulties.''
Senator Jim Sasser, a Tennessee Democrat who is chairman of the Budget Committee, said the Middle East crisis ''certainly gives the opponents of any reduction in defense spending a psychological leg up.''
The Democratic leaders are already seeking to pre-empt such moves.
''It's obvious that the Administration will use the crisis to minimize any reduction in defense spending,'' Mr. Mitchell said. While some additional spending will be required, he said the Middle East hostilities ''confirm the view that the Administration is placing too much emphasis on strategic and nuclear weapons.''
Still, Democrats and Republicans have remained solidly behind Mr. Bush's gulf initiatives, and the public backs that position. So much so, in fact, that 43 percent said in the Times/CBS News Poll that they would pay higher taxes to help protect Saudi Arabia and resist Iraqi aggression.
 
Hearings on Gulf Crisis
The House returns from its recess on Wednesday and the Senate comes back on Sept. 10. But hearings on the gulf begin this week, with testimony from Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, and budget talks are to resume Friday at Andrews Air Force Base south of Washington and are scheduled to run through the weekend.
Mr. Bush has the authority to protect the gulf operations from automatic budget cuts that are set to occur Oct. 15 under the budget-balancing law, according to Administration and Congressional budget officials.
But Congressional and Administration officials said a budget agreement was critical. ''Federal employees are now starting to show up and say, 'What about these furlough notices?' '' Mr. Sasser said. ''They're very concerned.''
''I see us going back right after the election,'' said Representative John P. Murtha, a Pennsylvania Democrat and chairman of the Defense Appropriations Subcommittee, of the prospect of a lame duck session. ''We'll work right up to Christmas trying to get this whole thing resolved.''
A post-election session would also allow the Senate to join the House in doing what most of its members were afraid to do, especially before Election Day: vote itself a pay rise.
The Times/CBS News Poll found that 70 percent said they would be less likely to vote for their member of Congress if he or she voted for a raise. Forty-two percent said they would be less likely to vote for a member who received contributions from a savings-and-loan institution, and 46 percent said they would be less likely to vote for a member who opposed capital punishment.
 
Issues Before the Senate
The Senate has the added business of a possible confirmation battle over Judge David H. Souter, the Supreme Court nominee, in hearings that are scheduled to begin Sept. 14, and ethics committee investigations of six senators accused of improperly using their offices to help political or financial supporters.
Most people have not yet formed an opinion of Judge Souter, the Times/ CBS survey says. The majority, 70 percent, said they had not heard enough about Judge Souter to have an opinion; 12 percent had a favorable view; 5 percent unfavorable, and 13 percent were undecided.
The survey, conducted several weeks after the reprimands of Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachussetts, and Senator Dave Durenberger, Republican of Minnesota, on charges of ethical misconduct, found a rising concern about lawmakers' ethical behavior.
Forty-six percent said that in the last 10 years, the standards of ethics in government had got worse; 33 percent gave that response in a January 1989 survey. In addition, more than 40 percent say they believed that at least half the members of the House and Senate were financially corrupt. Seventeen percent said most members are financially corrupt, 25 percent said about half, 40 percent said some and 10 percent said hardly any.
Although most people have a higher regard for their own lawmakers than they do of Congress at large, 16 percent said they believed that their own representative in the House is financially corrupt, while 62 percent said not corrupt. Nineteen percent said at least one senator from their own state was corrupt, while 62 said that was not the case.
 
Discontent Over Congress
The survey also showed continuing public discontent over the general performance of Congress. Forty-four percent of those surveyed said they did not approve of the way Congress handled its job, while 40 percent did approve. Sixty percent approved of the way their own representative handled his or her job and 21 percent did not approve.
But 40 percent said a new person should get a chance to represent their district in Congress, and 43 percent said their representative deserved to be re-elected.
Before the election, however, Congress will somehow have to do its business under the cloud of turmoil in the Middle East, an unstable economy and uncertain relations with the White House.
''This Congress has reached the point where it could in September accomplish enough that it would be a reasonably average Congress in terms of outputs of legislation and dealing with major problems,'' said Norman Ornstein, resident scholar at the American Enterprise Institute. ''Or it could be the least productive in modern memory.''
 
How the Survey Was Conducted
The New York Times/CBS News Poll was based on telephone interviews conducted from Aug. 16 to Aug.19 with 1,422 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the country. The exchanges were chosen so as to assure that each region of the country was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. The numbers were then screened to limit calls to residences.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of residential telephone lines and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to region, race, sex, age and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20, the re-sults based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
The percentages reported are the particular results most likely to match what would be obtained by seeking out all adult Americans. Other possible percent=ages are progressively less likely the more they differ from the reported results.
The potential sampling error for smaller subgroups is larger. For example, for either Democrats or Republicans or independents it is plus or minus five percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: September 4, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 5; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1626 words

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
Evacuation of Hostages Is Stalled As Iraqis Prohibit Foreign Flights

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 3

 BODY:
The weekend flights proceeded after President Saddam Hussein announced last week that foreign women and children were free to leave. Thousands of Western men remain in Iraq and Kuwait - detained as hostages, in hiding, or keeping a low profile - as Iraq's confrontation with Western and other nations continues over its Aug. 2 seizure of Kuwait, With security and living conditions reportedly worsening in Kuwait, Western and Asian diplomats were pressing today for the evacuation of several thousand foreign women and children still unable to leave the Iraqi-occupied country.
Besides having to negotiate transportation for American, European and Japanese women and children, the diplomats face the daunting task of locating people who are in hiding in a ghostly city, sliced into sub-sectors by military checkpoints, and patrolled by squads of soldiers.
Western diplomats and people arriving in Baghdad in the last few days from Kuwait after a 14-hour bus ride through the desert have reported that soldiers are searching house to house for weapons and foreigners.
''At first it was sort of detention by convenience,'' one diplomat said. ''If it was easy to round them up, they did it. Many were rounded up on the streets or at oil sites. Now it seems to be more systematic.'' 
Twenty-two Westerners, including eight Americans, arrived today in Amman, Jordan, on a regularly scheduled flight from Iraq, and 120 Bulgarians were able to leave by road.
''I'm happy to be out,'' Norma Moon, a Briton, told Reuters in Amman. ''Life is normal in Baghdad, but everybody is a bit tense because no one knows what will happen next. It all depends on the Americans.''
Explaining Iraq's refusal to let foreign flights land here, Naji al-Hadithi, the director general of the Iraqi Information Ministry, said the Government had decided not to allow any foreign aircraft to fly into Iraq, but it was prepared to charter planes for that purpose from Iraqi Airways.
Some diplomats said they believed that the move was an attempt by Iraq to weaken, at least symbolically, United Nations sanctions by forcing other nations to temporarily restore landing rights to Iraqi Airways planes.
''We are not interested in having an Iraqi Airways flight to our capital,'' a European envoy said. ''We don't want to pay that price.''
''There is nothing political about this,'' Mr. Hadithi said, ''It is just a commercial thing.''
Because of the sanctions, he said, ''we have planes we have grounded here, and we are facing competition from other airlines.''
''So,'' he said, ''these people can go on Iraqi Airways.'' If the women and children prefer to take buses through the desert to Jordan, Mr. Hadithi said, that was also possible.
 
Envoys Working Tirelessly
Diplomats from the United tates, Europe and Japan have created two task forces that have been working nearly around the clock to take advantage of President Hussein's pledge of freedom for women and children.
Iraqi officials are requiring the women to obtain exit visas in a process that takes up to 36 hours.
On Saturday night, as more than 300 women and children were checking in for a chartered Lufthansa flight, the Government announced that the flight had been canceled. Diplomats protested, and within 40 minutes the flight had been restored.
In meetings tonight, the diplomats discussed chartering planes to fly the women and children directly out of Kuwait or alternatively from Kuwait to Baghdad and then on to Amman, Jordan, for connections to the United States, Europe and Asia. Another proposal being given serious consideration is running a convoy of buses from Kuwait to Baghdad, though some diplomats feel that it would be inhumane to cause women and children to endure the long desert trek.
The road convoys, however, may be arranged faster than flights. ''It may be a question of how desperate we are to move these people,'' one envoy said.
If the choice is to fly out the foreigners, it now appears that they could travel first to Amman, the only capital that is still receiving Iraqi flights while King Hussein's Government ponders whether to fully carry out the trade sanctions.
Two Iraqi flights carried women and children on Saturday night and Sunday morning to Europe and the United States, and in exchange they were allowed to head back to Baghdad today with Iraqi citizens who had been stranded because the embargo stopped Iraqi flights and other airlines would not accept Iraqi Airways tickets. Iraq hoped that it might get more of its people home this way.
Diplomats estimate there are as many as 11,000 foreigners hiding in Kuwait, perhaps as many as 3,000 of them women and children.
 
Food Better Than Sanitation
Diplomats say they believe those in hiding have adequate supplies of food, at least for now. But they said sanitation was deteriorating. Many shops are closed, making it hard to buy such things as soap and toilet paper, and many of the foreigners have now been cooped up in apartments and houses, afraid to step out onto the streets, for a month.
''The city is dying,'' one envoy said. ''Food is not the problem. It's living conditions in general.''
The diplomats said that with the departures Saturday and Sunday of the 700 Western women and children, and a few men who were reportedly in ill health, most of the foreigners that Iraq is willing to release have left.
One of their gravest concerns in evacuating the women and children from Kuwait is that they will expose husbands and fathers to capture.
''We don't want the men being scooped up,'' an envoy said.
Iraq has threatened to hang anyone found sheltering foreigners, and Kuwaiti guerrillas, trying to drive out the Iraqi Army, have been spreading the word that they will shoot anyone who turns over a foreigner to Baghdad's forces.
Diplomats say that heavy firefights with small arms and automatic weapons are being reported almost every night.
Until a little more than a week ago, the embassies in Kuwait were occupied almost fully with the task of keeping in touch with the nationals in hiding, offering encouragement and in some cases, sanctuary. Some embassies divided their citizens into small groups of 8 to 12 and designated leaders whom the others would use as their liaison with the embassy. The groups telephoned each other when soldiers approached.
The Americans and other Westerners learned an important and surprising thing about the Iraqi soldiers: they would knock on doors, but not kick them in. ''If you didn't answer the door,'' a European woman from Kuwait said the other day, ''they would just go away.''
Iraq ordered the embassies closed, and to force out reluctant diplomats, shut off water and electricity and reduced telephone service.
 
Purifying Water
At the United States Embassy, Ambassador W. Nathaniel Howell, seven other diplomats and more than 20 other Americans told reporters on Saturday that they had begun breaking up and burning embassy tables and chairs to make fires to boil swimming pool water for drinking. They smoked a turkey and sun-dried fruit and vegetables to keep them from spoiling without refrigeration.
How long the diplomats can hold out is not clear, but when the American, British and other diplomats finally run out of food and supplies and have to leave the embassies, there will be another flashpoint in the crisis.
Mr. Hussein's Government says that since the diplomats ignored the order to vacate the embassies, they no longer have diplomatic status and will be taken into custody as if they were ordinary citizens of countries applying pressure on Iraq.
Many of the Americans and other foreigners in hiding have had frightening experiences.
Three American businessmen who had been in Kuwait only a few days before the invasion trapped them turned to a Lebanese businessman they had just met for shelter.
With soldiers all over the streets, the Lebanese man picked them up at their hotel in his car. But he soon ran out of gasoline. While the three Americans waited in the car at the side of the road with Iraqi tanks rumbling past, their friend went scavenging for gas.
After they had been in his apartment for a few days, Iraqi soldiers knocked on the door. The Lebanese man hurried his guests into a walk-in closet and went to greet the soldiers. He managed to steer them away but decided to move the Americans to the home of a friend.
Last Sunday, one of the Americans, an insulin-dependent diabetic, left Iraq through the intercession of the Rev. Jesse Jackson. The two other men are still hiding out. The Lebanese, in the meantime, had decided to abandon his apartment and business, and fled across the desert to Saudi Arabia.

PUB-DATE: September 4, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 10, Column 5; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 740 words

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
Gulf Price Tag for Egypt: $2 Billion Loss to Economy

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, Sept. 3

 BODY:
Egypt could get some short-term relief if the United States decides to go ahead with reported plans to cancel Cairo's $7.1 billion military debt. Payments due this year amount to about $660 million.
 
Bush Favorably Inclined
''My gut instinct is to do that,'' President Bush said at a news conference Saturday when asked about reports that he would ask Congress to forgive Egypt's military debt as a gesture of appreciation for its work in rallying Arab support for the American military effort against Iraq. On Friday, the United States made a $163 million cash grant to Egypt to help with its latest payment. 
If Egypt were not able to keep up the payments on the military-aid debt, provisions of American law would force the cutoff of the $2.3 billion a year in foreign aid it gives Egypt, its most important ally in the Arab world. This is the largest single foreign aid payment except for Israel.
Senator Claiborne Pell, Democrat of Rhode Island, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, indicated here today that Congress might look favorably on any Administration request to forgive the military debt.
''I believe given the leadership of Mubarak, we should cooperate with his needs,'' said Mr. Pell, who is part of a delegation of 36 Senators and Representatives who visited Saudi Arabia and met with the Egyptian President in his summer headquarters at the Ras el-Tien Palace in Alexandria.
On Sunday, Prime Minister Atef Sedki welcomed the White House plan to forgive military debts, but warned that the country's 55 million people, the vast majority of them poor, would inevitably have to carry added burdens. Egypt already has an unmanageable foreign debt of $50 billion, the subject of protracted wrangling with the International Monetary Fund. Even before the gulf crisis, Egypt had barely enough foreign exchange for needed wheat purchases.
 
Effect on Canal Revenue
In talks with the visiting Japanese Foreign Minister last week, President Hosni Mubarak spoke of a loss at least $2 billion in the next year. The Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, Butros Ghali, used the same number in an interview Sunday with Le Journal de Dimanche, an Egyptian newspaper.
Mr. Ghali said that reduced Suez Canal revenue, caused by a drop in shipping as a result of the United Nations embargo on trade with Iraq, could cost Egypt $400 million.
Canal shipping revenue could also be affected by a recent increase in rates announced by Lloyd's Insurance for oil tankers heading toward gulf states. In 1988, the latest year for which figures are available, the Suez Canal brought Egypt $1.3 billion.
In addition, a drop in tourism caused by fears of unrest in the region, could mean a $500 million drop in revenue in the next year.
 
Family Support System Undercut
The most significant blow, both in numbers and in its human impact, is the loss of wages by the more than a million Egyptian workers - some educated, many of them menial laborers - who were working in Iraq and Kuwait. The immediate loss was estimated by Egyptian officials at $1.1 billion a year.
And the effect is greater than the raw numbers. Each expatriate worker supported six or more relatives at home and was a repository of hopes for the future, building a modest stake of money and goods.
And in the street economies critical to the Middle East, there is a further effect. In Egypt, a quasi-official market in which hundreds of millions of dollars a year are exchanged outside the formal banking system is fed by the remittances of the expatriate workers. This market is critical to Egyptian businessmen seeking to purchase badly needed imports, who go outside the official banking system to get a more advantageous currency exchange rate.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: September 4, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 10, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 729 words

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
Lawmakers Touring Persian Gulf Stressing Sanctions Over Combat

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3

 BODY:

 
'Indefinite Time Frame'
Senator William S. Cohen, Republican of Maine, said that from what the legislators had seen, ''we're doing precisely the right strategy.''
''But the American people must be prepared for an indefinite time frame,'' Mr. Cohen added.
Other recent visitors to Saudi Arabia have made the same point, including Senator Sam Nunn, the chairman of the Armed Services Committee. 
The military's immediate mission ''is to deter aggression and defend if aggression takes place against Saudi Arabia,'' Mr. Nunn said Sunday on the NBC news program ''Meet the Press.''
''I keep reading articles where they are about to acquire the capability of having a massive ground attack,'' Mr. Nunn said. ''That's simply not what the military has been given in terms of instructions.''
''We've just had the embargo engaged for about 10 days or two weeks,'' he said, ''and the question of whether the embargo is going to work or not will depend a whole lot on whether we can mitigate the downside effects on a lot of countries in the world.''
In telephone interviews on Sunday from Jidda, the Saudi port where the legislators, traveling in two groups, met with members of the Kuwaiti government in exile, there was a familiar response: back up the economic sanctions with greater military involvement from other countries.
''The success of this rests on the continued ability to make this a world-against-Saddam Hussein situation,'' said Representative Richard A. Gephardt, Democrat of Missouri, the House majority leader,who headed a 22-member delegation to Saudi Arabia and other gulf countries.
 
Experts on the Run
The lawmakers gleaned their impressions from a whirlwind tour. The 14-member Senate delegation, for example, was briefed on Saturday by the American field commander, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, before flying by helicopter to the desert encampments of the Army's 101st Airborne Division and the Seventh Marine Brigade.
Then, after meeting the Emir of Bahrain on Sunday, the Senators were whisked to the battleship Wisconsin in the Persian Gulf and rushed back for a two-hour meeting with King Fahd in Riyadh, followed by the Kuwaitis.
The House members, who flew back to Washington after the meeting with Mr. Mubarak, announced upon arriving that much higher manpower levels were needed in the gulf.
Mr. Gephardt and the House Republican leader, Robert H. Michel of Illinois, called upon other nations, ''particularly our NATO allies,'' to make ''more significant contributions through the dispatch of additional troops.''
They also strongly endorsed higher levels of military spending in light of the buildup. ''We pledge to do our part in providing necessary funds,'' they said in a joint statement.
While the explicit goals of the United States and its Arab allies are to use the blockade to force President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait, several lawmakers said an equally strong undercurrent of opinion suggests that war may be inevitable.
From discussions they had with officials ranging from American generals to members of the Saudi ruling family, ''the two unspoken sentences at the end of every paragraph seemed to say that only force will move Saddam Hussein,'' said Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York.

SECTION: Section A; Page 16, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 524 words

HEADLINE: Another Wake-Up Call: Save Energy

 BODY:
Mr. Bush's attitude may mirror the public's own complacency. But that doesn't excuse it. The notion that the public should not in any way be inconvenienced by this crisis is naive and irresponsible. If Saddam Hussein is doing Americans any favor at all, it's to remind them that Washington desperately needs a coherent policy aimed at making the country more energy-efficient - beginning with higher energy taxes. 
The Bush Administration has merely been nibbling around the edges of such a policy. In an interview last week, Energy Secretary James Watkins confessed that the Administration was not yet ready to address tough questions such as whether the Government should press for higher auto mileage standards, nuclear power, energy taxes and new oil exploration in environmentally sensitive areas. He suggested instead that drivers put more air in their cars' tires - a handy tip, but hardly a strategy.
Congress also flounders. The Senate will shortly take up a bill that would mandate a 50 percent increase in fuel economy by the year 2001. Improving gas mileage would certainly help, and even Detroit concedes that modest gains are feasible. But the companies argue that as long as gas is cheap, consumers will demand bigger cars, and that to require Detroit (and Japan) to make only smaller cars would put them at war with their customers.
How cheap is gasoline in America? Very. Adjusted for inflation, fuel prices just before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait were the lowest they'd been in 40 years. The result is that when buyers are asked what they most want in a car, fuel economy, once near the top of the list, is near the bottom.
An energy tax adding, say, 25 to 50 cents to the price of a gallon of gasoline would provide therapy the country needs. The 1970's oil crises proved that higher prices promote energy efficiencies. The experience of other countries is also persuasive. Gasoline prices in most industrial nations are two to four times those in the U.S.; those nations' per capita fuel use is one-fourth to one-half what it is here.
Such a tax would have other desirable consequences. It would help reduce the Federal budget deficit. It would curb air pollution, including the greenhouse gases that threaten to warm the earth's atmosphere. And it would make alternative fuels more competitive.
Obviously, an energy tax can only be part of a more comprehensive strategy. But it's a good place to begin. Saddam Hussein has made the case for it. When will Mr. Bush?

HEADLINE: Immigrants Look Outside New York for Better Life

BYLINE: By KAREN De WITT

 BODY:
''There is fear,'' said Clarence Davis, whose said his business, Clarence Davis Realty in the East Flatbush area of Brooklyn, has increased 60 percent in the last three years as a result of the migration. ''I'm talking within the community. There are a certain number of youngsters who make their living selling drugs. They frighten the hard-working people. They don't want to be with that element. That is the reason many people decide to migrate.''
 
Continuation of Trend
Through much of Brooklyn, where many of the city's 900,000 to one million people of Caribbean descent live, real-estate agents specialize in relocation. In eight blocks on Church Avenue in East Flatbush there are six such companies. Mr. Davis said his business was booming. 
Dr. Joseph Salvo, deputy director of the Department of City Planning, said that from 1975 to 1980, the last period for which figures are available, 27,000 people of Caribbean descent left New York City and 60,000 moved from the Caribbean to the city.
Of those who left, the vast majority went to California, Florida and Texas. Others moved upstate and to New Jersey and Connecticut. Given that pattern, Dr. Salvo said, he expected the trend to continue in the 90's.
Caribbean groups, in which demographers include people from Barbados, Haiti, Jamaica, Martinique and Trinidad and Tobago, bolster that forecast.
Caribbean people say changes in United States immigration laws have made it easier for families of poorer people to enter the United States.
 
Crackdown in Jamaica
''Now you're getting the lowest of the low rural people,'' said F. Donnie Forde of Caribbean-American Media Studies Inc., a study organization in Brooklyn. ''They're the ones making trouble. They have no education and are trying to make it to the top by illegal means.''
An anthropologist at New York University, Constance Sutton, said of the new immigrants, ''They violate so many of the orientations of the West Indians, who don't want to get entrapped and pulled down by the illegal economy, by violence.''
In the mid-80's, the police in Jamaica cracked down on violent gangs in the slums of Kingston. Many gang members fled to the United States, where they formed new gangs. The gang members who moved to Brooklyn and Harlem altered the reputation of the Caribbean community, which had been known as hard working and law abiding, said some people of Caribbean descent.
When some officials use phrases like ''Jamaican posses,'' they stigmatize and stereotype a larger group, some people from the Caribbean contend.
Veronica Matthews, a nurse who immigrated to New York from Guyana with her husband, Walter, and four children five years ago, said many people did not know the difference between a Jamaican and a Guyanese accent.
''So we don't like people to say we're West Indian,'' she said. ''I tell people I'm a Guyanese, from South America.''
 
'Then There Are the Drugs'
''The community has changed,'' said Julietta Dyer, a nurse who immigrated from Trinidad and Tobago 23 years ago. ''It's much larger now, and some of the people - well, let's just say that once an elderly person could speak to you and correct you. That's not the case any more.''
Mrs. Dyer said the pace of city life was too fast and ''then there are the drugs.''
''I have a home here,'' she added. ''But my other children live in California and Chicago. And within the last four or five years there has been a lot of migration away from here.''
For many residents the migration represents a move from the streets and neighborhoods that Caribbean once proudly moved into.
''We used the term 'buy house,' which was really symbolic of establishing a toehold in this society,'' Paule Marshall said. ''That was my parents' generation. People that began coming here from 1900 to 1925. Their behavior is very much in keeping with other immigrant groups, seeking for a better life.''
 
To Move to Orlando
Until the changes in the immigration law in 1960's, Mr. Forde said, an immigrant from the Caribbean had to have $2,000 before immigrating to the United States. For Caribbean people, saving that amount indicated initiative and ambition, he added.
Mrs. Matthews and her family, confronted by a growing drug trade in their community, they have purchased land to build a house near Orlando, Fla., and plan to relocate in a year.
''I really don't have anything against New York,'' Mrs. Matthews said. ''You can really work and you can really make something of yourself. It's the drugs everywhere you turn. It's the drugs. Going and coming from work, you're afraid.
''My kids come here so innocent. They say, 'Mommy, I see this person selling this crack at school.' I say, 'Put your head straight and don't look.'
''I love this city. I love New York, all the different types of people here. But what is the sense of being here if you can't enjoy it? Now you look on TV everyday, and there is so much shooting, so much blood. I just can't get accustomed to this.''

SECTION: Section B; Page 7, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1599 words

HEADLINE: Growing Fiscal Problems Put Squeeze on Social Programs in Many States

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Sept. 3

 BODY:
''We probably have over 35 states who are in what I would say are degrees of fiscal difficulty, and I believe that human services, social programs, are clearly feeling the pinch in most of those states,'' said Gerald Miller, executive director of the National Association of State Budget Officers. ''There's no question the next couple of years will be much tougher, and the outlook is that those with the least ability to lobby the legislature will be hurt the most.''
Despite the political risks of raising taxes, legislators in the past year adopted $7.6 billion in tax increases, totaling 2.8 percent of state spending. It was the largest percentage increase since 1983.
Even with the new taxes, more than half the states surveyed by the Center for the Study of the States reported that revenue increases are equal to or lower than the inflation rate. The Albany-based center, established in May, is part of the Nelson A. Rockefeller Institure of Government, a research arm of the State University of New York. 
 
Less Revenue and Growing Costs
No organization analyzes the spending in all 50 states, but experts say most states face a common problem. Tax revenue rose at a smaller rate than anticipated, and the states faced growing, politically untouchable or federally mandated costs in programs like education, Medicaid and prisons, which make up the bulk of the budget. That left only a relatively small number of social services susceptible to cuts.
The states have tried to resolve the problem in various ways.
At one extreme was California, which led the nation in the tax revolt of the late 1970's and this year resorted to some of the nation's toughest cuts in education and social services.
Despite an overall budget increase of 12.8 percent, California was facing a $3.6 billion budget shortage this year, an increase of 200,000 new students, a 14 percent annual increase in its prison population and welfare rolls that are growing three times as fast as that in the general population.
 
Tax Increase and Budget Cuts
To remedy the shortage, the state approved $843 million in additional taxes and fees and $2.7 billion in cuts. The cuts included the elimination of $284 million in cost-of-living adjustments for welfare recipients, the aged, the blind and the disabled and $708 million in reduced funds for counties.
One agency affected is the San Fernando Valley Community Mental Health Center, which provides services to about 4,400 patients a year.
The director, Dr. Ian Hunter, said the cuts would force him to close a 23-bed residential program for homeless people who are mentally ill, an outpatient program for the homeless mentally ill, a 12-bed residential house for people in immediate crisis, the only Spanish-language outpatient program in the San Fernando Valley and several other programs.
''All of the patients we're seeing now are severely mentally ill,'' he said. ''We're seeing the hardest core, severely and chronically mentally ill, people who can't function without support. Without medication and therapy they're going to end up on the streets, in the courts, in emergency rooms, all the places that are much more expensive to maintain.''
 
Ashamed of His State
Dr. Hunter said the two other outpatient mental-health providers in the valley, which has about 2.5 million people, closed last year.
''This is the first time I've felt really ashamed to be associated with this state,'' he said.
Wholesale cuts in social programs were rare, however, and several states facing tight budgets had considerable success in avoiding program cuts.
In North Carolina, despite one of the most difficult budget years in memory, the Legislature avoided cuts and added to several social programs by stretching out some major construction programs and deferring efforts to make some major educational changes.
''We have enough problems in North Carolina right now without cutting back more on human services,'' said Bob Geolas, special assistant to Joe Mavretic, the Speaker of North Carolina's House of Representatives, who has been a longtime advocate of spending for social needs.
 
Competition Between Programs
Tight budgets have increased competition between different types of programs, experts say, and welfare programs are often the big losers.
A study by Ronald K. Snell, fiscal affairs director of the National Conference of State Legislatures, found that from 1976 to 1987 state spending for Medicaid sharply increased as a share of state personal income and was matched almost equally by a drop in spending on welfare programs, primarily Aid to Families With Dependent Children.
Last year state spending for Medicaid, half of which consists of nursing home care for the elderly, grew by 25 percent, according to the National Conference of State Legislatures. Spending for the dependent children program grew by 4.8 percent when applications for such aid were soaring in many states. Critics say the failure to keep pace with inflation is a quiet budget cut that continues to sap the recipients' purchasing power.
In Michigan, for example, from 1983 to 1987 Aid for Families With Dependent Children paid at about 60 percent of the poverty level. This year it pays at 56 percent of the poverty level. In Illinois, the average grant for such programs has lost from 45 to 50 percent of its buying power over the last decade.
 
Decline in Buying Power
Nationwide, from 1970 to 1990 the median state payment for the dependent children's program, adjusted for inflation, has fallen by almost 40 percent.
In many states tight budgets have affected services even though specific programs have not been cut. In South Florida, for example, lawyers for the poor have sued the state on the ground that personnel cuts are denying adequate service to food stamp recipients.
Legal Services of Greater Miami has been in litigation with the state since 1985 over this issue, and the state has twice approved consent decrees agreeing to provide services in an orderly, timely fashion.
According to Miriam Harmatz, staff attorney for Legal Services of Greater Miami, the system is so overloaded that people seeking food stamps face delays of up to two months in having their applications processed.
 
Priority on Unmet Needs
''Things improved slightly in 1988,'' she said, ''but since then over 150 positions in this district alone have been lost at a time when there's been an approximately 15 percent increase in the number of applicants.''
The current priority in many states involves efforts to address unmet needs that have developed in the last decade as Federal programs have withered away and problems like drug abuse and AIDS have added to the states' concerns.
In Mississippi, the state approved a landmark package of educational changes that include related social programs like dropout prevention, school nurses and literacy programs for parents to teach children. But the state failed to provide money for the program, and it is now in limbo.
In Georgia, officials scrambled to address the needs of abused and neglected children. The state says that reports of child abuse doubled from 1983 to 1988, to nearly 40,000 cases, but the number of caseworkers increased only to 502 from 369.
 
Program Freeze in Georgia
The Georgia Legislature passed a measure increasing the number of caseworkers to 667. But a worsening state budget picture led officials to freeze all new programs before the new workers were hired.
And last month Gov. Joe Frank Harris announced $332 million in budget cuts that will force the state's Department of Human Resources to cut an additional $29 million from its budget.
In Minnesota, legislators cut several health and mental health programs for children and rejected most proposals for new initiatives.
That sort of slow squeeze, along with continued tax increases, is what most states are likely to see over the coming years.
''I think we're going to see tax increases and program cuts, but I don't think the cuts will be draconian,'' said Mr. Miller of the state budget officers association. ''Instead, it will be more of a slow grinding down in programs so that they don't keep up with inflation or with additional demands.''

SECTION: Section C; Page 1, Column 4; Science Desk
