HEADLINE: Big Science; Is It Worth the Price?;
Small-Scale Science Feels the Pinch From Big Projects

SERIES: A periodic look at the impact of the largest new research projects.

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
Moreover, they warn, the financial pinch will probably worsen as pressures mount to trim the Federal deficit and as bills pile up for a new generation of big science projects costing more than $160 billion.
In dozens of interviews, experts in and out of Government said small-scale research was ''squeezed,'' ''in crisis'' and ''dying.'' And though traditionally wary of faulting the projects of peers, top science administrators as well as small-scale researchers are increasingly pointing to big instruments as villains.
''While attention and resources are being absorbed by visions of glory with projects costing billions, the infrastructure of science and technology in this country is on the brink of disaster,'' Dr. James A. Krumhansl, a Cornell University physicist, recently warned Congress.
In an editorial entitled ''The Funding Crisis,'' Dr. Daniel E. Koshland Jr., editor of the journal Science, recently said the health of small-scale research was jeopardized by financial neglect. 
''What the nation and the world really need,'' he wrote, ''is a major expansion of investigator-initiated science, because that historically has been the source of great discoveries that have opened new fields.'' In another editorial, Dr. Koshland called for across-the-board cuts of about $1 billion a year in big-science funds, saying the surplus could be used to ''bolster young investigators.''
Many big projects are in the initial stages of planning or construction, with payments now being made that will grow significantly in the course of the 1990's and beyond. Their construction costs are put at more than $60 billion and their operations at more than $100 billion. The projects, which include giant telescopes, atom smashers and planetary probes, aim at answering some of science's most esoteric and fundamental questions.
Experts say that without extraordinary measures to reverse budgetary trends, small projects will probably lose ground to their big brethren. The main reason is that modest endeavors have little or no glitter, and none of the political constituencies that protect big projects from budget pressures in the nation's capital.
Yet by nearly any measure - intellectual merit, economic payoff or sheer excitement among bright young investigators - small science is more important than its big cousin. Past successes include the transistor, the laser and antibiotics.
And small science continues to dazzle. Of 10 Nobel Prizes in Physics during the 1980's, one related to pure theory, three to big projects and six to small-scale endeavors. The ratio is even more pronounced with Nobel Prizes in Chemistry and Physiology or Medicine, virtually all of which flow from small research ventures.
 
Fears About the Future
Moreover, in terms of sheer numbers, small-scale research is the career of choice among the vast majority of American scientists, probably because it is more accessible and requires less investment by way of scientific instrumentation.
Even so, experts say the field is already squeezed financially, heightening fears about the future.
''It's a serious problem,'' said Erich Bloch, the outgoing director of the National Science Foundation, the Government's main agency for the support of basic science. ''There have been declines in certain areas. And for other ones the increases, in constant dollars, have not been sufficient to cover the increased cost of doing research. There is a squeeze being felt by a number of researchers.'' Dr. Richard S. Nicholson, executive director of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, the nation's oldest and largest general science society, said his group had started a project to investigate small-science woes, adding that the problem of poor financing had been exacerbated by a rising number of bureaucratic burdens.
''There's a really high level of discouragement and distress in the science community,'' he said. ''If you go around and talk to this country's top scientists, they're about to bag it.''
Dr. Robert L. Park, a physicist at the University of Maryland who directs the Washington office of the American Physical Society, said the economic repercussions of recent trends could be devastating.
''All the stuff at the heart of our economy is getting cut, while the things that are irrelevant, the space stations, are getting funded,'' he said. ''It's a crazy situation because the things that matter are so cheap. A half billion dollars would have us swimming in money.''
 
'A Crisis Situation'
This year for the first time, the Administration's proposed budget for the largest big science project of all - the $37 billion space station - exceeds that of the entire National Science Foundation. The 1991 request for the station is $2.5 billion and for the foundation $2.4 billion. Scheduled to be lofted piecemeal in the mid-to-late 1990's, the station is eventually expected to cost at least $120 billion, including its five-year construction period and operation over three decades.
Dr. Robert B. Hallock, a physicist at the University of Massachusetts at Amherst, recently helped form a group of low-temperature physicists to lobby in behalf of small science.
''We consider it a crisis situation,'' he said. ''I know many first-class researchers who have lost their money, and many people who have had level funding for five years at a time when inflation has doubled the cost of doing research.''
Most troubling, Dr. Hallock said, was that bright young scientists are leaving university careers because of tight funds.
''That's terrifying,'' he said. ''It means there are discoveries that won't be made and future generations of scientists that won't be trained. That has the potential to be a disaster for the nation.''
 
The Pressures
More Scientists, Rising Costs
The rise of extremely large projects is but one of several pressures on researchers conducting small-scale projects. Most fundamental is the sheer growth in the number of American scientists, which has fueled competition for scarce Federal dollars. Between 1978 and 1988, the most recent year available, the number of practicing scientists and engineers in the United States nearly doubled to 4.6 million.
On one level, that rise indicates health and vitality, but it has also caused consternation as grant applications have soared and the chances of getting a grant have fallen. This phenomenon haunts the National Science Foundation, the National Institutes of Health, the Air Force and the Veterans Administration, according to a recent study by the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment.
Another problem is that the cost of research is going up rapidly as demands rise for increased laboratory safety and environmental protection, as universities charge more for research overhead costs and as scientists seek the newest kinds of equipment, which is usually expensive. The result is that the scientific inflation rate far exceeds that of the civilian economy. Mr. Bloch of the National Science Foundation estimated that the cost of setting up a new investigator in physics or chemistry has roughly tripled in the last decade, to $300,000.
Finally, the Federal financing of small science has been lackluster at best, with many areas holding steady in the last decade or declining, the latter being especially true in recent years. The Federal budget for basic research rose modestly in the 1980's, going in constant 1990 dollars from $7.3 billion in 1980 to $10.7 billion in 1989, according to the National Science Foundation. But that rise included such things as growing military research as well as the Government's largest spate of big science projects ever. These efforts, dozens in all, included the $110 million Stanford Linear Collider at Stanford University, the $681 million Tokamak Fusion Test Reactor at Princeton University and the recently launched $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope.
In the same period, many areas of small science suffered. An example is condensed-matter physics, one of the hottest areas of science. Its studies of such esoteric phenomena as photon and electron transport have yielded advances in computer chips, tiny semiconductor lasers, the liquid crystals of computer displays, optic devices, composite materials of extraordinary strength and so on.
A large part of its Federal financing comes from civilian agencies that support materials science and engineering. Yet these funds dropped 22 percent from 1976 to 1987, going from $728 million to $562 million in constant 1982 dollars, according to a recent report by condensed-matter physicists at the American Physical Society. The report said funds had been essentially level or declining in several fields related to condensed-matter physics, even as these budgets have had to support a growing number of big facilities and machines.
''The crisis has become so severe that it threatens the viability of the field,'' the report concluded.
Another example is space science. During the 1980's, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration began a number of costly big-science probes and spacecraft, even as its financing of university scientists in many cases remained flat or declined. For instance, its budget for research and analysis in planetary exploration rose from $70 million in 1980 to $79 million in 1990 in constant 1990 dollars. But that increase suddenly disappeared when NASA officials cut the 1990 budget by more than $8 million for various reasons, including to pay cost overruns on spacecraft programs and to speed work on the $500 million Mars Observer spacecraft, which is to be launched in 1992.
''I'm hurting and other groups I know are hurting,'' said Dr. Robert M. Walker, director of the McDonnell Center for the Space Sciences at Washington University in St. Louis.
Even at Federal agencies that made sizable budgetary gains in the past decade, small science sometimes fared poorly. The basic research budget for the National Institutes of Health, the Government's main sponsor of biomedical research, rose more than 50 percent between 1980 and 1989, from $2.6 billion to $4.1 billion. Even so, the number of grants awarded for new research projects and continuing ones has recently dropped sharply, from 6,446 in 1987 to an estimated 4,633 in 1990.
''From our point of view this is really an emergency situation,'' Dr. Thomas Kelley, a virologist from Johns Hopkins University, told a recent meeting on biomedical finances held by the National Academy of Sciences, a private group that advises the Federal Government. Researchers blame the cutbacks on a rise in targeted funds for specific projects like AIDS, diabetes, cancer and the $3 billion project to map the complete human genetic structure.
The dilemma is similar at the National Science Foundation. Between 1980 and 1989 the foundation's basic research budget rose from $1.27 billion to $1.78 billion in constant 1990 dollars. But amid that increase, the foundation embarked on a series of new programs in addition to its more traditional financing of small science, including engineering research centers, big interdisciplinary projects and some large instruments.
The result is that the foundation's budgets for most small ventures in mathematics, physics, chemistry, engineering, biology and computer science have recently fallen, after inflation, below their 1988 levels, according to a study by the Association of American Universities. Over the decade the situation is not much better.
''The situation is growing increasingly desperate,'' said Dr. Daniel Kleppner, a physicist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who recently published a satire in Physics Today on the difficulty of getting Federal funds to pay for a $10,000 research laser.
Dr. Steven M. Younger, a physicist at the Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico, put it more bluntly, saying, ''The foundation of university science is dying.''
 
Lost Opportunities
Diamond Coatings, Backwater Settings
Behind the numbers is a drama of lost opportunities. One example is the emerging field of thin films of synthetic diamond, an advance that has opened a new era for electronics, optics, machine tools, chemical processing and military technology. The films radically improve the quality of the objects they coat, making tools and bearings last longer, lenses and windows resist scratches and loudspeakers give truer sound reproduction.
A panel of the National Research Council, a prestigious scientific group that advises the Federal Government, recently called diamond coatings ''one of the most important technological developments in the past decade'' and urged that research forge ahead to solve underlying problems that could frustrate its rapid development.
Despite such endorsements, the field is a Federal backwater, receiving about $5 million a year, according to Dr. Roy, who does such research at Penn State. ''The Federal money is simply not there,'' he said. ''We need to support a dozen universities at a critical level.'' More than 10 American companies are conducting serious research in the area, including General Electric, which recently announced it had created an advanced form of diamond with an enhanced ability to transmit heat and light.
In Japan, Dr. Roy said, the field is believed to receive about $150 million a year from government and industry. ''They're going gangbusters,'' he said. ''Already in 1984, Japan had 40 major efforts going. Today it's more like 100. It's a concerted effort.''
A surprising example of the pinch on small science comes from the emerging field of superconducting materials that work at high temperatures. These promise to revolutionize electric devices by making them far more efficient. Despite its intellectual allure, and a sizable amount of subsequent Federal financing, the endeavor has recently been hampered by budget reductions. Even Nobel laureates have felt the squeeze.
''Every worker in the field of the basic science of superconductivity in this country is experiencing repeated and severe funding cuts,'' Dr. Philip W. Anderson, a Nobel laureate in physics at Princeton University, told Congress earlier this year.
Another example involves a single researcher with a bright idea. It is electro-osmosis to clean hazardous waste sites. In theory, an electric current can cause contaminated fluids to flow into a holding reservoir, where they can be easily removed. Although lab tests are promising, and two Federal agencies have given grant applications on the work exceptionally high marks, no money has been forthcoming.
''I've got brilliant students working on it,'' said Dr. Ronald F. Probstein, Ford Professor of Engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. ''We've tried to get money for years. But we end up nowhere. It's sad. There's been a breakdown in the support of basic research.''
 
The Outlook
Battling Visions Of Grandeur
Experts say the budget crunch, barring a sudden reversal of Federal trends, will only get worse as the Government struggles to pay for the $160 billion in big science projects it plans for the 1990's and beyond.
''They have the potential to absolutely destroy the backbone of small science,'' said Dr. Paul G. Gassman, a chemist at the University of Minnesota and president of the American Chemical Society.
The problem starts when the Administration plans its request, said Dr. Park, who helps track the Federal budget for the American Physical Society. The bigger would-be projects, by virtue of influential investigators conjuring visions of grandeur, have usually been able to mount a lobbying campaign within agencies. ''There's no way for small science to do that,'' Dr. Park observed, noting that it is far more fragmented.
And even when the executive branch tries to do right by small science, as when the Reagan and Bush Administrations asked for large increases in the budget of the National Science Foundation, Congress often finds other needs more pressing, giving the foundation smaller rises than requested.
''The foundation is caught in the politics of scarcity,'' said John C. Crowley, an analyst at the Association of American Universities. ''The budget requests have been very good. If they had been funded, you would not be hearing squeals from the system.''
On Capitol Hill, the science foundation competes with big projects and other interests. For instance, the House appropriations subcommittee that oversees the foundation's budget also controls that for the Department of Housing and Urban Development, the Department of Veterans Affairs and NASA, which has the lion's share of the Government's big science projects. In Congress as elsewhere, big-project lobbies usually have good access to power brokers while their small rivals go relatively unrepresented.
''We're part of the bottom line,'' said Mr. Bloch of the science foundation. ''There's only so much money. It's very important to set priorities so we preserve the infrastructure first and look at the big projects secondarily.''
 
Fueling the engine of invention
Although advocates predict great things from an array of big projects, many scientists say that the most productive discoveries come from small teams working in relatively modest labs. Such teams produced Nobel-prize-winning work in X-ray crystallography, growth hormones and superconductivity. In fact, such 'small science' has won most of the Nobel Prizes awarded in recent years.
 
X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY
Beams of radiation, above, reveal the structure of complex molecules like strands of proteins. The molecules are crystallized and exposed to x-rays, allowing scientists to determine their structure. The technology has been crucial to the development of new drugs, pesticides and other useful chemicals.
 
GROWTH HORMONE
Fundamental new insights into cell growth and diversification followed the discovery of a chemical called nerve growth factor, below. It influences the maturation of embryonic nerve cells into the mature nervous system.
 
SUPERCONDUCTIVITY
High temperature superconductivity, right, in which electricity flows with no loss to resistence, could vastly raise efficiency in electronic devices and produce many other benefits. At right, the magnetic field produced by a block of superconducting material levitates a magnet.
 
 
The Series So Far
The series began on May 27 with an overview of several projects that supporters believe will herald a new age of discovery, but that critics fear will starve scarce Federal funds for smaller, more practical projects. An article on May 29 about the Superconducting Supercollider was followed on June 5 by a report on a project to decipher the entire human genetic code.. The space station Freedom was examined on June 10, and an article on June 19 discussed the Earth Observing System, which will study the global environment from space.

HEADLINE: Global Warming Research Is Backed

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3

 BODY:
Scientists say atmospheric buildups of carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide, chlorofluorocarbons and other gases - mostly from the burning of oil, coal and other fossil fuels - could cause a disastrous warming of the Earth's temperature.
The Bush Administration argues that there is still too much scientific uncertainty to warrant expensive steps, such as a proposed worldwide ceiling on carbon dioxide emissions.
The research council's Committee on Alternative Energy Research and Development Strategies, led by David L. Morrison of the IIT Research Institute in Chicago, was asked to consider what policy steps should be taken if the Government decides to take action on global warming. 
 
Statement by the Secretary
The panel said that funds in the Energy Department's current research budget should be shifted to earmark about $300 million a year for projects to improve energy efficiency and encouraging adoption of technology that would cut ''greenhouse'' gas emissions.
These steps ''would make sense for other reasons even in the absence of concerns about global climate change,'' the panel said.
To get the money, the scientists said the Energy Department could reduce spending on research into fusion power, fossil energy and other projects.
Energy Secretary James D. Watkins welcomed the report in a statement, but said the department's current research projects should not be cut.
''Although we agree with the priorities highlighted by this study, we believe that these priorities should not be met at the expense of other programs promising substantial, long-term environmental and energy security benefits,'' he said.
The committee did not make a precise cost estimate for what it called an insurance strategy for advanced research into renewable energy, conservation, nuclear energy and a range of other new ideas.
''These alternative technologies would be developed to the level necessary to understand their costs and impacts if concerns about greenhouse gas emissions and climate change heighten,'' it said.

HEADLINE: Alexander's Refocuses on Retailing

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
But management says that retailing may now make a comeback. The recent downturn in the real estate market in the Northeast has encouraged Alexander's to look for growth on its retailing end.
In addition, in mid-August Mr. Roth announced his interest in buying a controlling stake in Alexander's, which would end his tug-of-war with Mr. Trump, whose financial status has weakened in recent months. Such a move could give the board more latitude for adding stores to cater to growing number of shoppers in the lower to middle incomes that Mr. Farkas sees as an emerging market. 
The board has already moved to expand the retail group. In April, Alexander's opened its first new store in a decade, in the Bronx. And, Mr. Farkas says, it may be receptive to opening other stores.
Yet some retailing specialists say Alexander's, which has 12 stores in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, has passed its prime. ''Alexander's hasn't attracted a wide enough audience, either because of a lack of content or presentation or because of its ambience,'' said James Posner, a New York retailing consultant.
Still, Mr. Farkas, one of four sons of the store's founder, George Farkas, said the chain is in the enviable position of being ''the lone survivor of a group of middle-market retailers in the New York area.'' Gone are S. Klein, Korvettes, Mays, Lane's and Ohrbach's, chains which he said prospered until the 1970's by catering to the ethnic groups that were emerging then - ''the Italians, Jews and Irish.''
 
'Vibrant' Market Seen
Although many of those customers have since moved away from the area or have improved their incomes out of the middle market, he said, other groups of immigrants have replaced them, presenting an attractive opportunity for Alexander's. ''Our market is alive, well and vibrant,'' Mr. Farkas said. For the first time in recent years, the company may be able to take advantage of that position. The most promising development to top executives was a financial statement released in the middle of last month by Vornado Inc., a real estate concern owned by Mr. Roth's development company, Interstate Properties.
Vornado said it would buy an additional $15 million in Alexander's common stock, or as much as 25 percent. That would give a controlling interest to Vornado, whose current 27.8 percent stake makes it the chain's largest shareholder. Among other properties, Mr. Roth has several strip shopping centers in New Jersey.
 
Stock Price Has Fallen
Although Mr. Roth has declined to comment, his associates say the drop in Alexander's stock price gives him an opportunity to get a bargain. The stock closed on Friday at $30.625 a share on the New York Stock Exchange, only 12.5 cents above its low for the last year and far below its high of $57.375 earlier this year.
Mr. Roth may also be capitalizing on a weakened Mr. Trump. Mr. Trump, who also declined to comment about plans for his Alexander's stock, has been put on a short leash by bankers since his near-default last month on some bonds. Analysts say he is in no position to buy more Alexander's shares.
The investors were drawn separately to Alexander's by its real estate holdings, and in particular by the land value of its flagship store at 59th Street and Lexington Avenue in Manhattan. They hoped to develop the property into a multiuse high-rise building.
But they disagreed on how much retail space it should include. Mr. Roth reportedly wanted more retail space than Mr. Trump. They also argued over who would be entitled to make the critical decisions regarding their joint effort.
Retailing executives speculate that if Mr. Roth gains control, he would develop the store into a high-rise office and apartment complex with a retail component - not necessarily including an Alexander's store.
Mr. Trump and Mr. Roth have tried to capitalize on Alexander's assets. Most of its net profit last year of $21 million, on sales of $463 million, came from the sale of the sites of three of its stores.
The differences between the investors have caused Alexander's board to move cautiously in expanding the company's retail side. Alexander's reticent strategy has left it vulnerable to discounters and to the aggressive price cutting of such traditional retailers as Macy's, Abraham & Straus and Stern's.
Alexander's lost $2.46 million in its third fiscal quarter, which ended on May 5, compared with a loss of $3 million the year before. Its sales for the period rose by 7.1 percent, to $98.2 million. For the first nine months, it has lost $1.46 million, on net income of $19.1 million.
The value of Alexander's stock -and of Mr. Roth's and Mr. Trump's holdings - has also declined. Executives at the company agree that if it were not for the fallen stock price, both would have sold their shares because of their inability to follow through in developing the flagship store.
 
Investment Bank Hired
The investors even hired Morgan Stanley & Company a few months ago to explore ways to maximize value to shareholders. The investment bank has said that an option would be to sell the company. No bidders have emerged.
Alexander's family management, representing only about 4 percent of the stock after selling shares to Mr. Trump and Mr. Roth, has taken steps in the last 18 months to sharpen the company's retailing focus. It has stopped its costly promotional price- cutting on electronics because of the difficulty in competing with discounters and has instead concentrated on apparel - it has long imported lesser-known brands - home furnishings and ''more lucrative soft goods,'' Mr. Farkas said. It has also introduced automotive accessories.
The company also opened the Bronx store, taking over a site vacated by the defunct TSS-Seedman's retail chain. The store, Alexander's third in the Bronx, has had ''a very strong customer response,'' Mr. Farkas said, prompting the company to look for locations in downtown Brooklyn and in Jersey City. Mr. Farkas envisions opening a store every year.
 
The Lone Survivor
He thinks that Alexander's, as the sole survivor of the retail chains that catered to low- and middle-income shoppers, has captured the middle market.
''As the department store moved upscale, we find ourselves now only with small competitors, such as the Century 21 department store chain, and Conway's in Manhattan and Wertheimer's in Brooklyn,'' Mr. Farkas said. ''I think this is a very expandable business. We have a strong and loyal following.''
But one retailing consultant views the middle market differently. ''They were the original off-price merchant in the New York area, but now there are so many of them,'' said David J. Rachman, professor of marketing at Baruch College of the City University of New York.
''They were swept away by Marshalls, Filene's Basement stores and chains like Labels for Less,'' he added. ''Their real estate is much more valuable than their retailing potential.''

HEADLINE: Borrowing Is Resumed By Mexico

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Rather than the bank loans that were obtained in the 1970's and 1980's with few requirements attached, state-owned companies are floating bond issues today for projects like oil exploration, which should, in theory, generate enough revenue to repay the debt. They are the first bond issues floated by Mexican state enterprises in nearly a decade.
The biggest new borrower so far, Petroleos Mexicanos, or Pemex, is also the state's most profitable enterprise, a circumstance that should help to insure repayment of the bonds when they come due in seven or eight years. But in recent years, most of Pemex's operating earnings, more than $6 billion in 1989 alone, have been drained off by the Mexican Government, with its budget deficit. 
A similar pattern has befallen the telephone company and some other state enterprises. The Government's tendency to appropriate the earnings of state companies raises the possibility that it might, in some future cash shortage, absorb money earmarked to pay off the new bonds.
 
Danger Is Acknowledged
Mr. Ortiz and others acknowledge the danger, but they argue that the drain is not likely to continue. For one thing, they note, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari has cut Government spending sharply, reducing the need to drain money from state enterprises. The Government deficit, in fact, has dropped to 6 percent of gross domestic product - a measure of the value of all of the goods and services produced within the country - from 12 percent in 1988, according to Government data.
In addition, the telephone company and several other big state enterprises are being sold, and this privatization process means the Government can no longer latch on to their earnings easily. Finally, the prospectuses accompanying the new bond issues specify that the money is to be invested in income-producing projects and that the income is to be earmarked for debt repayment.
That, at least, is the case with Pemex, the biggest new borrower, says Francisco Rojas, the company's director general. The problem is that Pemex is not up for sale, leaving it vulnerable to future drafts on its income. And Pemex's old debt of $15 billion represents a big chunk of Mexico's $48.5 billion in bank debt.
 
A Reluctance to Borrow
Nevertheless, Pemex's reluctance to borrow more than it can safely repay is a big reason that the oil company is resisting pressure from the United States to increase oil production during the Middle East crisis, Mr. Rojas said in an interview.
Pemex will limit spending on exploration and production to slightly more than $2 billion a year for the next year or two, or just enough to satisfy rising domestic demand and increase exports slightly, Mr. Rojas said. Sixty percent of this spending is to come from operations and only 40 percent from foreign bond issues.
Putting this procedure in place, Pemex is floating $1 billion in bond issues this year in Japan, Europe and the United States, Mr. Rojas said, and similar bond issues are to be floated in 1991. Pemex, however, will not try again to raise $6 billion for exploration and production as it did in 1981, when oil prices were also high. Most of the $6 billion was borrowed.
''We are not going to borrow massive amounts, as we did a decade ago, to try to rapidly increase production,'' Mr. Rojas said. ''We don't want our economy to be heavily dependent on oil revenue only to have the oil price drop.''
 
Effect of Oil Prices
The oil-price drop in the early 1980's left Mexico without enough money to meet its foreign debt payments, and this was the main cause of the repayment crisis that endures to this day.
The caution in Pemex's new borrowing has helped to reduce the annual interest rate that Mexico must pay to float bonds. The most recent issues have returned a yield of 11.5 percent, compared with 17 percent when the process started last year.
''We don't have a target yet for how much we hope to raise from these bond issues,'' Mr. Ortiz said. ''We are still testing the market.''
Mexico's return to the world's bond market is so recent that the two American bond rating agencies -Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation -have not yet assigned a rating to the bonds. But the 11.5 percent yield assigned to the issues indicates that the markets consider the risk of Mexico's new debt to be similar to that of the bonds of Venezuela or Hungary, market experts said. Moody's rates the bonds of these two countries as Ba-1 or Ba-3, just below investment grade.
 
Reopened Bond Markets
Three other factors have also reopened international bond markets to Mexico at relatively low interest rates, bankers and economists say. One has been the Salinas Administration's spending cutback. The second has been the privatization program, intended to provide $20 billion or more to the Government. This money is to be used, in part, to repay foreign debt.
The privatization program, in turn, was an important reason that Mexico's commercial bank lenders agreed to a new debt plan that sharply reduced debt repayment for the next six or seven years.
The repayment plan, in effect, frees money that can be used to make payments on the new bond issues. The $48.5 billion in outstanding commercial bank loans has been converted into $42.5 billion in long-term United States Treasury issues, and payment of the remaining principal has been postponed. Interest payments have fallen to $3 billion a year from $4 billion, and as part of the debt agreement Mexico's bank lenders extended $1 billion in new credits to help with interest payments.
The World Bank has also made $2.4 billion in loans to Mexico this year, part of it earmarked for interest payments on old debt.
The upshot is that foreign debt repayment will fall to 2 percent of gross domestic product in 1990, from 4.5 percent last year and nearly 7 percent in 1988, the Government estimates. And the great hope is that the Mexican economy will be a lot richer - mostly through a much larger manufacturing sector - when the nation resumes repayment of principal on the old foreign debt, in addition to repayment of the bond issues now being floated and the World Bank loans.

HEADLINE: Credit Markets;
Move by Fed To Cut Rates Is Expected

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
''In the usual terms of growth versus inflation, the arguments for and against an easing of U.S. monetary poliy are nearly balanced,'' Marcos Jones, an economist at the Deutsche Bank Capital Corporation, wrote in a weekly letter to clients.
''But the potential impact of credit-related difficulties in the economy has grown to uncomfortable proportions, giving even the central bank a stake in a modest bout of reflation,'' he continued. ''So long as it can avoid a disorderly decline in the dollar, we expect the Federal Reserve to ease policy in the first half of this month.''
Fed officials have strongly suggested that before making their move they would prefer a stabilization of the Middle East situation, which in August generated one of the sharpest selloffs on record in world financial markets. But analysts said the Fed may not have that luxury. 
''We are coming close to the point where the Fed will have to move even though the market is not quite as stable as it might like,'' said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at the Chase Manhattan Bank. ''The key thing is to prevent a recession, and lower interest rates will help you do that.''
 
Job Data Awaited
In the next two weeks, the most likely occasion to prompt a Fed move seems to be the release of August employment data, which is expected on Friday. Economists do not anticipate a repeat of the July performance, when, excluding census workers, nonfarm payroll employment actually declined. But the forecasts do not envisage strong growth.
Excluding the census workers, estimates of the rise in payroll employment in August range from a low of 20,000 workers to a high of 125,000. A number in that range would not be indicative of a healthy, rebounding economy, analysts said.
''The August gain, all of which probably occurred in the private service-producing sector, reflects the effects of a five-week sample period and a modest bounceback from the sharp declines in July, rather than an improvement in underlying economic fundamentals,'' Brian Jones, an economist at Salomon Brothers, noted in the firm's weekly Comments on Credit.
 
Looking at the Numbers
Gary Schlossberg, a vice president and senior economist at the Wells Fargo Bank in San Francisco, said, ''If the economic numbers are really weak, the Fed may be inclined to ease even if oil prices are moving higher.''
An easing move by the Fed and a further reduction in tensions in the Middle East would be warmly welcomed in the corporate bond market, where new issues have become rare since the onset of the Persian Gulf crisis.
Excluding mortgage-backed and asset-backed financings, only 26 offerings of nonconvertible debt, totaling $4.1 billion, were made last month, according to figures from the Securities Data Corporation.
August is not normally a high-volume month, but the decline is stunning: in August of last year, 69 deals totaling $10.4 billion were offered.
''Apparently, corporate treasurers are not yet convinced that the latest rise in bond yields will last for long,'' said John Lonski, a senior economist at Moody's Investors Service.
 
No Increased Borrowing
But, he continued, ''the disappearance of new corporate bond sales has not been balanced by increased borrowing elsewhere - nonfinancial company commercial paper outstanding continues to contract.''
Taken in tandem, Mr. Lonski said the declines ''may be consistent with an overall drop in corporate borrowing that would be consistent with forecasts of the slowest economy since the 1982 recession.''
The corporate bond calendar is virtually empty for the remainder of this holiday-shortened week, but corporate finance specialists said a large backlog of issues is ready to come to market.
''Between now and the middle of October, you are going to see a lot of utilities, finance companies and foreign borrowers in the market,'' said one investment banker. ''But there is not likely to be a heavy run of industrial paper; they don't like rates at these levels, and for the time being, they don't need the money.''

HEADLINE: Talking Business; with Weinberg of Hartmarx;
Merging of Roles Seen in Retailing

BYLINE: By Isadore Barmash

 BODY:
Q. Is dual distribution still valid in these turbulent times for retailing?
A. Yes, more than ever. The industry volatility makes it more difficult for producers to find distribution channels, so they have to create their own. So more and more producers are going direct to the consumer. Not just us, but Liz Claiborne, Ralph Lauren, Phillips-Van Heusen, Florsheim shoes. In the 1960's and 1970's, we all concentrated on opening doors, meaning finding as many individual stores to sell to as we could. We still want to do that, but we also want to protect ourselves by having our own stores, too. 
Q. Are your stores primarily a pipeline for your own goods?
A. No. The key to the failure of many supplier-owned stores was that they were used to absorb the production errors of the owner-manufacturer. But those stores and all others must stand on their own and be able to compete. It is true that about 80 percent of what we sell in our stores is produced by us. But only between 15 percent to 18 percent of what we manufacture is sold through our stores; the bulk by far goes to other retailers. The answer to the question is that while we sell a lot of our own goods through our stores, everything they sell, our goods and others', has to be attractive and appealing so that our stores can be viable in the marketplace. But we take great pains to insure that our independent retail accounts have a product that is profitable and viable for them.
Q. Are there other advantages to having your own stores?
A. They keep us close to the consumer and give us market feedback. They make for more efficient production planning because our stores buy early, which helps us to better plan our manufacturing cycles. Our stores, too, can function as model showcases for our regular retail accounts. And having our own stores gives us an opportunity to launch and test new brands.
Q. Will a related trend, of retailers buying manufacturing plants, grow?
A. No matter what we call it, dual distribution or verticalization, I suspect that both trends will grow. Forward verticalization relates to producers who open or buy stores. Backward verticalization means retailers who buy, open or operate manufacturing plants, like the Limited's ownership of Mast Industries. The goal in both is the same: protecting the distribution channels and providing better service.
Q. Will you continue your retail expansion in the rest of 1990?
A. No, we are standing pat this year. Frankly, this is a year when we want to do better with what we've got. We have expanded a lot in recent years. Now we want a payback to that expansion. Next year, we may resume our new-store-opening program.
Q. Is there a fundamental change brewing in the clothes American men are buying?
A. We are not sure, but we are researching the matter. This 18-month lag in men's clothing sales is the longest down cycle since the recession years of 1973-74. Before those years, to spur demand we had a fashion-lapel change and the introduction of double-knits. Lately, we have been suffering from a lag in wardrobe replacement and higher prices created by rising wool costs. But we are optimistic for spring 1991 when there will be some fashion and silhouette changes and new, lighter fabric colors to replace the dark shades we have had in the last few years. Fabric prices, too, have stabilized. We ourselves will present four new fashion approaches in the Hart Schaffner & Marx line that we think will help to end the cycle.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Harvey A. Weinberg (Hartmax Corp.)

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Prime Rate Funds Difficult to Price

BYLINE: By Anise C. Wallace

 BODY:
Because these closed-end mutual funds invest in short-term floating-rate bank loans, their daily value, like that of a money market fund, is supposed to remain constant. But at some of these prime funds, the net asset values - or the prices investors pay to buy new shares - have begun to fluctuate. The value of the $670 million Van Kampen Merritt Prime Rate Income Trust, for instance, has risen slightly above $10 a share because some of its loans have appreciated in value, said Jeffrey W. Maillet, the fund's portfolio manager.
But on occasion the net asset value of the $1.1 billion Pilgrim Prime Rate Trust has dropped slightly below $10 for two reasons, a spokesman for the Pilgrim Group said. Pilgrim executives wrote down a $5 million loan to the Amdura Corporation in March after the company filed for bankruptcy protection. At the same time, the firm changed its accounting method, but executives would not discuss the reason for the change. 
This year, the five prime rate funds have been among the fastest growing of all funds and their investment returns have been the highest of all closed-end bond funds, according to Lipper Analytical Services Inc. For example, after shutting the doors to new business last winter, executives for the $1.7 billion Eaton Vance Prime Rate Reserves Fund in Boston reopened the fund to investors on July 31 and promptly raised an additional $100 million in one week.
At the end of July, according to Lipper, the five funds had $5.5 billion in assets. The current yield was 10 percent for Van Kampen Merritt; 9.98 percent for the Merrill Lynch Prime Fund Inc.; 9.86 percent for the Pilgrim fund; 9.78 percent for Eaton Vance, and 9.75 percent for the Allstate Prime Income Trust.
As the name implies, the goal of these funds is a yield that matches the prime lending rate, the benchmark rate that banks charge their highest-rated customers, currently at 10 percent. But to earn such a high yield after fees and expenses, the fund managers invest in bank loans to many low-rated, heavily indebted companies like Black & Decker, Hospital Corporation of America and Stone Container.
Executives concede that pricing the loans can be a problem. James B. Hawkes, president of the $1.7 billion Eaton Vance fund, compared the task to pricing real estate every day. ''The concept of a price today and a price tomorrow is not a helpful concept,'' he said. ''They don't trade every day.''
Nevertheless, because these funds sell shares daily to the public, the Securities and Exchange Commission has warned them to monitor the pricing of these loans carefully. So the funds have had to improvise. Executives of Van Kampen Merritt, for instance, use the services of a Wall Street firm that trades bank loans to price the 70 loans in their fund. ''We wanted an arms-length procedure that is similar to pricing securities,'' Mr. Maillet said.
Executives at Eaton Vance and Allstate, however, calculate the daily values themselves by analyzing interest rates and other so-called ''highly leveraged transactions,'' executives of these firms say. And unless a company has defaulted on a loan, Merrill Lynch carries the loan at its face value, said Gregg Durett, a vice president.
As in any market, of course, changes in supply and demand determine these loan prices. And even in this thinly traded market some loans command a premium while others sell at a discount. These days, some loans made to RJR Nabisco Inc. at the time of the 1989 leveraged buyout are considered ''cool'' and are less attractively priced than others, Mr. Snyder of the Loan Pricing Corporation said. ''Hot'' bank loans - those in high demand - include Gulfstream Aerospace, he said.
Because some funds' holdings are substantial, any discrepancies between a loan's market value and the price a fund uses to calculate its net asset value could be significant. For instance, Merrill Lynch has about $90 million invested in a short-term loan to Scotsman Manufacturing, which makes commercial prefabricated buildings. And Eaton Vance has $125 million, or about 7 percent of its portfolio, in one of the cool loans to RJR.
Because of their unusually strict policy on redemptions, though, it is unlikely that these fund managers will have to liquidate loans at market prices. But the price investors pay to buy new shares in these funds may not be exactly accurate.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
A Crisis Builds At Jordan Sites Housing Asians

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 4

 BODY:
[In Baghdad, the large-scale evacuation of Western and Japanese women and children stranded in Iraq and Kuwait resumed. Page A15.]
Officials have said the number of refugees arriving in Jordan could reach upwards of a million people within a week or two, perhaps more if war breaks out between Iraq and the United States-led multinational force in the Persian Gulf. The problem was left to Jordan for three weeks after the invasion of Kuwait. But in recent days United Nations officials, spurred on by private agencies like the International Committee of the Red Cross, have concluded that what confronts them is a vast human drama. 
With more than 100,000 Asians already enduring scorching heat and squalor in camps that dot the desert between the Iraqi border and Amman, the officials' problem is to cope with the already appalling conditions before events in Iraq take a turn for the worse, sending a still larger human torrent across the frontier.
To end the crisis, officials here must airlift the refugees out. One approach to that took shape with plans for a Soviet AN-124 aircraft, described as the world's largest commercial jet, to take nearly 500 Bangladeshi citizens from Amman to Dhaka, the capital of Bangladesh. The Soviet plane has been chartered with money donated by the European Community to make 10 trips to Dhaka.
 
Other Flights Arranged
United Nations officials said another 45 charter flights, some of them using other aircraft chartered from the Soviet airline Aeroflot, have been set for the next two to three weeks, at a total cost, together with the AN-124 flights, of $7 million. Many of these flights will carry Sri Lankans, whose Government, like that of Bangladesh, has said it cannot afford to charter aircraft of its own.
United Nations officials say that other nations, including Pakistan, Thailand and the Philippines, are following the example of India, which began taking some of its citizens out of Amman on chartered aircraft last week.
But when the United Nations charter flights now planned are completed, only about 15,000 of the refugees will have been taken home. The officials said no other flights could be chartered until ''donor nations'' - meaning mainly the United States, other Western countries and Japan - contributed the $50 million cost of getting the first 100,000 refugees home. Many more might well arrive here, pushing the costs of the airlift alone to hundreds of millions of dollars, before the costs of caring for the refugees are included.
Time, too, is a factor. The 110-degree heat of the Jordanian desert plummets at night, health conditions in the camps are appalling and food and water scarcities and other frictions, some of them ethnic, have already lead to fights. In recent days, there have also been reports that refugees have been beaten by Jordanian Army guards.
 
Food Airlifted From Italy
Efforts to lower the tensions by bringing in relief supplies gained momentum today when 120 tons of food arrived by air from Italy, along with 1,000 more tents, 500 of them from the United States. But a huge backlog persists.
Relief officials have also been looking at the possibility of chartering ships. Rolf Gemmy, a United Nations expert on mass migrations, told reporters that vessels at the port of Aqaba that have been idled by economic sanctions against Iraq could be used to ship some of the Asians home, but that increased insurance costs because of the war risks, together with other anxieties, were causing problems in negotiations with the shipowners.
As they struggled to fashion solutions to these and other problems, the relief officials confronted another difficulty: tensions and rivalries among themselves. Even before Prince Hassan took over the news conference today with his attack on the west, United Nations and Jordanian officials had traded barely disguised accusations about who was responsible for waiting utnil last Tuesday, 25 days after the Kuwait invasion, before starting to build the first barely equipped refugee camps in the desert.
Prince Hassan, who has been in charge of day-to-day running of Jordan for much of the past month while his brother, King Hussein, has been touring Europe and the Arab world in search of a diplomatic solution to the crisis, left no doubt where he placed the blame. In his statement to reporters, the Prince said that while attention had been focusing on the Western military buildup, ''a human tragedy of the widest dimension has received but scant attention.''
 
'Downtrodden of the Earth'
After a passing reference to the Western hostages in Iraq, the Prince implied that there were chauvinistic or racial reasons for the inattention. ''As the downtrodden of the earth, the plight of these persons, mostly nationals of the countries of the Indian subcontinent and of the Philippines and Thailand, has evoked only the faintest of responses from the world community, and from a world press more interested in war scenarios than humanitarian relief,'' he said.
The Prince concluded his appearance by abruptly announcing, in effect, that he wanted Mr. Essaafi, the United Nations Disaster Relief Coordinator, superseded or fired. By saying he planned to ask Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar to put someone in charge of coordinating aid to the refugees - Mr. Essaafi's current role -Prince Hassan appeared to be saying Jordan lacked confidence in the United Nations operation.

HEADLINE: Political Conflict Is Renewed Over Drilling in Arctic Refuge

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ARCTIC NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE, Alaska, Aug. 31

 BODY:
This kind of debate is not limited to Alaska. The Government has said it will try to mediate a dispute in Santa Barbara, Calif., over transporting crude oil. And oil industry executives are pushing, with no apparent success, for a reconsideration of President Bush's decision in June to bar new drilling off the coasts of California, Florida and other states.
But nowhere is the debate taking as sharp a focus as in this pristine, desolate region 250 miles north of the Arctic Circle.
''We are the nation's wilderness and we are also the nation's major source of energy,'' said Alaska's Governor, Steve Cowper, a Democrat who favors drilling in the refuge. ''This is a metaphor for the energy debate.'' 
The Arctic National Wildlife Refuge covers 19 million acres in the northeastern corner of Alaska, an area almost the size of Maine. It is a landscape virtually untouched by man in a state whose majestic wilderness, especially after the Exxon Valdez spill, is a powerful symbol of what is at risk when oil production or transportation go wrong.
The drilling debate centers on the section of the refuge that runs along the Beaufort Sea at the eastern end of the North Slope. The coastal plain, covering 1.5 million acres, or an area the size of Delaware, is a flat, virtually featureless tundra near the water, with gently rolling hills a few miles inland. It is 65 miles east of the Prudhoe Bay oilfield and the other fields of Alaska's North Slope.
The Eskimo village of Kaktovik, which like many settlements above the Arctic Circle has a satellite dish to receive television signals but is without running water, lies just outside the boundary of the refuge at the edge of the Beaufort Sea. But there are no roads within or leading to the refuge. Only a few hundred outsiders, including oil-company employees and tourists, fly into the coastal plain each year. Barren Desert or Sacred Place? The trade-offs among energy, environment and economy are clearly delineated here. To Senator Ted Stevens, Republican of Alaska, the coastal plain of the refuge is ''nothing but a frozen, barren desert'' containing oil that would contribute to national security by adding to domestic reserves.
To Representative Morris K. Udall, the Arizona Democrat who is a leading opponent of drilling, the area is ''a sacred place'' that should never be given over to oil rigs and pipelines.
To Archie Brower, a village leader in Kaktovik, oil development here means jobs to keep young people from leaving and money to prop up a local economy that is as fragile as the local ecosystem.
To Karen Jettmar, the assistant director of the Wilderness Society in Alaska, the refuge is ''a little island of protection in a sea of oil development.''
 
Amount of Oil Highly Uncertain
In 1987, after a five-year study, the Interior Department called the coastal plain of the refuge ''the nation's best single opportunity to increase significantly domestic oil production.'' While no one will know for certain whether there is any recoverable oil at all unless exploratory drilling is permitted, Government and industry estimates of the amount of oil in the region are as high as nine billion barrels, nearly as much as was in the Prudhoe Bay field before the pipeline opened in 1977.
The nine-billion-barrel figure, however, is by all accounts optimistic. The Interior Department study said the average of all estimates it had considered was 3.2 billion barrels.
In the eyes of the oil industry and its supporters, drilling in the refuge is particularly important now because production in the North Slope fields peaked last year at just under two million barrels a day, or about a quarter of all domestically produced oil and about an eighth of all oil consumed in the United States, and is expected to decline to less than half that within a decade. It would take at least six years to begin producing oil from the wildlife refuge.
 
Called a Turnpike in a Park
Oil-industry executives say that drilling in the refuge can be done in an environmentally sensitive way. Environmentalists contend that there are risks to wildlife, particularly the migrating caribou, and that no one yet knows the long-term effects of industrial development on the tundra. There is always the risk of a major spill from a pipeline or a production plant.
Moreover, environmentalists say that allowing oil development in the refuge is the equivalent of placing a stretch of the New Jersey Turnpike in a national park. No matter how carefully it is done, it will carry too high an esthetic price.
Both sides of the debate say the chances of a bill authorizing oil exploration will depend to a large extent on the course of events in the Middle East, from which the United States imports about 2.3 million barrels a day, at the low end of the estimate.
 
Intensely Negative Public Image
Environmental considerations aside, the oil industry's public image is still intensely negative. Some consumers and politicians have accused many companies of cashing in on the crisis in the Middle East by raising gasoline prices excessively, a charge the companies all deny.
The coastal plain has long been in a kind of legislative limbo. It has not been formally designated a protected wilderness area, as the rest of the refuge has. But no drilling is allowed pending the completion of extensive research by the Government and Congressional approval.
The Reagan Administration completed its research in 1987, when the Interior Department submitted a report to Congress concluding that the coastal area could be developed without significant impact on the environment. The report, which is being challenged in court by environmental groups, recommended that the Government begin selling oil-drilling leases in the region. The Bush Administration adopted the same position and is now seeking Congressional authorization.
 
Chance of Success Put at 19%
The 1987 report said there was a 19 percent chance of finding oil that would be economically feasible to recover, odds that are considered extremely favorable in an industry used to a success rate in exploration of no better than 5 percent.
All the big oil companies have done seismic and geological work in the region. The Chevron Corporation drilled an exploratory well on private land at the edge of the area several years ago. The results from the well are a corporate secret, but Chevron is among the companies most aggressively lobbying for the area to be opened.
For those who do not have access to sophisticated technical research, there is more immediate evidence right on the tundra: outcroppings of rock laced with oil, and spots where oil is seeping out of the ground. In addition, the coastal plain of the refuge is situated between confirmed oil finds. Besides the activity in the North Slope area to the west, the Canadian side of the Beaufort Sea to the east has been the scene of drilling activity in recent years, and some oil has been shipped out.
The oil companies with the most interest in the refuge are Chevron and those that have already invested heavily in the North Slope, including ARCO and the British Petroleum Company, which operate the Prudhoe Bay field jointly, and the Exxon Corporation, which has a big ownership stake in the North Slope fields.
 
A Big Find Would Be Economical
Any significant find would be highly economical because of the area's proximity to the 800-mile Trans-Alaska Pipeline, which transports crude from Prudhoe Bay and the rest of the North Slope south to Valdez to be loaded on tankers.
Industry executives say their 13 years of operating experience on the North Slope has proven that oil production, including the pipelines and roads that now crisscross the tundra, has not affected the caribou herds, waterfowl or any of the other animals in the region.
They also say that virtually every move they make on the tundra is heavily regulated.
''The environmental standards being applied in the oilfield are exemplary,'' said Scott Ronzio, an environmental scientist with ARCO.
But environmentalists are not giving up the fight. They say they see no evidence that the nation's concern with maintaining its remaining wilderness has ebbed significantly since the Valdez accident.
''There is a need to protect the land not just for wildlife and human recreation, but just to have it there,'' Ms. Jettmar of the Wilderness Society said.

LENGTH: 528 words

HEADLINE: Soviet Army Wives Demonstrate in Germany

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BURG, East Germany, Aug. 31

 BODY:
Townspeople said the women marched onto a main street, attracting German television news cameras. But no action was taken against them, and at week's end soldiers and wives said there had been no official retaliation.
 
Pent-Up Frustration
Though the women said the protest was specifically against the prospect of moving into temporary housing in winter, some also said the eruption represented ''pent-up frustration at the hasty withdrawal.'' 
''Look at the Americans and British, their soldiers are withdrawing in an orderly way,'' said one young wife of a warrant officer. ''We're just being driven out with our children in the middle of winter, with nowhere to stay.''
The unit in Burg is part of a unilateral withdrawal announced by Moscow last year, and not part of the general withdrawal of Soviet forces expected after German unification. Chancellor Helmut Kohl and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev agreed at a summit meeting in July that the Soviet forces, estimated at 360,000 men and 200,000 dependents, could withdraw over a four-year transition period.
 
Goodbye to Chocolate-Land
But the protest reflected a broader anxiety in the Soviet military about the transfer of the vast force in East Germany back to a homeland suffering from shortages and a lack of ready military housing. The difficulty of the move was reportedly the main reason Mr. Gorbachev sought to phase the withdrawal, and why West Germany agreed to build tens of thousands of new military housing units in the Soviet Union.
''There is uncertainty down to the last soldier,'' said Rainer Eppelmann, the East German Minister of Defense and Disarmament. ''They have to say goodbye to chocolate-land, and they face the prospect of returning to an impoverished homeland.''
Mr. Eppelmann reflected a widespread German assumption that the Soviet women were angered at leaving in part because as the wives of officers, which most of them are, they were earning up to 1,000 German marks a month (about $645 at current exchange rates) since the currencies of East and West Germany were merged on July 1. Soviet troops in East Germany were maintained by East Germany, and West Germany agreed to assume the responsibility after currency union.

PUB-DATE: September 5, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 14, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1073 words

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
Excerpts From Baker Testimony on U.S. and Gulf

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4

 BODY:
While the rules of the road developed during the cold war did in the end preserve peace - East-West in Europe - the task now is to build an enduring peace that is global in its scope and not limited just to Europe and not rooted in confrontation and tension. If we are to build a stable and more comprehensive peace, we must respond to the defining moments of this new era, recognizing the emerging dangers that are lurking before us.
We are entering an era in which ethnic and sectarian identities could easily breed new violence and new conflict. It is an era in which new hostilities and threats could erupt as misguided leaders are tempted to assert regional dominance before the ground rules of a new order can be accepted. 
Accordingly, Mr. Chairman, we face a simple choice. Do we want to live in a world where aggression is made less likely because it is met with a powerful response from the international community, a world where civilized rules of conduct apply? Or are we willing to live in a world where aggression can go unchecked, where aggression succeeds because we somehow cannot muster the collective will to challenge it?
Sadly, Saddam Hussein's attack on Kuwait will not be the last act of aggression that international society will face. So long as ruthless aggressors remain, the reality of international life is such - is that such predatory designs are going to emerge from time to time.
 
Design of a New Order
But the current crisis is the first opportunity to limit such dangers, to reinforce the standards for civilized behavior found in the United Nations Charter, and to help shape a more peaceful international order built on the promise of recent trends in Europe and elsewhere.
So it's our view, Mr. Chairman, that we must seize this opportunity to solidify the ground rules of the new order.
Second, from a strategic standpoint we must show that intimidation and force are not successful ways of doing business in the volatile Middle East or, for that matter, anywhere else.
The combination of unresolved regional conflicts, turbulent social and political changes, weapons of mass destruction and much of the world's energy supplies makes the Middle East particularly combustible. No one is immune from conflicts in the Middle East. And no one can feel safe when the danger of war escalating in the Middle East is so high.
If we want to encourage peaceful change, and to preserve the security of all of our friends in the area, we are going to have to remain a reliable partner for peace. We must help demonstrate that Saddam Hussein's violent way is an anachronism rather than the wave of the future.
Third, and perhaps most obviously, what is at stake economically is the dependence of the world on access to the energy resources of the Persian Gulf. The effects on our economy and our people, as I mentioned, are already being felt.
But this is not about increases in the price of a gallon of gas at the local service station. It is not just a narrow question of the flow of oil from Kuwait and Iraq. It is rather about a dictator who, acting alone and unchallenged, could strangle the global economic order, determining by fiat whether we all enter a recession or even the darkness of a depression.
 
Peril of World Recession
A sustained oil price spiral similar to what happened in 1973 and again in 1979 could easily cause higher inflation and interest rates worldwide, sending all of us into a sustained recessionary slide.
The burden could become particularly great for the new democracies of Eastern Europe, threatening to undo the democratic revolutions of 1989. It would also be painfully felt in the poorer countries of Central America, South Asia and Africa, threatening those who are now embracing market-oriented reforms and striving to improve living standards for their impoverished millions.
Once the present danger passes, however, we cannot let its lessons go unheeded. We have a responsibility, I think, to assure the American people that a decade from now their sons and daughters will not be put in jeopardy because we failed to work toward long-run solutions to the problems of the gulf.
The historic international consensus that we've built can become a solid foundation for successfully meeting our immediate objectives and for building a safer future. It can foster a future gulf environment that will protect our interests and help us avoid having to make this kind of massive diplomatic and military effort again.
In the long run, we seek a stable gulf in which the nations of that region and their peoples can live in peace and can live free of the fear of coercion. We seek a region in which change can occur and legitimate security concerns can be preserved, and preserved peacefully.
And we seek a region, Mr. Chairman, in which energy supplies flow freely. We will need to work together with Governments in the gulf and outside of it to build a more durable order.
We will want to insure that our friends in the area have the means to deter aggression and defend themselves, making it less necessary to send American men and women to help them. And we will work with the rest of the regional and international communityto prevent further Iraqi expansionism as well as Iraqi efforts to acquire and produce weapons of mass destruction.

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
U.S. Officials Begin Tour to Seek Financial Backing for Gulf Force

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Sept. 4

 BODY:

 
A Critical Need
But the officials said the United States was anxious to obtain French and British endorsement of the principle of financial as well as political ''burden sharing'' in the crisis before seeking contributions from Japan, West Germany and other Western allies.
Officials speaking to reporters on Mr. Brady's flight from Washington to Paris said a critical need was to get commitments for $10 billion or more to provide aid to Turkey, Jordan and Egypt, The Associated Press reported. An official traveling with Mr. Brady said other third world countries, including the Eastern Europe nations and countries like Brazil and the Philippines, would probably receive economic help, A.P. said. 
At the headquarters of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in Brussels today, the United States also asked its allies to lend ships and aircraft to help transport troops and equipment to the Gulf region. NATO officials said Britain, Italy and Portugal immediately offered help.
 
Aid for the Needy
For the moment, though, the European Community is concentrating on an aid package for countries badly hit by the gulf crisis, notably Egypt, Jordan and Turkey but also poorer nations that have been hurt by the increased world price of oil. Community foreign ministers are to meet Friday in Rome to discuss the plan.
Egypt has been hurt by the loss of remittances from Egyptians working in Iraq, Jordan by the loss of trade with Iraq and the burden of fleeing refugees, and Turkey by the loss of income from an Iraqi oil pipeline that crosses its territory and has been closed. The community is expected to offer up to $1 billion in aid to each.
As Mr. Brady arrived, France said today that it favored sending emergency medical and food aid to Iraq under the auspices of the United Nations. Mr. Dumas said emergency aid was contemplated in Security Council resolutions ordering the trade embargo against Iraq. Baghdad has warned that foreign hostages in Iraq will be hurt by any shortages resulting from the embargo.

PUB-DATE: September 5, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 15, Column 5; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 861 words

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
Hostage Evacuation Flights Resume From Iraqi Capital

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 4

 BODY:

 
Evacuation Is Resumed
''We're moving again,'' said a Western diplomat who for the last several days has been working with colleagues to arrange transportation for the foreigners and to obtain authorization for their movement from Iraq.
For more than a week, the task of getting the women and children to freedom has at times overshadowed other aspects of the Persian Gulf crisis as the confrontation between the United States and Iraq simmered at a tense stalemate.
Worsening security and living conditions in Kuwait are creating a sense of urgency among the diplomats. As many as 11,000 foreigners from Western countries and Japan are believed to be stuck in Kuwait, most of them hiding in fear of being rounded up by Iraqi security forces. 
About 1,400 of these are American women and children. Two hundred are British and there are several hundred other foreign women and children.
 
Norway Evacuating Embassy
This evening, Norway announced that it was ''temporarily evacuating'' its embassy in Kuwait because the situation had become intolerable.
Norway and about 20 other countries refused an Iraqi order 12 days ago to close their embassies in Kuwait, because they felt that doing so would be a tacit acceptance of the takeover by President Hussein.
Iraq cut off the electricity and water to the embassies, limited their telephone service, surrounded them with troops and said that the diplomats were subject to being detained if they left the embassy grounds.
Peter Raeder, the charge d'affaires of the Norwegian Embassy here in Baghdad, said in an interview tonight that he would appeal to Iraq on Wednesday ''to let the diplomats in our mission go safely from Kuwait and not be molested or troubled in any way.'' #11 Living in Embassy Three Norwegian diplomats, including Ambassador Hans Wilhelm Langva, and eight staff members are living in the embassy, Mr. Raeder said. He said they would probably try to leave on Thursday.
East Germany closed its embassy in Kuwait two days ago, and its diplomats were permitted to enter the East German Embassy in Baghdad.
Some diplomats said they believed that the Norwegian decision could be the beginning of the end of the diplomatic resistance in Kuwait and that several other nations might give up the struggle in the next few days.
''The European Economic Community countries are meeting to discuss whether to leave,'' one diplomat said.
 
Burning the Furniture
Some diplomats say they think it is unlikely that the United States Embassy in Kuwait, with eight diplomats and about 20 Americans who have sought asylum, can hold out for much more than a week. By last weekend, the Americans there were breaking up embassy desks and chairs for firewood to boil swimming pool water for drinking.
President Saddam Hussein announced early in the crisis that foreign men, women and children, would be detained in Iraq in the hope that their presence would deter President Bush from ordering an attack by American troops gathering in Saudi Arabia.
 
A Question on Television
Then, 12 days ago, during a televised meeting with the President, a woman among the hostages, whom the Iraqis describe as guests, asked Mr. Hussein if he would consider releasing the women and children. Within a few hours, Mr. Hussein announced that the women could go. He also said foreign citizens of Iraqi origin, including men, were free to leave.
But the other male foreigners, among them husbands and fathers of the women and children allowed to leave, Iraq said, would have to stay in the country, many of them quartered at strategic military and industrial installations, ''as long as this crisis continues.''
The last of the charters to leave today was a Boeing 707 carrying 28 Americans, most of them Iraqi-born American citizens, plus more than 80 Britons and other Europeans, and 18 citizens of Commonwealth countries. It took off for Amman from Saddam Hussein International Airport at about 11:30 P.M., more than four hours behind schedule. [The Americans and Britons, together with Irish and Australian citizens, then headed to London, Reuters reported from Amman.] One of the Iraqi-born Americans who was flying out, Matti Matti, a 67-year-old Chicago businessman, hugged relatives in the vast chrome and marble terminal and said he had feared he might get caught in a war.
''Of course I was scared,'' he said. ''But I was also thinking that maybe nothing would happen.''
He said the relatives he was leaving behind were ''very much worried'' about the prospect of war.

PUB-DATE: September 5, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 16, Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 696 words

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
For Asians, Gulf Is Fickle Godmother

BYLINE: By SANJOY HAZARIKA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, Sept. 4

 BODY:
Many in Kuwait and Iraq, especially ordinary workers, are returning virtually destitute to their homes, unable to draw on savings that are locked in Kuwaiti banks. Their new unemployment is likely to create major social and economic problems in South Asia because their earnings often supported large families.
 
Supporting 11 Back Home
A Bangladesh newspaper, Dialogue, estimated that each Bangladeshi in the Middle East supports about 11 people back home, compared with 3 people for every Indian employed there or about 7 for each Pakistani or Sri Lankan. Many families ''whose bread-earners are in Kuwait and Iraq are already desperate,'' the paper said. 
Every day, special flights evacuate hundreds of Indians and Pakistanis who were stranded in Jordan and Saudi Arabia. Sri Lanka, battered by ethnic unrest, says it is unable to afford a large-scale evacuation and has told its nationals to stay where they are and not to panic.
''Our people don't want to stay on, we have nothing to offer them back home, and we are not in a position to evacuate them,'' said a senior Sri Lankan diplomat here.
The remittances from the Middle East converted scores of impoverished villages and towns across South Asia into little enclaves of prosperity with gleaming new houses of marble, brick and cement replacing mud and thatch huts.
 
Property Prices Soar
Television sets, washing machines, videos, air conditioners and brand new cars announce the new-found wealth of the ''gulf-returned,'' as those who lived and worked in the Middle East were known. An Indian living in Kuwait or Dubai was regarded as a prize catch on the marriage market.
Property prices soared, pushing up the cost of living all around, especially in the state of Kerala in southern India, from which about 700,000 people have gone to work in the Middle East.
While Pakistan and Bangladesh are sending troops to Saudi Arabia to oppose President Hussein, India has criticized the invasion as well as its neighbors for the decision to send troops and the United States for its role in the crisis. While calling for a pullout of Iraqi troops, New Delhi has refused to use harsh words against Iraq.
External Affairs Minister Inder Gujral, who has visited Baghdad and Kuwait since the invasion, explained India's quandary in a television interview on Sunday night: ''Strong words would have put my own people in jeopardy.''
 
Blow to Exchange Reserves
The Middle East, especially Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates and Oman, have seen the principal concentrations of Indians and Pakistanis, mostly laborers like poor carpenters and masons, seeking to fashion a new life for themselves. The disruption of their lives means that foreign remittances, which are crucial for South Asia's foreign exchange reserves, will be slashed.
There has been, however, an initial burst of new savings in Indian banks by some Indians in the Middle East seeking to secure their money. According to one estimate, they have sent back more than $400 million since the crisis began.
The Pakistani Government has announced an initial payment of 6,000 rupees, about $290, to each earning member of a Pakistani family who has returned home from Kuwait or Iraq. The goal is to encourage them to become self-reliant.
''It is a major loss to us,'' a senior Pakistani official in Islamabad said in a telephone interview. ''Pakistanis in the Middle East send $2 billion back home, and of this figure, 15 percent came from Iraq and Kuwait.''

Bangladeshi refugees waited yesterday for food and water at the camp in Ruweishid, Jordan. (Associated Press)
