HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
Soviets Suggest Conference Combining Issues of Mideast

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 4

 BODY:

 
Longtime Source of Contention
The Kremlin's proposal for an international conference was long a cold-war bone of contention, with Israel maintaining strict opposition to such a forum as a means of addressing the Palestinian question.
President Saddam Hussein of Iraq has been denounced by the United States for saying that consideration of a military retreat from Kuwait must be contingent upon an Israeli withdrawal from territory occupied in previous Middle East wars.
In his speech, Mr. Shevardnadze gave no indication whether President Mikhail S. Gorbachev might pursue this point at his summit meeting with President Bush in Helsinki on Sunday.
''Presumably, Israel's agreement to its convocation could exert a positive influence on the overall situation in the Middle East and on efforts to defuse the crisis,'' Mr. Shevardnadze said, renewing the proposal for an international meeting on the Middle East. 
''For its part, the Soviet Union would not leave without response an Israeli move along these lines and might take a fresh look at the issue of Soviet-Israeli relations,'' he said, apparently referring to the question of restoring Moscow's diplomatic links with Israel. Relations were severed after the 1967 war in the Middle East.
 
Support for U.N. Effort
The move to link the conference proposal to the Kuwait crisis was something of a surprise, coming as it did only five days before the one-day Helsinki summit meeting, which is expected to emphasize Moscow-Washington agreement over how best to press Mr. Hussein to retreat from Kuwait.
Mr. Shevardnadze stressed that the Soviet Union felt ''duty bound'' by the United Nations Security Council resolutions condemning Iraq and pressing for a diplomatic settlement.
''Even hypothetically we should not acquiesce in any option that would fall short of restoring the sovereignty, territorial integrity and legitimate Government of Kuwait,'' he said, urging political approaches to ''remove the military presence of other countries.''
In the last week, a few Soviet officials have departed from the Kremlin's quiet tolerance of the Bush Administration's military buildup in Saudi Arabia, saying the buildup could continue after the crisis and jeopardize Soviet-American progress in disarmament.
But Mr. Gorbachev has made a point of saying before the summit meeting that the White House moved at the invitation of Saudi Arabia and in conformity with the United Nations Charter, and that there has been no flagging in Soviet-American cooperation.
 
List of 'Interlocking Problems'
Mr. Shevardnadze said the ''complex interlocking problems'' included ''the Arab-Israeli conflict, the fate of the Palestinians and the tragedy in Lebanon,'' all of them aggravated by ''critically high'' amounts of arms.
''Quite a few extraregional states, including the great powers, have contributed to that situation,'' he said.
''After one more look at the situation we still have come to the same conclusion,'' he said, saying that the Gorbachev Government feels the need to increase pressure for an international conference on the Middle East ''without deferring for a subsequent period'' the United Nations' efforts to bring about a comprehensive settlement.
Diplomatic efforts ''unquestionably'' deserve priority in tackling the Kuwait crisis, Mr. Shevardnadze said, while adding: ''The course at a peaceful settlement should in no way imply that the aggressor has nothing to fear.''
Predicting that the summit meeting in Helsinki would ''mark a major milestone on the road toward resolving the crisis,'' Mr. Shevardnadze said the Soviet Union was convinced that the sanctions against Iraq would work.
 
Baker Cool to Conference
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (Special to The New York Times) - In an interview with NBC News, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d appeared today to dismiss the proposal by Mr. Shevardnadze to convene an international conference.
Mr. Baker said that an ''extraordinary degree of international consensus'' already existed for dealing with Iraq and that considering all the actions taken by the United Nations so far ''we almost have an international conference.''
In what seemed to be a polite way of dismissing Mr. Shevardnadze's proposal, the Secretary said, ''We would like to see a little bit more of what the Soviets have in mind.''
 
Shevardnadze Arrives for Talks
TOKYO, Sept. 4 (Special to The New York Times) - Foreign Minister Shevardnadze arrived here tonight to begin three days of talks that Tokyo hopes will thaw decades of frigid relations before next year, when President Gorbachev becomes the first Soviet leader to visit Japan.
Both Japanese and Soviet officials here played down the likelihood of any major progress on the one issue that has kept Japanese money and technology out of Mr. Gorbachev's reach: the continuing dispute over four northern islands that the Soviet Union claimed in the last days of World War II. But the tempo of discussions about the islands has accelerated recently.
On Monday Ivan Frolov, a Politburo member and chief editor of the newspaper Pravda, said Mr. Gorbachev would bring with him ''something historic'' in his visit to Tokyo, scheduled for next spring. But Japanese officials say there has been little indication that the Soviets have any inclination to return the islands.

HEADLINE: Conservation, Not Nuclear, Will Stop Oil Binge

 BODY:
Also, in the 45-year history of atomic energy, nobody has found a way to dispose of nuclear waste safely. About 20,000 metric tons of nuclear waste sits today in heavily guarded spent-fuel pools around the country awaiting a national repository site. In the same Aug. 19 edition (Week in Review), you report that New York State couldn't find a place to dispose of the low-level nuclear waste it produces, ''enough low-level waste,'' you say, ''to fill an Olympic-sized swimming pool every year.'' 
By the time you have factored in all the hidden costs - the Three Mile Island cleanup, for example, cost $4 billion; Federal subsidies over 30 years totaled $40 billion; a national waste repository could cost $20 billion -atomic energy has turned into an atomic boondoggle.
Fortunately, we do have a low-cost resource available to reduce our excessive reliance on desert despots: conservation.
Thirty percent of all the oil used in the United States goes to power automobiles. In a May 22, 1989, editorial you argued that increasing the standards for automobile fuel efficiency by even one mile a gallon would save 420,000 barrels of gasoline per day. And, applying existing technologies more broadly could enable new cars to average 45 miles per gallon, which would reduce demand for oil by 6.5 million barrels a day, or 50 percent more than the daily output of both Iraq and Kuwait before Saddam Hussein's armies invaded. We could take other important steps to reduce our oil appetite and protect the environment. Federal legislation of the kind shunned by the Reagan and Bush Administrations could encourage better home insulation, efficient lighting and weatherization, not to mention mass transit. Investments in community and home conservation programs should be included in utility rate bases so that local power companies will be motivated to ''sell'' not only electricity, but also conservation.
A barrel of energy saved is as cost-effective as a barrel produced - and environmentally preferable. This country needs a conservation program that works.
 
MARK GREEN
Commissioner of Consumer Affairs
New York, Aug. 24, 1990

HEADLINE: New Jersey Taxpayers Don't Want an Explanation, but Relief

 BODY:
The Florio budget includes $33 million more in state funds for several Bergen County school districts. This was a discriminatory move, prompted by the Governor's need to win legislative backing for his new school funding formula, and but for this, we would not have needed a sales tax on paper products.
As for the Governor's new school-funding formula, I don't argue against more funds for the state's 30 neediest school districts, but it is questionable if several hundred other districts can spend the funds properly. Would it not have been wiser to set aside a sum to pay for special programs, such as nutrition and early-childhood education, in particular school districts? 
In last year's gubernatorial campaign, Jim Florio said he would not raise taxes because he felt confident an audit of state government operations would show areas of fat that could be trimmed. Now it appears his staff hopes to save only $100 million, and that is not even sure. In addition, why is the Governor having only 11 of 19 departments audited?
His popularity is plummeting not only because of massive tax increases, but also because the people of New Jersey feel betrayed by a Governor who was unprepared for a fiscal crunch, did not review the alternatives in an orderly manner before raising taxes and then reneged on his promise to conduct an audit.
Mr. Florio's popularity among New Jerseyans dropped to its lowest after his appearance on prime-time television last week to ''explain'' his economic policy. That's because taxpayers are not looking for an explanation. They are looking for relief from an unwarranted financial burden. And they are not willing to wait 10 years to get it.
 
JOHN H. EWING
Trenton, Aug. 23, 1990
 
The writer is ranking Republican member of the New Jersey Senate Finance Committee.

HEADLINE: Hey, America, Lighten Up a Little

BYLINE: The following was adapted from an unsigned editorial that appeared in the July 28 issue of The Economist.

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
America attracts such bile partly because it is more self-critical than other nations. Hypocrisy is often in the eye of the beholder: how dare a European look down his nose at a country to whose universities his brightest fellow-citizens flock? Foreign criticism often attacks American habits that the critics happily adopt a few years later: from refrigerators and Elvis Presley to negative campaigning and aerobics. To criticize America is to criticize what the future holds in store.
Misgivings about the direction in which some of America's ''culture'' is heading arise precisely because the American way today tends to be the way of the world tomorrow. By culture, we mean not painting and music, but way of living. The worry is about what might be called a ''decadent Puritanism'' within America: an odd combination of ducking responsibility and telling everyone else what to do. 
The decadence lies in too readily blaming others for problems, rather than accepting responsibility oneself. America's litigiousness is virtually banishing the concept of bad luck: a hotel refuses to allow an able-bodied guest to swim in its shallow rooftop pool because there is no lifeguard on duty. A drunken driver can sue his host for allowing him to get drunk.
If a prominent citizen becomes an alcoholic or is caught indulging some illegal appetite, he all too often claims he is a victim, not a fool. The habit of pleading insanity as an excuse for a crime is spreading. Increasingly, too, people are blaming their genes and finding sympathetic (and often foolish) scientific support. The exaggerated claims by a few scientists that they have found ''genes for alcoholism,'' or aggression, are well couched to prevent people taking the rap for their own actions.
To allow legal redress for negligence, or to seek to rehabilitate rather than punish victims - these are worthy aims. But fair redress is not always appropriate; sometimes the buck must simply stop. Just as an over-padded welfare state breeds a habit of blaming and expecting help from government, so America's legalism breeds the shifting of burdens onto someone else. It saps initiative from the economy quite as effectively as the state-sponsored variety.
Another facet of this phenomenon is the warped idea that the problem with America's underclass is a lack of self-esteem, and that the answer to poor educational performance is to teach more self-esteem. Bunk. The characteristic that in the past drove generations of immigrants from the underclass to prosperity was not self-esteem, it was self-discipline. The reason that Japanese schoolchildren - and the children of Asian immigrants in America - learn so much more than their American counterparts is discipline, not self-esteem.
To see how far such evasiveness has caught on, look at the new abundance of euphemism. Prisons have become ''rehabilitative correctional facilities,'' housewives are ''homemakers,'' deaf people are ''hearing impaired,'' a cerebral palsy society tells journalists never to use the word ''suffer'' about those with that ''disease'' (forbidden), ''affliction'' (forbidden), condition (allowed). Jargon cannot alter reality. How refreshing to hear a politician who favors both abortion and the death penalty described bluntly as ''pro-death.''
Take race. There are few countries anywhere on earth in which people are generally less prejudiced about color than Americans, stereotypes of the Old South and Bensonhurst notwithstanding. Yet there are few countries where the issue looms so large; where pressure groups are so quick to take offense at a careless remark or where words are made to carry such a weight of meaning. ''Black'' is fast following ''Negro'' into the lexicon of the forbidden, to be replaced by ''African-American'' in the never-ending search for a label without overtones. Some universities, egged on by their students, have recently imposed disgraceful restrictions on free speech rather than let bigots speak out on campus and be judged for what they are.
As for Puritanism, America's search for fairness has begun to conflict with its famous tolerance for new peoples, new ideas and new technologies. A conformist tyranny of the majority, an intolerance of any eccentricity, is creeping into America, the West Coast in particular. An increasingly Puritanical approach to art, married to a paranoid suspicion of child abuse, has made a photographer who takes pictures of parents with their children naked on the beach into a target for the F.B.I.
Add to that sort of thing the ruthless prudishness of the television networks about anything except gratuitous violence, and the gradual assertion of ''correct'' ways of thinking about such things as smoking and affirmative action. It all adds up to a culture of conformity that would rather bore than shock.
A television scriptwriter recently admitted that he put cigarettes into the hands only of baddies. A whole industry of pressure groups has arisen to persuade TV producers to push ''correct'' ideas on their (fictional) programs: smoking is bad for you; concern for the homeless is right; plastic bags are bad for the environment. All true, and all admirable. But fiction is fiction, not cautionary tales.
As Americans get ever richer, they seem to grow more risk-averse, so that they become paranoid about hazardous waste in their district, obsessed with their cholesterol levels, and ready to spend large premiums for organic vegetables. It being a free world, they are welcome to do so, even if the risks from hazardous waste are exaggerated or the risks from natural carcinogens in organic vegetables greater than from pesticides. But must they become killjoys in the process?
None of these things is confined to America, but - like everything else - they breed faster and more lushly in America. And now the infection has spread to politicians, who have discovered that a quick way to television prominence is to take outraged offense at every imagined slight. Careers can collapse because of a single ''gaffe'' that does not pass some ideological litmus test. Television seems to have done its best to drive humor out of politics. Can you imagine Lyndon Johnson getting away with half of his witticisms today? If we are all to enjoy the 21st century, America must lighten up a bit.

SECTION: Section B; Page 1, Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1322 words

HEADLINE: Cuomo's Campaign: Crime? Taxes? Look Elsewhere

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT

DATELINE: ALBANY, Sept. 4

 BODY:
Many political analysts say Mr. Cuomo, who is frequently mentioned as a possible Presidential contender, is well advised to handle such issues gingerly during this year's gubernatorial campaign.
''It's an incumbent's strategy,'' said Lee Miringoff, director of the Marist Institute for Public Opinion in Poughkeepsie. ''If you're running well and your challenger's not, keep the intensity of the campaign low.''
A low-key campaign that addresses broad national themes, like Social Security tax cuts, makes sense for Mr. Cuomo from a national perspective as well, political analysts say. 
''How he handles issues like savings and loans and the Moynihan Social Security tax cut plan, all that gets watched here,'' said Mike McCurry, a spokesman for the Democratic National Committee in Washington. In contrast, Mr. McCurry said, the Governor's handling of local issues, like New York State taxes, do not receive much attention outside the state.
 
Lessons in Other States
For a longtime incumbent like Mr. Cuomo, the need to distance himself from the state's problems is well illustrated by the fate of several other Northeastern governors.
In Connecticut, Vermont and Massachusetts, the incumbent Governors - William A. O'Neill, Madeleine Kunin and Michael S. Dukakis - all declined to seek re-election this year, at least in part because their popularity declined together with the regional economy.
Even aides to Mr. Cuomo acknowledge privately that crime and economics are issues that a strong opponent could use against the Governor. During Mr. Cuomo's tenure the state built a record number of prison cells, yet during the same period instances of violent crime rose by 20 percent. And while the state's income tax rates have fallen since Mr. Cuomo took office almost eight years ago, state taxes have grown steadily as a proportion of New Yorkers' incomes - from $7.20 of every $100 earned by state residents in 1983 to $7.70 last year.
Polls taken in recent weeks by the Marist Institute show that New Yorkers now rank the economy as the most important issue facing state government, with crime and drugs next. Those polls also show that Mr. Cuomo's approval ratings, while high for a Governor in office eight years, have fallen significantly from four years ago.
But Mr. Cuomo's Republican challenger, Pierre A. Rinfret, a political novice, has been unable to make his attacks stick, even on issues on which the Governor is considered most vulnerable. The effect has been to give Mr. Cuomo almost total control over how the issues of the campaign are cast.
 
Controlling the Spotlight
Typical of Mr. Cuomo's low-intensity style in this campaign are his earliest commercials. One radio advertisement discusses highway safety improvements during Mr. Cuomo's tenure -14,000 miles of road have been repaired since he took office - and urges motorist to drive carefully. A television commercial that took to the air last month does not even mention Mr. Cuomo's campaign or discuss his eight years in office. Instead it focuses on the proposed $1.9 billion environmental bond issue that voters will be asked to approve in November.
The commercials stand in stark contrast to the Governor's early commercials during the 1986 campaign. In those, he discussed his economic record and boasted of the number of jobs created during his first term.
Mr. Cuomo insists that he is spending campaign funds on advertisments for the environmental bond act because it is a worthy cause - and one potentially in trouble - not because the promotion fits into some overarching political strategy.
But others are skeptical. Environmentalists, some of whom have been the Governor's most outspoken critics, say the bond issue represents Mr. Cuomo's effort to link himself with a cause that tends to win support across party lines. And political strategists note that the commercials seem to elevate the Governor above the political fray, a move that has come to represent the peak of political savvy.
 
Focusing on Others
''What he's doing is a public service, but it's also good politics,'' said Hank Morris, a political consultant.
In his many swings across the state this summer - swings that have not been labeled campaign events but that have clearly had that purpose - Mr. Cuomo has not entirely avoided vexing issues like crime and the economy. Indeed, he has often introduced the subjects himself. But he has minimized discussion of his own actions and has focused on that of others.
Speaking recently in Schenectady, for example, Mr. Cuomo said he sympathized with other government officials in ''this time of reduced revenues.''
''Sixteen states are already in recession, 37 states are in big trouble,'' he said. ''The United States Government is suffering economically. That's why the President had to give up his pledge. He didn't want to. He didn't want to change his mind about taxes, but the economy was in such bad shape.''
In case the Schenectady audience was still tempted to concentrate on the Governor's responsibility for the state's economic problems or its high taxes, Mr. Cuomo directed their attention to the State Legislature. ''Every year the budget is higher than the Governor asked for,'' he said. ''Over the last eight years it's been $1.1 billion more than I asked for.''
 
Spreading the Blame
On crime and drugs, Mr. Cuomo has pressed recently for a Federal campaign to put anti-drug programming on prime-time television.
''How about giving us an hour every night, a half hour every night, prime time, where you get everybody in the country at the same time and say, 'We're going to talk to you about drugs.' '' Mr. Cuomo said to a group of police chiefs recently. ''All right, you can't talk the networks into it; they all want to make a profit. So raise $5 billion in tax money. You're going to do $500 billion to bail out the savings and loans.''
Political strategists say the Governor's technique of spreading the blame for New York State's problems is one that is likely to work well because, in the end, most voters do not expect Mr. Cuomo to solve the problems of a sagging economy or a soaring crime rate anyway. What they do demand from him is that he offer the reassurance that he is concerned about the situation and has it under control. And creating the perception of caring and control is, most political strategists agree, what Governor Cuomo does best.
''When Mario Cuomo talks about these things, you feel that something is being done,'' said David Garth, a political consultant. ''That is perception, and it's part of his gift.'' Even if Mr. Cuomo leaves vague just how he plans to solve the problems, Mr. Garth said, ''he gives, when he talks, the promise of performance.''

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Wednesday about new mainframe computers from Fujitsu misidentified the employer of Japanese computer executives arrested in 1982 for the theft of information about I.B.M. computers. They worked for Hitachi, not Fujitsu.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: 2 Contenders at Hartford Debate Claim an Edge in Ability

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Sept. 4

 BODY:
The hourlong debate, which was taped here for broadcast on Connecticut Public Television, marked one of the few moments of complete even-handedness in what has been through the spring and summer a wildly out-of-balance race. Until today, Mr. Morrison, a far better-financed and better-known candidate who also has the backing of the party, had displayed an almost complete disregard for Mr. Cibes as a threat.
For one hour, however, they were simply two men in suits who want to be governor, apparently equal before the eye of the camera.
On topics including education, crime and how the state can the business climate to attract jobs, Mr. Cibes repeatedly returned to what he described as a stone wall that cannot be broken through without dramatic change - the tax system. 
The 8 percent sales tax and 13.8 percent corporate tax are already among the highest in the nation and cannot be raised much further, he argued. With a shortfall in revenues that could approach $800 million next spring, or more than 10 percent of the total state budget of just over $7 billion, the question the next governor will have to face is what to save and how to save it.
''The people want someone who is willing to make hard choices,'' Mr. Cibes said. ''It's the hard truth that we need to undertake tax reform.''
Mr. Morrison said the main difference in perspective that he would bring to the budget problems is that new taxes would be a last resort, and not a first strike. He said he would impose an immediate hiring freeze and work to increase efficiency in spending, so that revenues will go further. ''We will squeeze the dollars in Hartford harder,'' he said.
As for sparks, only on the question of the candidates' experience and perspectives on government in the 80's was there anything close to acrimony. Mr. Morrison repeatedly tried to link Mr. Cibes, a longtime confidant and campaign adviser to Gov. William A. O'Neill, with what Mr. Morrison described as the failed policies of the last few years under the O'Neill administration.
 
Role in Raising Taxes
He said Mr. Cibes, whose political experence has all been in Connecticut, including 12 years in the General Assembly, did not understand Washington or the ways in which aid for the state might be used by a governor with connections.
He reminded viewers that Mr. Cibes, as co-chairman of the Assembly Finance, Revenue and Bonding Committee, was the ''architect and engineer'' of the record tax increases last year. The increases, including raising the sales tax from 7.5 to 8 percent, aroused animosty among residents, and according to opinion polls were a major reason for Mr. O'Neill's steep decline in popularity. Mr. O'Neill stopped his drive for re-election in March.
Mr. Cibes, who said he was not apologetic about the increases because they saved important services and education grants to towns, said Mr. Morrison was out of touch with the state.
He also tried to link Mr. Morrison, a former legal-assistance lawyer to the poor who has represented the Third Congressional District since 1983, with Government decisions to cut back local and state aid, policies that Mr. Cibes said had battered Connecticut and worsened the economy. ''You really don't have enough experience about what has been going on in this state over the last 10 years,'' Mr. Cibes said.
Another point concerned whether Mr. Cibes's tax plan would mean increases or cuts. Mr. Cibes said the main point was that cutting the corporate and sales taxes was an immediate priority to try and keep businesses in the state. The trade-off is the income tax, which he said would raise the bottom-line tax payment for a family earning $100,000 about 1.5 percent, or $1,500.
Mr. Morrison, who has proposed a referendum on the income tax before action in Hartford, said the major point was that most people would pay more and that they would have no choice about it.

SECTION: Section B; Page 3, Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 617 words

HEADLINE: New York Post Owner Issues Ultimatum on Costs

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
Mr. Kalikow's representatives asked the unions for $27 million in annual savings, said someone at the meeting who spoke on condition that he not be identified, but a statement by Richard T. Nasti, the paper's general manager, released late yesterday put the figure at $25 million.
''This is a bitter pill for the unions,'' said Theodore H. Kheel, a lawyer who is an unpaid adviser to the Allied Printing Trades Council, an umbrella organization that includes the 10 unions at The Post, The Daily News and The New York Times.
 
Unions Aren't Blamed
At yesterday's meeting, Mr. Kalikow's representives presented union leaders with a plan for savings from each union, though they said that Mr. Kalikow was willing to negotiate on how the savings could be achieved. 
Mr. Kheel said the only positive note was that Mr. Kalikow had not blamed union excesses for the paper's financial situation and had indicated that he was flexible as to how the savings might be created.
But the savings could mean a combination of reduced overtime and salaries, reduced staffing requirements and layoffs for the paper's approximately 1,000 unionized employess.
A spokesman for Mr. Kalikow said he was not available for comment.
Union officials said they did not want to discuss specifics of what Mr. Kalikow had proposed until consulting with their members.
Mr. Kalikow's demand is reminiscent of a similar ultimatum in February 1988 when Rupert Murdoch, then the paper's owner, demanded $24 million in savings that he said were necessary before he could sell the paper to Mr. Kalikow. Unions gave Mr. Murdoch most of what he asked, and Mr. Kalikow acquired the paper for about $37 million.
Mr. Kalikow's representatives said he had invested about $120 million in the paper. At the time that he sold it, Mr. Murdoch said he had lost about $150 million during his 11 years as owner of The Post.
For unions, Mr. Kalikow's demands create a difficult problem that goes beyond the potential loss of jobs and wages at The Post.
Union leaders said they were concerned that The News and The Times, which have also been financially damaged by the slowdown in the regional economy, would seek any concessions granted at The Post.
 
Books to Be Examined
Spokesmen at both The Times and The News declined to comment yesterday.
In the statement, Mr. Nasti said union leaders would be allowed to examine The Post's books.
About 10 days ago, Mr. Kalikow arranged for the resignation of Valerie B. Salembier, the paper's president, in order to save money.
Both union leaders and representatives of Mr. Kalikow described yesterday's meeting as cordial and frank, without the bitterness that has characterized the unions' stalled negotiations with The News, which have been under way since January.
''This is a case of rational people sitting down and doing what must be done to preserve jobs and keep the paper running,'' Mr. Nasti said in his statement.

HEADLINE: Metropolitan Diary

BYLINE: By RON ALEXANDER

 BODY:
Chain letter indeed! It's a joke that in 1990 people still fall for them. And a stellar cast had fallen for this one. Leafing through the stack of letters, I was amazed by the eclectic assortment of correspondence. Barry Slotnick, the lawyer, sent along a slightly risque poem about Mary and how she ended up with a little lamb. The comedian Jackie Mason, not wanting a jinx two weeks before his show opened in Los Angeles, responded: ''Oy vey! I am so nauseous that I got this &*a&%N chain letter, but I am not taking any chances.''
Then there were effusive epistles from Oliver Stone, the Oscar-winning director; Depeche Mode, the rock band; Tom Smothers and Dick Martin, the comedians, and such corporate honchos as the chief executive of Lord & Taylor and the chairman of Macy's. No wonder the mail's late. 
Four days have come and gone. Have I won the lottery? No. Have I been brushed with bad luck? No. And I can't say I'm waiting for it to happen. But on the way home from work yesterday, I found myself crossing the street to avoid a black cat. Just in case. ALAN W. PETRUCELLI
Conversation overheard by Suzanne Gran in Bloomingdale country. The speakers, two women of a certain age, exiting from a movie theater.
Woman One: ''The way they talk now! I've never heard such language!''
Woman Two: ''Dirty doesn't bother me. Dirty I can take. It's the way he treated his brother.''
Herewith, positively the last words on those strange sentences created to use the entire alphabet in as few words as possible, and used primarily for checking typewriter keys.
The following pair - submitted by Daniel K. Weiller, Jane Hannauer and Lucille Sutton, among others - use proper names, which some spoilsports insist is cheating. On the other hand, the sentences weigh in at 29 and 28 letters respectively, which is commendable indeed. Without further ado: ''Quick, wafting zephyrs vex bold Jim.'' ''Waltz, nymph, for quick jigs vex Bud.'' Somehow we're still fond of brown foxes jumping over lazy dogs.
 
Dear Diary:
All those commercial tie-ins to particular parts and moments of televised Mets and Yankees games! There's the Nothing-Beats-the-Wiz Scoreboard and the New York Telephone Call to the Bullpen. Totes umbrellas get a plug at rain delays. Where will it end? How long before Ralph Kiner says, ''That strike was brought to you by the I.L.G.W.U.''? Or before Rusty Staub allows, ''That sacrifice was a piece of cake - Pillsbury Bundt Cake''?
I can see it now: the Soloflex Seventh Inning Stretch, a WD-40 Slide, a Yale Lock Shutout. But when Scooter exclaims, ''Laughing Cow!'' I'll know nothing's holy anymore. JAMES W. PENHA

MORNING ENCOUNTERS
 
He usually wears a yellow T-shirt
And green skivvies.
I usually wear
What I wore yesterday.
He holds his boxer's leash
In his fist.
I hold a three-pound weight
In each of mine.
''How far do you go?'' he asks
From behind, abreast, ahead.
''Three miles,'' I say. ''And you?''
''Five, but you're doing swell.''
Decrescendos
In the early morning air. VEUVE VAN HOOK
 
Dear Diary:
Hiking resolutely toward the Wednesday Greenmarket in Union Square, I'm passing the offices of Calet, Hirsch & Spector on Park Avenue South. (An unemployed copywriter, I'm especially alert when passing large ad agencies). A handsome woman stands looking out from behind the glass doors. She acknowledges me and I do a double take, because she is clad in the unmistakable uniform of a doorman.
I screech to a halt and put my Pro Walkers in reverse. I meet her eye and inquire, through the glass, ''Door Person?'' Without missing a beat she nods yes and a lovely smile lights her face.
I walk on toward the fresh vegetables, marveling that yet another barrier has fallen. JAMIE SCOTT

''P.S. If anything goes wrong call my Mom.''

LENGTH: 784 words

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Harder Times, Softer Politics

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
In the 26 years from 1947 to 1973, the authors point out, average family incomes rose by 111 percent. But in the last 16 years, they have edged up just 9 percent. And even this marginal increase has come at considerable effort. Virtually the entire gain is attributable to the entry of middle-class housewives into the paid labor force. 
That is only part of the bad news. Since the 19th century, the ''trickle-down'' of wealth from sucessful businesses had had a leveling effect: A disproportionate share of the gains from American economic growth ended up in the pockets of workers. But since the mid-1970's trickle-up has replaced trickle-down. In 1973 the poorest 40 percent of families took home 17 percent of income, while the richest 20 percent pocketed 41 percent. By 1988 the share of the poorest 40 percent had slipped to 15 percent, while the share of the top fifth had grown to 44 percent.
The ground lost, the two economists note, has been almost entirely at the expense of the young. The typical family with a head in the 25- to 34-year-old bracket earned 2 percent less in 1987 than in 1973. And among the young, the poorly educated bore the brunt: The one family in six whose primary breadwinner did not finish high school earned a stunning 29 percent less.
Lagging incomes translate into lagging living standards. Since 1973 the percentage of families owning homes has slipped for every age group under 55. Those in the 25 to 29 group have been most dramatically hit, with the percentage of homeowners slipping to 35 from 44. Young workers are also much more likely to fall between the cracks in the health insurance system. In one 28-month period spanning 1985 through 1987, 28 percent of Americans were covered for less than the full 28 months. Among 18- to 24-year-olds, however, 52 percent suffered from interruptions in coverage.
Why has this economic malaise had so little political impact? More specifically, why was President Reagan not touched by high mortgage rates, exploding college tuition costs and a lack of affordable day care? And why has President Bush, a leader known for keeping one finger on the public pulse at all times, resisted a cut in payroll taxes while pushing for a cut in the levy on capital gains?
One answer is that the best organized group of lower- and middle-income Americans, retirees over 65, have been bought off with Medicare and fatter Social Security checks. Another is that the labor movement represents a shrinking proportion of workers. And in the process of downsizing, the image of unions has changed: Once seen as the defender of the working class, they must now compete for influence with other, equally well-financed interest groups.
Frank Levy, an economist at the University of Maryland, offers an entirely different explanation: Eroding living standards have indeed had a political impact, but popular frustrations have been deflected in unexpected directions.
Voters may not blame the President. But they apparently do blame state and local governments, which have had an increasingly difficult time raising taxes to pay for badly needed local services. By the same token, unfocused economic frustrations may also play a large part in the public's anger over ''unfair'' competition from Japan and other rapidly developing export economies.
Ironically, the hard-pressed middle class may well be the biggest beneficiary from access to cheap imported clothes, shoes, appliances and autos. But then, irony is nothing new to the American political system, which for better or worse has always been successful in fragmenting and diffusing class interests.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
New Valid Logic President Wants More Market Share

BYLINE: BY Lawrence M. Fisher

 BODY:
''Running a $200 million company amid the rapidly evolving electronic design automation market demands a balance between long-range and day-to-day management activities that is best achieved through the traditional C.E.O. and C.O.O. structure,'' said W. Douglas Hajjar, Valid's chairman and chief executive officer.
Despite its growth, Valid is substantially smaller than the market leader in electronic design automation, the Mentor Graphics Corporation of Beaverton, Ore. But Mr. Klaus said he would try to increase Valid's share of the market. He said Valid was in stronger shape than its relative market share would indicate.
''I didn't want to go to a company where I had to do a total turnaround,'' Mr. Klaus said. ''I wanted a company with a base to build on, not a shell.''
He noted that Valid has strong new products, a large customer base and solid finances. ''Valid is extremely well positioned,'' he said.
Mr. Klaus was previously with Sytek Inc., Mountain View, Calif., a maker of computer networking products that was acquired by the Hughes Aircraft Company last year. He joined Sytek in 1983 as vice president for marketing and sales, and was president and chief executive officer at the time of the merger.
Prior to Sytek, Mr. Klaus spent three years at the Amdahl Corporation as a vice president, and 13 years at the Control Data Corporation in a variety of sales, marketing and operations positions.
Mr. Klaus holds a bachelor of science degree in mathematics from California State University at Northridge. He and his wife, Julie, have two children.

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 4

 BODY:
ARCO introduced the first in August 1989 in the Los Angeles area, a replacement for regular leaded gas. The company has been studying other kinds of low-emission gasolines.

HEADLINE: Purchasers Report Slip in Economy

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:

 
Still Growing
''The manufacturing sector and the overall economy are very weak; there is no question about that,'' said Robert J. Bretz, chairman of the asssociation's survey committee. ''But the index is consistent with real economic growth of 1.3 percent for 1990.''
The gross national product, measuring the total value of the nation's goods and services, expanded at an annual rate of 1.5 percent from January through June, the Commerce Department has reported. 
The Middle East crisis made some components of the Purchasing Managers' Index seem overly strong. But even without this stimulus, the overall index would have signaled a still-intact economy, Mr. Bretz said. Some other economists agreed.
''Mostly the American economy is moving sideways, neither expanding nor contracting,'' said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at Prudential-Bache Securities. ''What is keeping a lot of industries going are exports.''
The export stimulus was clearly not as vigorous as it was earlier in the summer. An index measuring export orders fell to 53 in August from 57 in July and 56.5 in June. Although the index had weakened, a 53 level meant that more than half of the purchasing executives said export orders had risen last month.
 
Production Index Plunges
Another big component of the Purchasing Managers' Index, a gauge of factory production, also fell sharply, to 48.5, from 52.1 in July, 53.9 in June and 56.3 in May. That was the lowest reading since January, when the index fell to 45.4.
The below-50 level meant that a majority of the 300 companies in the survey reduced production in August, and they might do so again in September. The new-orders index was 46.4 in August, essentially unchanged from 46.2 in July and well below the nearly 55 level in May and June.
The Middle East crisis skewed survey components dealing with inflation, order delivery time and inventories. Prices were higher than they would otherwise have been, order delivery time longer and inventories larger, Mr. Bretz said.
The price index jumped to 58.2 in August from 50.9 in July and June. The rise came mostly because of price increases for petrochemicals, plastics and other petroleum-based commodities and for items like aluminum, copper and nickel, whose production requires huge amounts of electricity. Oil is often used to generate electricity.
The order-delivery-time index also rose smartly, to 51.1 in August from 47.3 in July. This increase meant that a majority of the purchasing managers reported that delivery time had lengthened. Normally, delivery delays mean the economy is strong and companies are inundated with new orders.
But last month, the stretched-out delivery times reflected nervousness among purchasing managers, Mr. Bretz said. They ordered more supplies than needed, fearing the Middle East crisis might cause shortages.
The stockpiling that resulted from the extra ordering also pushed up inventories. The index measuring inventory levels rose to 44.1 in August from 39.3 in July. Nevertheless, the less-than-50 reading meant more companies were shrinking inventories than expanding them.

HEADLINE: U.S. Reports 0.4% July Gain In Construction Spending

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4

 BODY:
Analysts had said the weakness in the construction industry was a result of consumer caution, high interest rates, stringent lending requirements and overbuilding in some areas.
 
May and June Data Revised
Construction spending had not risen since a four-tenths of a percent increase in March. It fell nine-tenths of a percent in both May and June and 1.9 percent in April. 
The latest report showed that May and June were weaker than first reported. The Commerce Department had initially said that spending in May was down three-tenths of a percent and was unchanged in June.
Residential spending in July fell four-tenths of a percent, to $190.5 billion, its fourth consecutive drop, including a 3.4 percent loss in June.
Single-family spending was down 1.3 percent, to $110.2 billion, for its fourth straight decline, including a 1.6 percent drop in June. Apartment construction fell 1.6 percent, to $18.4 billion, for its third straight drop, including a 3.6 percent decline in June.
''The new-structure component will continue to move down, certainly through the end of the year,'' said David Seiders, the chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders. He said the report showed a strong performance only in additions and alterations.
''This is what we usually see in down cycles,'' he said. ''People just add on to houses.''
Nonresidential spending rose 2.5 percent in July, to $107.5 billion, after a 1.8 percent gain the previous month.
''The only truly bright spot is the industrial component,'' which was up 9.3 percent in July, Mr. Seiders said.
The other two big nonresidential components - office buildings and other commercial construction such as shopping centers - remained weak, Mr. Seiders said.
Government spending edged down two-tenths of a percent, to $108.6 billion, after rising seven-tenths of a percent the previous month.
Over all, construction spending in July was 3.1 percent aboveJuly 1989's $429.0 billion.

HEADLINE: Program Buying Trims Dow's Loss to 0.99

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Volume on the exchange slumped to 92.9 million shares, the slowest since Dec. 26, 1989, when it was 76.7 million shares. The year's slowest day until yesterday had been Friday's 96.5 million.
In an indication that the market as a whole was weaker than Dow shares, 814 stocks on the New York Stock Exchange fell, with 82 hitting new lows, while 673 advanced, with five reaching new highs.
 
Heavy Program Buying
Birinyi Associates, which monitors program trading, said that heavy program buying, particularly in the last half-hour, lifted the Dow 6.70 points. One two-minute buying flurry just before the close raised the Dow nearly 8 points, Birinyi said. 
The possibility of armed conflict continued to be ''the major uncertainty'' in the Middle East, said Francis H. Schott, chief economist of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, although, he added, ''oil-price concerns seem to have abated a bit.''
''The overall political question,'' he said, ''remains unresolved whether the Iraqis will be forced out of Kuwait without armed conflict and how it can be done.''
 
Focus on the Fed
At the same time, he said, ''There continues to be major concern about Federal Reserve policy because the conflict in the Middle East has interfered with the normal process of easing in which the Federal Reserve would normally be engaged.''
The two factors - ''the uncertainty about the Middle East and the delay in easier Federal Reserve policy'' -are depressing the market, he said.
Crude oil for delivery in October rose $1.80 a barrel yesterday, to $29.12, which pushed bond prices down and lifted yields on long-term Treasury bonds to 9.01 percent.
 
Employment Data Awaited
New economic data released yesterday, including a weaker-than-expected purchasing managers index, showed that the economy was faltering. But Wall Street is not expected to pay much attention to such statistics until Friday, when August employment data are released.
Dr. Schott forecast the numbers would show that the economy was weak enough to suggest that the Federal Reserve would ease monetary policy ''sometime this month.''
Taking their cue from the decline in stocks in Tokyo and most of Europe, traders in New York sold off shares in the first 20 minutes yesterday, depressing the market 27 points. After several unsuccessful attempts to gain ground, stocks rallied around 1 P.M. and improved from then on.
Changes in Dow stocks were small: Alcoa rose 7/8, to 65 1/4; Procter & Gamble 5/8, to 77 5/8, and I.B.M. 5/8, to 102 1/2.
 
Transportations Fall
With the rise in crude oil, the Dow transportation index fell 5.36, to 896.08, but Delta Air Lines was the only stock in the index to fall as much as a point, slipping 1, to 55 3/4. UAL, still unable to make headway on financing for a union buyout, hit a new low of 89 1/2 before ending at 91 3/4, down 1/4.
The big disappointment of the day was Pinnacle West Capital, the utility company, which plunged 3 3/4, to 12 3/8, in heavy trading after Pacificorp, another utility, gave up a 10-month takeover battle in exchange for a 30-year agreement to exchange power.
Among the insurance stocks, Progressive rose 3 3/8, to 52 7/8, a new high, although analysts said there did not appear to be news to account for it. General Re rose 1 3/4, to 75 3/4, after Michael A. Smith of Shearson, Lehman Brothers recommended it. Marsh & McLennan rose 1 1/4, to 71 1/2.
 
Big Rise for Adobe
Adobe Systems, the software producer, rose 3 1/8 on the Nasdaq, to 28 1/8, in heavy trading after it agreed to license Apple Computer to use its Postscript software and printer technology. Apple was unchanged, at 37.
Nike, the athletic shoe maker, rose 3 1/8, to 68 5/8. Fred Anschel of Dean Witter Reynolds, had recommended the stock two weeks ago, when Alice Ruth of Montgomery Securities had turned cool on the stock because of recession fears.
The Standard & Poor's 500 stock index rose 0.53, to 323.09; the Nasdaq composite rose 0.46, to 381.67, and the Amex market value index fell 0.65, to 322.74.

HEADLINE: Productivity Data Revised

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4

 BODY:
In the first quarter, the department reported that productivity fell 1.9 percent. 
Analysts, while agreeing that the increase was positive, said that it mainly reflected the fact that fewer people had jobs. As companies shed staff, they eliminate the least efficient jobs first, raising productivity figures.
The new figures, closely watched by industry and government, are considered an important measure of the efficiency of the American economy and the ability of its workers to compete with their counterparts overseas.
The department said that manufacturing productivity increased at a seasonally adjusted rate of 4 percent. Long-lasting durable goods manufacturing was up 7.3 percent while non-durable goods fell 1.4 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Mixed in New York After Advancing Overseas

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
''We're trying to decide whether it's a reversal of direction or what, and we just don't know,'' said Robert Ryan, chief foreign exchange dealer with the Bank of New York Company.
The dollar has slumped in recent weeks because of pessimism about the United States economy and the effect the Persian Gulf crisis could have on it. 
 
Jobless Report Awaited
Dealers said the markets were looking toward the scheduled release Friday of the Labor Department's employment figures for August. The markets expect the report to confirm that the economy is slowing down and to reinforce arguments that United States interest rates must come down.
Many economists say that the United States economy is headed into a recession and that the Federal Reserve will move to encourage lower rates. But such a move would be a negative for the dollar, which is supported by higher interest rates and has struggled lately to compete against currencies of nations with higher rates.
The dollar fell to 143.40 Japanese yen in New York, compared with 143.79 late Friday. United States financial markets were closed Monday in observance of the Labor Day holiday. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar rose to 144.05 yen, from 143.55 at Monday's close. Later, in London, it was quoted at 143.55 yen.
 
The Pound Declines
The British pound fell to $1.8810, from $1.8905 late Friday.
The dollar also strengthened against the German currency, rising to 1.58115 marks, from 1.5755 on Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's prices, included: 1.3135 Swiss francs, up from 1.30835; 5.2965 French francs, up from 5.2865; 1,179.00 Italian lire, up from 1,170.00, and 1.16075 Canadian dollars, up from 1.15625.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Precious Metals Shunned After Last Week's Decline

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Gold futures settled $1 to $1.40 higher on the Commodity Exchange, with the contract for delivery in September up $1.40, to $383.70 an ounce. Silver futures ended 4.1 cents to 5.4 cents lower, with September at $4.719 an ounce.
Light sweet crude oil jumped $1.80 a barrel for the near-month contract on the New York Mercantile Exchange amid reports the United States Navy had stopped and boarded a tea-laden Iraqi-flag freighter in the Gulf of Oman as part of the trade blockade against Iraq. 
Any sign of rising tension in the Middle East is likely to prompt an increase in crude oil prices and in inflation fears, a situation that is ordinarily bullish for gold.
But after gold prices dropped last week from more than $415 to less than $385 an ounce, investors have become leery about buying the metal, said Fredric Tordella, president of the MTB Banking Corporation, a New York-based dealer of precious metals and foreign currency.
He said the market's Aug. 27 plunge of $26.70, its steepest decline in seven years, ''really shook a lot of people up - not only their pocketbooks but their faith in the metals market and how it's going to react to the current situation.''
Anne Orton, a vice president of the precious metals and currency dealer Deak International Inc., agreed that last week's big drop ''took a lot of steam out of the market.''
Soybean futures, meanwhile, surged on the Chicago Board of Trade, rebounding from levels that some analysts had viewed as excessively low after a weeklong decline.
But wheat futures retreated for the sixth consecutive session and hit new life-of-contract lows across the board, reflecting abundant supplies worldwide. Corn futures were mostly higher.
The corn and soybean crops moved rapidly toward maturity last week, according to the Agriculture Department's weekly crop-progress report, which was released after the close.

HEADLINE: Obituary;
Irving Berezin, 78, Dies; Led a Consulting Firm

 BODY:
He died of pancreatic cancer, a spokesman for the family said.
Mr. Berezin had recently retired as executive secretary of the New York State Advisory Council on Employment and Unemployment. He was appointed to the post in 1976.
In 1966, Mayor John V. Lindsay appointed him to the Human Resources Administration, charged with consolidating New York City's antipoverty, manpower-training, welfare and youth programs.
He became vice president for administrative services at New York University in 1967 and he set up his own consulting firm, Irving Berezin Inc., in 1973. Earlier, he had been a senior partner in the public-relations and management-consulting firm of Anna M. Rosenberg Associates.
From 1941 to 1945, on loan from the Air Force, he was chief of manpower utilization for the New York region for the War Manpower Commission.
He is survived by his wife, the former Dorothy Isaacs; two daughters, Joan, of Berkeley, Calif., and Judith, of Manhattan; a brother, Herman, of Laguna Hills, Calif., and two grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
BAKER WARNS U.S. TO HAVE PATIENCE ON IRAQ EMBARGO

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5

 BODY:

 
'We Will Review Our Options'
President Bush told 30 members of Congress during a closed White House meeting that if the sanctions do not work, ''We will review our options,'' his spokesman said.
The comment seemed to convey a threat to turn to the use of offensive military force against Iraq. But Administration officials said Mr. Bush was seeking to address Congressional concerns about goods being shipped to and from Iraq despite the embargo. They said the options he had in mind focused on ways to plug those gaps.
In the Persian Gulf today, the Defense Department announced that the Navy had released an Iraqi cargo ship that the crew of an American guided-missile frigate boarded and seized on Tuesday. It was the first Iraqi vessel seized by American forces imposing the blockade. 
 
Soviet Suggestion Rejected
It was not clear why the ship, the Zanoobia, was released. But the Pentagon said the Navy was watching the vessel ''until its ultimate destination has been determined.''
The State Department said tonight that it was checking unconfirmed reports that an American citizen had been shot and wounded in Kuwait City. The Department said in a written statement that it had checked with hospitals in the Kuwaiti capital and that none said they had any knowledge of the man. The Department declined to release the man's name, but said it had spoken with his family. Administration officials said they had no way of determining the truth of the report, which they had received earlier today. The source of the report was not known.
As the Sunday meeting with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev approached, the White House went out of its way to praise overall Soviet actions during the gulf crisis. But it responded coolly to Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze's call on Tuesday for an international conference on the Middle East and brushed off any suggestion that the Helsinki talks could produce a mediator's role for Mr. Gorbachev in the Persian Gulf.
Mr. Bush's meeting in the White House was with members of House and Senate delegations who had recently returned from visits to Saudi Arabia, where they inspected American forces who are deployed in the desert in an avowed effort to deter an expansion of the Iraqi occupation of Kuwait.
 
Some Gaps in Embargo
Marlin Fitzwater, Mr. Bush's spokesman, quoted Mr. Bush as telling the lawmakers that his principal weapon against President Hussein was the economic embargo of Iraq. He quoted Mr. Bush as saying: ''We must keep pressure on Iraq and convince Saddam Hussein that time is against him. The sanctions must succeed. If not, we will review our options.''
Mr. Fitzwater declined to elaborate on the President's remarks. But another Administration official, who insisted on not being identified, said Mr. Bush was not hinting at offensive military force, but was responding to concerns expressed by some Congressmen that there were gaps in the embargo, including air shipments of food and other supplies into Iraq.
''What he was saying was that in terms of how we can strengthen the application of the sanctions, there are all kinds of options,'' the official said. ''We can undertake stricter enforcement measures. We can hit the countries that are violating the actions by trying to impose penalties. Those could involve denying landing rights to their aircraft or bringing the violators into the public eye by naming them, which we've avoided doing so far.''
The question of how long it would take for the economic sanctions against Iraq to take effect, and beyond that how long American forces would remain in the Middle East, took the fore today, one day after Congress returned to work and lawmakers came home from trips to the Middle East.
 
Crippling Effect on Iraq
During his testimony today Mr. Baker declined to answer repeated questions about both issues. Instead, he appealed to the public to stand behind Mr. Bush.
Mr. Baker said the Administration was ''very optimistic'' that economic sacntions ''can begin to have some real bite rather soon.''
But a Government analyst, who insisted on not being identified, suggested that it would be a long time before the embargo has the kind of crippling effect on the Iraqi economy that the Administration is seeking.
''Short of a conflict breaking out, I don't see a quick end game,'' the analyst said. ''We're talking about months, maybe stretching into a year or more, for the sanctions to have an impact.''
 
Public Support for Bush's Plan
The analyst said most of the focus around the world had been on the bans on food imports and oil exports, but noted that Iraq imports three-quarters of its manufactured goods and 20 percent of its labor force.
Still, he said: ''Does everything shut down at once? No. They'll make arrangements.''
The question of public support during a protracted struggle has been of major concern to policymakers since the gulf operation began, officials said. To keep that support going, Mr. Bush has given three speeches on the issue so far and nine news conferences. The White House announced today that he will address a joint meeting of Congress on Tuesday at 9 P.M., Eastern time.
Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House majority leader, said he also believed that public support would continue.
 
Air-Blockade Proposal
''If the American people understand what is at stake in this case and why we're there, why it's important that we be there, they will support the effort,'' Mr. Gephardt said. But a few of the lawmakers who met with Mr. Bush and who questioned Mr. Baker expressed reservations about some aspects of the military operation and the embargo against Iraq.
For example, Senator John Glenn, Democrat of Ohio, said the United States should begin to block air shipments into Iraq. So far the United States and its allies in the region have only blockaded naval traffic into and out of Iraq, acting under the authority of the United Nations Security Council.
Mr. Baker said the Administration might consider an air blockade if the United Nations' committee on sanctions does not find a way to stop such shipments into Iraq. But he raised it only as a vague possibility and Mr. Fitzwater said Mr. Bush had no plans to expand the military blockade to include aircraft.
 
Hussein Suggestion Dismissed
Mr. Baker and Mr. Fitzwater responded coolly to the Soviet suggestion made by Mr. Shevardnadze on Tuesday that an international conference be convened on the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and other Middle East disputes, including the Israeli occupation of the West Bank.
They suggested that it was merely a new version of an old Soviet proposal that the United States has frequently rejected. Mr. Baker said Washington continued to believe that an Israeli-Palestinian dialogue is the proper way to begin the Middle East peace process.
He said that President Hussein had suggested that the Israeli-Palestinian issue should be linked to the Kuwaiti invasion, adding, ''We, as you know, have minimum low regard for those suggestions.''
Mr. Fitzwater said the Bush Administration did not believe that Moscow was trying to begin a mediation effort in the gulf crisis, despite today's unexpected visit to the Soviet Union by Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz of Iraq. And he made it plain that Mr. Bush would not welcome such a plan.
 
Soviet-Arab Ties and Policy
''We do not feel that's beneficial,'' he said.
Another Administration official said Moscow's talk about a Middle East conference and its discussions with Mr. Aziz reflected a central fact that while the United States and the Soviet Union have cooperated in the gulf to a large degree, their interests and policies are not identical.
''They have a stake in the gulf that is separate from our stake,'' the official said. ''There's basic agreement on preventing aggression, basic agreement on getting Hussein out of Kuwait. But beyond that there are different policies.''
He continued: ''They have a close relationship with certain Arab clientele that requires them to maintain a balance in their policy. At the same time that Gorbachev is putting strong words out and imposing sanctions, he's also trying to show some flexibility toward the Saddam regime.''

HEADLINE: MEDICARE'S WOES FOUND WORSENING

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
Not surprisingly, increases in payments to physicians have been growing at rates well above that of general inflation under Medicare's system of basing payments on customary charges. In the fiscal year ending this month, the amount will grow an estimated 13.2 percent, up from a 10.9 percent rise in the previous year. While payments to hospitals were placed under limits to help rescue the program in 1983 and freezes on physician fees have occasionally been imposed, systematic attempts to limit payments to physicians are only now about to be tried. Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, sent to Congress last Friday a preliminary outline for a national schedule of Medicare fees to physicians, which is to take effect in January 1992.
Another problem is the weakening economy. Medicare payments to doctors are financed from general tax revenues, with an assist from monthly premiums paid by the elderly. The program pays hospitals with money from a tax on payrolls, and this fund is expected to begin to decline in the middle of this decade as its revenues no longer keep up with Medicare's growing costs. If the economy deteriorates more and employment rates drop, tax revenues could fall even further behind Medicare's needs. 
 
The Surge in Outlays
All in all, Medicare outlays are 27 times the $4 billion of 1966, the first year of operation, and are projected to reach $320.8 billion in the year 2000, according to a 1987 Government estimate that assumed moderate inflation rates.
Gail R. Wilensky, the Administrator of the Health Care Financing Administration, which runs Medicare, said the agency's trust fund for hospitals is expected ''to go belly up around 2005.'' But Government actuaries say the fund could run out of money as early as 1999, depending on trends that include the state of the economy, inflation rates and the number of Medicare beneficiaries.
Yet Americans' expectations of Medicare seem to be rising. Consumer advocates and spokesmen for the elderly, like John Rother, legislative director of the American Association of Retired Persons, say the program does not cover some of their most urgent needs, like Alzheimer's disease and other long-term illnesses, as well as medical checkups, dental work, eyeglasses, hearing aids and prescription drugs.
At the same time, doctors and hospitals say they are becoming increasingly disillusioned with the program. Indeed, some doctors are beginning to talk of refusing to accept Medicare patients, citing the growing burden of paperwork and restrictions on fees and on the treatments they will be reimbursed for. For example, a new law that took effect last weekend makes the doctor, instead of the patient, responsible for handling the often confusing paperwork that Medicare requires before it pays.
 
'The Hassle Factor'
And on Jan. 1, a new requirement will limit the added fees that doctors can charge patients to 25 percent of the amount that Medicare pays; there is currently no limit.
Also, experts say the schedules being drawn of what Medicare will pay for a doctor's services may be a step toward more restrictions that will slow the growth in payments to doctors.
''If the hassle factor continues, the reduction in reimbursement continues, finally the doctor gets to the point where he says I don't need this anymore,'' said Dr. James S. Todd, executive vice president of the American Medical Association.
Marilyn Moon, a senior research associate with the Urban Institute, said there was some concern about Medicare following in the path of the Medicaid program for the poor. Many doctors and hospitals now avoid accepting Medicaid patients.
Then again, Ms. Moon noted, elderly patients provide most of the business for most physicians, except in a few specialties, and therefore it would be difficult to turn away such patients.
As for hospitals, 62 percent of them will lose money on Medicare patients this year, said Carol McCarthy, president of the American Hospital Association. Executives of hospitals, which received 55 percent of Medicare spending in 1989, say that like physicians, their institutions must make up the losses through higher fees to private health plans. But employers, who pay a large share of private health insurance, have begun to challenge this shifting of costs and demand discounts from providers of medical care.
 
Money-Saving Strategies
Some experts, like Carolyne K. Davis, a former Medicare Administrator, think Medicare can survive without drastic changes. They say the program can be kept afloat through money-saving strategies, like those used by private health plans, that direct patients to hospitals and doctors selected on the basis of quality of care and cost. They say that eliminating unneeded medical procedures could yield large savings.
But critics like Deborah Steelman, who was an adviser in President Bush's election campaign and heads an advisory council on Social Security and health policy, say the Government program will have to be at least partly dismantled, forcing the elderly to finance even more of their own health bills than they now do.
Medicare already absorbs about 18 percent of the nation's spending on health care, and such expenditures are growing faster than any other part of the economy - about 10 percent each year. Even if the Bush Administration succeeds with its proposal to cut $5.6 billion from the program in 1991, Medicare's budget would still increase to $110.4 billion.
Payments to hospitals - $60 billion in 1989 - are financed by a 1.45 percent tax on employees' wages and a matching amount paid by employers. Most of the payments to physicians ($43 billion this year) come from general tax revenues, with about 27 percent of the total contributed by the $28.60 monthly premiums paid by enrollees. (About $5 billion goes for equipment like wheelchairs, limited home care and administering the program.) ''Either we are going to have to change the financing or change something about what we pay for and how much,'' said Ms. Wilensky, the Medicare Administrator.
 
Would Have Affluent Pay More
Some experts say affluent elderly Americans should pay more of their health costs, freeing Government money to keep the program going. Dr. Todd of the American Medical Association said the elderly should pay Medicare premiums on a scale reflecting their assets.
''But Congress is going to be shy about doing anything that arouses the elderly constituencies,'' said Theodore Marmor, a professor of public policy at Yale University. Many members of Congress were embarrassed last year when elderly voters revolted against a surtax on Medicare premiums for catastrophic illnesses, and the new law was repealed. The more affluent elderly would have paid the highest tax.
Ms. Steelman proposes transferring part of what is covered by Medicare to a new form of Government-regulated private insurance that would be purchased by people during their working years and would cover all medical costs up to, say, $25,000. The money saved by Medicare would be used to pay all costs for the elderly that exceed $25,000, including long-term care and prescription drugs, which are not covered now.
Ms. Steelman conceded that her approach was ''futuristic.'' She said the Government should test her plan with volunteers to see how it works and whether company health plans would participate. Her proposal will be included, along with alternatives, in a report to the President and Congress early next year, Ms. Steelman said.
Dr. Todd called for ''a fundamental change that would first determine the level of health care to which everyone should have access and then decide how to pay for it.'' Noting that ''one-third of Medicare dollars are spent on patients in the last six months of their lives, and a fair amount of it futilely,'' he said that both the medical association and Government health officials are looking at proposals for standards that could ''eliminate care that is unlikely to be beneficial.''
 
Payroll Tax Rise Sought
The medical association also favors an increase of four-tenths of a percent in the payroll tax, and tax incentives to encourage savings for retirement ''so that the individual would have accumulated enough to provide for care for both acute and chronic illnesses.''
Ms. Davis, now a health-care adviser with Ernst & Young, the consulting firm, noted that the trust fund had overcome earlier threats to its survival. ''In 1982,'' she said, ''it looked like the hospital trust fund would be bankrupt by the period between 1986 and 1990.'' The shortage eased after a radical change in Medicare's method of paying hospitals.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 2, 1990, Tuesday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article on Sept. 6 about the financial squeeze on Medicare misstated the limits on physicians' charges to Medicare patients. Since 1987, Medicare has limited what a doctor may charge for each service to an amount based on that doctor's 1984 charges, plus a specified annual increase.

HEADLINE: Seoul Rejects North's Plan to End Hostilities

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 5

 BODY:
There were even jokes and bantering about the weather and a general recognition in comments by both sides that they seem to understand the rationale for each other's positions.
At the morning session in a huge conference hall at the Hotel Intercontinental, a modern luxury hotel on the south side of the Han River, for example, Prime Minister Yon Hyong Muk of North Korea said he recognized that mutual distrust ''stems from the perception that each side is trying to swallow up the other politically and militarily.''
In what struck some listeners as an unusually even-handed appraisal, Mr. Yon said North Korea believed that Seoul and the United States would attack, but he recognized that Seoul was also suspicious that North Korea would attack the South and try to spread Communism. 
''We have to talk heart to heart to eradicate distrust,'' he said. He then presented a nine-point plan for military disarmament, including withdrawal of 43,000 American troops and a ban on American nuclear weapons as a prelude to an overall reduction in troop forces by both sides.
Repeating long reiterated positions, Mr. Yon also called on Seoul to take three immediate steps to build confidence and to make the talks a success this week. Those were to abandon South Korea's bid to enter the United Nations as a separate country, stop joint military exercises with the United States, and release three South Koreans jailed in the last year for unauthorized visits to North Korea.
There were no formal responses to those proposals in the sessions, but Seoul officials made it clear the demands were unacceptable. A senior South Korean official said they would be an infringement on the sovereignty of South Korea and its right to conduct an independent foreign policy.
But South Korean officials said they were delighted that North Korea took the talks seriously enough to outline the proposals, which could now be the basis of future discussions.
Prime Minister Kang Young Hoon of South Korea, in his presentation, outlined a less-sweeping set of proposals to upgrade cultural contacts, family exchanges and to begin joint economic ventures to build confidence and pave the way for future military discussions.
 
'New Kind of Rapport'
But North Korea sees such less-important exchanges as coming at the end of long negotiations on troop levels and arms.
Both Prime Ministers also sounded the theme that it was time for 70 million people on the Korean peninsula to recognize the end of cold-war assumptions elsewhere in the world and bring a reconciliation in one of the last remaining trouble spots that is a relic of East-West tensions.
''The world weather vane has shifted drastically,'' Prime Minister Kang of South Korea said. ''A new kind of rapport, coexistence and cooperation is blowing hard, knocking down ideological and political barriers around the globe. The common wish and hope of our compatriots is that our divided people will be reunited.''
Mr. Kang said that ''if both societies open up to each other, engage in exchanges and cooperation'' and take other limited steps, ''conditions for political integration will ripen.''
North Korea also called for a three-phase reduction of troop strength by North and South.

HEADLINE: Rights Observers Reportedly Ousted in Yugoslavia

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 5

 BODY:
She said the three had been kept several hours at a local police station, and then ordered to leave the country within 24 hours. A report from the Helsinki federation offices in Vienna said Miss von Kohl and the others had ''persona non grata'' stamped in their passports, a detail explicitly denied by the Serbian government.
The Serbian authorities have taken an increasingly hard stand against critics of their handling of the crisis in Kosovo, an autonomous province within Serbia where the population is overwhelmingly Albanian and Muslim. 
The conflict between the majority Albanians and the Serbian government in Belgrade deepened in July when the Serbian republic suspended the authority of Kosovo's legislature and took complete control of the region.
Opposition by Albanian groups has stiffened and this week culminated in a general strike that has effectively shut down the economy of the province. But the Serbian government, led by President Slobodan Milosevic, has refused to have any discussions with leaders of the Albanian opposition groups, who it says are campaigning to break away from Serbia.
As nationalist feeling mounts in Serbia, the largest of Yugoslavia's six republics, any challenge to the Serbian cause - particularly in the long-sensitive region of Kosovo - has been taken by Serbian nationalists both in the Government and in the newly formed opposition as an affront to the nation's dignity and honor.
Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, and Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, were in Kosovo's capital, Pristina, last week when the police, using tear gas and clubs, dispersed an unauthorized but peaceful demonstration by Albanians protesting the suspension of their local government and press. In the violence that followed, 21 people were reported injured, including 7 policemen.
Shocked by the police reaction, Mr. Dole called the Serbian Government's tactics ''Stalinist'' and suggested that he would recommend steering United States aid away from the Serbian republic as long as rights abuses continue.
Last Friday, Aleksandar Prlja, the Serbian spokesman for foreign affairs, accused Mr. Dole and his delegation of helping the cause of Albanian separatists. Mr. Prlja called Mr. Dole ''a known Albanian lobbyist in the Senate and an explicit anti-Serb politician in the United States.''
In an interview today, Mr. Prlja said any steps to deny aid to Serbia would spell the dissolution of Yugoslavia. ''That would be the end of Yugoslavia,'' he said. ''No Yugoslav Government could accept that.''

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
Thatcher Prepares for Costly and Patient Struggle

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Sept. 5

 BODY:
But she said last weekend that sanctions should be given ''a few months'' to work, a formula used again today by one of her top aides. ''If the sanctions policy is consistently applied over time, it could be effective,'' he said. ''I don't think military action is inevitable.'' 
 
Help for Three Nations
At a news conference here today, Mr. Brady said neither the British nor the French had been asked to provide a specific amount to help offset American military expenses. The British have sent ships, planes and about 2,000 military personnel to the gulf to help enforce the United States-led blockade of Iraq, and the French have also sent forces to the region.
Mr. Brady said the money he and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d were now trying to persuade American allies in Europe, the Middle East and Asia to provide included an unspecified amount for the rest of this year that was intended mainly to help Jordan, Egypt and Turkey deal with refugees and economic disruption.
