Britain, France, Sweden, West Germany, Spain and Japan have all already announced plans to send money, food, tents and the like, particularly to Jordan, which is being overwhelmed by tens of thousands of refugees from various countries.
 
Brady Leaves for Korea
Mr. Brady did not say how much money the United States wanted for burden-sharing in 1991. American officials said that besides humanitarian aid, the money was needed partly to offset United States military costs and partly to help international agencies like the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank deal with the economic effects of the crisis.
Mr. Brady left London for Korea today and is expected to go on to Japan from there. Mr. Baker's itinerary this week includes Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Egypt, and he is to consult West Germany, Italy and other NATO allies in Brussels on the burden-sharing plan after the meeting between President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union in Helsinki on Sunday.
Mrs. Thatcher's inner circle is convinced that British public opinion will support a long-range military strategy in the gulf, her aides say, and the Prime Minister expects to see bipartisan approval of the Government's actions in the House of Commons on Thursday.
 
Briton Boycotted in Jordan
AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 5 (Reuters) - Dozens of Jordanian journalists walked out of a news conference given today by the British Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, protesting what they called London's aggressive policy against Jordan and Iraq.
The journalists stalked out of the hall amid applause from colleagues after one read a statement accusing Britain of a ''strategy to humiliate the Arabs and keep them slaves.''
The statement also accused Britain of ignoring Israel's occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip, southern Lebanon and the Golan Heights.
Responding to the walkout, Mr. Hurd said ''one sad consequence'' of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait was that ''world attention is no longer focused on the Palestinian problem.''
''Britain and the world have not forgotten that there was occupation of the West Bank, Gaza and Jerusalem and the need for a solution that took into consideration Palestinian self-determination and Israel's right to security,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
Excerpts From Iraqi Statement Declaring War of 'Right Against Wrong'

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5

 BODY:
It is now your turn, Arabs, to save all humanity and not just save yourselves, and to show the principles and meanings of the message of Islam, of which you are all believers and of which you are all leaders.
It is now your turn to save humanity from the unjust powers who are corrupt and exploit us and are so proud of their positions, and these are led by the United States of America.
Foremost among these Arabs in response to the initiative for the victory of Iraq are the people of the Palestinian intifada, the people of the stones who are fighting the Zionists in their own land, for the occupation is always injust and therefore weak. For in Yemen, Tunis and Libya and Sudan and Mauritania, these are all believers who believe in the Arab world and in Islam. And they know where the truth lies for this will be extended to believers outside the Arab and Islamic world and therefore, this battle will take a human aspect. 
As for the naval and air troops of the United States and all that have accompanied them, it will not - never frighten our rulers, or leadership, or even our people, instead, it will just make us believe more in the route that we have chosen for the victory of our people and of our nation and of humanity. It will never frighten us, the use of their modern weapons or their high technology because we believe in our principles for social justice and the rejection of injustice and weakness.
 
Fighting U.S. Presence
The slogan of believers is, never to turn back. We are sure of victory and we will never let it go of our hands. And through our struggle, many heads will be lost, for God has written this in his holy books. HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
Hussein Hardens Line, Saying Sanctions Deprive Children of Milk

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sept. 5

 BODY:
''The children of Iraq are dying,'' he said, ''because they're being deprived of their milk and their food and their medicine,''
 
An Issue With Emotional Appeal
Mr. Hussein has chosen the emotional issue of denying children their milk as a main theme of his campaign against the trade sanctions, and this line appeared to reach a peak in the message tonight.
Western diplomats said they had heard no reports of people dying of starvation, and say they have seen no evidence of critical shortages of food and medicine four weeks after the sanctions were imposed.
Diplomats who monitor the economy here said milk is still widely available. A woman shopping in an neighborhood grocery store this week said the sanctions had yet to begin affecting her family. 
''There are certain kinds of European baby's milk and foods that you can't find in every store,'' she said, ''but if you keep looking, you will find it.''
 
Concerted Compaign
The Government has been orchestrating street demonstrations of small children and mothers protesting the blockage of milk and medical shipments to Iraq. In Jordan, supporters of the Iraqi leader have paid for big newspaper advertisements to appeal for contributions to buy milk for Iraq's children.
A few more Western women and children who had been detained in Kuwait and Iraq continued to leave Iraq in a small trickle, while thousands of others awaited permission to leave.
An Iraqi Airways jet chartered by the French took 145 Westerners, including 10 Americans, to Jordan, airport officials said. Earlier, two scheduled Iraqi Airways flights took 14 Westerners, including 6 Americans, to Jordan.
The Iraqi Goverment also released messages purportedly from seven hostages, including an American. The hostages who sent the messages were ''at a vital installation,'' the official Iraqi press agency said, but did not indicate where. Diplomatic Solution? Of late, the Iraqi leader had toned down his public statements, and diplomats analyzing the crisis said they believed he sincerely hoped that a diplomatic opening might be found. Washington has also turned down the volume and sharpness of its statements.
There had been hopes here that talks in Amman, Jordan, between Javier Perez de Cuellar, the Secretary General of the United Nations, and Tariq Aziz, the Foreign Minister of Iraq, might lead to a breakthrough.
But two days of meetings ended inconclusively last Friday and Saturday. Iraqi officials have been unwilling to discuss what took place in the meetings but they seem disappointed.
''The meetings were negative,'' said Naji al-Hadithi, Iraq's director general of information. ''The crisis is not something that can easily be solved in one or two meetings.''
King Hussein of Jordan arrived in Baghdad today and went straight into talks with President Hussein, the Iraqi press agency reported. The King has been traveling in the Middle East and Europe, trying to develop a consensus on a plan by which Iraq would pull out of Kuwait, which it seized on Aug. 2, in exchange for a mutual withdrawal of American troops from Saudi Arabia.
The Iraqi agency reported that the President met the Jordanian King at the airport. It was King Hussein's second trip to Baghdad since the invasion of Kuwait. His last visit was on Aug. 13, a day before he went to the United States for a meeting with President Bush.

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
EAST BLOC TO SELL MASKS TO SAUDIS

BYLINE: By CHUCK SUDETIC, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SOFIA, Bulgaria, Sept. 1

 BODY:

 
Offers of Cheap Oil
''They are trying to tempt us with cheap oil, with business for Hungary, with offers to buy all sorts of things,'' Mr. Jeszenszky said in Budapest, adding that Hungary was among the first countries to cut economic relations with Baghdad. ''We'll do our best to get in line with the other East European countries.''
The Western diplomats said they did not know whether the Soviet Union had agreed to sell chemical-weapons protection equipment for Saudi Arabia or whether it played any role in helping to arrange the deal being worked out with the East European countries. 
An official at a Bulgarian arms export company, Kintex, said American diplomats had approached the company for the first time two weeks ago to discuss such a purchase. Once identified by Western inteligence agencies as a major arms supplier to terrorist organizations, Kintex has in the last month sought to recast itself as an above-board arms trading company.
Bulgarian Government officials said they were uncertain whether the United States was buying the equipment for Saudi Arabia or simply arranging the transaction for the Saudi Government, which has no diplomatic ties with Bulgaria.
 
U.S.-Soviet Cooperation
The Kintex official said he thought that the United States and the Soviet Union were cooperating in the transactions. ''Our information is that they're playing this game together,'' he said, adding that the company has also been approached by private Western arms dealers scrambling to purchase chemical-weapons protection and cleanup devices to sell to Saudi Arabia.
''The idea, as we understand it, is to help provide equipment for the needs of the Saudi civilian population,'' a senior Bulgarian official said. ''The object is civil defense.''
''The dimensions of the deal are quite large,'' the Bulgarian official said, but he refused to elaborate because no final agreement has yet been struck. Saudi Arabia has a population of about 17 million.
Western diplomats said that the armed forces of Saudi Arabia and the the United States and other forces there were adequately equipped with protective gear for chemical weapons.
The Bulgarian official denied that oil shipments from Saudi Arabia were a factor in the deal, but he underscored Bulgaria's interest in renewing diplomatic ties with the Saudi Government.
 
Sanctions Strain East Europeans
Hungary, Romania and Bulgaria have been especially hard pressed as a result of the United Nations sanctions against Iraq, which has been a significant oil supplier to these countries.
Bulgaria signed a four-year deal with Iraq in July under which the Iraquis were supposed to supply $1.2 billion in oil to pay off debts to Bulgaria that they incurred during their war with Iran. The Bulgarians counted on the oil to make up for price increases and cutbacks in Soviet oil deliveries.
The country is already feeling the pinch of oil-supply disruptions. Six-hour gasoline lines are the rule throughout Bulgaria, and hourlong electricity cuts have been introduced in the capital, Sofia, to conserve fuel.
Bulgaria has already applied to the United Nations for economic aid predicated on hardships caused by the sanctions.

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
Japanese and Soviets Issue Rare Joint Appeal on Gulf

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 5

 BODY:

 
Arms Suppliers Faulted
''Part of the cause of the current crisis can be placed with those countries that supplied arms to Iraq, which includes the Soviet Union,'' Mr. Nakayama said. ''As the country with the most influence over Iraq, we want you to use that influence to bring about the liberation of hostages of all countries,'' he told his Soviet counterpart, according to a spokesman for the Japanese Foreign Ministry.
Mr Shevardnadze said that Moscow's influence over Mr. Hussein was ''limited'' and added that the Soviet Union was acting to put the United Nations sanctions against Iraq ''into complete effect.'' 
Both Japanese and American officials have been carefully watching Mr. Shevardnadze's words here for clues about what the Soviet position will be when Mr. Gorbachev meets President Bush in Helsinki, Finland, on Sunday. But Mr. Shevardnadze said nothing to suggest that the Soviets had new initiatives to bring to the summit meeting. He made no comment on statements by Secretary of State James A Baker 3d, who said on Tuesday that American troops would be remaining in the gulf for a long time.
The central Soviet-Japanese issue, which is expected to be raised on Thursday when Mr. Shevardnadze and Mr. Nakayama meet, is the dispute over the ownership of four islands that the Soviet Union took in the closing days of World War II.
 
A Quid Pro Quo Wanted
Japan has held out the return of the islands as a prerequisite for economic aid and investment in the battered Soviet economy. The Soviets have so far refused to budge, although the tempo of discussions about the islands has considerably accelerated in recent months. A growing number of Japanese officials are expressing alarm that Tokyo could be left behind in the new era of East-West collaboration if no progress is made.
In recent weeks, some Soviet officials, including Boris N. Yeltsin, the President of the Russian republic, have talked about demilitarizing the islands, which are now used as a base for Soviet troops and aircraft.
Mr. Shevardnadze said today that he was willing to talk about troop reductions, but only in the broader context of Asian-Pacific security issues. So far, Japanese officials have been publicly cool to the idea, for fear that it might lead to reducations in the 60,000 American troops stationed in Japan.
Mr. Shevardnadze also proposed a series of exchanges between the Soviet and Japanese military forces, but Japanese officials said such activities would be premature.
 
Free Exercise of Diplomacy
In the joint statement, the two Foreign Ministers demanded that all restrictions on diplomatic activities in Kuwait be lifted. They also expressed ''grave concern about the conditions of the foreigners detained in Iraq and Kuwait in contravention of the obligation that arises from international law and the norms of human rights.''
Mr. Shevardnadze said that while Soviet women and children have been evaculated from Baghdad, a number of economic experts remained. He did not term them hostages, but left their status in Iraq unclear.
Mr. Shevardnadze will meet with Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu and have an audience with Emperor Akihito and Empress Michiko before he leaves Japan on Friday.

HEADLINE: Crisis of Drugs Remains Top Priority, Bush Says

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5

 BODY:
But his comments were met with skepticism from some lawmakers, who said the Administration's drug strategy was not providing adequate support for treatment and education programs, and was focused too heavily on casual drug users rather than addicts.
 
Criticism on Strategy
''The strategy remains just what it was on Day 1, a nicely packaged pile of paper that lacks true commitment,'' said Representative Charles B. Rangel, a Manhattan Democrat who is chairman of the House Select Committee on Narcotics. ''The Administration's anti-drug strategy has not been responsive to the concerns of inner-city and other chronic drug abusers, whose drug abuse is fueling the crisis.'' 
A year after President Bush gave a nationally televised speech to unveil his drug strategy, the results of the Administration's $10-billion-a-year war on drugs are mixed.
Casual use of illegal drugs appears to be sharply declining, and recent studies have suggested that the nation's cocaine epidemic has peaked. Figures made public last week by the National Institute on Drug Abuse showed that hospital emergency room visits related to cocaine use have dropped by nearly a quarter since last fall.
At the same time, hospital reports of deaths linked to the cocaine and heroin have continued to increase, an indication that drug addiction may be growing even as casual drug use declines. Federal researchers say the number of drug-related slayings could set a record this year.
''I think a prudent and cautious judgment on our present circumstances would be that the drug problem - in general, nationwide - is no longer getting worse,'' William J. Bennett, the national drug policy director, said at today's news conference. ''In some significant areas it is getting better.
On Capitol Hill, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., the Delaware Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, today released his own evaluation of the Bush drug strategy. It said that ''some things appear to be working quite well, others appear to be ineffective, still others may be counterproductive.''
The report, prepared by the committee's Democratic staff, praised President Bush and Mr. Bennett for ''helping to shape the nation's attitudes'' on drug abuse and said their leadership played a ''key role in combating casual drug use, which appears to be plummeting.''
Yet Mr. Biden renewed his criticism that the Administration had put too little money into drug treatment, had failed to recognize the need for drug education programs and was not offering sufficient economic incentives to Latin American nations to encourage them to curb cocaine production.
''Anyone who lives in one our major cities - or a rural town - can tell you, the war on drugs is far from won,'' the report said. ''And on some fronts, we appear to be further behind than we were a year ago today.''
Representative John Conyers Jr., a Democrat who represents Detroit, said, ''Drug czar Bennett and President Bush cannot deny that we are losing the drug war in our inner cities.''
Mr. Conyers, chairman of the House Government Operations Committee, said the Adminstration's drug strategy was focused too heavily on law enforcement and had failed to address problems in low-income urban areas.
''We will never win this war on drugs until we rethink and refocus the priorities of the drug strategy,'' he said.

SECTION: Section A; Page 22, Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 707 words

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
Drug War Underlines Fickleness Of Public

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5

 BODY:
Why? Clearly one possibility can be dispensed with. Not even those who believe there are some hopeful signs suggest that the drug scourge has vanished.
The answer is more in the public mind than on the nation's streets. A review of the entire episode teaches a great deal about the alliance of Presidents and news directors, as well as something about the pitfalls of policy by polling public opinion. 
''I can tell you exactly why it happened,'' said Robert Lichter, of the Center for Media and Public Affairs, a private, nonpartisan group that monitors television coverage of Washington. Mr. Lichter said the waxing and waning of attention is an illustration of how a President, with the help of the press corps, can shape the national agenda, at least temporarily.
In the summer of 1989, concern about the drug problem was on the rise. In July, 22 percent of the public said drugs were the nation's most important problem, already a high number.
Robert Bezilla, a poll taker long affiliated with the Gallup organization who has studied the rise of the drug issue, noted that it emerged at a quiescent moment, before the appearance of either of today's most prominent fears, recession at home and war in the Persian Gulf.
In mid-August of 1989, the White House let it be known the President would address the issue in a speech on prime-time television. Journalists responded. Mr. Lichter said that in the last two weeks of August and the first few days of September the three network news programs each ran an average of nearly three stories a night about drugs, as against fewer than one a night before the President set plans for his speech.
Then, a year ago today, Mr. Bush gave his speech declaring a war on drugs. It was the only prime-time television talk to the nation he has given. For the next week, the network news programs each averaged four stories a night about drugs, Mr. Lichter said.
''There was this tremendous upsurge in media coverage associated with Bush's speech and that drove the issue way up in the public consciousness,'' Mr. Lichter said. That was when The New York Times/CBS News poll found 64 percent of the public put drugs at the top of the agenda.
''Then it went away,'' Mr. Lichter said. ''Other issues came in. The media stopped covering it, and the public stopped thinking about it as much.''
Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Manhattan, said part of the reason the media stopped paying attention was because Cabinet members were not speaking out about the crisis in their areas of authority, for instance the way hospitals were overwhelmed by the victims of drug violence.
So what purpose did this temporary surge in interest serve? In his speech last year Mr. Bush said one of his first missions as President would be ''to keep the national focus on our offensive against drugs.''
The White House is sensitive to criticism that Mr. Bush expressed concern about a problem and then wandered off. So on the first anniversary of that speech Mr. Bush held a news conference today to say that curbing drug use remained the nation's top priority, even if ''other subjects preoccupy all of us these days.''
But in recent politics there always seems to be another subject to preoccupy the public. Who even talks about the Berlin Wall or Tiananmen Square any more? Getting the public's attention, particularly on a subject that the polls show is already gnawing at people, is no real trick for a President, even a President who lacks a knack for the bully pulpit part of his job. The trick is holding that attention.

HEADLINE: ACID RAIN REPORT CONFIRMS CONCERN

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHABECOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5

 BODY:

 
Major Conclusions
In its final draft report, made public today, the study group found that scientific evidence ''clearly demonstrated'' these conclusions:
* Aquatic life is being damaged by acid rain in about 10 percent of eastern lakes and streams. But much of the damage is probably caused when snow melts in the spring, pouring concentrated amounts of acid water into the streams.
* Visibility is being reduced in the eastern United States and in some metropolitan areas of the West.
* Acid rain is contributing to the erosion and corrosion of stone and metal structures. 
* Acid rain is reducing the ability of red spruce trees at high altitudes to withstand the stress caused by cold temperatures.
The study group, made up of representatives from government agencies, also found evidence of a number of other effects, including the probability that the pollutants that cause acid rain may be causing respiratory illness and other health effects in humans.
While the group found that ''the majority of North American forests are healthy,'' its computer projections also found that acid rain may produce nutrient deficiencies that would lead to forest decline in the decades ahead.It also found that acid rain may be contributing to the decline of sugar maples in some areas of eastern Canada, although the maple problem is related to ''localized soil nutrient deficiencies.''
 
Key Sources of Emissions
The report confirmed that emissions of sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxides, many of them originating at coal-fired power plants in the Midwest, are, as scientists have long believed, the source of acid precipitation - acidic rain, snow, fog and dry particles. Ozone, a pollutant formed in the lower atmosphere when volatile chemicals from auto exhausts and other sources react with sunlight, also contributes to the damage attributed to acid rain, the report said.
At a news briefing today, members of the study group said that the findings provide a firmer basis for policy making. But they conceded that the study, which cost $537 million to prepare, left a number of important questions unanswered, including the economic cost of acid rain damage.
James R. Mahoney, director of the program, said that the findings were surrounded by ''considerable uncertainty.''
But he also said that the work of the program ''significantly reduced the scientific uncertainties about acidic deposition processes and effects.'' ''Many, but not all, of the scientific consensus views reported in the early 1980's have been supported by more recent studies,'' he said, ''but the more extreme views in both directions expressed by some individual scientists and in some of the media have been rendered unlikely to be correct.''
Dr. Mahoney said that energy conservation should be first of the list of permanent measures to be taken to resolve the long-term problem of acid rain.
 
Reactions Are Mixed
Industry groups said the report showed that damage from acid rain was less than feared and that there was no need to rush into expensive control measures.
Thomas R. Kuhn, president of the Edison Electric Institute, an association of privately owned electric utilities, said, ''The most compelling results of the study point out that damage from acid rain is much less than we feared in the late 1970's and early 1980's.''
Environmentalists said the report included little that was new and made little difference in terms of policy.
David Hawkins, a lawyer and air pollution expert for the Natural Resources Defense Council, said that ''President Bush was wise not to wait'' for the report to formulate an acid rain proposal.
''Little comes out of it that we didn't know before we started,'' he added.
Among the unanswered questions, Mr. Hawkins said, are the long-term effects on forests and the details of health risks.
''Our reaction is that this is a very expensive exercise in documenting the obvious,'' he said.
The final report will be made public in the next few months after the public has a chance to comment on the draft.
Eileen B. Claussen, the E.P.A. representative on the panel, said that while the report had not definitively cleared up all the issues, it underscored the need for the acid rain control legislation proposed by President Bush. That legislation would cut sulfur dioxide emissions by 10 million tons, nearly half of current levels.

HEADLINE: Where's Their Fair Share?

 BODY:
So far, with the exception of Britain, France and Saudi Arabia, the nations arrayed against Iraq have offered practically nothing.
The forces gathering against Iraq are called a united military effort. So far, they consist essentially of some 100,000 soldiers and sailors from the United States, 2,000 from Egypt and 7,000 from all our European allies. And the American taxpayer has been picking up almost all the cost, with significant help only from the Saudis plus a modest recent pledge of $1 billion by Japan. 
Senator Sam Nunn, no alarmist, now estimates that the gulf crisis could cost $50 billion over the next 12 months for military operations and economic aid to victimized states. That's twice the Bush Administration estimate; it sounds more prudent. There is no way Americans can be expected to shoulder so much of that burden.
West Europeans and Japan rely on gulf oil even more than the U.S. does. That's the practical reason to insist that they meet their responsibilities. There's also a principled reason. They all profess their determination to resist Iraq's aggression.
The arguments some Europeans and Japanese make for vacillating are almost as repellent as the vacillation. For instance, some of their leaders say they feel awkward about giving money for U.S. military operations because that will make Americans look like mercenaries.
Yes? Well, better to look like mercenaries than like sideline soldiers or deadbeats, eager for us to protect their oil with our blood. Let them send more of their own forces. That goes for the British, French and Egyptians as well.
The Germans and the Japanese beg off on the grounds that their Constitutions forbid military action beyond their borders. That's understandable. But it should not traduce their constitutional consciences to dispatch minesweepers or doctors or transport ships and planes - or cash. With American lives on the line, this kind of hair-splitting sounds cynical.
In recent days, Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady and Secretary of State James Baker have been asking members of the European Community to shoulder specific financial responsibilities, notably to help shield the new democracies of Eastern Europe and refugees in Jordan. And brave Turkey desperately needs trade and aid help to offset its sacrifice. The American officials also are asking help to offset the costs of keeping forces in Europe. These requests are necessary, and just. The European Community foreign ministers meet in Rome tomorrow to discuss these matters. If they want aggression to be defeated, energy prices and supplies kept secure and a voice in matters of war and peace, they will have to stop playing games and start paying their share.

HEADLINE: Yes, We Can Retool As Cold War Ends

 BODY:
Thousands of smaller defense contractors, vital for regional economies, may be the most fertile ground for diversification. A survey of small to mid-size Ohio-based defense contractors shows most of their contracts averaged one year or less. And many small shops are set up to service one or two larger contractors.
The Pentagon can help break down barriers between the defense and commercial marketplaces. Obviously, fighter aircraft and commercial transports are entirely different animals. But what about electronics and computer chips, where defense and commercial customers increasingly use the same technology?
The Defense Science Board disclosed that standard commercial microchips were 5 to 10 years ahead of those the Pentagon buys and just as rugged. If the Defense Department could fill more of its needs by buying products off the shelf, companies could use the same technology, products and work forces for orders in both markets, according to Norman Augustine, chief executive officer of Martin Marietta.
Agencies like the Commerce and Labor Department could point out areas of emerging technology, export opportunities and contracting possibilities with other Federal agencies.
We all have a stake in the post-cold war era. Let's not simply leave our future in the hands of a few company officials.
 
BETTY G. LALL
EUGENE CHOLLICK
New York, Aug. 21, 1990
 The writers are, respectively, project director and researcher at the Council of Economic Priorities, a public-interest research group.

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
Forget About Gulfo

BYLINE: By William Safire

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Here are four graphs on burden-sharing from a two-decade supporter of the Mansfield Amendment: 1. Money: The $8-a-barrel rise in oil prices since the invasion, combined with the two-million-barrel-a-day increase in production by the emirates and the Saudis, means added profit to them of $3 billion a month, a third of that from the U.S. alone. That windfall should be for protection, not profiteering; all money generated by the blockade of Iraqi-Kuwaiti oil should be escrowed in the Overthrow-Saddam Fund. 2. Arab participation: The states to benefit most from the realignment of the Arab world are Egypt, our ally, and Syria, our bedfellow. Cairo should put 50,000 soldiers in Saudi Arabia soon if it wants to assume Arab leadership; Damascus should mass its 4,000 tanks on its Iraqi border to force Mr. Hussein to split his forces. 3. European troops: Turkey, a NATO member, has a long border with Iraq. NATO forces should be moved quickly from facing the Soviets to NATO's southern flank to face its new military-economic threat. Ships, planes and French tokenism are not enough; unless NATO nations are willing to put soldiers on the new front line, the U.S. will speed its NATO drawdown. 4. Soviet double-gaming: Mr. Bush should tell Mr. Gorbachev to choose sides. A thousand Russians are even now teaching Iraqi troops how to use the most modern Soviet equipment to kill Americans; not only should they be withdrawn forthwith, but the largest army in the world should participate actively in the world police action. 
How's that for burden-sharing? To the extent that freeloaders defect, beg off and goldbrick, we can grumble and retaliate - but not lay down the burden. That is because our vital national interest lies in keeping a proven aggressor and poison-gasser from becoming a nuclear power.
Now we can address a trio of optimistic assumptions that afflict the self-negotiators of C.C.I.: 1. Saddam Hussein can be persuaded to leave Kuwait. If only we give him a fig leaf - like knocking over the Kuwaiti rulers, with a permanent payoff from Kuwaiti oil profits - doves hope he will be a reasonable fellow.
But he has burned his bridges in giving back his Iranian waterway conquest. Without Kuwait, he has no gulf outlet; this is not only a matter of ''face,'' but plain power and money. He won't budge. 2. A blockade will make him reasonable. He put his people through eight years of privation in war with Iran for no gain and remains in power. As we starve Iraq, he will starve our hostages on TV; the crueler side will win, and that is not our side. 3. Patient squeezing will get him to close his poison-gas plants and stop building nuclear bombs.
This notion, at the base of every C.C.I. editorialist's proposed deal, elevates wishful thinking to world-class self-delusion. Why on earth should he give up the fearsome power that has made him the most dangerous man in the world? When has a despot bent on dominance ever voluntarily emasculated his source of terror?
Incredibly, Secretary of State Baker encourages daydreams of a tamed Saddam Hussein by proposing an open-ended sojourn - a Gulfo, or regional Persian Gulf organization patterned on NATO - to ''contain'' rather than defeat the Iraqi dictator. Westerners would sail about in airconditioned warships while neighborhood troops would patrol his borders for decades.
The Gulfo notion is as divorced from reality as the Concerned Isolationists' dream that peaceful squeezing will cause the aggressor to regurgitate Kuwait and disarm.
Gulfo is being advanced to conjure a vision of a deal that fails to deal with Mr. Hussein's nuclear buildup -a false promise of ''all sharing the burden'' of containment forever.
The typesetter rightly recognized this as wimpish mush. Either the Butcher of Baghdad will be defeated, or he will give new meaning to ''the nuclear club.''

LENGTH: 1339 words

HEADLINE: Boat Club: A Haven in a Wave of Condos

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN

 BODY:
Inside the yacht club's rusty gates, there are no more yachts to speak of. Old boats litter the boatyard, with weeds grazing on their wooden hulls, and the ranks of fishermen who still fish have dwindled. Much of the hard work around the clubhouse is done by the Coke machine, which dispenses Budweisers.
Even at the end of Clasons Point, a place largely hidden from the violence and decay of neighborhoods just across the Bronx River, the club has never fashioned itself as an island. If its members have kept a distance, they say, it has been through their vision of the club as a good, quiet place in a stormy world.
But as though after a rain, pastel-colored condominiums have sprouted along the last stretch of Soundview Avenue. And where the avenue ends at the Point Yacht Club, members have begun to fear for its survival. 
''We're being surrounded,'' said Arthur Seifert, who has spent all of his 64 years in the area, the last 20 of them as a member of the club. ''The condominiums have changed everything.''
The powerful Manhattan real-estate developers building Shorehaven, as their condominium venture is called, describe it as the largest nonsubsidized residential development in Bronx memory. Stepping carefully around fears that 1,158 new middle-income neighbors might overwhelm a community ensconced in old bungalows and beached houseboats, the developers have drawn local politicians strongly behind them. And for the moment, with about 200 of the condo units built, spokesmen for Shorehaven say they have no designs on the city-owned land that the Point Yacht Club leases month to month.
As waterfront property, the land cannot be sold. But the club, which inherited the site from a homesteader who received the title for his service in the Spanish-American War, pays only $450 a month in rent.
 
Assurances and Fears
At auction, the lease might command 10 times that amount. And despite assurances that the land's use is not now in debate, club members fear that once it is - perhaps after Shorehaven fills with new homeowners -the value of their investment might not register on the scales of a city more desperate each year for cash.
''You know how when they give a toy to a little kid and he loves it more than anything?'' said Felix Hernandez, the club's rear commodore. ''That's how I feel about this place.'' Mano, as Mr. Hernandez is known, does not have the look of a sentimental man. Large and round, with the leathery skin of a life in the sun, he spends off-hours driving cleaning machinery over Orchard Beach for the Parks Department. Around the club he is described as a Hemingwayesque figure, presumably because he is one of the few older men who still venture out to sea.
But legends swirl around other club members, particularly when they sit down to sip refreshments by the clubhouse pool table or the shaded benches outside.
 
A 52-Pound Lobster
Among them is Billy J. Pajer, a fisherman turned building maintenance man whose best fish story involves the capture of a 52-pound lobster and its eventual sale to a Cuban restaurateur on the Seventh Avenue IRT. There is Mr. Seifert, a sometime adventurer, knickknack collector and backyard inventor who once imported a 1909 Swedish trolley car to Brooklyn, where it rolled about a mile. And there is the Point Yacht Club's commodore, Anibal (Tex) Texeira, whose three decades as a New York City homicide detective hold tales like the time he went undercover as a psychiatric patient in Bellevue Hospital to catch a murderer.
Among the honorary members is Ramond Masa, 42, a crusader for the rights of the disabled. Better known as Megaman, Mr. Masa, who comes by the club to water-ski, has sought to inspire other paraplegics like himself with such actions as dangling in his wheelchair from the Brooklyn Bridge, samurai swords in hand.
''We don't get normal people,'' Mr. Pajer said.
To such men, there is no confusing the club's essence with the sum of its battered parts. As their eyes wander the grounds, they pass over the old tires, the rusty oil drums, the weeds dotted with weathered bits of plastic. Instead, they are drawn toward the horizon, fixing on the slate-blue clubhouse, the picnic tables or the few small fishing craft still bobbing off the end of their dock.
 
'A Lot of Character'
Not so long ago, they recalled, theirs was but one of half a dozen yacht clubs in the area. They were nice places but not fancy, the collective memory holds, the kind of clubs where everyone knew each other.
''I tell you it had a lot of character,'' Mr. Seifert, who is also a historian, said of the area. ''It was almost like Coney Island.''
By most accounts, Clasons Point saw its best days after World War I. At the end of a trolley line, the Clasons Point amusement park, the site of what was at least momentarily the world's biggest swimming pool, was still going strong. Bootleggers favored the creeks running out of the point, and its casinos, Gilligan's and Kane's, were frequented by such gangster notables as Pretty Boy Floyd and Legs Diamond, Mr. Seifert has written.
But through the Depression and the next World War, decay was quick. Shipbuilding petered out along the waterfront, boatyards closed and the abandoned lots grew over with weeds. In the 1950's and 60's, a local doctor built the Shorehaven Beach Club into a favorite weekend retreat of middle-class Jewish families from the Bronx, but by the 1970's it too was fighting weeds.
Even before a consortium of Manhattan developers received approval three years ago to build condominiums on the beach club's old site, Clasons Point and the Point Yacht Club had already started to change.
In nearby Harding Park, Hispanic families had begun to move in alongside the European immigrants who had lived there for years. Down the point, the park alongside the club swarmed each night with drug users, prostitutes and other unwelcome revelers, the police said.
 
New Recruits for Club
The club, its membership dominated by names like Smitty or Jasinski, found itself under some pressure from local politicians to integrate. It found Mr. Texeira when he helped to fix a small legal problem for a friend of the then-commodore. And along with Joe Rodriguez, a decorated Bronx firefighter, Mr. Texeira found new recruits by the handful.
The 48 members, who now include 35 Puerto Ricans and two women, elected Mr. Texeira commodore last year. With carpenters, electricians and plumbers among them, the members say they could easily muster the funds and expertise to overhaul the club - if they had more security than a month-to-month lease.
''I know it's an eyesore,'' said Mr. Texeira, a tough-talking man who says he lives in fear of lawyers who have stopped by from time to time on behalf of the Shorehaven development. ''If we had a lease, we could really bring this place up.''
Still, most members see some blessings mixed with Shorehaven's negative points - a new park for Clasons Point, more police patrols, economic betterment for the borough. They just wish they could be around to enjoy it, they say.
''What's nicer than a flag and a boat?'' Mr. Seifert asked as he stood one afternoon on the club's dock, an old barge that some tug-captain friends hauled up years ago in exchange for bottles of whisky and steak dinners. ''They just don't appreciate what we are.''

HEADLINE: No End to Rising Subway Crime; It May Get Worse, Chief Asserts

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
Contributing to the rise in subway crime, he said, are the many juvenile repeat offenders, who often commit crimes within days of being released.
 
Juveniles Heavily Involved
More than 25 percent of all subway robberies are committed by juveniles, like the gang of youths who the police said killed Brian Watkins of Provo, Utah, on Sunday night when he tried to stop them from beating and robbing his parents at the 53d Street subway station in Manhattan.
In the first six months of 1990, the number of reported felony crimes committed in the subways rose 17 percent, to 8,977 felonies, compared with 7,663 in the first half of 1989. Transit police officials attribute the increase to a sharp rise in robberies, which jumped 22 percent, to 4,518 reported incidents in the first half of 1990, compared with 3,714 in the same period last year. 
''The numbers are not going down and will probably not go down for a while,'' said Chief Bratton, who succeeded Vincent Del Castillo, who resigned under pressure because of rising crime. ''These kids have no sense of the results of their actions. They fail to understand that if you stab someone, the person might die. These kids live for the minute and don't have value systems like the rest of society.''
 
Preventive Actions Taken
Mr. Bratton said that in the last five months he started a number of programs to deter subway crime, like conducting sweeps to arrest fare evaders; putting more officers in plainclothes to foil robbers; giving experienced officers incentives to stay on patrol duty, where they are needed most, and working with the Family Court to insure that repeat subway offenders serve time in jail.
But critics of the transit police said those efforts would not be effective until there were more transit officers in the subways who were committed to enforcing the law and ferreting out crime.
The present force is short 500 officers, and many of the officers would prefer to be on the New York City Police force.

LENGTH: 963 words

HEADLINE: Rinfret Proposes Cutting Spending and Taxes to Bridge Gaps

BYLINE: By FRANK LYNN

 BODY:
''He's going to Florio New York,'' Mr. Rinfret said of Mr. Cuomo, referring to Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey, whose tax increases just after he took office in January have touched off a taxpayer rebellion.
 
Fiscal Steps
Mr. Rinfret's proposed these fiscal steps:
* Freezing state spending next year, an action that would mean no pay increases for state workers.
* Reducing the state work force by 20 percent through attrition.
* Placing a lid on state school aid. Mr. Rinfret said the state's problems in education reflected ''a teaching problem, not a problem of money.'' 
* Eliminating the $150 million excellence in teaching program and replacing it with a $50 million program of school excellence incentive awards.
* Performing a ''complete overhaul'' of Medicaid, including transferring 240,000 welfare recipients of the state-run health insurance program to private insurance carriers.
Mr. Rinfret tackled a sensitive legislative pork barrel item when he said that he would ''gut'' the $120,000 budget line that enables legislators to give grants to favorite organizations and programs within their districts.
 
Tax Cuts Over 4 Years
On the tax side of the ledger, Mr. Rinfret pledged a $5.5 billion tax-reduction package over four years. His tax proposals included these:
* An accelerated phase-in of state income tax reductions, reducing the state's top income tax rate to 7 percent by 1992, a year sooner than Mr. Cuomo would.
* An exemption of $150 in clothing purchases from the state and city sales tax.
* A reduction in local property taxes through a five-year elimination of the local contribution to Medicaid.
* An elimination of the gross receipts taxes on utilities that are passed on to consumers.
* A three-year reduction in the 15 percent business tax surcharge.
* A change in state estate taxes to conform with the more liberal Federal allowances.
 
Issue of School Aid
Mr. Rinfret's plan comes after Mr. Cuomo and the State Legislature approved a $1.8 billion tax-increase package this year. A $1 billion package of tax and fee increases was approved last year, when a tax cut also went into effect .
Most of the programs that he would freeze or change and the taxes he would cut have been approved by his fellow Republicans in the State Senate majority. But his campaign manager, Assemblyman John Faso of Kinderhook, acknowledged that even Republican legislators would resist a ban on any more state school aid. Long Island Republicans, including the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino of Oyster Bay. are particularly strong supporters of school aid.
But Mr. Rinfret left himself an escape hatch when he said his proposals ''were not set in concrete'' except for a no-tax-increase pledge for next year. ''That is set in concrete,'' he said. Mr. Rinfret, who acknowledged that he had been ''ambivalent'' about the proposed $1.9 billion environmental bond issue being promoted by the Governor, said in response to a question in Manhattan that he would vote against it in November. ''Can we afford this when the state is broke?'' he asked.
State Comptroller Edward V. Regan, the only Republican elected statewide in 1986, announced his opposition to the bond issue on Tuesday - putting the two leading Republican candidates at odds not only with Democrats but also with the Republican State Senate leadership, which favored the borrowing, subject to voter approval.
 
'Simplistic in the Extreme'
Mr. Rinfret said his staff and Republican legislative aides had been working on the fiscal package for two months and insisted that he was not engaged in the fiscal gimmickry that he has accused the Governor of. ''I wouldn't be so stupid,'' he said.
But some legislative aides questioned how politically realistic some of the Mr. Rinfret's proposals were. The Governor's press secretary, Gary Fryer, called the package ''simplistic in the extreme.'' Addressing the proposed cuts in the 120,000-member state work force, Mr. Fryer said there had been effectively a freeze on state employees during the Cuomo administration except for prisons, parole and probation and the state police. He added that 70 percent of state spending went back to localities so that any major cuts would drive up local taxes.
Mr. Rinfret said he could finance these tax reductions by leveling off state spending that would in turn encourage economic growth. ''We're saying no more increases, stop the growth in spending,'' he declared at a news conference.
Mr. Rinfret said several times that the Governor had ''stolen'' funds from pension systems and other reserves to balance his current budget and that such one-time revenues would leave a $1.5 billion gap in the state budget next year even before anticipated increases in welfare, Medicaid and capital spending that would widen the gap to a minimum of $2.5 billion.

HEADLINE: Dukakis Orders Further Cuts As State Tax Collections Fall

That prompted Mr. Dukakis to order his Cabinet to make cuts of about 4 percent of executive branch spending.

HEADLINE: Budget Negotiators Prepare for a Last-Ditch Effort to Cut the Deficit

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5

 BODY:
Then, with their opening bids on the table, Mr. Darman and about two dozen lawmakers from both parties will begin an isolated weekend of bargaining in an effort to reconcile these positions that have long been irreconcilable.
 
Little Headway in 3 Months
These same people made little headway in three months of talks this the spring and summer.
Now they are faced not only with an economy that appears much weaker than it did when their discussions broke up early last month, but also with a military commitment in the Middle East of unknown cost and duration. That would seem to mitigate against an agreement. 
But one factor - the calendar -leads the negotiators to think they can reach an agreement over the weekend. If nothing is done, across-the-board spending cuts of more than 40 percent in most Government activities, including the military, will go into effect automatically starting on Oct. 1, at the start of the fiscal year 1991. Such cuts are seen by both sides as untenable.
The automatic cuts would result because the deficit forecast for fiscal 1991 is far above the $64 billion ceiling set by the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget-balancing law.
 
Projected Budget Deficit
Last month Mr. Darman put the prospective deficit in the $1.2 trillion budget at almost $170 billion if the savings and loan bailout is not counted, and at $232 billion if the bailout is included. This afternoon, just before meeting with Republican lawmakers, the budget director said changes in the economy in the last month had probably pushed the top figure to $250 billion.
Both sides acknowledge that the target under the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law will have to be changed. All agree that the economy would collapse under a deficit reduction package of $100 billion or more.
But they also say that changing the budget law without making what an Administration economist called ''a down payment on some enduring budget reduction strategy'' would be economically and politically disastrous.
The financial markets, they say, would conclude that the politicans did not have the stomach to make even a modest dent in the deficit, sending interest rates soaring in the face of likely inflation.
Politically, said Representative Leon E. Panetta, the California Democrat who heads the House Budget Committee, ''neither party can face the election without having something in place.''
 
Need for a Credible Plan
Keynesian analysis suggests that raising taxes and reducing spending is the wrong medicine for an economy on the verge of recession. But economists in the Administration and Congress are convinced that the drag of a $50 billion deficit reduction package would be offset by lower interest rates.
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, has said for years that the Fed would be able to drive rates down if the politicians enacted a credible long-term deficit-reduction plan.
Mr. Darman and Mr. Gephardt told reporters today that they were committed to cutting the deficit by $50 billion in the fiscal year 1991 and by $500 billion cumulatively over the next five years. Other lawmakers and officials, including Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, made similar statements publicly.
But, pushed on what they really think, lawmakers and Administration officials said the most optimistic outcome was a deficit reduction of perhaps $40 billion and that $25 billion was more probable.
 
How to Cut $25 Billion
Stanley E. Collender, a budget specialist at Price Waterhouse, the accounting firm, who probably follows the negotiations more closely than any other expert outside the Government, suggested how the budget negotiators might arrive at the $25 billion figure.
Before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, negotiators were considering Pentagon spending cuts of $10 billion to $12 billion. But given the new military commitment, Mr. Collender said, $6 billion is the largest reduction that could be expected.
Democrats in Congress are unlikely to accept bigger cuts in domestic spending than in military spending, he said, so the most that could be taken from the domestic ledger would be $6 billion. That makes $12 billion in spending cuts.
The Administration and Republican lawmakers, Mr. Collender said, will not let taxes be raised more than spending is cut, so the largest possible tax increase is $12 billion. Adding $1 billion for reduced interest costs that would result from the lower deficit, and Mr. Collender comes up with $25 billion.
''What drives it is how much defense can be cut,'' he said.
 
'There Has Got to Be Symmetry'
Without accepting Mr. Collender's figures, Mr. Panetta said the reasoning was sound. ''Whether anybody likes it or not, there has got to be symmetry,'' he said.
Senator Jim Sasser, the Tennessee Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, said he hoped to persuade his colleagues that the military spending in the Persian Gulf was such an ''extraordinary, temporary cost'' that it should be counted separately from other military expenditures.
Some economists in the Administration and Congress said a $50 billion cut in next year's deficit would have been reasonable if it had been enacted last spring, but might not be wise now. They contended that the Federal Reserve's monetary policy wsould take time to affect the economy, and that even if lower interest rates became effective this month it might be too late to offset higher taxes and lower spending across the economy.
Thus, the economists said, tax and spending changes might have to be postponed until April instead of becoming effective in October or January, and that would limit their impact in the next fiscal year.
One Administration economist suggested that the spending and tax decisions could have a ''safety valve'' that delayed them automatically if the economy turned really sour.
Until now, Mr. Darman has shared the budget negotiations with John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, and Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady. But Mr. Sununu will be with the President in Helsinki this weekend, and Mr. Brady will not return until Saturday from a trip around the world to raise money from allies to offset the effect of the conflict in the Persian Gulf.

HEADLINE: End-of-Year Shortage of Oil Forecast

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5

 BODY:
Mr. Easton said the loss of exports from Iraq and Kuwait was about 4.3 million barrels a day, of which about 3.3 million would be made up by the additional output agreed to by Saudi Arabia and other oil producers.
 
Private Economists Pessimistic
While he suggested that over time key areas of the country could find heating oil in short supply, private economists painted a much grimmer picture. ''We are convinced that the usable commercial crude oil stocks will be depleted by the end of October,'' said Edward N. Krapels, president of Energy Security Analysis in Washington, a consulting firm that tracks the price of oil. 
Mr. Krapels added that the daily shortfall in production could easily reach two million barrels, pushing the price of oil to $40 a barrel.
That prediction is significantly larger than the one made by the 21-nation International Energy Agency, which estimated last month that oil-producing countries could make up for all but 500,000 barrels of the loss from Iraq and Kuwait.
Mr. Easton, as one of the first representatives of the Bush Administration to testify on the energy supply situation since Congress returned from its August vacation, encountered a host of worried lawmakers, who expressed frustration over the rising cost of gasoline, accused the oil industry of price gouging and criticized the Administration for refusing to tap the nation's 560-million-barrel reserve to ease rising prices. Most members of Congress have supported Mr. Bush's actions.
''Despite urging from many in Congress, the Administration refused to ease the pain of consumer price increases by drawing down the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, which could have prevented both a shortfall and Wall Street speculation about it,'' said John Conyers Jr., Democrat of Michigan and chairman of the committee.
''The U.S. is being held hostage, not by Saddam Hussein, but at the gas pump,'' said Chuck Douglas, Republican of New Hampshire.
 
Collusion Issue Played Down
Mr. Easton also tried to play down questions about collusion by the oil industry to push prices up. ''I don't think we have enough empirical evidence at this point to make statements like that,'' he said.
The members of the panel pressed him on how the Administration was planning to address the problem of the country's growing dependence on imported oil. While he said the first priority would be to promote a more efficient use of fuel, Mr. Easton added that the Administration was looking at a series of tax breaks to promote production, as well as efforts to open up drilling in new areas.
But he declined repeatedly to be specific, saying that more than 700 proposals had been submitted to the Energy Department, which will propose a policy to the President by the end of the year. He added that the President would make his recommendations to Congress by early next year.

HEADLINE: Ripple Effect of Soviet Oil Drop

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
In addition, early this year Moscow stopped its worldwide marketing of Iraqi oil, which it had received in exchange for arms shipments, according to experts. Experts say Iraq produced that oil, estimated at 145,000 to 200,000 barrels a day last year, outside its quota set by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, and its loss further reduces world supplies.
The Soviet Union's own exports will average about 3.3 million barrels a day this year, down from 3.7 million barrels a day last year, according to Robert E. Ebel, the vice president for international affairs of the Enserch Corporation of Dallas. Mr. Ebel, a former Government intelligence officer, said that in 1988 exports reached 4.1 million barrels a day.
Eastern European countries that took about half the Soviet exports, paying for them through barter or in currencies that are not freely exchangeable on world markets, have borne the brunt of the export cuts, according to Western experts. Some of that crude was refined and sold to Western countries. They were also major users and processors of Iraqi oil, generally acquired by barter. 
There is also some reduction in sales of Soviet crude to Western European countries that paid in hard currency, but Soviet oil income could still rise because the price of a barrel is up sharply.
The Soviet Union is the world's biggest oil producer, but as an exporter it trails Saudi Arabia, the world's largest, which had an OPEC quota of 5.38 million barrels under the last agreement before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. But it is ahead of Iraq, which had a quota of 3.14 million barrels, and Kuwait, which had a quota of 1.5 million. The United Nations-led embargo has denied world markets the 4.6 million barrels a day from Iraq and Kuwait, but OPEC has authorized other members to produce more oil to try to make up the loss.
The United States is the second-largest producer, with about 8.5 million barrels a day of crude oil and condensates, but it also the world's largest importer, buying about the same amount it produces, in normal times.
Compared with these numbers, the Soviet declines are small, but they come at a time of market tightness.
The Iraqi barter with the Soviet Union ended early this year, months before the invasion of Kuwait. Robert Mabro, director of the Oxford Institute for Energy Studies, said that the Iraqis had been paying for ''arms, flour, tractors, whatever,'' and that none of the oil actually went to the Soviet Union; it was simply sold or re-bartered. Western experts are not sure why the barter stopped; one suggested that it was for a debt that had been paid off.
With demand heightened by tourism and other factors, Eastern European countries like Yugoslavia and Bulgaria, which were large users of Iraqi oil either through direct barter or through the Soviet Union, are importing refined products, adding to the pressure on Western European refineries, according to Western experts. And oil traders in New York say that demand for gasoline in Europe is so strong now that some cargoes have gone from the Gulf Coast of the United States to northwestern Europe, opposite the normal flow, driving up prices in the United States.
Moscow was also channeling 90,000 barrels a day of Iraqi oil to India, and is reportedly making that up from domestic production. With that diversion and the decline in Soviet output, deliveries to Eastern Europe are down by 30 percent, by some estimates.
Soviet officials have told the former members of the Soviet bloc that they will demand payment for oil in hard currency beginning next year, and have reportedly asked for cash even sooner from some countries. But Western analysts doubt that the countries can meet the deadline.
The main reason for the decline in Soviet production is a decision early last year to decrease investment in the oil industry, in favor of investment in areas that could put products for consumers on store shelves.
''If perestroika means anything, it means cuts in energy and military capital expenditures,'' said one analyst based in Paris, who said he could not be publicly identified.
The oil and gas sector had soaked up 70 percent of the new investment capital available in the late 1980's, according to Thane Gustafson, a professor of government at Georgetown University and an expert on the Soviet oil industry, When production began to drop in 1985, he said, ''their response was to throw money at the problem. But this time they've decided explicitly not to do it again. The Soviets have said 'no,' they will let oil output fall.''
Ethnic unrest and a general breakdown of the Soviet economy are adding to production problems, experts say, but have not been as important as the lack of investment.
Mehdi Varzi, an oil expert at Kleinwort Grieveson Securities, in London, pointed out that Soviet production peaked in 1988, before the unrest in Azerbaijan, site of much of the oil service industry, and before the restiveness of other republics and the general breakdown of the economy.
''They really haven't undertaken the necessary measures in maintenance, well workovers, replacement of equipment and so forth, what is normally called good industry practice,'' Mr. Varzi said.
A ''wild card'' for future oil production, according to Mr. Gustafson, is that some republics have asserted a claim to their mineral resources.
The Soviet Ministry of Geology and the government of the Turkmen republic made a joint announcement earlier this week that they would open about 90,000 square kilometers, or 56,250 square miles, to exploration by Western companies. This was the first joint announcement between the national government and a republic, Professor Gustafson said. About 85 percent of existing production is in the Russian republic, however.
Soviet and American oil production is declining at roughly the same rate. But oil companies in the United States say that Soviet geology offers far more promising possibilities than does that of the United States. ''They have not developed a technical base for drilling deep for oil,'' said Mr. Ebel of the Enserch Corporation. Rather than drill below 10,000 feet, he added, they moved on to other oilfields, but now they have run out of new fields.

 CORRECTION:
A brief front-page summary yesterday about a decline in Soviet oil production referred incorrectly in some editions to the United States' ranking as an oil producer. It is the world's second-biggest, after the Soviet Union.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Chairman Is Named For Emery Worldwide

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER

 BODY:
Long a leader in the trucking industry, Consolidated fell into a financial crisis after the April 1989 acquisition of Emery Air Freight for $478 million. Unable to reverse Emery's losses, which were running at $1 million a week at the time of the acquisition, Consolidated reported its first loss since 1961 and suspended its common stock dividend for the first time in 19 years. 
In July, Lary R. Scott, 54, Consolidated's president and chief executive officer and the architect of the Emery deal, resigned under pressure and was replaced by the former chief executive of Consolidated, Raymond O'Brien, who is 68. J. Frank Leach, 69, who had been on Consolidated's board since 1975, but was not an employee, joined as president and chief operating officer.
Mr. Bass, who is credited with returning Coopervision to operating profitability, believes he can do the same for Emery. It is ''a company with 42 years of infrastructure and a franchise,'' he said. ''We have the ability to leverage that franchise and exploit niches underexplored by other players,'' he said, but added that he was not yet sure how to do so. ''Literally, I've got a lot of homework to do,'' he said.
Before joining Cooper in March 1989, Mr. Bass was vice chairman and president of Federal Express. He is also a former chairman and chief executive officer of Midway Airlines. He received his B.A. in English from Middlebury College in Vermont. He and his wife, Paula, have three children.

HEADLINE: White House Opposes Plan for Data Base

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5

 BODY:
The proposed data base would include all industrial technology -dealing with physics, chemistry, biology, communications, transportation, medicine and other sciences - developed with the aid of Federal- and state-financed research. The Federal Government spent $6 billion last year on university-sponsored research. But the Administration said today that the final project would duplicate existing Government data bases and that a $25 million pilot project would be too costly. 
 
Approach Seen as Piecemeal
House Democratic leaders contend, however, that the Government's approach has been piecemeal and that access to the current data bases depends on knowledge of their existence and protocols - rules governing the communication and transfer of data between machines. They argue that technology transfer through data bases provides the biggest return for the investment.
Raymond G. Kammer, the deputy director of the Commerce Department's National Institute of Standards and Technology, told the House Small Business Committee that although the Administration supported the legislation's goals, it opposed the proposed project. Mr. Kammer said the Government had several programs designed to give American companies access to federally financed technology in specific areas.
''We do not need additional authorizing legislation to develop and/or implement them,'' Mr. Kammer said.
This view was challenged by Representative John J. LaFalce, Democrat of upstate New York, chairman of the committee. He said that under existing programs a business in need of technical assistance had to know ''10 different protocols needed to access 10 different data bases.''
 
Keys to 'Competitive Kingdom'
Mr. LaFalce said consolidation of industrial technology data in a single data base would mean that ''all a business needs is access to a personal computer and a telephone in order to have the very best technological expertise.''
Similarly, Representative Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, chairman of the Small Business Subcommittee on Regulations, Business Opportunities and Energy, called technologies ''our keys to the competitive kingdom'' and urged the Government to give American companies access to industrial technologies.
Joe Shuster, the chief executive officer of Teltech Inc., a Minneapolis information systems company, said that ''smart, world-class competitors are constantly looking for leverage, and nothing today provides more economic leverage than technical knowledge - nothing.''

HEADLINE: Prices of Oil Rise Again Amid Signs of Hoarding

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:

 
Controls Imposed by Texaco
'It appears to be happening all through the distribution chain; wholesalers, retailers and customers are topping off their tanks in anticipation of higher prices,'' said Paul Weeditz, a spokesman for Texaco Inc. ''We have had spot outages at some terminals.'' He added that the company had imposed a system of controls limiting the amount distributors can withdraw each day to prevent runs on storage terminals and shortages.
''Yes, people are filling their tanks,'' said Deborah Urso, a spokesman for the Mobil Oil Company. ''They are filling up because they are nervous about price.'' 
Sales made directly to gasoline stations are following normal patterns, but intermediate buyers, called jobbers, have been increasing their demand, said James Huccaby, a manager of supply for the Chevron Corporation. ''We do not know if they are keeping it in their tanks or selling to other accounts on an unbranded basis. But jobber demand is up.''
A rush by motorists to fill their tanks could cause shortages because of the sheer number of cars on the road, oil industry officials said. ''There are 140 million vehicles on the road,'' said Cyrus Tahmassebi, chief economist for Ashland Oil Inc. ''If each one of them starts carrying five more gallons, that is a tremendous amount of gasoline; almost 17 million barrels.''
Current supplies of crude oil and refined products appear to be adequate, according to figures released yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. Gasoline inventories, for example, remained virtually unchanged during the week ended Aug. 31 at 210.5 million barrels compared to 210.9 million in the previous week.
But the loss of 4.3 million barrels a day of exports from Iraq and Kuwait could start producing shortages as early as November, according to the International Energy Agency, a monitoring agency for the industrialized nations.
The agency said stocks on hand appeared adequate to meet demand for now, but colder weather could bring regional shortages. The agency said the 24 countries represented had stocks adequate for 98 days of consumption on July 1, two days better than a year ago.
Demand in the fourth quarter will be 1.25 million barrels a day higher than the third quarter because of weather, estimated Mehdi Varzi, an oil analyst with Kleinwort Grievson Securities in London. In trading there, the benchmark Brent crude closed at $30.95 a barrel, up 80 cents on the day.
 
Buying From Far East Cited
The higher prices, he said, were being driven by buying from the Far East. ''Underlying all this is fear that war will break out in the Persian Gulf and Far Eastern customers will suffer, so they need to retain a higher level of stocks than other areas of the world,'' he added.
Similarly, an analyst in New York, who declined to be quoted by name, said war fears were also propelling prices upward. ''People are reluctant to let go of the barrel they have,'' he added. ''If war breaks out, they may be better off with that barrel.''
Yesterday, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq made one of his most inflammatory statments to date, calling for Arabs to unite in a holy war against United States forces in Saudia Arabia and to depose King Fahd of Saudi Arabia. Shortly before Iraq invaded Kuwait, touching off the current crisis, oil was selling for about $21 a barrel.

HEADLINE: Vehicle Sales Tumbled 21.4% in Late August

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 5

 BODY:
For all of August, the annual selling rate was 6.8 million. Since January, cars have been selling at a rate of approximately 6.6 million.
Faced with sluggish demand, most auto makers have been paying rebates of as much as several thousand dollars on many car and truck models. In the last week, the Big Three domestic auto makers have announced a new round of rebates on most of their 1991 models, which are just beginning to arrive in showrooms. These new rebates are generally smaller than those for the 1990 models that dealers are trying to clear out. 
The Big Three and the Japanese auto makers that operate factories in the United States sold 388,661 domestically built cars and trucks in late August, compared with 494,261 during the comparable period of last year.
 
Big Three Auto Sales Off
The number of domestic vehicles sold by the Big Three was off 26.4 percent in late August, and the number sold by Japanese ''transplants'' was 15.9 percent higher. Thus, the Big Three's share of sales resulting from domestic production fell to 82.5 percent, from 88.1 percent a year in the 1989 period.
Sales of all American-built cars fell 18.8 percent in the late August period, to 257,241. The General Motors Corporation sold 105,306 American-built cars in the Aug. 21-31 period, down 21.5 percent from a year earlier; Ford Motor sold 62,829 cars, down 32.8 percent, and the Chrysler Corporation sold 27,549 cars, down 31.7 percent.
Of the ''transplant'' auto makers based in Japan, the Honda Motor Company sold 25,224 cars, an increase of 38.3 percent; the Toyota Motor Corporation sold 22,781 cars, an increase of 23.7 percent, and the Nissan Motor Corporation sold 5,484 cars, a drop of 33.7 percent.
Sales of light trucks were off 25.6 percent, to 132,186, in the period. G.M. sold 55,030, a drop of 24.3 percent; Ford sold 46,678, a drop of 22.4 percent; Chrysler sold 23,072, a drop of 33.2 percent, and Nissan, which builds trucks at a plant in Smyrna, Tenn., sold 6,640, a drop of 35 percent.
The Persian Gulf crisis has not had a big effect yet on vehicle sales, several analysts said. Scott Merlis, automotive analyst for Morgan Stanley & Company in New York, noted that higher inflation and interest rates, which have been evident for the last month, usually depress auto sales after about 90 days have elapsed.
But Joel Pitcoff, sales and marketing analyst for the Ford Motor Company, said Ford dealers near military bases had reported a slowdown. He cited the Fayetteville, N.C., area, near Fort Bragg, as an example.
For the entire month of August, sales of all cars and trucks, imported and domestic, fell 16.7 percent, to 1,174,126, from 1,408,891 in August 1989. Car sales were off 17.6 percent, to 802,868, and truck sales declined 14.6 percent, to 371,258.
The Big Three's total vehicle sales in August, including imported models, fell 23.6 percent; the Big Three captured 56.8 percent of the market, compared with 61.3 percent a year earlier. Sales by Japanese car makers, including vehicles built in the United States, captured 33.5 percent of the market in August, compared with 28.6 percent a year ago. Vehicle sales by importers outside Japan fell 20.4 percent; the market share of these non-Japanese importers was 9.8 percent, down from 10.1 percent a year ago.
G.M. sold 241,014 American-built cars in August, a drop of 18.7 percent from a year ago; Ford sold 153,604, a drop of 26.8 percent, and Chrysler sold 61,207, a drop of 32.3 percent.
G.M.'s total market share in August was 33.9 percent, compared with 34.5 percent in August 1989. Ford had 23.6 percent, compared with 24.4 percent. Chrysler's total market share was 10.6 percent, compared with 12.5 percent.Toyota's market share was 10.1 percent, compared with 8.2 percent, and Honda's market share was 6.6 percent, compared with 5.6.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Fund Yields Are Mixed

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
The new data will take into account the Middle East crisis, and the analysts said they should show that the economy was weaker and close to a recession.
Managers of tax-exempt funds repositioned themselves this week and increased the number of days that securities are held in portfolios by 2, to 59.
Assets fell by $812 million, to $79.9 billion, while the average seven-day, tax-exempt, compounded yield increased 9 basis points, to 5.43 percent, and the 30-day average yield rose 4 basis points, to 5.29 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. 
For investors in a 28 percent tax bracket the equivalent taxable, seven-day compounded yield is 7.54 percent; it is 8.10 percent for investors in the 33 percent bracket.
Among tax-exempt funds with assets of better than $100 million survyed by IBC/Donoghue's, the Spartan New Jersey Municipal Money Market Portfolio showed the best return for the week, with a yield of 6.14 percent. The fund is distributed by the Fidelity Distributors Corporation of Boston.
Of the funds investing primarily in New York securities, the Spartan New York Municipal Money Market Portfolio, also distributed by Fidelity, showed the best return with a yield of 6.02 percent.
Meanwhile, assets of taxable funds declined by $2.1 billion, to $398.8 billion. Analysts said that among the possible causes were the settling down of the bond and stock markets and the cash settlement on Treasury notes bought at auction last week. Institutional assets declined by $900 million, to $84.1 billion, while consumer funds fell by $1.2 billion, to $314.7 billion.
The average days to maturity of securities held in managers' portfolios increased by one, to 46.
Donoghue's said the seven-day compounded average yield for a taxable money-market fund fell a basis point, to 7.75 percent, while the 30-day average yield fell a similar amount, to 7.77 percent.
Of the general-purpose money market funds with assets of more than $100 million, the Dreyfus Worldwide Dollar Money Market fund had the best return for the second week. Its yield is 8.62 percent.
