HEADLINE: Dow Up 14,85 to 2,628.22, on Light Volume

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Trading volume continued sluggish at 120.6 million shares, up from 96.5 million on Tuesday, which was the slowest day of 1990. A solid 953 stocks advanced, with 13 hitting new highs, while 571 fell and 68 set new lows.
''The market doesn't like a standoff in the desert any more than those who have to be on duty in that environment,'' said Robert H. Stovall, president of Stovall/Twenty-First Advisers. ''Aimless drifting on modest volume may be the market's role until there's a basic change in the investing environment.'' 
Many traders and investors continued to mark time until employment figures are released tomorrow. There is widespread feeling that they will show that the economy is extremely weak. Whether it is weak enough to induce the Federal Reserve to stimulate the economy by lowering interest rates is still uncertain, although many feel such a move is near.
Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. -worried about earnings, the price of oil and other uncertainties - eliminated its buy recommendations on nine Big Board technology stocks, including I.B.M. and Xerox, and 10 over-the-counter high-tech issues.
 
Looking at Fundamentals
''We didn't feel there was enough fundamental justification that these stocks could go up in a down market,'' said Richard C. Billy, a Prudential-Bache electronics analyst.
Forecasting lower sales of computer chips in the wake of a decline in personal computer volume, a Goldman, Sachs & Company electronics analyst, Rajiv Chaudri, cut his earnings estimate for Texas Instruments. He also cut his earnings estimates for Motorola and Intel.
Predicting ''a softer economic environment, Shearson, Lehman Brothers' electrical equipment analyst, Robert T. Cornell, cut his earnings estimates for General Electric, Emerson Electric, Maytag, Square D, Westinghouse and Whirlpool.
With the California real estate market slowing, Paine Webber's savings and loan analyst, Gary Gordon, trimmed his earnings estimates for three West Coast companies, Golden West Financial, H. F. Ahmanson and, for 1991, Great Western Financial.
 
Compaq Computer Loses 2 1/2
Of the Big Board stocks that Prudential-Bache no longer recommended, I.B.M. fell 1/8, to 102 3/8; Xerox 1/4, to 40 3/4; Compaq Computer 2 1/2, to 45 3/8; NCR 1 1/4, to 61 1/8, and Silicon Graphics 3/8, to 29 1/4. Digital Equipment rose 1, to 66 1/2, and Marshal Industries 3/8, to 22, while Control Data was unchanged at 14 and Policy Management Systems was unchanged at 37 5/8.
In Nasdaq stocks on the list, Advanced Logic fell 1/2, to 9; Autodesk 1/2, to 49 1/4; Molex 1/4, to 19, and Pioneer Standard Electronics 1/8, to 11 3/8. Intergraph rose 5/8, to 15 3/8; Maxim Integrated Products 3/8, to 9 5/8; Software Publishing 3/4, to 23 3/4; Sun Microsystems 1/8, to 29 1/8, while Terradata was unchanged at 21, and Linear Technology was unchanged at 11 3/4.
Texas Instruments fell 3/8, to 27 3/8, and Motorola 2, to 69 1/8. On Nasdaq, Intel fell 1, to 32 1/2, in heavy trading.
G.E. fell 1, to 60 1/4, also in heavy trading, and Emerson Electric 3/8, to 33 7/8. Square D, which touched a new low of 43 1/4, closed at 43 7/8, up 1/4; Westinghouse remained unchanged at 32 1/4, and Whirlpool rose 1, to 24 1/2.
Golden West rose 3/8, to 26 1/2; Ahmanson 1/8, to 16 7/8, and Great Western 3/8, to 14 3/8.
 
JAPANESE STOCKS FALL
TOKYO, Thursday, Sept. 6 (AP) -Japanese stock prices fell today while the dollar moved slightly higher against the yen.
The Nikkei average of 225 stocks lost 266.43 points, or 1.1 percent, to close at 23,811.91. The Nikkei had risen in early trading, but retreated by midday. It was down as much as 450 points during the afternoon.
The dollar finished the morning trading session at 142.40 yen, up 0.10 yen from Wednesday's close. The dollar had opened at 141.48 yen, its lowest level since Oct. 19, 1989, when it opened at 140.97 yen.
Currency dealers said the dollar rebounded following reports that an American citizen had been shot by an Iraqi soldier in Kuwait. In Washington, the State Department said it was trying to confirm the report.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off in Heavy Selling On Talk of Fed Rate Move

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Heavy dollar selling began in Asia and carried over into European and United States dealing later.
The sales were prompted by speculation that the Federal Reserve might soon seek to foster an economic rebound in the United States by pushing interest rates down. Falling American rates would reduce returns on dollar holdings and thus lessen investment interest in dollars. 
Currency dealers said the dollar was also hampered by speculation that West Germany and Japan might soon raise their interest rates. Higher rates in those countries, especially if United States interest rates fall, would tend to spur demand for German marks and the yen.
''I think, on the whole, it was a lot of speculation about the Fed easing,'' David Marshall, an analyst with MMS International, said of the dollar's selloff. ''There was speculation about U.S. rates moving down and other rates moving up.''
Financial markets are awaiting the Government's monthly unemployment report, due tomorrow, for indications of the economy's condition last month. Some analysts expect only a small rise in non-farm employment and any such softening in the labor market would bolster the case for the central bank to loosen its monetary policy.
One of the most pronounced moves of the day was the dollar's drop against the yen. It was quoted at 141.65 yen late in New York trading, down from 143.40 on Tuesday. Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar fell to close at 142.30 Japanese yen, down from 144.05 yen on Tuesday, and in London it fell to 141.75 yen.
The dollar also weakened markedly against the British pound in New York and against the German mark. A pound fetched $1.9055 in late trading, compared with $1.8810 Tuesday. In London, the British pound rose to $1.8990, from $1.8750 late on Tuesday.
Against the German currency, the dollar fell more than two pfennigs, to 1.5580 marks, from 1.58115 in New York trading.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those of late on Tuesday, included: 1.2945 Swiss francs, down from 1.3135; 5.2180 French francs, down from 5.2965; 1,162.00 Italian lire, down from 1,179.00, and 1.15245 Canadian dollars, down from 1.16075.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, an ounce of gold for September delivery cost $2.40 more, or $386.10, than on Tuesday. The Republic National Bank in New York later quoted a bid of $387.20 for a ounce of gold, up $2.60 from the late bid on Tuesday.
Gold moved to a late bid of $387.75 an ounce in London, up from $382.50 late on Tuesday. In Zurich, it rose to close at $385.75, from $382.25 late on Tuesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong trading, gold fell $4.33 to close at $384.02.
In New York and London, silver prices rose. On the Comex, an ounce of silver for September delivery rose to $4.735, from $4.719 on Tuesday. Silver rose in London to a late bid of $4.78 an ounce, from $4.75 late on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Tough New Campaign for U.S. Clothing

BYLINE: By Kim Foltz

 BODY:
This is the fourth year the New York-based council has formed a close association with the Miss America Pageant. In exchange for the council's substantial sponsorship of the pageant, the reigning Miss America makes numerous appearances at stores nationwide to promote American-made clothing.
In the new advertising campaign, one spot, titled ''Excuses,'' shows workers saying goodbye and packing up on the closing day at a clothing factory. In the background are voices of shoppers making excuses about why they do not bother to check the label to see if the clothes they are buying were made in America. ''Look, I'm on my lunch hour,'' one exasperated woman says. ''Next time I'll check where it's made.'' 
As the factory gates are being padlocked, the announcer tells viewers that because of foreign competition nearly half a million apparel and textile workers have lost their jobs. ''Buy American and Americans work,'' he says.
In a second guilt-edged commercial, a mother is shown explaining to her son that they have to move because his father lost his job. ''Why?'' the child asks. ''Because a lot of people are buying clothes made in other countries,'' she replies as the announcer recites the job-loss toll.
''Most people only think that Americans are losing jobs because of imported cars,'' said Robert E. Swift, the executive director of the council. ''We want to warn them that by buying imported clothing, they are sacrificing their standard of living and their neighbors' jobs.''
Mr. Swift also said the time was right to make this type of appeal because the public was increasingly concerned about the growing trade deficit and the weakening economy.
The council, which was formed in 1984, is primarily made up of members from the textile, apparel and fashion industries. When the organization began publicizing the difficulties of the American apparel and textile industries in 1985, the commercials had a softer appeal. Using celebrities like Bob Hope, Ted Danson and Loretta Swit, the ads told consumers that American-made clothing was superior in quality to most imports and urged people to look for the ''Made in the U.S.A.'' labels. All garments are required to have a tag showing where they were made.
Mr. Swift said studies showed that since the council's campaign began, consumer attitudes about imported clothes have changed. Researchers have found that about half of the women shoppers say they check labels for a garment's country of origin. In addition, some polls have shown that a large majority of Americans now believe that American companies make better-quality clothing.
Even though the council says it has been successful in telling consumers about the benefits of American-made clothing, it is now taking a tougher line in its advertising because imports have continued to grow. In the early part of the last decade, imports accounted for about half of all clothing sold. Mr. Swift said that figure had risen to 60 percent last year.
During the last 10 years, 14 percent of the apparel manufacturing plants in the country have closed, and the council attributes most of the problem to the rise in imports.
And the situation has become worse. The council reports that during the last year 65,000 jobs in the textile and apparel industries were lost and 49 factories permanently shut their doors.
''We want people to realize that buying American-made clothing has an added benefit beyond quality,'' Ms. Small-Weil said. ''We want them to realize they can save someone's job.''

This scene from a new television commercial created by Warwick Baker & Fiore for the council dramatizes the closure of an American clothing plant. (The Rowland Company)

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
CRACKS APPEAR IN EMBARGO AS SEVERAL NATIONS DISCUSS RELIEF FOR IRAQ AND KUWAIT

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6

 BODY:

 
U.N. Committee Meets
The United Nations resolutions allow for the delivery of food and medicine to Iraq for humanitarian purposes. A United Nations committee met today to create a mechanism to judge when an emergency existed that would warrant such aid, but broke up with no decision.
The White House announced today that President Bush had accepted an offer to broadcast a televised message to the Iraqi people and said he would use the message to explain United States policy in the Persian Gulf.
In the Administration's first public enumeration on the size of American forces in the gulf region, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said that the total buildup of United States forces there -including sailors deployed at sea - had reached 100,000, but that it was ''too soon as yet'' to halt the flow of troops and weapons.
 
Operation Called Successful
Mr. Cheney told members of the Institute for International Strategic Studies, meeting at Hot Springs, Va., that the monthlong operation ''has been an enormously successful one.'' 
As he spoke, the State Department confirmed reports today that an American man in Kuwait City was shot and wounded on Wednesday while trying to escape Iraqi soldiers who had burst into his apartment.
A State Department spokesman said the man, who was not immediately identified, had been shot in the arm but not seriously hurt. He is hospitalized in Kuwait City. An Iraqi official in Baghdad called the shooting ''an unintentional incident,'' but a State Department spokesman, Mark Dillen, condemned the act as ''outrageous behavior'' and said the Iraqi Ambassador here had been summoned to explain the shooting.
The shooting came as Iraq seemed to be conducting a relatively aggressive roundup of Americans and other Westerners hiding in Kuwait City. An Iraqi official said Baghdad was reviving a law calling for prison terms up to life for any foreigner caught trying to leave without an exit permit.
A hopeful sign for the 2,200 Americans trapped in Kuwait came today when the State Department said that on Friday a chartered Iraqi airliner would take Americans in Kuwait to Amman, Jordan, after first stopping in Baghdad.
Mr. Dillen said charters would continue as long as there were Americans who wanted to leave Kuwait. An Iraqi airliner chartered by Canada left Baghdad for Ankara, Turkey, today with a group of Westerners, including 12 Americans, from Kuwait City. The Associated Press reported that the flight arrived in London late today for refueling and that all but 24 of the 158 passengers were to continue to Toronto.
The American-led multinational force in the gulf got a boost today when Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain told an emergency session of Parliament that she plans to send reinforcements to the gulf. She gave no immediate details, but her aides said Britain had not ruled out deploying more ground troops.
On the apparent cracks in the blockade, the United States and most other Western nations have opposed any exceptions for now, contending there are no acute shortages of food and medical supplies in Iraq.
 
Hardship in Kuwait
The United States has not directly addressed the issue of shortages in Kuwait, where hardship conditions in the wake of the Iraqi invasion have contributed to the exodus of foreigners along the Iraqi-Jordanian border.
The suggestion that Iran might seek to drive a wedge in the sanctions came in The Teheran Times, which is close to the Iranian President, Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani.
''There is a humanitarian question that has to be pondered upon in Iran these days: Should the Islamic Republic help the Iraqi Moslem people in these hard times when they are facing an economic blockade?'' the newspaper said.
''Since according to U.N. resolutions food and medicine are not included in the sanctions, by choosing to help the Iraqi people Iran will not be breaking any international law,'' it added.
 
Iraqi Is in Beijing
In Beijing, Iraq's Deputy Prime Minister, Taha Yassin Ramadan, led a high-level delegation that is trying to persuade the Chinese to break ranks with the Western-led embargo. China hinted that it might answer the appeal.
The United Nations resolution ''clearly stipulates that the embargo against Iraq does not include supplies intended strictly for medical purposes and foodstuffs in humanitarian circumstances,'' a Chinese spokeswoman, Li Jinhua, said at a news conference.
China has supported Security Council resolutions on the gulf but has taken a softer line than the four other permanent members - the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union.
India and Yugoslavia have also indicated that they might seek to send food and medicine to its citizens trapped in Iraq and Kuwait.
 
Defining Humanitarian
In New York, the Sanctions Committee of the Security Council met today to consider what defined humanitarian assistance, and in effect to set a standard for individual nations to follow. Nations are not now obliged to seek exceptions from the committee.
When the committee meeting broke up tonight, a diplomat said ''they are in complete disarray'' on the issue.
Diplomats close to the meeting here today said the committee had come close to an agreement on how to aid Jordan, where the refugee problem has assumed huge proportions.
The committee, which includes all 15 members of the Security Council, will meet again on Monday.
 
Iraqi TV Offer to Bush
In a campaign stop in Topeka, Kan., today, Mr. Bush's spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, explained the circumstances surrounding the President's decision to go on Iraqi television.
''Iraq's Information Minister has offered to broadcast a message from President Bush to the people of Iraq on their state-run television,'' he said. ''Although we have not heard from Iraq directly, we accept their offer of a broadcast to the Iraqi people. The President will tape a message to the Iraqi people in the next few days which will be provided to the Iraqi information minister.''
Iraq offered to send a television crew to Washington to interview Mr. Bush. It was not clear whether the White House's offer to send a taped message would be acceptable to Baghdad.
 
Friend Tells of Shooting
The State Department's confirmation of the shooting of an unidentified American came from a friend of the wounded man, Mr. Dillen said. The friend was also seized by Iraqi soldiers but not harmed.
An American consular officer was allowed to talk with the friend, who told the diplomat that the wounded man he had been shot when he tried to escape through his apartment window from Iraqi soldiers.
The two Americans were taken to a hospital in Kuwait City. The unharmed man was then taken to the Mansour Melia Hotel in Baghdad, where the consular officer interviewed him.
A State Department official on the Kuwaiti task force said tonight that the American was shot while leaving his apartment through a window. The official declined further comment.
Leaving the State Department this afternoon, the Iraqi ambassador to the United States, Mohammed al-Mashat, was questioned about the incident.
''It was an unfortunate incident,'' he said. ''Nobody knew that he was an American. It was during the curfew time and when he violated the curfew soldiers are under orders to enforce it. So he got a slight injury to his arm.'' The Iraqi envoy called the incident ''an accident.'' The State Department official called this remark ''ludicrous.''
When asked if the man would be allowed to leave Kuwait, as other sick Americans have been permitted to do, the Iraqi envoy replied: ''The sick people have already left. We're studying his case carefully.''
Mr. Mashat said that American diplomats will have access to the man, whom State Department spokesmen would not identify.
Mr. Dillen denied that the injured man was violating curfew or had ignored commands by Iraqi soldiers to stop. He said the shooting was ''another indication of the lengths to which the Iraqis are willing to go to carry out their inhumane policy of using innocent foreigners as shields while denying them the right to leave.''

HEADLINE: 2 Koreas, Ending Initial Talks, Agree on a Session in the North

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 6

 BODY:
''We place tremendous importance on these meetings,'' Ahn Byung Soo, the North Korean spokesman, said at a news conference this evening. ''Although there are still differences of opinion, there are also commonalities. The fact that such broad matters have been discussed is meaningful.''
Both sides emphasized that they had rejected each other's main proposals, but without the usual tone of accusation that accompanies exchanges between them. They regarded it as a success that the highest contacts between the two countries since World War II occurred without a hitch, although there was an inability to agree on a joint statement. 
Pyongyang, for example, reiterated its appeal to South Korea to stop trying for a seat for itself in the United Nations, to suspend its joint military exercises with the United States, and to release from prison two priests and a young woman who made unauthorized visits to North Korea in the last year.
 
Meeting with President
Prime Minister Yon Hyong Muk of North Korea took that message directly to President Roh Tae Woo of South Korea, who received all the delegates at the presidential palace known as Blue House after the talks adjourned at lunchtime today.
Mr. Roh was said to have listened to Mr. Yon's plan without responding except to offer praise for the general atmosphere. The South Korean President also asked Mr. Yon to seek a meeting later with President Kim Il Sung, the 78-year-old leader of North Korea.
The South Korean delegate spokesman, Hong Sung Chul, said Seoul was willing to listen to North Korea's ideas about the United Nations, but that the military exercises were essential deterrents to an invasion. He said the jailing of the three visitors to Pyongyang was an internal security matter.
But Mr. Hong also said he thought the talks had been valuable.
''Of course, we reached no agreements that would stir up the nation,'' he said. ''But because the eyes of the people were on us, both sides approached the talks with a sincerity unlike anything seen in the past.''
A main element of the atmosphere was the spectacle of Koreans divided for 45 years getting to know each other, discovering their common language and learning that they shared some of the same hopes about the future and legacy from the past.
 
Dissident Students Arrested
North Korea is widely considered among the world's most isolated countries and repressive police states, and the Northerners were such subjects of curiosity that even the 50 journalists accompanying the delegation were followed by television cameras and photographers wherever they went. Television and newspaper coverage has been intense all week.
Aside from the talks, delegates adjourned a couple of times for meals together as well as an afternoon of dance and music performances, and a couple of movies by South Korean film makers. The journalists went on a field trip to one of Seoul's biggest afternoon daily newspapers, but they were rebuffed in their request to visit with South Korean dissidents.
Outside the hotel, dissident student groups and others sought to deliver messages of support to the North Korean delegates but they were blocked by the heavy security. A few were arrested and later released.
Two fundamentally different approaches that appeared difficult to reconcile emerged from the talks.
 
Phased-In Troop Withdrawal
North Korea put its priority on what it said was the independence of Korea, interpreted each time as a code word for immediate expulsion of 43,000 American troops, a banning of American nuclear weapons and other ties with Washington.
Those and other steps, with a phased-in withdrawal of troops by both sides, were deemed by Pyongyang to be prerequisites to improved ties.
But South Korea took the view that there must first be exchanges of families, performers, athletes and other visitors, as well as joint business ventures and economic ties, before the two countries can narrow the larger military and political issues dividing them.
North Korea rejected that idea, saying that Seoul seemed to want to drag out the process and lend permanence to the divided state on the peninsula, holding to its longtime view that South Korea is still a kind of American colony lacking real legitimacy.
 
Both Favor Reunification
Indeed, North Koreans refrained from referring to Prime Minister Kang Young Hoon of South Korea as Prime Minister, instead addressing him as ''Chief Delegate.'' Later, South Koreans took satisfaction that Mr. Yon referred to Mr. Roh as ''Mr. President,'' saying that that reference recognized that South Korea does indeed exist as a country.
Both sides said they favored eventual reconciliation and even reunification, but each stuck to its vision of doing so on its own terms.
The next meeting is scheduled for Oct. 16 in Pyongyang, and Seoul officials said they were hopeful that it would take place. But they seemed to be crossing their fingers.

LENGTH: 1446 words

HEADLINE: Dukakis Accuses No. 2 of Plotting a Coup

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Sept. 6

 BODY:
After learning of Ms. Murphy's plans, Mr. Dukakis twice this week postponed his departure on a 13-day trade mission to Europe, and aides described him earlier today as virtually a prisoner in his own state. But this evening, he suddenly left for Berlin, joining his wife and state officials who had left on Monday as scheduled.
He said at Logan Airport that he had not spoken with Ms. Murphy today but that he believed what he took as assurances from a press conference Ms. Murphy held this afternoon that she would act responsibly while he was away. But he added that he would cut short his trip if Ms. Murphy took drastic measures.
At the afternoon news conference, Ms. Murphy hinted that she would execute a plan once the Governor had departed. Her announcement tonight that she would disclose the plan's details on Friday, coupled with Mr. Dukakis's departure, left unclear exactly what was going to happen over the next few days in Massachusetts, where the feud between the Governor and the Lieutenant Governor has overtaken the Middle East crisis as the topic of conversation. 
 
'No Mutual Respect'
''Everybody knows we need to take some steps right now,'' said Ms. Murphy, who has a Ph.D. in economics. ''When I'm in charge, I'll show you how I'll make the decisions. I want to show people that there's a very serious difference between me and the Governor on the sense of urgency around this.''
After a phone conversation with Ms. Murphy on Wednesday, Mr. Dukakis said: ''What I heard was a candidate who was trying to use this state's fiscal situation for personal political gain. We're going to make sure that this campaign and this particular candidacy doesn't make some kind of charade out of what are some very serious problems.''
Ms. Murphy said after the phone conversation that Mr. Dukakis and his aides ''were asking me to promise not to do anything and that is irresponsible.''
''There is no good will here and certainly no mutual respect,'' she said.
 
Economic Problems Develop
Massachusetts' fiscal troubles began in 1988 while Mr. Dukakis was running for President. The problems stemmed from a downturn in the state's economy, not recognized at the time, causing revenue from sales and income taxes to fall. Over the last two years, with Governor Dukakis and the Legislature at an impasse, revenues continued to fall, causing a deficit of about $1 billion in the $13 billion budget. In July, after heated debate, the Legislature finally passed the biggest tax package in the state's history and slashed the budget by 4 percent, but even so, revenues have continued to fall below expectations.
On Tuesday, Mr. Dukakis, who by then had heard of Ms. Murphy's plan and of reports that it included a 4 percent cut in spending, issued his own orders to Cabinet officers to draw up plans for an additional 4 percent cut of their budgets, across the board, or about $150 million.
The spat between Governor Dukakis and Lieutenant Governor Murphy, both Democrats, has further tarnished the image of the state's Democratic leaders, who have been widely blamed for the falling revenues and rising taxes in Massachusetts, which has slipped into recession after a decade of spectacular economic growth during most of the 1980's.
The budget mess has also given the small Massachusetts Republican Party, with only 13.5 percent of the state's registered voters, its best chance of capturing the Governor's office for the first time since 1970.
A poll published in The Boston Globe earlier this week suggested that either of the two Republican candidates, Steven Pierce, the House minority leader, or William F. Weld, a former United States Attorney in Boston, would defeat any of the three Democratic candidates. The poll, of 436 likely voters in the November general election, stunned many political analysts here. It had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus five percentage points.
In recent months, Ms. Murphy seemed to have been badly hurt by the public perception that she was close to Governor Dukakis, a now widely reviled figure here, and a poll published today in the Boston Herald said she was favored by only 15 percent of likely Democratic primary voters, down from 23 percent in May. The poll, of 400 people, had a margin of sampling error of five percentage points.
 
'Scorched Earth Policy'
One of the Governor's aides, who spoke on the condition that he not be identified, said an adviser to Ms. Murphy had counseled her to pursue a ''scorched earth policy'' and to make a very public break with the Dukakis Administration.
But if indeed Ms. Murphy was seeking to bolster her prospects for election, the initial public reaction seems to indicate that she has not succeeded. Paul Tsongas, a Democrat and former United States Senator, said, ''I don't think people buy this kind of thing.''
And in a serious defection, one of Ms. Murphy's main supporters, Philip Johnston, the secretary of human services, said today that he was switching his allegiance to another Democratic gubernatorial candidate, Francis X. Bellotti, a former state attorney general. Mr. Johnston was said by colleagues to be disappointed by Ms. Murphy's actions.
The third Democratic candidate, John R. Silber, president of Boston University, dismissed the incident as ''the kind of coup d'etat you find in musical comedy.''
 
Stealing the Spotlight
Ms. Murphy did succeed in focusing public attention on herself, taking momentum at least temporarily away from her opponents. But it will now be up to her, as acting Governor, to show that she really does have a plan that can resolve a deep-seated fiscal crisis that has defied other political leaders for months.
Ms. Murphy, a former secretary for environmental affairs and a longtime officeholder who was elected lieutenant governor four years ago, complained today that Mr. Dukakis had ignored her proposals for resolving the budget deficit and had excluded her from an emergency meeting of top state officials on Sunday to discuss how to deal with evidence the budget crisis was worsening.
In the Massachusetts system the governor and lieutenant governor run separately.
The latest crisis began on Monday when Mr. Dukakis, who is not running for re-election after 12 years as Governor, postponed his departure for a 13-day trip to Europe that had been designed to boost Massachusetts' exports to help the state's faltering economy.
It was originally announced that Mr. Dukakis had delayed his departure because of new figures that showed state tax revenues in August had fallen below estimates made a month earlier.
 
Word of Ms. Murphy's Plan
Adding to the atmosphere of intrigue, Steven Crawford, Mr. Dukakis's press secretary, said Ms. Murphy had canceled a meeting with the Governor on Friday and had failed to show up for a Cabinet meeting on Tuesday to discuss the budget, though she had repeatedly assured Mr. Dukakis and his assistants that she did not intend to take any actions while he was out of the country. Mr. Dukakis had only learned that Ms. Murphy had a ''plan'' from news reports Wednesday afternoon, Mr. Crawford said, but when the Governor phoned her, she refused to divulge her intentions.
It remains unclear precisely what Ms. Murphy's plan to resolve the budget mess involved. But some state officials said it included the step Mr. Dukakis took Tuesday, ordering the further 4 percent cuts to bring the budget in line with falling revenues.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 8, 1990, Saturday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a dispute between Gov. Michael S. Dukakis and his Lieutenant Governor, Evelyn Murphy, described one aspect of the dispute incorrectly in some copies.
Ms. Murphy's plans on the state budget are reported to have included the possibility of dismissing the Secretary of Administration and Finance, not the Secretary of Human Services. The article also misstated Mr. Dukakis's tenure in some copies. He has been Governor for 12 years, not 16.

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
On the Campaign Trail, Bush Invokes Gulf Crisis

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Sept. 6

 BODY:
''Every use of force unchecked is an invitation to further aggression,'' Mr. Bush said in Tallahassee, at a barbeque fund-raiser for Rep. Bill Grant, Republican of Florida. ''Every act of aggression unpunished strikes a blow against the rule of law - and strengthens the forces of chaos and lawlessness that, ultimately, threaten us all.''
 
Patriotic Tone Struck
Mr. Bush's appearances in Topeka and Tallahassee set a patriotic tone that Mr. Bush and Republican strategists apparently want to strike in discussing the Persian Gulf crisis in the fall election season. Republicans are hoping that the American military deployment in Saudi Arabia will bolster their efforts to project the party as the safeguard of a strong defense and a strong economy. 
Mindful of the need to maintain Democratic support for the gulf operation, Mr. Bush drew no overt link between the crisis and domestic political issues. But the two themes were intertwined through both speeches on the campaign swing, which Mr. Bush made aboard the new Air Force One, a specially equipped Boeing 747 making its maiden flight.
At a fund-raising luncheon for Governor Hayden, Mr. Bush combined discussion of the gulf crisis with talk of domestic political issues, jabbing at Congress for not coming to an agreement on the 1991 Federal budget as he sought to bolster public support in the American heartland for the deployment of American troops in Saudi Arabia.
He peppered his speech with references to farmhouse culture, ''traditional values'' and common sense. He summoned the memory of Eisenhower, the World War II supreme commander who lived in Abilene. And he reminded his audience of the fictional Kansas girl, Dorothy, of the book and movie ''The Wizard of Oz.''
 
'A Wonderful Movie Set'
''For more than half-a-century, generations have marveled at a wonderful movie set here in Kansas,'' he said. ''Ask anyone from Warsaw to Wichita: They know what Dorothy said, 'There's no place like home.' ''
''There is nothing I want more,'' he continued, ''than for our Ameican servicemen and women to come home. And they will once we've completed a mission that does right by American, and does right by the entire world.''
To personalize his message, Mr. Bush included in his speech a series of vignettes about Kansans who are serving in Saudi Arabia in the 190th Air Force Refueling Group.
And the President's appearance at the luncheon gave the candidate, Mr. Hayden, an opportunity to draw the patriotic message into his own remarks. Mr. Hayden said: ''The message to the President from the people of Kansas is clear: We support you Mr. President. We respect your decision in this time of crisis.''
Before leaving Washington today, Mr. Bush was telephoned by President Turgut Ozal of Turkey, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany and President Francois Mitterrand of France. He also telephoned President Hafez al-Assad of Syria ''to discuss the situation and get his perspective on events in the gulf,'' Mr. Fitzwater said.

PUB-DATE: September 7, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 9, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1579 words

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
As Forces in Gulf Build, U.S. Weighs Its Options

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6

 BODY:

 
A Decision on the Sanctions
At some point, certainly before the end of the year, Mr. Bush will have to decide whether economic sanctions have been effective. If the answer is no, he will face a decision about whether to use military force and if so, when, where, how much and to what end.
At this point, much of the military advice the President is getting urges him to rely on air power and technological superiority and avoid a land war to the degree possible.
Most analysts do not expect Mr. Hussein to force Mr. Bush's hand by launching an offensive of his own before mid-October. If the Iraqis did strike, American forces would lack a land force with heavy equipment sufficient to throw back an all-out assault by the 265,000 Iraqi troops based in the southern half of Iraq and in Kuwait. 
By some estimates, the United States, the Saudis and the rest of the international force would be hard pressed to prevent damage to the Saudis' main oilfields. But they are confident that an Iraqi offensive could eventually be stalled and contained, while air assaults on stategic targets in Iraq would eventually batter Iraq's military capacity and morale.
 
The Potential Scenarios
After mid-October, according to high-ranking Defense Department and White House officials, who spoke on condition that they not be identified, the President's options for offensive action would range from attacks on dams and roads as a way to step up economic pressure, through an attempt to kill or kidnap Mr. Hussein, the Iraqi leader, to an extensive military campaign to push the Iraqis out of Kuwait - and perhaps to continue to move into Iraq itself, perhaps all the way to Baghdad.
Such a campaign might well involve a drive north by Army units on the left flank, marines on the right, and an amphibious assault, not unlike those at Anzio and Inchon, by other marine forces now held in floating reserve.
Fighting could begin in one of three basic ways. Iraq could attack Saudi Arabia, which American experts, both inside and outside the Government, now consider extremely unlikely. President Bush could decide that the sanctions would not suffice, in a reasonable length of time, and order an offensive. Or a war could grow out of a small incident, like an inadvertent clash between American and Iraqi warplanes or some grievous mistreatment of hostages.
The fabrication or exaggeration of a pretext for action by either side is not unthinkable, as the manipulation of the Gulf of Tonkin incident at a key moment in Vietnam shows.
 
A Technological Edge
If war began, American planners would seek to make the most of their technological capacity, which includes such elements as electronic deception to complicate Iraqi air defense, laser- and radar-guided missiles and, above all, an arsenal of weapons and devices that should enable American troops to fight effectively at night, something the Iraqis are not yet able to do.
The planners would also seek to exploit vastly superior American air power to minimize the huge Iraqi superiority in troop and tank strength. Even when the United States deployment as now envisaged is complete, Baghdad is expected to have at least a two-to-one advantage in men and tanks, officers said.
Even the battleship Wisconsin could come into play, launching its cruise missiles at important targets like command and control centers.
By using missiles fired from afar, the Pentagon strategists would hope to limit American casualties and avoid the kind of ''Arab-Israeli desert blood bath,'' as one general put it, that took place in 1973. More than 20,000 soldiers were killed or wounded in the two-week war that year.
''The numbers are scary, especially their infantry and artillery strength,'' said Bernard E. Trainor, a retired Marine general and former New York Times military correspondent who heads the national security program at Harvard University's Kennedy School of Government. ''But in the end, numbers don't count, if you have a concept that exploits your enemy's vulnerabilities. The Germans were outnumbered 10-to-1 in 1940, but they still overran France.''
 
The Need for Troop Strength
Col. Harry Summers, a retired Army officer who writes and lectures on tactics, is much less sanguine.
''You can certainly punish him with air power,'' Colonel Summers said of Mr. Hussein. ''You can destroy his air force. But that's not decisive if what you want to do is forcibly eject Saddam Hussein from Kuwait and make it hard for him to return. That takes troops on the ground, and I wouldn't want to try it with any less than 10 armored divisions, which you could only get by moving most of the Seventh Army down from Europe.''
A first step in any offensive operation would be the destruction of Iraqi fighters and bombers, either on the ground or in aerial combat, and the elimination of the 36 SCUD-B missile launchers.
Anthony Cordesman, the author of ''The Lessons of Modern War,'' a history of the Iran-Iraq conflict, said that ''we have the ability to win air superiority very quickly.''
The Iraqi Air Force's planes - a few top-notch Soviet-built MIG-29's but mostly older MIG-23's and French-built Mirages - are considered inferior to the best American hardware.
Available to American commanders would be Awacs radar planes to help fighter pilots spot enemy aircraft, EF-111 and EC-130 electronic jamming planes to confuse Iraqi electronic systems, and a huge arsenal of fighters, fighter-bombers, ground-attack planes and bombers - F-15's, F-16's, A-10's and Harriers in Saudi Arabia, F-111's and F-117's in Turkey, F-14's, F/A-18's and A-6's on board the carriers Independence, Saratoga and Eisenhower, and even B-52 bombers based on Diego Garcia island in the Indian Ocean.
For Iraqi forces in the desert, there would be no jungle to provide cover, which greatly reduced the value of American air superiority in Vietnam.
 
Talk of 'Surgical Strikes'
In theory, the economic pressure could be tightened through the limited use of air power. Mr. Hussein's fragile domestic economy, strained by the embargo on food shipments, could be further disrupted through attacks on bridges, highways or even the two big dams just west of Baghdad and other hydroelectric plants.
There is much talk in Washington of ''surgical strikes'' from the air, but the experience of the Vietnam War, when pilots found it tremendously difficult to hit even large targets like the Paul Doumer bridge in Hanoi, makes some observers skeptical. A former naval pilot who flew dozens of missions over Hanoi and Haiphong said recently, ''Surgical strikes exist only in think-tanks and mental institutions.''
In addition, the American military establishment, starting with Gen. Colin L. Powell, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, is firmly opposed to gradual escalation or limited offensives, having concluded that the Vietnam War was lost precisely because of a limited application of force.
''Once you get air superiority, they will want to flatten Baghdad,'' Representative Aspin commented.
Flattening Baghdad would inevitably entail thousands of civilian casualties - Muslims killed by Christians - and that might put intolerable pressure on the coalition of western and Arab countries lined up against Iraq.
''We ought to play to our strength, which is air power,'' said Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who heads the Senate Armed Services Committee. ''But if we use military force in a way that alienates a lot of our partners in this operation, we will lose the embargo, and we will have that erode very rapidly, in which case we will be counterproductive to our own aims.''
 
One Military Solution
Finally, an extensive campaign of air bombardment would threaten the Western hostages who have reportedly been dispersed to strategic targets around Iraq to act as ''human shields.''
Asked what he would do if told that a military solution was needed, a leading Congressional expert on Mideast warfare commented: ''Establish air superiority, launch air attacks on civil and military targets away from population centers, especially in the southern desert, then try to push into and through Kuwait, stopping on a line curving northwest from Basra, where the fertile land ends and the major highways leading south from Baghdad peter out.''
Such a plan, which was mentioned in interviews with several other experts, would be dependent for its long-term success on either inducing the downfall of a humiliated Saddam Hussein or a continued program of air interdiction to prevent the effective resupply of Iraqi troops and thus to make a major counterattack impossible.
''Even that,'' said the expert, who described himself as a hawk, ''would be quite a difficult proposition.''

HEADLINE: San Francisco Journal;
City That Loves Opera Faces a Night to Lament

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 6

 BODY:
No other American city dotes on its opera company as San Francisco does, and opening night is the pinnacle of the social season. Canceled along with Friday's performances of ''Suor Angelica'' and ''I Pagliacci'' are three first-night galas that raise money for the opera and the Museum of Modern Art, Saturday's new production of ''Wozzeck'' and Sunday's free concert in the park.
For those who attend opening night, a ritual worthy of Cecil B. DeMille, the evening is a breathless reunion with friends who have been scattered for the summer from Europe to Lake Tahoe. For those who gawk from the sidewalk, it is a stuffier version of the Academy Awards, with limousines pulling into the carriage entrance of the War Memorial Opera House, disgorging women in emeralds and furs and men in tails and stiff shirts. 
''It's an electric night and there aren't many of those anymore,'' said Peter J. Seely, the general manager of Trader Vic's.
The cancellation of opening night, and threats from opera management that the entire 23-week season could be a casuality of the orchestra's wage demands, has cast a pall on a city that has yet to fully recover its tourist business after last fall's earthquake.
Herb Caen, the columnist for The San Francisco Chronicle, who has attended 42 consecutive openings, noted this week that the opening had more to do with economics than culture. ''Not only does the recalcitrant orchestra have to eat, but so do hairdresses, jewelers, couturiers and plastic surgeons,'' he wrote. ''This is another blow to the city's already faltering economy.''
The 69-member orchestra and the opera's management have bumped heads before, most recently in 1987 when a contract settlement was announced 10 minutes before the dress rehearsal for the opening-night performance of ''Il Barbiere di Siviglia.'' That contract lifted orchestra members' annual salary, on average, from $30,000 to $40,000.
At the start of these negotiations the musicians were seeking parity with the local Symphony, where orchestra members average $57,000 for a longer season but fewer hours of work. Since then the union has scaled back its demands while continuing to reject a 4 percent salary increase.
In contrast to the 1987 dispute, orchestra rehearsals were canceled this year as soon as the old contract expired. Lotfi Mansouri, the opera's general director, said rehearsing without a no-strike pledge might force management to agree to excessive salary demands rather than risk a last-minute walkout.
Locked out of the Opera House, orchestra members have instead set up their music stands on the sidewalk. There, amid lunchtime strollers, the tuxedoed members of Musicians Local 6 play the overture from ''The Magic Flute'' and ''Entry of the Guests'' from ''Tannhauser.''
The music drifts through Mr. Mansuri's open windows. ''I'd rather hear it from the pit,'' he said through clenched teeth.
Despite the lockout, opera lovers -those with box seats and those with standing-room tickets - expected the curtain to go up on time until an announcement to the contrary Tuesday.
Within hours of the cancellation, the wooden floor for the party tent was disassembled behind the Opera House and Mr. Seely called his supplier to say he would not need 400 extra duck breasts. At the stage door, security guards swamped with inquiries posted a cardboard sign that said, ''Don't Ask - We Don't Know.''
And at Mrs. Swig's house, the telephone rang with word from Saks Fifth Avenue that her dress had arrived, a Bob Mackie gown with an iridescent skirt the color of autumn leaves and a bodice covered with forest green bugle beads.
''I guess we don't have to hurry about alterations,'' Mrs. Swig said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: David Sprung, who plays the French horn with the San Francisco Opera Orchestra, conducted the orchestra yesterday in a concert near War Memorial Opera House. A labor dispute over wage demands caused the cancellation of opening night, planned for tonight, for the first time in its 67-year history. (Terrence McCarthy for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: With Barry Trial Behind It, Capital Focuses on Primary

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6

 BODY:

 
Call for a New City Image
''We need to build a city that can be respected, that we can be proud of,'' Mr. Ray, a man with a boyish grin and a buttoned-down look, tells voters as he moves frenetically about town preaching economic moderation, improved education, strong family values, self-help and law and order.
Mr. Ray has put together an efficient organization and has raised $1.1 million, more than twice as much as any other candidate. He has significant support in almost all sections of the city and is poised to unleash a last-minute burst of television commercials.
Polls indicate not only that he is well out in front in the race but also that the undecided vote, at one point more than 30 percent of the voters, is rapidly shrinking. The polls also indicate that among the more cutting issues are leadership in a post-Barry era and a solution to the city's drug epidemic. 
Mr. Barry's name is rarely invoked by most of the candidates. But when they speak of ''leadership,'' the clear euphemistic message is that they consider Mr. Barry's 12-year tenure to be an administrative, economic, sociological and political failure, particularly the latter years.
 
Scattering of Barry Group
Mr. Barry, a Democrat, has yet to endorse anyone, a political move with the potential to cut both ways. His once-powerful grassroots organization has scattered but is expected to coalesce again to an extent after Tuesday because he plans to run for a City Council seat in November as an independent.
The mayoral candidates have plastered the city with colorful political posters. The airwaves are filled with candidate debates and candidate advertisements.
''Lines are beginning to harden,'' said Joslyn Williams, the leader of the city's Democratic Party. ''People weren't paying any attention while the trial was under way. But I sense they are focusing now and what they seem to be concluding is that John Ray is the sort of quiet, solid politician that can give them a breather from the Barry noise and confusion and embarassment. I'd say it's John's race to lose.''
A recent poll by The Washington Post indicated that Mr. Ray had the support of 33 percent of all registered Democrats, about twice the support of his nearest competitor, Charlene Drew Jarvis, also a member of the City Council since 1979. Trailing Ms. Jarvis, with about 10 percent of the vote each, were Walter E. Fauntroy, the city's nonvoting representative in Congress for the last 19 years; Sharon Pratt Dixon, a former power company executive, and David A. Clarke, a member of the City Council since 1975 and its chairman since 1983.
The Democratic primary can be won with a plurality of votes.
 
Single G.O.P. Candidate
The unopposed candidate in the Republican primary is former Police Chief Maurice T. Turner Jr. He is running on a law-and-order platform, a popular political position in view of the city's serious drug problems. Still, most political analysts say he has little change of beating a Democrat in November unless his opponent is Mr. Clarke.
Mr. Clarke is the only white candidate. The city is about 70 percent black and racial lines were hardened by the Barry trial, which Mr. Barry contended was an effort by white prosecutors to bring down a black leader.
While the latest polls indicate Mr. Ray is well out front in the race, they also show considerable movement by Ms. Jarvis from earlier polls, in which she ran last or next to last. Political analysts credit much of this movement to her repeated attacks on Mr. Ray for accepting large contributions from the city's powerful real estate developers and to her allegations that he favored lifting rent controls to help landlords.
Ms. Jarvis's campaign platform calls for more careful management of the city's budget and curtailment of some programs to head off a deficit. But she favors expansion of education, anti-drug and job programs.
 
'Closing the Gap on John Ray'
''I think I'm closing the gap on John Ray,'' she said today during a dedication ceremony at a newly renovated apartment building.
Ms. Dixon, perhaps the best stump speaker in the race, also feels she is closing the gap on Mr. Ray. She notes that she has moved up to third in the polls, after being on the bottom much of the campaign, and she boasts she received the endorsement of The Washington Post a few days ago.
''I've got momentum going,'' she told a gathering of elderly people at a luncheon today.
Like all of the candidates, Ms. Dixon calls for fiscal responsibility to head off an expected municipal deficit and, like all the candidates, she avoids talk of any tax increase. Otherwise, her platform is considerably unlike that of any other candidate.
She is the only candidate to have publicly called on Mr. Barry to resign. Further, she says if she becomes mayor, one of her first moves will be to cut 2,000 workers from the city payroll of almost 50,000, now one of the largest in the country and one that she maintains is almost twice that of Los Angeles.
''I'll use a shovel, not a broom, to clean house,'' she declares.
Mr. Fauntroy and Mr. Clarke appear to have lost momentum in the race. But because the contest can be won with a plurality, political analysts are not writing either of them off.
''So far, it looks like John Ray is the winner because he's coming off as the best antidote to Marion Barry,'' said Mark Plotkin, a former Democratic political worker here who is now a political analyst for WAMU-FM, a National Public Radio affiliate. ''But never forget that you don't have to close but so far to win by a plurality in a crowded field. It can still be done.''
Mr. Fauntroy has had difficulty putting together an effective campaign organization, in part because he had few serious challenges during his years on Capitol Hill. His campaign has mainly centered on a boast that his experience in Congress has given him the tools to run a city competently. He also has charged repeatedly that Mr. Ray is too closely allied to white developers.
Mr. Fauntroy's opponents contend that he has done little on the Hill to help the city. They say he has been especially ineffective in winning more Federal financing.
Mr. Clarke, unlike Mr. Fauntroy, has a strong campaign organization. He also has significant support in the black community, though he is white, because of his longtime support for housing, job and health programs. However, his black support is still limited and his unalloyed liberalism scares off some whites. As a result, he has had a difficult time maintaining campaign momentum.

HEADLINE: Budget Negotiators at Crossroads on Energy Taxes

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6

 BODY:
Mr. Bush, who is scheduled to leave Washington late Friday for a summit meeting in Helsinki with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union, will open the talks at the Air Force base on Friday morning, and may check in late Sunday or early Monday when he returns.
 
The Details Are Secret
Each side's negotiators have pledged secrecy on the details of their plans, partly so as not to give the other side a political advantage that could result from a specific proposal that might be deemed unpopular.
But officials familiar with deliberations that went on throughout the day said the energy issue was the one remaining matter on which Democrats were having difficulty agreeing. In a brief statement to reporters Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, said only that Democrats wanted to ''recommit'' themselves to ''energy security for the United States.'' 
He said other Democratic priorities included protecting social welfare programs for low-income families, insuring that any tax increase is ''progressive and fair,'' encouraging economic growth and jobs, and providing ''adequate'' funds for a strong and effective national defense.
Bob Dole of Kansas, the Senate Republican leader, was a little more explicit about the approach his party might take on energy policy. ''Hoepfully, we'll be able to address in this budget summit meeting some incentives for production,'' he said. ''They've got to produce some oil, not just some tax breaks.''
 
A Question of Support
Despite what remain as major difficulties in reaching an agreement among themselves, negotiators from each party say their biggest concern is whether the final compromise on spending cuts and tax increases can be sold to the rank-and-file members of Congress, particulary House Republicans who are still angry at the President for abandoning his 1988 campaign pledge of no new taxes.
One indication of the political trouble that may lie ahead for Mr. Bush came today when Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the House Republican whip, put forth his own proposal for $134 billion in tax cuts over the next five years.
Mr. Gingrich, who is a member of the Republican negotiating team, said that with the possibility of a recession now at hand, tax cuts rather than tax increases were needed, to stimulate the economy.
The measures proposed by Mr. Gingrich include the capital gains tax cut long sought by the Bush Administration, as well as corporate tax breaks to encourage business investment, tax credits to low-income families with children and expansion of tax breaks for contributions to Individual Retirement Accounts.

HEADLINE: Baseball;
Two Yans' Partners Want to Sell Their Interests

BYLINE: By JACK CURRY

 BODY:

 
Worth Has Soared
McCluskey said some analysts had estimated that the Yankees are now worth between $300 and $400 million. Although McCluskey would not discuss the asking price, it seemed apparent that he was seeking between $30 million and $40 million for the shares. By contrast, when Doubleday and Company Inc. sold the Mets to Nelson Doubleday and Fred Wilpon in November 1986, the price was about $100 million.
''They know they can realize a fairly attractive return on their investment,'' McCluskey said. ''Now is a good time to sell.'' 
During a recent trip to Japan, McCluskey said, he had discussed the available portion of the Yankees with foreign investors.
''There are options with overseas buyers and that includes Japanese buyers,'' McCluskey said. ''The Japanese are very fond of the sport of baseball. It's one of the largest pastimes in Japan. It's worth exploring and we will explore it.''
Although a sale of a minority share need not be approved by the other major league owners, a sale to foreign investors would likely draw their attention as some among them have expressed reservations about foreign ownerships of a major league team. Japanese interests do own minor league teams.
Satter, who is from Boston, and Leighton, from Cleveland, would not confirm that they had put their percentage of the team up for sale.
''I have no comment on that,'' Satter said in a telephone interview. ''I have no comment on what we're doing.''
''I can't comment on that,'' Leighton said in a telephone interview.
Ansbacher Inc. specializes in media mergers and acquisitions and its clients are usually newspapers, magazines and book publishers. McCluskey said that the investment bank had recently increased its work in the entertainment industry and that the Yankees qualified as entertainers.
McCluskey said his clients' portion of the Yankees had been on sale for a week and that there had been a handful of conversations.
''We've opened up a few discussions and they've been very encouraging,'' he said. ''There will be many more discussions.''
McCluskey predicted that the sale would probably happen in the next four months.
 
Angels 12, Yankees 6
The Yankees lost a lot last night in the first inning. They lost two runs, a player, a coach and their manager after a questionable call on an apparent home run.
It took a few hours and a gallant but futile comeback effort before they actually lost the game, 12-6, to the Angels in 11 innings at Yankee Stadium.
Dante Bichette smacked a double off Lee Guetterman to drive in Luis Polonia, a pinch-runner, with the winning run. The Angels added five more runs as 11 players batted in the inning. Polonia even came around to bat and had a run-scoring single.
The Yankees had charged back from a 5-0 deficit to take a 6-5 lead into the ninth, but Bichette hit a homer with one out off Eric Plunk to tie the score.
With the Yankees trailing by 4-0 in the first, Steve Sax singled and scored when Jim Leyritz lined a ball into the right-field seats. Both players were in the dugout and the runs were on the scoreboard when the umpires called the ball foul. A slow-motion television replay clearly showed that the ball was fair.
The Yankees bickered with the three-man umpiring crew and ejections soon followed. Coach Mike Ferraro was thrown out by the first-base umpire, Jim Evans. Drew Coble, the home-plate umpire, ejected Leyritz and Manager Stump Merrill was tossed by the third-base umpire, Tim Welke. Dale Ford was the only umpire who did not eject a Yankee and he was at home for personal reasons.
The Angels took the early lead by raking Chuck Cary for five runs in one and two-thirds innings, with Dave Winfield slamming a three-run triple.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jim Leyritz of the Yankees, right, was called back after hitting what he thought was a home run in the first inning. But the home plate umpire, Drew Coble, changed his mind after a protest by the Angels. Leyritz argued the changed call and was thrown out of the game. (Barton Silverman/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Tell Iraq: We're United. Against You.

 BODY:
Nevertheless, some Soviet officials have sent mixed signals about the growing U.S. military presence in the Persian Gulf. And if Presidents Bush and Gorbachev do nothing else in Helsinki, they need to dispel any notion in Baghdad of being able to play Moscow against Washington.
Moscow has supported U.N. resolutions condemning Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, including the economic embargo, and stopped arms shipments to Baghdad. Mr. Gorbachev did what he could to underline these points to Iraq's visiting Foreign Minister. Nonetheless, in a situation as tricky as the gulf, Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev will have disagreements. Far better to try to resolve them before they become dangerously divisive. 
The Soviet Foreign Ministry, for example, has been proposing to deal with the gulf crisis in the context of an international conference about all major Middle Eastern conflicts, including the Palestinian question and Lebanon. The Bush Administration was right to promptly throw cold water on the idea.
It would be absurdly wrong and diversionary thus to legitimize Baghdad's argument that its takeover of Kuwait is in any way comparable to Israel's occupation of the West Bank. That began only after Arab armies attacked Israel. As for Israeli-Palestinian talks, Mr. Bush rightly wants them to begin, but apart from the gulf crisis.
Soviet officials also maintain that all outside forces in the gulf should be brought under U.N. command, and that force should be used only with that body's approval. Such an arrangement might be plausible if there were a standing and trained U.N. military force; or if nations besides the U.S. were contributing fairly to the common military effort; or after Iraq withdraws from Kuwait.
For now, the U.S. supplies most of the troops and shoulders most of the risks. If Moscow and others want to say more about how force might be used, let them send more of their own forces. Meantime, Mr. Bush cannot and should not subject the safety of U.S. forces to the whims of kibitzers.
His agenda for the summit meeting is probably modest and practical. He will ask that Moscow withdraw its almost 200 military advisers from Iraq. Their presence, while not critical militarily, sends the wrong signal. He also has constructive things to say about ways to bolster Eastern European economies during the crisis.
And whatever else the two leaders accomplish Sunday, their meeting will be a success if one point hits Iraq like lightning: Get out of Kuwait.

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
Gouges and Giveaways

BYLINE: By LEON V. SIGAL

 BODY:
Even countries with long-established free markets experience occasional price-gouging. But in Eastern Europe, where markets are just beginning to flourish, the entrepreneurial impulse is to get rich quick, even at the expense of customer loyalty. That's sure to rouse resentment of privatization. 
Price-gouging is not the only unpleasant aspect of privatization, as is evident from the West German, Italian and American businessmen crowding the better hotels in Budapest and Prague to talk deals. For every representative of a major corporation considering a long-term investment in Hungary or Czechoslovakia, there are many sharp operators looking for a fast buck.
Even government officials who push for rapid privatization in order to break the apparatchiks' stranglehold acknowledge that many of the deals they want to make may go sour. But how else can anyone find out the right price for a state enterprise when there's no real capital market? What's the actual worth of businesses with outdated plant and equipment and a skilled but overstaffed work force?
''Our opponents accuse us of giving the country away -often to foreigners - and they're right,'' says a senior Czech official who wants to privatize fast. ''But these enterprises won't be very productive if they continue to be owned and run by the state. And entrepreneurs won't have the incentive to make a firm work unless they own it.''
''What's sad,'' he said, ''is that the people who will benefit most are the old apparatchiks. They're in a position to cut the deals and end up managing the same firms they once ran for the state - at vastly higher salaries. Meanwhile, former political prisoners who were kept from developing marketable skills will be worse off.''
He knows the political backlash may come before the economic results are in. ''Economically, we have to privatize. Politically, we may pay for that with our own careers. But there's no alternative.'' LEON V. SIGAL

SECTION: Section A; Page 26, Column 5; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 426 words

HEADLINE: Cable TV Bills Open Door to Competition

 BODY:
Regardless of how a cable operator may retier or manipulate services, regulators are instructed to compare annual changes in cable rates for similar programming in both bills. Because rates for the most popular tiers of service have risen more than 40 percent (three times the rate of inflation) since deregulation, and because the bills would allow the public to challenge prices, the legislation should provide consumers with long overdue rate relief. 
H.R. 5267 and S. 1880 would also open the door to competition in the cable industry. Both bills would prohibit cable companies that have an ownership interest in cable programming from refusing to sell that programming under reasonable terms and conditions to potential competitors, like the satellite and wireless cable industries. With popular programming available to alternative transmission technologies, competition to cable has a much greater likelihood of developing.
The legislation does not address all consumer problems with cable rates, service or anticompetitive activities. With just one month left in the Congressional session, only ivory-tower free-market ideologues like Mr. Hazlett would expect Congress to correct all the policy imperfections involving the industry. From a practical perspective, cable legislation like S. 1880 and H.R. 5267, which would put a lid on cable rates and open the door to competition, and which is ready for floor consideration in both the Senate and the House, is not a bad starting point for the protection of consumer interests.
 
GENE KIMMELMAN
Legislative Director
Consumer Federation of America
 Washington, Aug. 20, 1990

SECTION: Section B; Page 1, Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 686 words

HEADLINE: Racketeering Suit Against Carpenters Chief

BYLINE: By CRAIG WOLFF

 BODY:
The suit ''represents an application of the civil RICO law in order to eradicate systematic, ongoing and poisonous corruption,'' said Roger S. Hayes, deputy United States Attorney of the Southern District of New York.
James Fox, chief of the New York office of the F.B.I., said, ''We think that finally with this case we'll be able to nail the carpenters union and return it to the rank and file.''
The union, the District Council of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America, represents more than 30,000 carpenters and other tradesmen in 22 union locals - from furniture and drywall installers to woodworkers, dock builders and floor coverers - making it one of the largest and most influential in the construction industry. 
The suit named as defendants Paschal McGuinness, its president since 1984, its first and second vice presidents, Irving Zeidman and Frederick Devine, its secretary-treasurer, Francis J. P. McHale, and the former boss of the Genovese family, Anthony Salerno, who is currently serving a 170-year sentence for racketeering.
Repeated messages seeking comment from Mr. McGuinness and the other officers were not returned. Joe Fitzpatrick, a spokesman for the union, said that he had been unable to reach them as well.
The complaint lists several instances in which the prosecutors say Mr. McGuinness demanded bribes from different companies and permitted the employment of nonunion workers. But overall, the emphasis of the suit is less on detail and more on a sweeping view of an industry that the prosecutors said has been ''infiltrated and exploited'' by organized-crime figures for decades.
 
Pattern of Payoffs Seen
''There has been a single pervasive pattern of payoffs, right through the 22 local unions,'' Marla Alhadeff, an assistant United States Attorney, said. ''At the very least, the district council officers looked the other way, but we also believe they committed affirmative acts of racketeering.''
A civil suit, Ms. Alhadeff said, provides the Government with an opportunity to try to bar organized-crime figures from participating in the union, stop union officials from associating with reputed Mafia members and replace union leaders with court-appointed officers. For these reasons, she said, the Government is not seeking monetary damages.
The suit - the 14th time the Government has taken civil action under RICO - continues a new strategy on the part of prosecutors seeking to disrupt the Mafia's control over labor.
In the past, prosecutors concentrated their efforts on the Mafia's traditional crimes: drug trafficking, illegal gambling and loan sharking. Investigations have recently focused on economic crimes, particularly in the construction industry, and on the inflation of prices through rigged bidding and kickbacks.
In the suit filed yesterday, Mr. McGuinness was charged with accepting or demanding payoffs from 11 New York companies. The three other officers also were charged with accepting or demanding payoffs from 24 other companies, the prosecutors said. Officials in the United States Attorney's office said that the contractors were not charged because the main objective of the suit was to oust the union officials.
