HEADLINE: Tough Market Will Put Nordstrom to the Test

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
Nordstrom officials, in their typically low-key and matter-of-fact way, do not seem very concerned about the slugglish sales climate. Industry analysts say a big reason is that Nordstrom already has two successful stores in the Washington area, and it has conquered other tough territory, like Los Angeles, before.
In fact, in the last 15 years that the Seattle-based chain has been spreading from the Pacific Northwest, Nordstrom has quickly become a dominant player in each region it has entered. In the process, it has set back competitors with its keen emphasis on satisfying customers.
The retailer now has highly successful stores in Alaska and in Northern and Southern California, as well as in the Middle Atlantic States. Nordstrom, which plans a Chicago cluster in a few years, professes to have no interest in locating within New York City. 
The bright brick and granite, 245,000-square-foot store in the Garden State Plaza shopping center in Paramus will be Nordstrom's second-largest store, after one in downtown San Francisco. It will compete head to head with Macy's, its chief rival in several cities, and will co-anchor in the large shopping mall.
 
High Salaries for Salespeople
Nordstrom has prospered in part by paying salespeople salaries and commissions as high as $100,000 a year to motivate them. Even so, it has had some highly publicized disputes with employees who said they were not paid for performing extra work.
Besides its service, which other stores have begun to try to match, Nordstrom attracts shoppers with a rich mix of nationally branded and designer clothes. Much like Macy's, Nordstrom keeps expansive inventories that exceed expected sales in case business suddenly bulges. But a recent slowing in sales and heavy overstocks have hurt Nordstrom's earnings in the last two quarters.
In addition to the slow retail pace in the area, financial pressures have shuttered such old-line stores as B. Altman & Company, Bonwit Teller and even newer upstarts like Alcott & Andrews. And the future of chains with very high debts like Bloomingdale's and Macy's is hardly as bright as it once was.
''We would have liked to open here at a healthier time,'' said James F. Nordstrom, one of three co-chairmen. ''But we made a commitment two and a half years ago for this store, and naturally we had to follow through with it.
''We are encouraged by the income diversity of this market. It is one of the broadest we've ever seen.''
 
Sizing Up Competition
Although he considers R. H. Macy & Company as Nordstrom's chief rival, ''even though we are a little above them in price,'' and Saks Fifth Avenue an important competitor, ''even though they compete with us only on the high end,'' Mr. Nordstrom said, ''We feel that there will be a demand for what we are doing here as it has been everywhere we have gone.''
He added that Nordstrom's average sales were about $400 a square foot, ''but we hope to do more here.''
Other merchants and analysts say Nordstrom's success in shearing off some of Macy's loyal customers and in luring new ones depends on convincing affluent shoppers that the store's salespeople are attentive and accessible, that it has an unusually deep and varied assortment of goods, and that it offers a high value relative to the prices it charges.
As an upscale fashion specialty store, Nordstrom has concentrated on higher-priced goods, which inherently have a higher markup, and therefore profit. The company has also been able to increase its profit return on sales to 5.3 percent last year after taxes, from 4.8 percent the previous year, one of the best margins in its segment of the industry.
 
A Reflection of Success
In ways large and small, the newest store reflects much about how the retailer got to where it is and how it will try to duplicate that success in the New York area.
The Paramus store, which replaces a Hahne & Company branch, is basically a new structure, with three levels surrounding an atrium so that merchandise departments confront the shopper in a circular arrangement. Warm, paneled walls let the women's clothes, accessories and men's wear departments show off a variety of color, a traditional Nordstrom feature that appears to make stores inviting and attractive in an era of often pale, even bleak decor in many stores.
In a brief spot-check of merchandise during a tour of the store earlier this week, it was clear that Nordstrom aims to appeal to a broad range of customers. Its private-label men's suits include wool garments as low as $375 and Oxxford wool suits from $1,295 to $1,345. Its shirts include City of London, Ferrell Reed, all-cotton brands from $69 to $90. Allan Edmond men's shoes are priced at $205, and Bally brands cost $265.
 
Calvin Klein and Liz Claiborne
In women's wear, Martinez Valero shoes from Spain cost $99.95. Calvin Klein ''bodysuits'' are $65. And Liz Claiborne clothes for women are widely displayed in several of the company's collections, all relatively moderately priced.
In another small, but telling, detail, Nordstrom's appears to be one of the few places that charges only 25 cents for a cup of coffee in its three restaurants.
Asked why, Mr. Nordstrom, one of the retailer's three co-chairmen, replied: ''Frankly, I don't like restaurants that charge $1 for a cup of coffee when it only costs a few cents. We want to use our restaurants to attract and keep our customers in case they want to go out for something to eat. So we keep the restaurant prices moderate.''
The company, which was founded in 1901 in Seattle, also does some other things differently. Nordstrom as of today will be operating 61 stores in seven states, with sales of about $2.8 billion. But unlike most large chains, the company has buyers in each store to respond directly to reports from sales clerks and comments by customers.
Other large retail chains buy centrally, through a headquarters purchasing staff that receives data on customer preferences from local store and department managers.
Still, it is Nordstrom's much-lauded prowess in handling customers that has given it a cachet far beyond its existing markets.
The reputation was marred earlier this year by complaints by Nordstrom employees filed with the Washington State Labor Department accusing the retailer of failing to pay some employees for extra work. Among other things, the employees said, they had to deliver items to customers' homes and offices and had to spend extra time with customers outside their own departments.
In response, Nordstrom's set up a $15 million reserve in February to compensate employees and moved to improve its record-keeping procedures.
 
Flexibility and Paternalism
While Nordstrom uses many of the same sales training techniques that other stores do, its core approach is to motivate salespeople through high commissions and a paternalistic culture that engenders a general initiative to keep the customer happy at almost any cost.
Sales representatives are also given more authority and autonomy than in most stores, Mr. Nordstrom said. ''They decide such things as special orders, when the goods are delivered, obtaining extra garments if needed and handling problems. But, mainly, they are urged to be attentive.''
Nordstrom's management arrangement is also unusual. The three co-chairmen are James; his brother, John, and their cousin Bruce, all grandsons of John W. Nordstrom, who opened the first store with Carl F. Wallin, a shoemaker. The company has no chief executive.
''Since none of us will work for the other, we all work as a committee,'' James Nordstrom said jokingly.
 
Analysts Lower Estimates
On Tuesday, while preparations were being completed, with employees listening to instructions and electricians and carpenters putting on the finishing touches, Nordstrom held a lunch for analysts. It turned out to the company's disadvantage, as several of the Wall Street analysts cut their earnings estimates after what was termed a disappointing meeting.
William Smith of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company said Nordstrom executives reported that sales for July showed a slim gain, while those at the company's stores in California and Washington were soft.
He said that he expected the company's third-quarter earnings to be flat or slightly lower than the 27 cents a share of a year earlier and that 1990 earnings should be $1.50 a share, versus $1.51. ''I think that Nordstrom's enthusiasm may be tempered by the slow retail environment,'' he said.
But in an interview afterward, Mr. Nordstrom did not appear worried. ''We'll know in just a few days how well we'll do in Paramus,'' he said. ''It doesn't take long. We feel that our Eastern expansion is our key to future growth for us and our employees.''

HEADLINE: Crude Up By $1.66, To $31.43

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
''It takes less and less to move the market more and more,'' said Robin West, president of the Petroleum Finance Company, a Washington-based consulting firm.
 
Uncertainty of Traders Cited
He attributed the market's jump to the uncertainty of buyers and sellers about how to interpret unfamiliar events. ''People don't understand what the implications of war are and they don't understand what the implications of peace are,'' he said. ''The easiest reaction is to panic.'' 
Robert P. Boslego, an oil analyst in Lexington, Mass., said, ''The market as a whole is very unclear as to what the equilibrium price really should be, and it is fishing, so to speak.''
Several analysts described a market that is setting itself up for the possibility of a fast slide. The inventory levels of producers and refiners indicate that users farther down the distribution chain, from industrial companies to distributors to retailers, have bought extra supplies in anticipation of shortages or price rises. If those companies judge that the crisis is waning and that they should use up those extra stockpiles, their purchases would drop and prices would fall, even if consumption did not change.
That was not the assessment of buyers yesterday, however, as the crude oil price approached its post-invasion high.
 
Bad News Emphasized
The bad news cited by traders included the report overnight that an American had been shot in the hand by Iraqi troops in Kuwait; Saddam Hussein's call on Wednesday for a holy war, the second by the Iraq President since the invasion, and Congressional testimony, also on Wednesday, by an Assistant Energy Secretary predicting shortages by the end of the year, an expectation that had been raised earlier by private analysts.
Based on that news, however, John H. Lichtblau of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation in New York, said, ''I can't figure out why prices are near $32.''
''Volatility is part of the game,'' said Mr. Lichtblau of yesterday's 5.6 percent oil price rise. ''Everybody is sort of tense, in continuous fear that there will be a war starting at any moment,'' he added. ''But the traders don't know anything about the world situation that everybody else doesn't know.''
Pulled upward by crude, the price of gasoline rose to 95.07 cents a gallon, up 2.8 cents, for October delivery, and the price of heating oil was 88.24 cents a gallon, up 4.87 cents, also for October delivery.
Crude oil contracts for November and December delivery also rose beyond $31 a barrel.
''It's just the same old story,'' said one broker on the floor who asked not to be identified: ''more expectations of increased hostilities.''
 
Self-Reinforcing Expectations
At Ashland Oil Inc., a refining company, Cyrus Tahmassebi, the chief economist, said that price changes reflected daily mood changes in the market about the likelihood of war, but that some expectations were self-reinforcing. For example, he added, if the market believed that shortages were likely, ''then everyone wants to stock up with inventories, and that could cause even more tightness in the market.''
Mr. Tahmassebi said that the short-term price trend would be higher.
Mr. Lichtblau suggested, however, that ''if there is any kind of calming statement, I think you would see prices come down again.'' He said the loss of Iraqi and Kuwaiti crude to world markets - a total of about 4.5 million barrels a day - pushed the price of a barrel of crude to about $27 in New York, and that the rest of the increase, more than $4, was because of the fear of war.
Others attributed even more of the elevated cost to the war fear. Vahan Zanoyan, of the Petroleum Finance Company, said he expected production by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to be the same by the middle of this month as it was before Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 because of extra production by Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and others.
 
Not a Permanent Dent
In that case, he added, the invasion did not represent a permanent dent in supplies, but a one-time loss that he put at about 100 million barrels. But when the crisis began, he pointed out, crude stocks around the world stood about 250 million barrels higher than at the same time the previous year, indicating the loss could be absorbed easily.
Mr. West predicted that even if war came, the results were likely to resemble those of the ''tanker war'' that began in 1982, when Iran and Iraq bombed each other's tankers and export facilities.
 
Hard to Ignite
The main Saudi terminal on the Persian Gulf, Ras Tanura, is probably out of reach of the Iraqis, he said, and crude oil, as was discovered in 1982, is harder to ignite than many people imagine. ''These facilities are harder to hit and easier to repair than people think,'' he added.
But Mr. Boslego said that if shortages developed, then oil was ''still undervalued, relative to the kind of price we would need to seriously affect demand.'' If a reduction in OPEC output has to be made up by consumers going without, he added, ''a pretty substantial increase in price will be required to balance the market.''

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Uncertain Fallout From Gulf Crisis

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d told Congress this week that the Administration expected to maintain a long-term military presence in the gulf. But nobody knows what that means in terms of forces or weapons or stockpiles, above and beyond planned military outlays for the next five years. With the budget deficit worsening, not only from the Middle East conflict but also from the savings and loan bailout, the pressure will still be on the Pentagon to hold down military expenditures by reducing outlays on weapons systems related to strategic deterrence of the Soviet Union, now that the cold war is officially over, and on expensive long-range projects like ''Star Wars.''
The July estimate by the Congressional Budget Office for the Federal deficit for the current fiscal year, which closes at the end of this month, was for a deficit of $165 billion. But that has now been swollen by $68 billion for the additional costs of the savings bailout, raising the estimate to $233 billion, compared with the Gramm-Rudman target for this year of $100 billion. With the sluggish economy cutting tax revenues, plus the extra costs of the gulf operation, the current year's deficit will go still higher, probably to about $250 billion. 
The next fiscal year's ''baseline'' deficit figure - not counting any steps Congress may take to cut the deficit - is also estimated to be about $250 billion, without allowing for a faster rate of military spending; that figure compares with the Gramm-Rudman target for the 1991 fiscal year of $64 billion, which is supposed to shrink to $28 billion in 1992 and zero in 1993. It seems as sure as death and taxes that Gramm-Rudman targets will be changed, but with the White House-Congressional budget negotiations still in the spotlight, nobody yet knows how. The anticipated cuts in military spending and rises in energy taxes have been hit hard by the gulf crisis and the climb in oil prices.
Added to the military costs are the new economic burdens, like the effect of higher oil prices on the United States and other industrial countries, on Eastern European countries struggling to move to market economies, and on Middle Eastern states opposed to Iraq's effort and suffering the costs of closing pipelines or losing trade. American officials are using a figure of $3 billion a year to cover such losses, although Turkey and Egypt alone are each asking for $2 billion more. In many countries, reaching from South Asia to Latin America, there may be additional losses resulting from greater unemployment and business failures.
A cardinal uncertainty is whether the Middle East crisis will have its primary effect in strengthening recessionary or inflationary forces - or both at the same time. A majority of economists now say the correct answer is ''both at the same time,'' replicating the stagflation of the 1970's that resulted from the oil shocks of 1973-74 and 1979. Some economists say a recession has already started, and a majority now expect one to begin in the fourth quarter or early in 1991.
But that forecast is still far from unanimous. A sizable minority of economists still say the United States will squeak through without anything that can be technically defined as a recession - two consecutive down quarters - although even the relative optimists expect growth to stay sluggish through 1991. Virtually everyone expects the gulf crisis, the climb in oil prices and the worsened budget deficit to put upward pressure on prices.
All of this has driven the dollar to its lowest level ever against the German mark, the Swiss franc and some other currencies. This will help to sustain American exports and the economy, but will add to inflationary pressures. The Federal Reserve, confronting the inflation-recession dilemma, seems to be holding in place, hesitant to ease further in the midst of the gulf crisis, at least until it sees the whites of a recession's eyes.

HEADLINE: U.S. to Help Soviets Lift Oil Output

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6

 BODY:

 
Moscow Seeking Credits
American officials said they expected economic assistance for Moscow to rank high on the Helsinki agenda. The Soviets are also seeking credits from the United States for the purchase of American grains, beef and poultry.
The Mosbacher mission will include food executives who are prepared to discuss with their Soviet counterparts ways of lifting food production and improving food distribution. Earlier this week an acute shortage of bread in Moscow was laid to breakdowns in the Soviet distribution system. 
American credit lines to finance food purchases could be opened by normalizing trade relations, which is linked to liberalizing emigration laws, a move expected later this month in the Soviet Parliament. President Bush has said he would then ask Congress to waive the Jackson-Vanik amendment to the 1974 trade law that bars normal tariff treatment to countries restricting emigration. Tariffs on Soviet imports now range up to 10 times as high as most other countries.
Although Congress will be in session only a few more weeks this year, Mr. Mosbacher said the new trading relationship ''could happen this year.''
The business group will see President Bush in Helsinki on Sunday and later, in Moscow, meet Mr. Gorbachev and other Soviet officials.
Among the executives accompanying Mr. Mosbacher will be Lodwrick M. Cook, chairman of ARCO; Kenneth T. Derr, chairman of the Chevron Corporation; Mark C. Hungerford, chairman of Texaco Inc.; H. Leighton Steward, chairman of the Louisiana Land and Exploration Company; John J. Murphy, chairman of Dresser Industries, Dwayne O. Andreas, chairman of the Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, and Donald M. Kendall, chairman of Pepsico Inc.
The world's largest producer of oil, the Soviet Union would like to increase oil exports to take advantage of higher prices caused by the Middle East crisis, but because of mismanagement, outdated equipment, deteriorating pipelines and a shortage of capital, the country's output has actually been falling.
Production this year is projected at 500,000 barrels a day less than the 12.1 million of 1989. Soviet output last year was greater than that of Saudi Arabia, Iraq and Kuwait combined. Its reserves are estimated at 60 billion barrels, twice those of the United States, but about a tenth those of Saudi Arabia.
Last year's exports totaled 3.7 million barrels daily - greater than Iraq - with about half going to the West and the other half to Eastern Europe.
''You don't have to be a brilliant economist to see that they'd like to raise production,'' Mr. Mosbacher said.
Last year's exports yielded $20 billion, or 40 percent of the Soviet Union's hard-currency earnings.
 
Sending a Signal
Mr. Mosbacher said that the Bush Administration was ''sending as strong a signal as we can that we're stepping up to the plate'' to improve economic relations with Moscow.
Last month the Administration granted export licenses for six Control Data Cyber 960 mainframes to the Soviet Union, the most powerful computers ever exported to that country from the West.
Mr. Gorbachev, who is preparing a new economic program to free market forces and promote private ownership, also wants to integrate the Soviet Union into the global economic community by joining organizations like the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
Washington's longstanding opposition to Soviet membership in these institutions has receded.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
New Leader at Witco Is First Non-Wishnick

BYLINE: By Daniel F. Cuff

 BODY:
In March, Mr. Toller, 60, was named vice chairman, and Denis Andreuzzi, 59, was picked as president and chief operating officer, putting them in competition to succeed Mr. Wishnick.
When Mr. Wishnick reached age 65 he was given board approval to serve in the top post for three more years while a successor was chosen. ''I can leave now, knowing that Witco will be shepherded by the right people,'' he said in a statement yesterday. 
Mr. Wishnick, who has spent a half-century with the company, plans to remain on Witco's board and the executive, compensation and management committees. He has been chairman since 1964 and chief executive since 1971. He and his family own 17 percent of Witco stock.
Mr. Andreuzzi will continue as president and chief operating officer and will take on the additional post of chairman of the board's executive committee.
Mr. Toller will be the first non-Wishnick to take the helm. ''I'm very humbled by that,'' he said. ''It's a tremendous opportunity but a substantial responsibility to carry on that tradition.''
Before joining Witco, Mr. Toller was president of the Continental Carbon Company, a maker of carbon black, a chemical used to reinforce rubber. Continental, a unit of Du Pont's Conoco petroleum operation, was bought by Witco in 1984. Mr. Toller became Witco's chief financial officer in 1986.
His entire career, before Witco, had been spent at Conoco. Upon graduating from the University of Arkansas with an economics degree, he joined the big petroleum company at its administrative headquarters in Ponca City, Okla. Conoco was acquired by Du Pont in 1981.
At Witco, Mr. Toller will be guiding the company as the Mideast crisis pushes up the cost of its petroleum. ''It's a case of cautiousness,'' he said, ''but I still see a bright future for the chemical industry.''
No big changes are expected. ''We've got a very fine company,'' he said. ''Management strength, I think, is exceptional. It's a little bit of a worn phrase, but if it isn't broke, don't try to fix it.''

HEADLINE: Flat Sales Last Month At Retailers

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Among the best performers was Wal-Mart, whose total sales for August jumped by 30 percent from the corresponding period a year ago. The sales at stores operating at least a year - called same or comparable stores - were up by 13 percent.
Comparable-store results are considered the best guide to a retailer's health. They exclude revenues that come from opening new outlets. 
Sears, Roebuck & Company, the Chicago-based retailer that led the industry in annual sales volume last year, experienced some improvement in August over recent months, though its sales were still uninspiring. Its total sales rose by 4.7 percent from August of last year, while its same-store sales were up by 4.1 percent.
 
Slight Growth at K Mart
At the K Mart Corporation, the nation's second-largest retailer, sales edged up by 1.6 percent on a comparable-store basis. The company's total sales, including from stores opened in the last year, grew by 11.1 percent.
But the J. C. Penney Company said its store and catalogue sales for the four weeks that ended on Sept. 1 slid by 1.2 percent, from a record amount in the corresponding 1989 period. Those at its comparable stores declined by 2.4 percent.
''I would say that the list of retailers reporting disappointing sales is growing,'' said Jeffrey Edelman, an analyst at Barclays de Zoete Wedd. ''We are in a consumer slowdown. And before it's over, we're going to have more disappointments.''
 
Cautious Christmas Outlook
Mindful of the economy's weakness and the negative effect that the Middle East conflict has had on consumer confidence, the retailers are planning conservatively for the important Christmas season, when they typically look to make as much as 60 percent of their annual profits.
''This will be another difficult Christmas for most retailers, marking the first time in a while that we've had two poor Christmases back to back,'' said Jeffrey Feiner, an analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company.
The grim outlook for retailers, however, may be good for customers. Shoppers may find merchandise marked down earlier than normal, as retailers pour on the promotions to increase sales.
But because inventories are being kept lean, the retailers may not need to be as aggressive in moving merchandise as they were last year, when financial problems at some chains caused rampant price cutting.
Several retailers bucked the trend in August. Wal-Mart, a rapidly expanding discounter based in Bentonville, Ark., that is widely expected to challenge Sears and K Mart, posted a double-digit gain in its same-store sales.
Following is a list of sales reported by retailers for August and for their fiscal years to date:
 
Sears: Overall sales rose by 4.7 percent in four weeks that ended on Sept. 1, to $2.63 billion; seven-month sales rose by 2.8 percent, to $18.73 billion.
 
K Mart: Up 11.1 percent for the four weeks ended Aug. 29, to $2.33 billion; seven-month sales up 12.2 percent, to $17.16 billion.
 
Wal-Mart: Up 30 percent for August, to $2.74 billion; year-to-date sales up by 26 percent, to $17.05 billion.
 
J. C. Penney: Down by 1.2 percent for the four weeks ended Sept. 1, to $1.21 billion; seven-month sales up 3.4 percent, to $7.87 billion.
 
Dayton Hudson Corporation: Up 19.9 percent for the four weeks ended Sept. 1, to $1.19 billion; seven-month sales up 13.8 percent, to $7.34 billion.
 
May Department Stores Inc.: Up 12 percent for four weeks ended Sept. 1, to $762.4 million; seven-month sales up by 10.1 percent, to $5.14 billion.
 
Woolworth Corporation: Up 7.3 percent for four weeks ended Sept. 1, to $515 million; seven-month sales up 8.4 percent, to $3 billion.
 
Limited Inc.: Up 14 percent for four weeks ended Sept. 1, to $408.3 million; seven-month sales up 18 percent, to $2.67 billion, excluding results of Lerner Woman unit, which has been sold.
 
Melville Corporation: Up 8.4 percent for four weeks ended Sept. 1, to $674.2 million; eight-month sales up 10.8 percent, to $4.93 billion.
 
Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc.: Up 1.1 percent for four weeks ended Sept. 1, to $199.7 million.
 
TJX Companies: Up 13.7 percent for four weeks ended Sept. 1, to $216.5 million; seven-month sales up 12.6 percent, to $1.32 billion.

HEADLINE: The Media Business;
New England Monthly Closes

 BODY:
New England Monthly, a six-year-old regional magazine that has won two National Magazine Awards, will cease publication with its September issue.
In announcing the demise of the magazine, John Van de Kamer, its president and chairman, cited the general decline in magazine advertising, which has been felt nationwide, and the weakness of the economy of the Northeast in particular.
''After a $5 million effort to make a profit, the most prudent thing to do is to shut the magazine down rather than continue to build up debt,'' Mr. Van de Kamer said. 
Mr. Van de Kamer said no buyer for the magazine could be found. The publication, which is owned by New England Magazine Holdings Inc., had an audited circulation of 120,000.
The magazine was noted for its good writing and attracted writers like John Updike, Tracy Kidder and Dan Okrent. For instance, an article in the August issue by a Portuguese emigre, titled ''Talking in the New Land,'' described growing up in Peabody, Mass. And the September cover article discusses one man's fight to preserve New England's rural landscape.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Mixed Despite Jump in Oil

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:

 
Two Views of the Report
Market participants said a rise of 50,000 or less in non-farm payroll employment, excluding census workers, would be considered positive for the credit markets and would reinforce the notion that the Federal Reserve Board will soon move to combat anemic economic conditions by easing credit.
Conversely, a rise of 100,000 or more in payroll employment, excluding census workers, would be a negative for the credit markets, traders said. While not an enormous increase, a rise in payroll employment of that magnitude would in all probability convince the Fed that the economy is not on the verge of a recession and that no change in monetary policy is warranted.
Even though attention has been focused on the employment report for much of this holiday-shortened week, the market's reaction will likely be muted if the numbers live up to expectations. 
''Everybody has already factored a relatively small increase in employment into prices,'' said Kristen Foster, a financial market economist at Citicorp Investment Bank.
As a result, ''yields won't fall much if the number is as anticipated,'' she said. ''But we could see quite a reversal in short-term note and bill rates if the numbers are much stronger than expected.''
 
Less Optimistic Outlook
Although Ms. Foster and other analysts said they were fairly certain the Fed would react to a weak employment report by easing its monetary policy, some market participants were not quite so sanguine.
''I don't think one payroll employment number is as significant as the Street is expecting it to be,'' said Edward J. Sawicz, president of the Discount Corporation of New York, primary dealers in Government securities. ''The figures would really have to be far below expectations for the Fed to move.''
By late yesterday, the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 97 31/32, up 5/32, to yield 8.94 percent, down from 8.95 percent late Wednesday.
Among Treasury note issues, the 8 3/4 percent 10-year notes were offered at 99 18/32, up 2/32, to yield 8.81 percent. And the 8 1/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 5/32, down 1/32, to yield 8.03 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates inched higher. In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.37 percent, up a basis point. Six-month bills were offered at 7.31 percent, up 2 basis points. And one-year bill rates also rose by 2 basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.21 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
 
California Tax-Exempt Bonds
Elsewhere, the California Housing Finance Agency offered $185 million worth of bonds in the tax-exempt municipal bond market.
The bulk of the issue consists of term bonds that mature Sept. 1, 2031. The securities carry a 7.85 percent coupon and were preliminarily priced at $100, or par.
Merrill Lynch Capital Markets acted as lead manager for the negotiated sale. The issue is rated AA by Moody's Investors Service and A-plus by Standard & Poor's.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal securities, dealers said that prices of most widely quoted issues rose by 1/8 point to 1/4 point in quiet trading.
Corporate bond traders said that activity was light and that prices of most issues were unchanged to up 1/8 point.
Prices of high-risk, high-yielding ''junk bonds'' ended slightly lower yesterday in very light trading. But the Resolution Trust Corporation, which is charged with disposing of the assets of failed savings institutions, sold a block of $25 million of junk bonds, traders said. Among the issues that were offered for sale were some of the highest rated issues like Duracell, First Brands, Playtex and Vons.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve reported that two of the three measures of the nation's money supply declined during the week ended Aug. 27. The third and largest measure, M-3, rose by $3.9 billion.
The money report had no effect on prices in the credit markets.

HEADLINE: Stocks Slide As Oil Rise Continues

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
At one point just after 2 P.M. the Dow had slumped as much as 43 points but recovered by the close to 2,596.29, down 31.93. Crude closed at $31.43, up $1.66.
 
Program Trading Data
Birinyi Associates, which monitors program trading, said that six selling programs toppled the market more than 42 points. No daily record is available of the biggest traders but the New York Stock Exchange often lists Kidder, Peabody; Morgan Stanley; Susquehanna; Bear, Stearns, and Paine Webber as the top five. The first three, the Big Board said, often act for themselves while the other two represent clients. 
Although trading volume actually picked up slightly, it remained an anemic 125.6 million shares, up from 120.6 million the day before. Traders tend to discount stock movements on slow days because so few people are in the market.
Stock market declines outnumbered advances 2 to 1, with 960 stocks down and 76 hitting new lows while only 511 were up and only 12 hit new highs.
 
Weakness in Blue Chips
The weakness extended not only to the Dow blue chips but also to the broader Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks and into the smaller stocks on the Nasdaq index.
The S.&P. 500 fell 3.93 points, to 320.46, matching the 1.2 percent decline on the Dow. The Nasdaq composite fell 3.66, or almost 1 percent, to 378.78. Falling far less, the American Stock Exchange's market value index dropped to 324.50, down 0.91, or three-tenths of 1 percent.
In a sign of further weakness in the smaller stocks, Mr. Grennan of Shearson said over-the-counter issues ''got hit from the opening bell,'' the first time that had happened after six stabilizing sessions.
''Basically the focus is on the Middle East,'' said Kenneth P. Ducey, senior vice president of S.G. Warburg & Company. ''The volume is lackluster and it looks like the economy isn't going anywhere.''
''People want to see how the Middle East finally settles up,'' he went on. ''Anything can happen and nobody wants to step up. The market could easily drop 100 points if something happens.''
Summing up Wall Street's pessimism over the deepening recession, Mr. Ducey added, ''And somebody pulled the plug on Motorola.''
Heading the most-active list on the New York Stock Exchange, Motorola, the big electronics producer, plunged 7 5/8, to 61 1/2, after falling 2 the day before. Rajiv Chaudri, electronics analyst for Goldman, Sachs, cut his earnings estimate on Motorola on Wednesday and other investment houses followed. Referring to the economic slump, Reuters quoted David Angel, research director of Dataquest, as saying, ''We've got to batten down for heavy weather.''
With other high-tech producers under intense review, Honeywell tumbled 3 1/2, to 94 3/8; Digital Equipment 1 3/4, to 64 3/8 and Texas Instruments 1 1/8, to 26 1/4. I.B.M. traded as low as 101 1/2 but closed at 102 3/8, unchanged. Shearson, Merrill Lynch, Smith Barney and Morgan Stanley recommended I.B.M. yesterday. First Boston eliminated its buy recommendation yesterday, a day after Prudential-Bache. Compaq Computer traded as high as 46 3/4 but ended at 45 1/2, near its low for the day, but up 1/8.

HEADLINE: Rush Is On to Secure East Europe Trademarks

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6

 BODY:
American Express's commercials are an example of how a number of American companies are using trademarks as a first approach to the commercial potential of Eastern European markets. Companies of all stripes are busily registering their copyrighted slogans, labels and logotypes and sometimes displaying them in countries where their products are not yet in demand, not affordable, not readily available or even known.
 
Magazine Names
Time Warner Inc. is registering its Sports Illustrated and Money magazines in Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia as a prelude to publication there. The National Basketball Association is taking steps to protect the names of American basketball teams in Yugoslavia, where the sport is popular. 
Those American companies like McDonald's, Coca-Cola, Gillette and Levi Strauss & Company that have been in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe for some time had their trademarks registered long ago to protect them from piracy.
But the political changes of the last nine months have set off a wave of activity as lawyers hastily double-check their companies' trademark portfolios to make sure they are protected. Other companies have design consultants sift through the latest in Polish, Hungarian and East German slang to avoid the expensive gaffe of creating brand names with offensive - or just plain dumb - connotations.
One company, Anheuser-Busch, has been negotiating for the right to use the Budweiser name in several European countries. In most of the Continent, the name is owned by a small brewery in Czechoslovakia.
 
The Allure of the West
''The allure with trademarks for Eastern Europeans is that they connote the West,'' said Ted Murphy, a representative of the United States Trade Association, based in New York. ''The people there want to have these products, and they've been denied them for so long that there's probably a lot of pent-up demand.'' Before a televised performance of the National Symphony Orchestra of Washington last February in the Soviet Union, the program's sponsor, the Procter & Gamble Company, promoted its name with a long advertisement. ''It was a 12-minute video of who we are,'' said Terry Loftus, a Procter & Gamble spokesman. ''Soviet citizens had a chance to see what brands we offered.''
Such advertisements are calculated to promote good will for American brands in Eastern Europe, but the dissemination of trademark names and symbols may come back to haunt American companies. While the ads establish name recognition, they may also open the way to piracy where it has not been a problem before.
''There's a potential for real abuse,'' because of a lack of enforcement in some countries, said Don deKieffer, general counsel for the International Anti-Counterfeiting Coalition, a Washington-based organization that monitors the counterfeiting of products and intellectual property.
 
Not Rich Enough Yet
''So far, Eastern Europeans haven't had the opportunity to counterfeit,'' he said. ''They haven't been rich enough. Only time will tell if legal systems in those countries are up to the challenge.''
Lack of enforcement makes some companies hesitant about risking the use of their trademarks in Eastern Europe, said Dick Rivers, a lawyer with Akin, Gump, Strauss, Hauer & Feld.
''You want to make sure someone's not going to set up a shop down the street with your trademark,'' Mr. Rivers said. ''You have to have some hope of going into a Hungarian court and getting a court order saying, 'No, you can't do that.' ''
Another problem is a lack of private trademark lawyers in those countries, said John Pachtner, a spokesman for Levi Strauss & Company. In Eastern Europe, companies usually have to work directly with the Government, a distinct change and disadvantage, he said, from the way things are done in the United States and Western Europe. The way companies register their trademarks in Eastern Europe is not much different than in industrialized nations in the West. The companies pay a fee of about $500 to register with the local equivalent of the United States Chamber of Commerce, which conducts a search to see whether the brand name or design is already in use. If not, the company then has the exclusive right of use, sometimes for 10 years, sometimes permanently, depending on the laws of the country.
 
Trademark Requirements
Some nations, like Czechoslovakia, require proof of use of the trademark in that country. In others, like Romania, it is merely enough to register.
West German and East German companies that were part of the same operation before the partition of Germany after World War II may have to fight over who gets to use the trademark after unification, but most American trademarks are registered in both countries and should be valid in the unified Germany, trademark lawyers say.
The esthetics of a trademark involve another kind of risk. In the last year, American designers have begun to create brand names and logotypes for companies planning to introduce their products in Prague, Budapest and East Berlin. Marketing strategists recognize the potential for offending or alienating possible customers with an inappropriate turn of phrase or image, said J. Roy Parcels, a New York-based designer.
Corporate marketing officials were hesitant to mention specific cases for fear of disclosing information to competitors. But an oft-cited generic example of the potential for mix-ups involves the word ''gift.'' In English, it has an unfailingly pleasant connotation. In German, it has taken on the meaning of poison.
 
Dangers in Translation
''It's a fear that every marketer has, that he will go into a market where his word has a bad connotation,'' said Mr. Parcels, who is designing Eastern European trademark packages for two companies that he refused to identify. ''The concern we would have in Eastern Europe is, what are the words which have come to mean different things in the last few months. You've got to consult someone who is current in the marketplace. That becomes critical.''
At a Commerce Department exposition in Washington this summer to promote the value of trademarks in opening foreign markets, trademark lawyers with the Government, more commonly seen wearing dark suits, dressed up like Tony the Tiger, M&M candies and the Kool-Aid pitcher. In attendance were a number of American executives and diplomatic officials from Eastern Europe, as well as tourists and children eager to meet brand-name characters they recognized from television.
''As foreign trade plays an increasingly important role in the health of our nation's economy, trademarks make it possible for the American producer with an excellent product and good marketing savvy to expand his or her markets worldwide,'' said David Bucher, director of the United States Trademark Examining Operation, the branch of the Commerce Department that licenses trademarks in this country.
Mr. Bucher then donned a Mr. Peanut costume and went off to shake hands with Boy Scouts and sign autographs.

HEADLINE: Slow Growth Projected in Corporate Spending

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6

 BODY:

 
Setting a Record
The projected investment would exceed last year's record spending of $501.6 billion. But the 5.1 percent increase would be less than half of the 10.4 percent spending gain in 1989 and the lowest percentage increase since a 3.1 percent advance in 1987. Capital spending rose 9.5 percent in 1988. 
The new estimate is down from the 5.5 percent spending increase that businesses said they planned in the previous survey completed in May.
''It confirms the economy is sluggish and expectations for the future are that it will continue to be sluggish,'' said Thomas Runiewicz, an economist with the WEFA Group in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa.
After-tax corporate profits, which rose 1.5 percent from January through March, fell two-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter and many analysts expect them to fall further in the last half of the year.
Businesses are often reluctant to make capital investments as their profit margins weaken.
 
Effect of Gulf Crisis
Mr. Runiewicz said that most of the survey was completed before the Persian Gulf crisis. He said higher prices and uncertainty created by the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 could prompt additional cuts in investment spending.
But economists at Mitsubishi Bank in New York suggested in their current newsletter that the crisis would have little effect on 1990 investments, ''given that most of this spending is already set in motion.''
Mr. Runiewicz said that business investment contributed to economic growth in 1988 and 1989 and that the slower increase in capital spending this year would reduce growth.
Many analysts have been looking for continued business investment to help keep alive an economy that has been weakening for more than a year as the Federal Reserve kept a tight rein on credit to curb inflation.
 
Predictions of Recession
Even before the oil-price shock associated with the Persian Gulf crisis, some economists had said the economy was headed for a slight recession later this year.
Spending on replacements for aging plants and equipment and on expansions help increase the nation's productivity, an increasingly important factor in view of the stiff competition from overseas.
Before adjusting for inflation, the department projected a 5.4 percent spending increase this year, to $534.8 billion, after gains of 11.4 percent last year and 11 percent in 1988.
It said the investment increase for all industries includes a 4.7 percent gain for manufacturing companies and a 5.8 percent advance for mining, transportation and other nonmanufacturing businesses.
Manufacturers are projecting investment spending this year of $192.4 billion.
The gain includes a 2.6 percent increase by industries making durable goods - expensive items expected to last at least three years - and a 6.4 percent increase by those engaged in nondurables like food and clothing.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar, After Broad Loss, Is at 11-Month Low vs. Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The market consensus appears to be that the report will show a gain of 50,000 to 65,000 non-farm jobs. But there is considerable debate whether a figure within that range would cause the Fed to take action.
The central bank is under considerable pressure to ease rates to avert a recession. But lower interest rates could add to inflationary pressures at a time when the price of oil continues to rise. 
Some speculate the Fed will decide against easing because of the sagging dollar.
''The dollar is too weak to ease now,'' said Earl Johnson, a vice president at the Harris Trust and Savings Bank of Chicago.
Lower interest rates in the United States reduce the incentive for foreigners to invest in dollar-denominated securities.
Foreign capital is critical to financing the nation's budget deficit. The United States has attracted foreign capital in the past by offering higher yields on government securities than those available elsewhere in the industrialized world. The interest-rate advantage has been narrowed, however, as yields in Europe and Japan have risen recently.
Against the Japanese currency, the dollar fell one yen today in New York trading, closing at 140.65. Despite weeklong weakness in the Japanese stock market, the yen has continued to gain ground, at the expense of the dollar and a number of European currencies.
Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 141.65 yen, from 142.30 yen at Wednesday's close. Later in London, it fell further to 141.05 yen.
The pound was bolstered by anticipation that Britain will join the European exchange-rate mechanism at a meeting of European finance ministers in Rome this weekend. The mechanism establishes currency rates for a basket of European Community countries.
In London, the pound rose to $1.9075, from $1.8990 late Wednesday. In New York it cost $1.9125 to buy a pound, up from Wednesday's $1.9055.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold Prices Up for 3d Day; Grain and Soybeans Climb

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Gold futures settled $3.20 to $3.60 higher on the Commodity Exchange in New York, with the contract for spot delivery up $3.60, to $389.70 an ounce. The heavily traded December contract settled at $396.20.
Silver futures settled 3.3 cents to 3.7 cents higher, with September at $4.77 an ounce. 
The spot gold price has climbed $7.40 an ounce this week after plunging $32.70 last week amid perceptions that the Persian Gulf confrontation was cooling off.
 
Inflation a Concern
Heightened tensions in the gulf this week have provided support for gold, but investors seem to be responding more to economic news, especially to signals of higher inflation, said Stephen W. Platt, an analyst who follows the precious metals and oil markets for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Gold is often considered an investment hedge against inflation.
Mr. Platt said a remark on Wednesday by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, before the Senate Banking Committee had apparently caused some of the demand for gold. Mr. Greenspan said it could take several years to reduce the United States inflation rate.
Oil prices rose sharply for a fifth straight day on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Grain and soybean futures settled mostly higher on the Chicago Board of Trade amid expectations of more sales of American grain to the Soviet Union. The soybean market drew further support from reports that hot, dry weather had begun to put stress on soybean crops in Nebraska.
Wheat futures settled 1 3/4 cents to 2 3/4 cents higher, with September at $2.65 3/4 a bushel; corn was 1/4 cent lower to 1 3/4 cents higher, with September at $2.43 a bushel; oats were 1 1/2 cents to 2 1/2 cents higher, with September at $1.11 1/4 a bushel, and soybeans were 1/2 cent lower to 5 1/2 cents higher, with September at $6.17 1/4 a bushel.

LENGTH: 1143 words

HEADLINE: Job Growth Hits a Standstill, While Unemployment Rises

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7

 BODY:
Moreover, observed the Commissioner of Labor Statistics, Janet L. Norwood, today's data showed ''the first signs of trouble'' in two labor market indicators watched closely by professionals to spot emerging trends. These showed jumps both in the number of workers who left jobs for any reason in the last five weeks and in those who were laid off or dismissed.
While most analysts continued to stop short of declaring the economy in recession, today's report made that prospect more likely and added pressure on the Federal Reserve to spur economic activity by cutting interest rates.
 
'A Very High Risk'
''I don't think this is telltale evidence that a recession is in progress,'' said Edward F. McKelvey, a senior economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company. ''But there's a very high risk of being in recession in the next six months to a year.'' 
In Ottawa, the Canadian Government announced that its unemployment rate soared to 8.3 percent last month from 7.8 percent in July.
Despite the increasingly somber economic data, much of it confirming anecdotal evidence of anemic growth or decline in real estate and other markets, it remained uncertain whether the Federal Reserve would move soon to try to spur growth. Some analysts thought the board might act within days to cut rates, but others predicted no change. They cited the doubling of the price of crude oil this summer, uncertainties related to the military buildup in the Persian Gulf and unresolved negotiations to reduce the Federal budget deficit.
 
Inflation Fears Blunted
One relatively bright spot in the report today was a moderation in wages that blunted some inflation fears. Average hourly and weekly earnings each rose a modest two-tenths of 1 percent in August, compared with jumps of six-tenths of 1 percent in July.
Employment figures became particularly grim this summer for teen-agers. Teen-agers in August accounted for 223,000 of the 295,000 decline in the number of people employed, according to a department survey of households, which is used to measure the unemployment rate. The household survey is released along with a monthly survey of company payrolls, which economists say gives a better picture of job growth.
With the population of 16- to 19-year-olds shrinking rapidly, analysts had assumed that teen-age joblessness would pose no particular problem, but instead the rate climbed from 14.1 percent in June to 16.3 percent in July, and further to 16.7 percent in August. That was nearly two percentage points above the level of August 1989.
Not only are jobs scarcer, but fewer teen-agers are looking for work, their participation rate in the labor force having dropped from 56.5 percent last year to 50.9 percent. For black teen-agers, this combination of fewer jobs and less interest in seeking them means that only 22.8 percent of them hold a job now, compared with 28.7 percent a year ago.
 
Rise in Black Joblessness
The household survey also showed that the overall black jobless rate climbed five-tenths of a point in August, to 11.8 percent, seven points more than the rate for whites, which climbed two-tenths of a point, to 4.6 percent.
Over all, the percentage of Americans holding jobs has slipped to 62.5 percent, a decline of half a percentage point in the past two months.
The number of workers in the private sector fell by 295,000. That decrease, paired with a modest reduction in the labor force last month, raised the number of jobless by 189,000, to a total of 7,003,000.
Of these, 3,325,000 have been jobless for less than five weeks, up from 3,120,000 such people in July. The number of job losers - those laid off or discharged - rose to 3,367,000 from 3,088,000. The number of people leaving jobs and people who joined or rejoined the labor force all declined.
 
Factory Jobs Plummet
The department's survey of company payrolls, meanwhile, showed that non-farm jobs climbed a skimpy 45,000 last month, including only 17,000 new service jobs. Counting the departure of 120,000 temporary census workers, though, jobs declined over all by 75,000. At the same time, the department put out an improved figure for July, revising the decline in jobs to 89,000, including layoffs of census workers, from the 219,000 earlier reported.
Another 45,000 factory jobs were lost last month, twice as many as in July, with the bulk of the losses in durable-goods industries, particularly electronic and transportation equipment. From a post-recession peak in January 1989, factory jobs have tumbled by 455,000.
Construction continued its recent downturn last month, losing 40,000 jobs to bring the total to almost 100,000 jobs lost in the past three months.
The length of the average private-sector work week was unchanged last month at 34.5 hours. But the index of aggregate weekly hours fell for the second month in a row to 124.6, with the department for the first time using the 1982 figure as its base of 100. Some regard this index as the best single indicator of the gross national product, The percentage of industries adding workers fell back to 46.9 percent in August from just over 50 percent in July.
 
Highest Rate in 2 Years
At 5.6 percent, the nation's jobless rate is the highest since it reached that level in August 1988. It has not been higher since the 5.7 percent posted in March 1988.
When domestically based military personnel are included, the jobless rate rose one-tenth of a point last month to 5.5 percent. Officials said the Middle East deployment and reserve call-up had no significant effect on the figures.
Among the 11 largest states, the biggest changes were a one-point rise, to 6.7 percent, in the jobless rate for Florida and a one-point decline, to 3.6 percent, in the rate for North Carolina. New York's rate eased to 5 percent from 5.3 percent while New Jersey's was unchanged at 4.8.
Because of relatively small samples, the department cautions against taking state figures seriously in the short run.
Regionally, the Northeast and the West showed improvement in August, their jobless rates moving down to 4.9 and 5 percent, while conditions worsened in the South and Midwest. These figures, unlike the others, are not adjusted for seasonal variation.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1, Column 6; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1234 words

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
DEPOSED KUWAITI OFFERS $5 BILLION FOR GULF EFFORT

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, Sept. 7

 BODY:
Kuwait, Saudi Arabia and other wealthy Arab nations, by agreeing essentially to pay for the American forces in the gulf, clearly increased the staying power of the Bush Administration in the confrontation with Iraq.
 
Fear of Public Reaction Eases
Administration officials feared that the blockade might require six months or more to choke the Iraq economy enough to have serious effects, and that as costs mounted the American public, already worried about a recession, might turn against the whole operation.
Mr. Baker went today from Jidda, Saudi Arabia, to Taif, to Abu Dhabi in the United Arab Emirates, and finally to Cairo. He told reporters with him that in addition to discussing financial arrangements he had a full discussion with the Arab leaders of these countries about the possible military options against Iraq, should diplomacy not bear fruit. 
Mr. Baker told Congress last week that the additional cost to the Pentagon of deploying American forces in the gulf would be roughly $6 billion by the end of the year, or about $1.5 billion a month, assuming no fighting breaks out. On Thursday, American officials said, the Saudis promised to contribute roughly $400 million to $500 million a month to cover all fuel, water, transportation and other costs for American troops stationed on Saudi soil.
Besides Kuwait's commitment today, Mr. Baker won a promise of financial aid for Washington from Sheik Zayed al-Nahyan, the leader of the United Arab Emirates, but he declined to specify the amount, saying it was still being formulated.
The Saudi, Kuwaiti and United Arab Emirate contributions should constitute well over $1 billion a month for the United States. That amount, when coupled with the money Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady has been raising on his tour of Europe, should not only cover the costs of America's involvement in the gulf, but may even produce a profit for the Treasury.
Although Kuwait's assets were officially frozen shortly after the invasion so they would not fall under Iraqi control, the United States and other Western nations have permitted dispersals of money to the Kuwaiti royal family under licenses granted by the applicable governments.
In addition to the $2.5 billion the Kuwaitis committed to the United States, the Emir, who still controls the estimated $100 billion Kuwaiti foreign investment fund, also promised to give another $2.5 billion to Egypt, Turkey and other poor Middle Eastern nations that have committed troops to a multinational force confronting President Saddam Hussein, the Iraqi leader.
Sheik Zayed of the United Arab Emirates also told Mr. Baker that his country would make a substantial commitment to these poorer nations, but no details were disclosed.
 
'Some Pretty Good Progress'
Asked if the United States was now in a position to cover all its costs from the gulf military intervention, Mr. Baker said: ''I will let you be the judge of how we are doing. We are making, it seems to me, some pretty good progress.''
''The Kuwaiti Government has committed economic assistance in the range of $5 billion between now and the end of the year to be used in part to defray some of the direct incremental costs for the presence of our forces and assistance to countries adversely affected, such as Egypt and Turkey,'' Mr. Baker said. ''The Kuwaiti attitude was very, very forthcoming. They were very appreciative of what the United States and countries aligned with them are doing to defeat Saddam Hussein and obtain the return of their country.''
He added that of the $5 billion ''at least half'' would go to the United States.
Mr. Baker said he had discussed military options with the Kuwaitis, Saudis and Sheik Zayed. It was difficult to tell whether this was in preparation for some action, or just a statement intended to unnerve President Hussein.
''During the course of our meetings we had discussions regarding all options,'' Mr. Baker said, ''and we made the point, as we have publicly, that we cannot and do not rule out any options. We hope that there is a peaceful settlement to this issue. We hope that the unanimous resolutions of the Security Council are carried out. But obviously, we discussed the full range of issues relating to this matter.''
 
New Experience for Emir
The Kuwaiti Emir sat next to Mr. Baker in an overstuffed chair as American reporters shouted questions at him at a photo session. Diplomats said it was the first time the Emir had had such an experience and the first time he had ever spoken with reporters.
He said he would not mind seeing the United States and its allies use military force to drive Iraq out of Kuwait.
Speaking through an interpreter in a barely audible voice, the Emir said, ''I, as a person whose country has been aggressed against, hope that the issues will be resolved as soon as possible -no matter by what means.''
Asked if he was worried that Kuwait could be destroyed, he said: ''In order to restore my country to what it was before, we will not spare any amount or value. We have to liberate Kuwait. Whatever it takes, we would like to have it done.''
 
U.N. Ultimatum Urged
Kuwait's former Housing Minister, Yahya al-Sumait, who is also in exile in Taif, suggested that the United Nations give Iraq an ultimatum setting a deadline for a withdrawal, which if not met, would trigger a military response.
Mr. Sumait said of President Hussein: ''Knowing the man and knowing his intentions, I don't think seriously that peaceful solutions will be the result. We don't have much time because Kuwaitis are living in a nightmare.''
When Mr. Sumait was asked if the ruling Sabah family in Kuwait would be prepared for an election as part of a diplomatic solution to the crisis, he dismissed the suggestion, saying: ''No one in Kuwait will want any other leadership than the Sabah family. I don't think that this is for discussion.''
Regarding reports that Iran intended to break the United Nations sanctions on Iraq, Mr. Baker said that one of the gulf leaders, who have close contacts with Iran, had told him that the Iranians told them that they intended to ''substantially observe'' the boycott.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
BUSH WANTS A RISE IN MOSCOW'S FORCE

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7

 BODY:
Mr. Gorbachev has indicated that the Soviet Union, which has at least two warships in the Persian Gulf, would not send additional forces unless Washington is prepared to establish a United Nations command.
Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev are expected to discuss efforts to arrange elections in Afghanistan, as well as Soviet political and economic reform and the expansion of Soviet-American trade and economic ties. Administration officials said Soviet efforts in the gulf crisis had left Mr. Bush even more disposed than before to discuss an expansion of American technical help to Moscow. But they said he was not prepared to talk about direct economic aid. 
The two leaders will also seek to lend momentum to negotiations on treaties that would reduce strategic nuclear weapons and conventional armed forces in Europe, officials said.
A senior Administration official said today that Mr. Bush was not carrying new proposals on these issues. But the Administration has issued such disavowals before previous summit meetings at which the President has laid out substantial initiatives.
 
United Front Against Iraq
As Mr. Bush prepared to leave for Helsinki tonight, officials said the President was looking forward to the summit meeting primarily as a chance to demonstrate superpower unity against Iraq. After the summit meeting, the two leaders have scheduled a news conference at which they are expected to again denounce the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.
Officials said Washington hoped the meeting could also produce a more formal joint communique. But in any case, the United States was calculating that a powerful signal would be sent by the sight of Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev standing together on the Middle East after decades in which the two countries' regional policies have often collided.
''We'd like to show there is no daylight at the top of the international alliance against Saddam,'' an official said. ''That way, the Iraqis can't play us off one against the other, which they are clearly trying to do.''
American officials expect Mr. Gorbachev to seek assurances from Mr. Bush that the United States will not act unilaterally in the gulf. The Helsinki meeting will also be a chance to demonstrate to the Soviet people that the United States firmly backs Mr. Gorbachev politically and economically, the officials said.
 
Testing New Relationship
In a broader sense, American officials said they saw the Helsinki meeting as a chance to test the new Soviet-American working relationship during a crisis period.
A senior Administration official said today that Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev would discuss the 190 Soviet military advisers in Iraq, whom Washington would like to see withdrawn.
The official said the United States would be ''very happy'' if Mr. Gorbachev agreed to send more military forces to the gulf, especially ground forces. He acknowledged that Washington had opposed Soviet military involvement in 1986 when a multinational force was created to protect oil shipping through the Persian Gulf.
But, he said, ''The Soviets, I think, have demonstrated by their support against Iraqi aggression that they do see the situation there in a similar way to us, and therefore I think a cooperative approach is warranted.'' Soviet Troops on Saudi Soil? American officials said the Saudis told Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d during his visit there on Thursday that they would be willing to accept Soviet troops on their territory. But it is not clear precisely how those troops might be dispatched, since the two countries do not have diplomatic relations.
The Soviet Union has been looking to the United Nations Security Council's Military Staff Committee as a vehicle for carrying out such operations, but that committee has been moribund for decades and the United States has shown little interest in reviving it.
Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin and chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, said today that Mr. Bush should agree to work with Moscow to set up a United Nations military command to enforce the economic embargo against Iraq.
But Administration officials said they opposed such a plan, which the Soviet Union has also suggested, primarily because the United States has provided the bulk of the forces now in Saudi Arabia and does not want to give up control of them.
 
Certain Kinds of Soviet Aid
Mr. Bush is prepared to talk to Mr. Gorbachev about expanding American technical assistance in light of the cooperation Moscow has offered in the gulf crisis. But officials insisted that this would not be offered as a quid pro quo for greater Soviet involvement in the Mideast military operation.
And they said Mr. Bush would not offer direct economic aid to Moscow, but would instead talk about more programs like a forthcoming mission in which American officials and businessmen will try to help boost Soviet oil production.
Both sides are expecting the meeting to prod talks on a treaty reducing conventional armed forces in Europe and another accord reducing long-range nuclear arsenals. A senior Administration official said it would be difficult, but not impossible, to sign both treaties this year.
 
SHEVARDNADZE WOULD GO TO IRAQ MOSCOW, Sept. 7 (AP) - Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union sain today he is willing to go to Iraq to help settle the Persian Gulf crisis, Tass reported.
''If need arises, I am ready to travel to Iraq,'' Tass quoted Mr. Shevardnadze as saying in an interview with soviet journalists while flying home from an official visit to Japan. He also said he expected Presidents Bush and Gorbachev would discuss at the Helsinki summit meeting how to influence events in the gulf by working with other Arab countries.
Mr. Shevardnadze again proposed an international conference on the gulf that also would take up the Arab-Israeli conflict in Lebanon.

HEADLINE: Berlin Turning Into a Mecca for Jazz

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER

DATELINE: WEST BERLIN, Sept. 7

 BODY:
Quasimodo has long been one of Europe's best-known music clubs, and recent jazz programming has reinforced its reputation. During a 10-day span in July, headliners from the United States included Archie Shepp, Wayne Shorter, Pharoah Sanders, Les McCann, Mike Brecker, Sun Ra and Nat Adderley.
Jazz stars who visit West Berlin do not necessarily perform at Quasimodo. Sheila Jordan sang to packed houses at an intimate club called Lohmeyer's this year, and Gerry Mulligan played in a high school auditorium. Bands led by Art Blakey and Herbie Hancock have given well-attended outdoor concerts. 
''There isn't a true jazz scene in Berlin the way there is in New York, but what we have is definitely becoming bigger,'' said Giorgio Carioti, the owner and manager of Quasimodo.
 
Owner Was Bartender
Mr. Carioti was born in Italy and came to Berlin in the 1960's as a student. He found work at Quasimodo as a bartender and bought the place in 1975.
This summer, Mr. Carioti opened a cafe upstairs from his nightclub. Sitting at a corner table one recent afternoon, as the strains of Charlie Parker's saxophone wafted from the speaker, he mused about what the collapse of European Communism might mean for jazz.
''Until now, it hasn't really been possible for most musicians to think about touring Eastern Europe,'' he said. ''There were problems with money. There were visa problems. You couldn't reach people on the phone.
''Now there are all sorts of new possibilities. Now a band can think about touring East Germany, playing in Dresden, in Leipzig, in Rostock and then going on from there through Poland and Czechoslovakia, or even farther. Berlin is the logical center for tours like that.''
 
Reverse Chauvinism
Berliners throng to hear famous jazz players from the United States, but are not always kind to local musicians. Club managers have learned that the word ''jazz'' is hardly an automatic draw, and that the public does not readily accept the experimental and avant-garde music favored by some young players here.
Nonetheless, Berlin is one of the best places in Europe to hear live jazz. Berlin-based bands play a wide range of styles. Many perform be-bop and free jazz. Others range from an all-female saxophone quartet to a band that specializes in compositions by the clarinet stylist Sidney Bechet.
One of the clubs that regularly feature local jazz bands is Badenscher Hof, which is tucked behind a main street in a residential neighborhood. Considerably smaller than Quasimodo, it attracts a mixed crowd of enthusiastic fans. They sit below faded posters announcing Berlin concerts by John Coltrane and Duke Ellington and eat jambalaya prepared by a chef whose apron says ''Cooking With Jazz.''
 
Drawing on Eastern Europe
One recent weekend the featured band at Badenscher Hof was a well-regarded be-bop quartet called Der Harte Kern. The pianist, Niels Unbehagen, said before his first set that he thought Berlin's musical future was bright.
''The best German musicians are already here, and now people from all over Eastern Europe are turning up,'' Mr. Unbehagen said. ''The bass player I'm working with tonight is from the Soviet Union. These are very musical countries. You're going to see some very original music coming out of here.''
Jazz was frowned upon by most of the recently deposed Communist regimes in Eastern Europe, for its associations with both freedom and America, and the musicians and fans were sometimes harassed or even jailed. But in recent years, interest in jazz has grown as repression eased. Several jazz musicians from Eastern Europe have won international reputations.
Among them is Conrad Bauer, an East German trombonist. Mr. Bauer began his musical career in a rock band in the 1960's. When the police warned him that his lyrics were too provocative, he decided to turn to jazz. He was first allowed to tour abroad in 1977 and since then has performed in the United States and most European countries.
''Now that there's no wall, everything in East Germany is totally different,'' Mr. Bauer said in an interview. ''Under the dictatorship, all culture was subsidized and controlled. We had youth clubs in every city run by the party. Nobody knows what's going to replace that. In six months, some new structure will start to take shape.''
There are said to be 250 to 300 active jazz musicians in West Berlin, and Mr. Bauer estimated that there are perhaps 150 more in East Berlin.
''People in the East love jazz,'' he said. ''They want to hear more of it. If their economies improve, so will the music.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Sun Ra performing last month at Quasimodo, a jazz club in West Berlin. (Jan-Peter Bonning for The New York Times)

PUB-DATE: September 8, 1990

SECTION: Section 1; Page 11, Column 4; National Desk

LENGTH: 501 words

HEADLINE: Black Baptists Urge U.S. to Use Diplomacy in Gulf

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 7

 BODY:

 
Lives, Not Oil
The tone of the resolution was in keeping with the cautious response of most major religious groups to the military deployment: balancing condemnation of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait with concerns that the United States act out of humanitarian motives rather than to protect oil interests.
The National Baptist Convention said Mr. Bush had been correct to send troops to the Middle East after the invasion so the United States could negotiate from a position of strength.
But by pursuing diplomatic efforts for a negotiated settlement, it went on, ''we will prevent the loss of countless lives and spending billions of dollars that should be utilized to feed the hungry, clothe the naked, heal the sick, train the unlearned, house the homeless and encourage the lonely,'' the convention said. 
The denomination also commended the Rev. Jesse Jackson for helping win the release of some Western hostages in Kuwait, and warned the United States not ''to appear to choose one nation over another as allies in the Persian Gulf, just out of economic and material interests.''
 
The Shadow of Racism
The Rev. T. J. Jemison, the denomination's president, said after the vote, ''I just can't see lives being taken, fighting over oil.''
On Thursday, before the convention took up the Persian Gulf issue, Mr. Jemison told the delegates that race relations were at a critical point in the nation's history.
The Baptist leader, who led one of the first successful boycotts of segregated busing - in Baton Rouge, La., in 1953 -said racism in America was worse now than during the civil rights struggles of the 1960's. President Ronald Reagan and his appointments to the Supreme Court are a large part of the problem, he said, adding that blacks will feel the impact of their decisions for decades.
''They call themselves strict constructionists, but I call them strict segregationists,'' he said of the Justices. As for Mr. Reagan, he went on, ''he will be remembered not because he didn't have a memory, but he will be remembered because he gave respectability to racism.''
